HEADLINE: Africa Trade Bill

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman's March 28 column mentions studies showing that an Africa trade bill stalled in Congress would "create jobs in Africa and scarcely affect employment here." But analysis exposes the two leading studies as fatally flawed. 
 An International Trade Commission report asserts that granting the 48 sub-Saharan African countries free access to the United States market would displace fewer than 1,000 American jobs. The commission assumed that the trade bill would generate no new capital investment in Africa. But without new factories, few new African exports can be created. The American job loss would be minimal -- as would African job gain.
The Congressional Budget Office has observed that whatever the new bill's provisions, most African apparel and textile shipments will by law have to be deemed "import sensitive," and therefore subjected to standard tariffs. So the bill is really a Catch-22.
 
JOCK NASH
Washington, March 28, 2000
 
The writer is Washington counsel for Milliken & Co., an American multinational textile company.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Surges As Growth in Incomes Slows

BYLINE: NYTimes.com/TheStreet.com 

 BODY:
Consumer spending surged in February, even though income growth slowed, government data showed yesterday.
Two other reports showed strength in factory production. Together, the data indicated that the five interest rate increases over the last 10 months had done little to slow the economy. 
 The Commerce Department said personal spending rose 1 percent in February, after rising a revised 0.6 percent in January. The gain was more than twice the 0.4 percent rate of income growth in February, a slowing from January's 0.7 percent rate of income growth. The savings rate, the amount of income left after spending, fell to 0.8 percent in February -- its lowest level since the government started keeping records on savings rates in 1959.
Alternative forms of income, like stock gains and increases in home prices, are not factored into the savings rate, but economists say a low savings rate is a worrisome sign that consumers are still willing to spend more than their income allows.
The pace of manufacturing, meanwhile, is also picking up. A survey of March manufacturing activity in the industry-heavy Chicago area showed that factories were busy, with higher production rates, even as rising costs for energy and raw materials continued to accelerate. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago index rose to 57.4 in March, compared with 56.7 in February. (Numbers above 50 denote economic growth.)
Another report on factory orders, from the Federal Reserve, showed a decline of 0.8 percent in February -- the second consecutive monthly decline. But the bulk of the decline came in the volatile transportation sector, which reflected a drop in airplane orders. Excluding transportation, factory orders rose 0.5 percent in February, reversing a drop in January.
Joe Lavorgna, senior United States economist with Deutsche Bank, said the first-quarter data indicated an annual growth rate of 5.8 percent. "There is little doubt that domestic demand this quarter is as strong as it was last quarter," he said.
But he also noted that there would be drags on first-quarter growth because growth in business inventories eased and the United States trade deficit continued to widen.

HEADLINE: Security Council Votes to Let Iraq Buy Oil Gear

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 31

 BODY:
The Security Council voted unanimously today to allow Iraq to import $1.2 billion in spare parts and other equipment this year for its ramshackle oil industry, so that more oil can be pumped efficiently and safely to pay for civilian goods and public service projects.
At the same time, the council's Iraqi sanctions committee completed work on four lists -- of food, pharmaceuticals, educational material and agricultural equipment -- that Iraq will be permitted to purchase without a committee review, although United Nations officials will oversee and approve the purchases. 
 Since December, Iraq has been allowed to sell unlimited quantities of oil, although earnings are monitored and expenditures controlled through a United Nations escrow account. A third of the profits -- $20 billion since 1996 -- goes to pay claims arising from Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait, which led to international sanctions against President Saddam Hussein.
The resolution today, introduced last week by the United States, increases, to $600 million from $300 million, what Iraq can spend on oil equipment in the six-month period that ends in June. The vote also covers retroactively the six-month period that ended in December. The council all but promised to keep the higher level in future six-month reviews.
Secretary General Kofi Annan has been pressing for a higher ceiling on buying equipment since last year. In a report on March 10, he said Iraqi oil fields, which still use 1980's machinery, could not sustain the rate of pumping reached last fall, when production hit three million barrels a day.
The United Nations is moving to increase oil production as the United States presses other oil-producing nations to raise output, to try to reduce the prices of gasoline and heating oil. But Western diplomats said there was no direct connection, because upgrading Iraq's oil industry has been an issue for many months.
Iraq had been pushing up its capacity before oil prices began to rise late last year.
The four lists of civilian goods no longer subject to scrutiny by the sanctions committee include not only food, but also soap, packaging and storage materials. In the education category, the list of 137 items include classroom furniture, printing equipment, paper for textbooks, photocopying and duplicating machinery, sports equipment and clothing, musical instruments, and audio-visual aids.
The medical list runs to about 50 pages of specific pharmaceuticals, plus a variety of supplies for baby and child care and equipment for hospitals like sheets, radiology film, surgical goods and anesthesiology equipment.
As Iraq has begun raising larger sums for goods to relieve citizens' hardships, relief organizations have asked Mr. Annan to look at longer-term development projects in Iraq. United Nations officials and diplomats are divided on the issue, with some saying planning wider social programs to be paid for by oil money should be Iraq's job, not theirs.
Mr. Annan told the council this month that the "oil for food" program was never meant to be a full development program for Iraq, but only a supplement to the government's own resources and expenditures.
Western diplomats most critical of Mr. Hussein say the Iraqi government has billions of dollars, much of it earned through smuggling and black-market activities, that it chooses not to spend on public projects that would alleviate hardship and improve health and sanitation. Relief officials say that is not an excuse for denying Iraqis many basic needs or for isolating them indefinitely.
Under current Security Council resolutions, sanctions on Iraq cannot be lifted until it can be certified free of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and long-range missiles to deliver them. A new arms inspection system is now being created for Iraq. Its chief inspector, Hans Blix of Sweden, is to present his management plan for the new system in the middle of April.
At that point, he will have to go to Baghdad to begin compiling a list of unanswered questions and uninspected sites, which the Iraqis will have to deal with if they want to be declared disarmed. Mr. Hussein's government has given no indication they will allow him to visit.

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1306 words

HEADLINE: Cutting Crime, Keeping Our Rights

 BODY:
The police shootings of Amadou Diallo and Patrick Dorismond exposed a seemingly intractable problem. How can police aggressively keep guns and drugs off the street, while respecting the civil rights of citizens? The Op-Ed Page asked a few experts.
H. Richard Uviller is a law professor at Columbia University. 
 I'm for gun control of all kinds. But even the most comprehensive program will make little difference in our high rate of gun violence. Guns used in crime are rarely licensed.
The only way to reduce gun crime is to go after the unlawful guns secretly carried by dangerous people. And the only way to do that is for police to approach suspicious people, to expand traffic stops to include a search for guns and yes, even to stop cars and people, lawfully, as a pretext for a gun frisk. The Supreme Court has said such stops are constitutional. True, the court recently (and unfortunately) held that the unverified tip from an anonymous informer does not justify a stop and frisk, even where the information is that a described person is carrying a gun. But all that means to a resourceful cop is that the tip will be verified by some other suspicious circumstance.
Aggressive street patrol is the most effective strategy for illegal handgun interdiction. But "aggressive" does not mean brutal or abusive, much less murderous. Officers assigned to these gun runs must be carefully selected and rigorously trained. It's not the only way to reduce violence, but it is a critical component of any sane policy.
Geoffrey Canada is president of the Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families.
I would start with more training and better screening of undercover police officers. And then I would insist that all undercover officers wear a wireless microphone that records all verbal exchanges with suspected criminals. The recordings should be made not only of the officer doing the buy or bust, but of the back-up officers as well. This tape should be a permanent part of the arrest record and should be reviewed by superior officers routinely.
These tapes would give answers to potentially important questions. How were suspects approached? What verbal exchanges occurred? What did back-up officers say (or not say) to suspects? The tapes could point police superiors to undercover officers who were inappropriate, overzealous or racist. They would also provide many training opportunities for officers and important, albeit incomplete, information to the public about why officers used deadly force.
Frank Serpico is the former New York City police detective who testified about police corruption in the 1970's.
We can have a safe society where the civil rights of individual citizens are not capriciously violated. What can be done?
* The mayor must reverse his vetoes of an independent audit board on police misconduct.
* There must be better psychological screening of recruits to ensure that they are the type of people that we want maintaining order and protecting our streets.
* There must be better training of recruits and instructors in the academies, which includes training in psychology, ethics and specialized combat.
* The rule that allows police officers involved in shootings to take 48 hours before they tell their story must be abolished.
* Minority representation in the police department must be increased.
* The office of the special prosecutor that was created as a result of the Knapp Commission hearings was disbanded in the 80's as no longer necessary. We need to reappoint a special prosecutor now to look into matters of police misconduct.
* There must be an end to selective enforcement of drug and weapons violations.
* We must have a mayor and police commissioner who have a greater respect for the racial, economic and cultural diversity of the citizens of New York.
Mathea Falco, president of Drug Strategies, a nonprofit research institute, was assistant secretary of state for international narcotics matters in the Carter administration.
The fatal police shooting of Patrick Dorismond shows once again that we cannot arrest our way out of our drug problems. Using undercover officers to approach apparently law-abiding citizens and to try to entrap them in a crime completely distorts law enforcement's legitimate goal of making communities safer.
Although politicians like "street sweeps" for their public relations value, these sweeps do not have any lasting impact and too often violate individual rights and increase distrust of the police. But as numerous studies have shown, sustained community policing -- in which officers work closely with neighborhood residents -- can drive out street dealers.
Patrick J. Lynch is president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
Keeping one's balance between effective policing and showing the proper respect for your fellow New Yorkers takes a skilled acrobatic performance. But that tightrope stretches precariously when cops are feeling cheated by their contract, criticized by the community, used by the politicians and pressured by their bosses.
The notion that our cops are trigger-happy or out of control is unsupported by facts or statistics. But you can't counter this misconception unless you communicate with the community.
The pressure to produce numbers is a flawed approach to law enforcement. Quality of arrests is more important than quantity. Officers are not unwilling to go after the low-level criminal, but these arrests shouldn't simply satisfy a production schedule or risk lives. So to restore lost faith, we must tone down the politics, turn up the dialogue, do away with quotas and pay cops a living wage.
Richard E. Green is head of the Crown Heights Youth Collective in Brooklyn.
Yes, the police need to change tactics. But the community must also be ready to de-escalate the "scold" war it has conducted against the police and the Giuliani administration, and show the same level of moral indignation when young people lose their lives at the hands of one another. Since the shooting of Amadou Diallo, I have known four young people who have lost their lives due to violence.
The clergy, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, police officers and community leaders must come together to develop solutions. Our community leaders should consider patrolling their own schools (which is done in Philadelphia) and setting voluntary curfews for our youth. To make our communities safe, we must stop maligning all officers and start working with them.
George L. Kelling is the co-author of "Fixing Broken Windows: Restoring Order and Reducing Crime in Our Communities."
Aside from the underlying political fight, two important policing issues are raised by the recent shootings.
Special units, such as the street crimes unit and anti-drug operations like Operation Condor, can be effective tools, but they can also be troublesome and potentially dangerous. While special units have been important ingredients in the Police Department's crime-reduction efforts, they tend to be remote from neighborhoods and communities.
The second issue is police planning. Police increasingly rely on analysis of crime data, mapping and other methods to develop tactics for addressing specific problems. When they discover that guns are the primary instruments of murder in black neighborhoods, is it racial profiling or smart policing to target anti-gun efforts there?
Resolutions to these issues are possible, but not easy. They involve balancing individual rights with community interests, effectiveness with costs, and the tradeoffs among important values. Getting out of the current political mess, however, is the first step. Police and neighborhood leaders will have to seek each other out aggressively and honestly. Then, they can get back to the business of improving policing.

HEADLINE: Farmers Are Scaling Back Genetically Altered Crops

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 31

 BODY:
For the first time since 1996, American farmers expect to plant fewer acres with genetically engineered crops, largely because of concerns about selling those crops in international markets, the government said today.
According to a study released by the United States Department of Agriculture, farmers said they would plant more acres of corn and soybeans, the nation's two biggest crops, in the coming planting season but that a smaller part of their acreage would be devoted to genetically engineered varieties. The survey showed, for instance, that biotech corn plantings could be down 24 percent from a year ago and soybeans could be down 9 percent. 
 The nation's largest seed companies disputed the figures, saying that the use of genetically altered seeds in the United States was expected to be flat or up just slightly this year.
"What we know is what our invoices are telling us and that is, on a percent basis we're very similar to last year," said Doyle Karr, a spokesman at Pioneer Hi-Bred, the nation's largest seed company, and a division of DuPont.
Whether or not American farmers are planting genetically altered seeds, of course, is of major importance to the nation's largest biotechnology and food companies, many of which have invested billions of dollars in the technology, and watched the use of the biotech seeds grow tremendously over the past four years, to 62 million acres a year ago from 3 million acres in 1996.
Officials at the Department of Agriculture say the decline they expect in biotechnology acreage, the first since widespread planting of such crops began 1996, was probably due to the growing debate, particularly in Europe and Asia, over the use of the seeds to fight pests or protect crops against weeds.
Environmental groups say the crops were improperly tested and are potentially dangerous to the environment and humans. And major food companies like Frito-Lay, a division of Pepsico say that because of consumer uncertainty they have decided to avoid such crops.
The Agriculture Department study, a survey of thousands of American farmers conducted in early March, showed that farmers expect to plant 25 percent of their corn fields with genetically engineered seeds this year, down from 33 percent a year ago. They also expect to plant biotech seeds on 52 percent of their soybean fields, down from 57 percent a year ago.
Keith Collins, the department's chief economist, said biotech acres "look like they're down a little bit, but they haven't fallen off the table."
"Farmers have asked if they plant biotech will they have a market," Mr. Collins said. "Questions have been raised about the international market. But it doesn't look like farmers are fleeing biotech either."
Mr. Collins said some of the survey's numbers ought to be tempered, however, because while the study showed a drop in the percentage of cotton planted with biotech seeds, it failed to take into account that cotton acreage had risen sharply from a year ago. The survey may have also overstated the decline in biotech acreage devoted to soybeans because of possible miscounting a year ago, he said.
Indeed, the major seed companies say sales are expected to be up slightly this year. Officials at Monsanto said they recently found indications of a small increase after contacting companies that license their technology.
"We don't see a decline," said Carl Casale, a spokesman for Monsanto in St. Louis. "We see a market that is at least what it was last year if not better."
Several seed company executives, including Anthony Minnichsoffer, a spokesman at Novartis Seeds, say they expect less so-called Bt corn, a seed that releases its own insecticide to fight off the European corn borer, because there have been fewer problems with the pest, but otherwise sales of biotechnology products are stable.
"It doesn't look like it's changed significantly, maybe one or two percentage points up or down," Mr. Minnichsoffer said.
But farming organizations back up the Agriculture Department's predictions. The American Corn Growers Association said a survey it conducted in February showed that biotechnology plantings were expected to be down as much as 16 percent. And an informal survey conducted this month by the National Corn Growers Association found that 175 farmers from 23 states showed a 20 percent decline in plans to plant biotech corn this year.
Rod Weinzierl, executive director of the Illinois Corn Growers Association, said that in parts of the state, biotech corn plantings were expected to drop as much as 50 percent, largely because farmers fear that exports to Asia could dwindle.
Some farmers are also complaining about a shortage of nonbiotechnology seeds for the planting season, which is just getting under way.
They say that some of the big seed companies have not been able to deliver the traditional seeds they are asking for and in several cases have offered discounts on biotech seeds, suggesting that there is either an oversupply of biotech seeds or a shortage of traditional seeds.
"There's probably more of a shortage this year because there were probably more people who wanted to use" varieties that are not genetically modified, said Stanley Blunier, a corn and soybean farmer in Forest, Ill. "If it's not a shortage, it's tight."
Mr. Blunier, 48, is planting about 50 percent of his soybean fields with biotech seeds and about 70 percent of his corn fields with biotech seeds, a slight increase in biotech acreage from a year ago, largely because he has assurances that he can sell his biotech crops, he said.

LENGTH: 456 words

HEADLINE: Albright Drops Objection to Loan Deal for Russia Oil Company

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that she had dropped her objections to $500 million in loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank to a Russian oil company that had been accused of fraud.
The company, Tyumen, wants to spend $292 million to hire a Houston company, Haliburton, to rehabilitate an oil field in western Siberia, and $198 million for ABB Lummus Global, of Bloomfield, N.J., to modernize a refinery near Moscow. 
 The chairman of the United States Export-Import Bank, James A. Harmon, said in a statement today that the bank's board would "take up this matter at the earliest possible opportunity."
The bank had been close to approving the guarantees when Dr. Albright intervened on Dec. 22. At that point, the company had been accused of fraud in its dealings with BP Amoco, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and George Soros, the investor, over the bankruptcy of another oil company, Chernogorneft. All were investors or creditors in Chernogorneft.
A senior State Department official said tonight that negotiations between BP Amoco and Tyumen were sufficiently advanced that the loan guarantees should be issued.
"Our view is, it is back on a mode where people are talking to each other in a normal commercial way," the official said. "Waiting longer risks having us drawn into the details of these commercial disputes in a way that really isn't appropriate."
James B. Foley, a State Department spokesman, said today that since December, the Clinton administration "has been engaged in an extensive review of the concerns and allegations that were raised in this case."
Tyumen has been privatized, he pointed out, and "we have also opened a dialogue with the Russian government to impress upon them the need to address weaknesses in Russia's legal framework that led to the abuses in this case."
Dr. Albright blocked the loan guarantees during a time of heavy fighting in Chechnya, but State Department officials have said her action was not related to Russia's use of force in crushing the rebellion there.
Tyumen's president and chief executive, Simon Kukes, said in a statement: "These loan guarantees will create thousands of jobs in the United States and Russia and enable significant cooperation with Western partners on technical and managerial levels."
An American spokesman for the Tyumen, Rory Davenport, said the State Department's reversal was a confirmation of the business practices of Tyumen's leaders, "and saying that they have a good business plan and a good potential for growth."
"It's kind of like a seal of endorsement," he said. "It will allow them to attract more Western partners, more Western financing. That's very, very important."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Posts Its First Gain Of the Week

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Technology stocks remained the market victors in the first quarter, but old standbys like Intel seemed to be eclipsing Internet darlings by the end.
In an appropriately discordant finish to a wild and crazy quarter, major market indexes moved in opposite directions once again yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average was up solidly for most of the session, but reversed course late in the day to close at 10,921.92, down 58.33 points, or 0.5 percent. Computer programs related to end-of-quarter portfolio shuffling were cited by market participants. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index posted solid gains. The S.& P. rose 10.66 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,498.58. And the technology-laden Nasdaq rallied for the first time this week, gaining 114.94 points, or 2.6 percent, to 4,572.83.
The session closed the books on a volatile quarter in which technology stocks were widely expected to return to earth. In fact, the Nasdaq composite index experienced four declines of 10 percent or more in the first quarter, but rebounded each time.
Value stocks, generally old-economy companies whose shares look relatively cheap, were expected to reassert themselves. That, too, happened, but only briefly. And some of those stocks were pounded as investors proved unmerciful toward companies with bad news.
"Because of the inconsistencies in the market, it was one of the most difficult quarters in my memory," said Laszlo Birinyi, who has a stock market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "And I think this will continue. There is too much information and too many uninformed investors."
Among industry groups, electronics-related stocks -- from instruments to semiconductors -- did extremely well. As the week ended, Internet concerns that provide services to both consumers and businesses showed weakness, while investors flocked to technology companies with proven earnings, companies like Intel and Cisco. Natural gas stocks posted big gains in the quarter, and so did oil and gas drillers.
But it was a very bad period for hotel and motel operators, engineering and construction stocks and life insurance companies.
Led by energy, technology and health care (otherwise known as biotechnology), small stocks fared well. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-cap issues finished the quarter at 539.09, up 6.8 percent.
The quarter started badly for all sectors of the market, but particularly for the 30 stocks that make up the Dow: at one point the index was down more than 13 percent.
The blue-chip index rallied as long-term interest rates began to ease even as short-term rates climbed. The Dow did particularly well last month, rising 7.8 percent. Still, it is down 5 percent for the year.
The S.& P. 500, which was down for much of the quarter, is now up 2 percent for the year, thanks to a 9.7 percent gain in March. In fact, the month just ended was the best for the index since December 1991.
And the Nasdaq composite, which fell 7.9 percent last week and was down 2.6 percent for March, nevertheless closed out the quarter 12.4 percent above its year-end mark.
At the quarter's end, even the most optimistic market analysts acknowledged that technology stocks remain overpriced after their recent dips.
"There is no question that technology got ahead of itself on valuation," said Jeffrey Applegate, chief market strategist at Lehman Brothers. "And if we got overvalued in technology, chances are we will have to get undervalued as well. That is particularly true for the Internet stocks."
Business-to-business stocks suffered yesterday amid concerns about companies banding together to create their own buying groups on the Internet.
For the first quarter, technology stocks were the walkaway winners. The list starts with Intel, the world's biggest chip maker and a component of the Dow, the S.& P. and the Nasdaq composite. The stock was the best performer on the Dow, gaining more than 61 percent.
Strong as it was, that performance badly lagged that of the biggest gainers in the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq. The top New York Stock Exchange gainer was Avista, which rose 164 percent, while Safety-Kleen was the top loser, down 89 percent.
Scientific Atlanta, an S.& P. component and the No. 5 gainer on the Big Board, rose 126 percent. LSI Logic was up 116 percent. Neturgy Networks, the top Nasdaq gainer, rose 478.1 percent, while Superior National Insurance, the Nasdaq's biggest loser, slid 79 percent.
There were several notable flame-outs, particularly among well-established names. The foremost was Procter & Gamble, which makes everything from Pampers to Crest to Tide. Investors battered the shares last month after the company gave a surprisingly downbeat projection on earnings for the balance of its fiscal year. The day of the announcement P.& G. lost one-third of its market capitalization. For the quarter, the stock was down 48.4 percent.
Other big names in the Dow that fared poorly were Johnson & Johnson, the maker of Band-Aid bandages, baby care products and Tylenol pain reliever, which fell 24.4 percent on the New York Stock Exchange; and International Paper, which fell 23.8 percent.
Despite the big fluctuations and concerns about technology stocks, analysts said overall stock fundamentals remained solid.
"The equity outlook is good," said Byron Wien, United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "Technology and telecommunications stocks are too frothy, but at the same time the companies are doing fabulously. The question is to watch out for the stocks that get ahead of themselves."
Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, predicted that the second quarter would be much like the first, as investors seek out the likely winners among technology stocks.

Good Period for Treasuries
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rounded out the best first quarter in more than a decade as a 7.9 percent decline in the Nasdaq composite index this week made fixed-income securities more attractive to some investors.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 20/32 yesterday, to 105 29/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.83 percent from 5.87 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Hey, Rudy G.: Bring Back The Sopranos

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
FOR a devotee of the "Godfather" movies, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a shocking gaffe during this year's State of the City address. It came right after he described his crusades against organized crime at the Fulton Fish Market and the carting industry.
"We've reduced the influence of the Mafia so much," Mr. Giuliani boasted, "now when they do mob shows, they don't even set them in New York any more. They put them in New Jersey. They do 'The Sopranos' in New Jersey." 
 This is something to celebrate? Ordinarily city officials try desperately to keep industries from crossing the river, especially the ones deemed integral to New York's image. Television networks and film companies get tax exemptions and other favors because they generate publicity that lures tourists here.
But now millions of television viewers are gazing at the wonders of New Jersey. Soon busloads of tourists will be admiring the swamps below the Pulaski Skyway, and only veteran New Yorkers will remember the mob hits at Umberto's Clam House and Sparks Steakhouse. The executions in the next "Godfather" movie could take place at the Applebee's in Livingston Mall.
How can New York regain its status as the capital of organized crime? The obvious answer is to make Tony Soprano a relocation offer he can't refuse. The official term is an Inducement Resolution, which is a package of benefits from the city's Industrial Development Agency for companies demanding a bribe to come in from the suburbs.
"A deal with the Sopranos would require some creativity," said one lawyer who has negotiated many such deals with the city (and who insisted on anonymity to avoid offending either the mayor or the mob). "Typically the city offers a company exemptions from sales tax, but that won't be very helpful because the Sopranos usually don't pay sales tax anyway."
Fortunately, the city has a history of creative corporate welfare, so there are precedents to draw on for a Soprano aid package. By borrowing the language from past deals for media companies, banks and insurance firms, it's simple enough to fill out the paperwork for the Industrial Development Agency:
Applicant: Soprano Family Enterprises ("Sopranos").
Employment: 3,782 jobs.
Type of business: Waste management, trucking, adult entertainment, commercial construction, corporate security, home-appliance sales, used-automobile exporting, commercial lending, miscellaneous personal financial services.
Net revenues for last fiscal year: "Substantial" (F.B.I.).
I.D.A. Benefits: $250 million in low-interest bonds for purchase in Staten Island of residences, including home offices, for relocated Sopranos executives. One three-acre industrial site in Brooklyn, to be sold for $1 and granted adult-entertainment zoning waiver allowing operation of Bada Bing dancing establishment. Seven city-owned lots, currently unoccupied, adjacent to Belt Parkway and Gowanus Canal, to be leased for 99 years at no cost, for miscellaneous storage purposes.
PROJECT DESCRIPTION. Sopranos, a privately held company, is willing to consolidate and expand its operations by relocating to New York City. In return for benefits, the chief executive, Anthony Soprano, guarantees to keep 100 jobs in the city for a period of either 15 years or "as long as I'm boss."
F.B.I. analysts project that Sopranos' relocation would add 900 jobs to the city's garment, carting and construction industries. Adverse environmental impacts -- e.g., increased traffic congestion at rush hour -- are expected to be negligible due to unique nature of these "no-show" jobs.
Economic analysts calculate that the "multiplier effect" of these activities will be an additional 2,782 jobs. Some will be in related service industries like ammunition sales, emergency medical care, mortuary services, floral sales.
The remainder will be created by the indirect economic stimulus of Sopranos' activities, like the increased demand for new automobiles due to export operations. Assuming a rate of .6 gangland slayings per year, tourist visits to murder sites are projected to create 47 jobs.
Recommendation: New York City has an unusual opportunity to revive an industry weakened by an exodus of leaders to out-of-state correctional institutions. At a small cost per job, the city can stimulate its economy and assure its prominence in future installments of "The Godfather." I.D.A. staff urges prompt approval by sundown today.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Group Led by AT&T Invests In Web Phone Call Provider
AT&T, British Telecommunications and Liberty Media Group are making a $1.4 billion cash investment in Net2Phone, an Internet telephone services provider. The deal is the latest in a series of moves by AT&T to strengthen its Internet presence.
Net2Phone, which handles about 40 percent of calls routed over the Internet, said separately that it had sold a minority stake to the Internet search engine Yahoo through a stock swap valued at $150 million. Page C2. 

Web Auctioneers to Set Safeguards
The Consumer Product Safety Commission said that two of the biggest Internet auction sites had agreed to new safeguards to protect people from buying dangerous second-hand products on the Web. The agency said the auction sites, eBay and Amazon.com Auctions, had agreed to links with the commission's site to warn buyers and sellers about products that had been deemed hazardous, or in some instances even outlawed. A7.
 
Engineered Crop Planting to Decline
An Agriculture Department survey says American farmers expect to plant a smaller percentage of their acreage with genetically engineered crops this year for the first time since 1996. But the farmers say they plan to increase total acreage and seed companies say total sales of genetically engineered seeds has not declined this year. A6.
 
Consumer Spending Rose 1 Percent
Consumer spending rose 1 percent in February, while income growth slowed to 0.4 percent, and the savings rate fell to its lowest level since the government began keeping records in 1959. Factory orders fell 0.8 percent in February, the second consecutive decrease. C2.
 
Japanese Unemployment at Record
The number of Japanese workers looking for jobs climbed to 4.9 percent in February, a record high, as bankruptcies rose and companies trimmed jobs in the aftermath of an economic downturn last fall and winter. C2.
 
Environmental Coffee Rules Studied
Sales of coffee that meet the tastes of gourmets and a variety of environmental standards have exploded recently. The members of the North American Free Trade Agreement have assembled a team of 100 representatives of coffee roasters and importers to begin standardizing the criteria under which coffee can be certified as having been grown in conditions that are good for health, the environment and workers. Above are freshly picked coffee beans ripe for roasting. C2.
 
Bank of New York Cuts Chief's Pay
The Bank of New York said that it had paid its chairman and chief executive, Thomas Renyi, less last year than in 1998 because of the bank's role in a Russian money-laundering scandal. His total compensation fell to about $6.75 million from $7.55 million. C16.
 
Cable Rights Negotiations Extended
ABC and Time Warner Cable have agreed to another extension of negotiations in their dispute over rights for Time Warner to carry ABC's stations over its cable systems. The two companies have been at odds over how Time Warner will compensate ABC for continuing to retransmit ABC's stations. C16.
 
Shares of Drkoop.com Plummet
Shares of the Internet health company Drkoop.com plunged more than 40 percent after its accountant said Drkoop has lost money since it started and might not survive. C3.
 
Financier Gets 10-Year Sentence
Financier Mario Conde, who symbolized Spain's get-rich-quick boom in the 1980's, was sentenced to more than 10 years in prison for his role in the $2 billion failure of the country's biggest bank. C2.

Putin Vows to Maintain Russia's Nuclear Might
Vladimir V. Putin, in his first official trip since being elected president, visited a nuclear weapons design center and vowed to preserve his nation's nuclear might. But he also emphasized that he supported ratification of the Start II arms reduction treaty and negotiations for further cuts in strategic nuclear arms. A1

A British Internet service provider agreed to pay $25,000 to a physicist who said he was libeled in messages posted on electronic bulletin boards carried by the company. A5
 
U.S. Advises Taiwan on Defense
A team of military officials will go to Taiwan this weekend to show officials there a secret Pentagon study on how problems in Taiwan's air defense system make it vulnerable to attack from China. A4
 
Uganda Toll Passes Jonestown
The number of deaths linked to a cult was raised to 924, surpassing the 913 in 1978 at Jonestown, Guyana. Ugandan officials promised to catch the killers, but investigators showed no sign of tracking down cult leaders or confirming that any had survived. A5
 
U.N. Lets Iraq Buy Oil Gear
The Security Council voted unanimously to let Iraq import $1.2 billion in spare parts and other equipment this year for its oil industry. A council panel also completed work on lists of food, pharmaceuticals, educational material and agricultural equipment that Iraq will be permitted to purchase without review. A5
 
Bahrain Reopens Iraq Embassy
Arab diplomats said Bahrain would soon reopen its embassy in Baghdad, which has been closed for 10 years, since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Bahrain would be the third Gulf Arab state, after Qatar and Oman, to reopen an embassy in Iraq. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Campaign Briefing

 BODY:

THE REPUBLICANS
 
KEYES ON THE TRAIL -- Still pursuing his Republican presidential bid, Alan Keyes told Wisconsin voters this week that Vice President Al Gore, the presumed Democratic nominee, has a "pretty good chance" of winning the election. Mr. Keyes said Mr. Gore would benefit from "economic prosperity and peace" in a race against the presumed Republican nominee, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Mr. Keyes, who spoke to voters at the Monroe County Fairgrounds, said Republicans needed to promote moral values and oppose abortion, which he called worse than slavery. Dirk Johnson 

THE REFORM PARTY
 
CALL FOR 'HARDBALL' ON OIL -- Patrick J. Buchanan said yesterday that the United States should stabilize oil prices in part by lifting sanctions on Iran and Iraq, selling them oil-drilling equipment and threatening to withhold military aid from Persian Gulf allies unless crude prices fall to $20 a barrel. "This is the dark side of globalization," Mr. Buchanan said in an advance copy of a speech at Boston University. "We should play hardball with those who play hardball with us."
 
THE VOTERS
 
THE RACE IN PENNSYLVANIA -- With the major presidential candidacies effectively settled, interest among political professionals is shifting to an array of theoretical vice-presidential nominees to see how they fare in the polls. The latest measure, from Pennsylvania, finds that a local Republican, Gov. Tom Ridge, adds five points to Gov. George W. Bush's current four-point lead over Vice President Al Gore. A Bush-Ridge ticket was polled at 46 percent, to 37 percent for Mr. Gore, who was measured without running mates. The poll, conducted for the Commonwealth Foundation/Lincoln Institute, measured a Bush ticket with the evergreen theoretical nominee, Colin L. Powell, at 47 percent to 37 percent over Mr. Gore. The survey had a margin of error of four percentage points. Francis X. Clines
 
THE SOUTH
 
AN UNUSUAL SWITCH -- For years, Democrats in South Carolina have stood before cameras to announce their conversion to the Republican Party, but this week, there was a far more startling switch: Two moderate Republican state representatives said they were becoming Democrats, the first Republicans to do so in the state since the end of Reconstruction. Mickey Whatley and Dr. Margaret J. Gamble said they were tired of being pressured to vote along party lines, though they can now also escape difficult primary challenges. The move reduces the Republican majority in the state's House of Representatives to five votes. David Firestone
 
FREE ADS COMING -- Starting today and continuing through the month, a North Carolina broadcasting company will provide a total of 180 minutes of free broadcasting time on each of its four television stations so candidates for governor can explain their positions on main issues. Both parties hold primaries on May 2. Capitol Broadcasting, based in Raleigh, plans to allow each of five candidates -- three Republicans and two Democrats -- to tape three two-minute spots; personal attacks on opponents will be prohibited. Each spot will run six times on WRAL-TV, a CBS affiliate in Raleigh; WJZY-TV, the UPN affiliate in Charlotte; WRAZ-TV, the Fox affiliate in Durham, and WILM-TV, the CBS affiliate in Wilmington. Jim Goodmon, Capitol's chief executive, sat on a 1998 White House commission recommending that television stations give candidates broadcast time in the month before an election. Kevin Sack

HEADLINE: SEEKING ANSWERS, CENSUS IS STIRRING PRIVACY QUESTIONS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Saturday is Census Day, the day the government takes a demographic snapshot of every man, woman and child in America to find out how many of them there are and where they live and how old they are and what race they consider themselves, and to make it possible to tabulate, among dozens of other factors, their education, marital status, income and housing conditions.
To some people, this is an invasion of their privacy. 
 Most people interviewed at random in several cities around the country were happy, even eager, to answer the census questions. But it was not hard to find ones who were upset.
"Some of it was too personal," said Tom Donahue, a retiree who lives in the Charlestown section of Boston. "I didn't fill in those parts. I just left them blank."
Adriana Farrell, a software developer in suburban Minneapolis, asked, "Am I Hispanic because my mom is from Ecuador?"
At a bar on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Ken Rickert, an elevator mechanic, said he would not return his census form because "this is a government institution, and I don't want any part of it."
Carolyn Berghoff, a member of the Chicago Lyric Opera's choir, said she and her husband, Robert, a lawyer, had answered all the questions except the ones dealing with income, which they left blank. "The older you get the more reluctant you are to give out that kind of financial information," Ms. Berghoff said.
The Census Bureau wants to know where people were living on April 1, and it mailed census forms earlier this month to 120 million home addresses, asking who would be living there on April 1.
In an interview today, Kenneth Prewitt, the census director, said, "There's not a single question on the census that was not put there to fulfill some very serious piece of legislation or government program.
"If you think Head Start is invasive, if you think mass-transit routes are invasive, if you think the location of veterans hospitals is invasive, then maybe so, but they depend on the census," Mr. Prewitt continued. "Cost-of-living increases for Social Security and veterans could not be calculated without the census."
There are two census forms. Most households get the short form, which asks seven basic questions about the number of people living at each address and their age, sex and race. Hardly anyone objects to answering these questions.
But 1 household in 6 gets the more elaborate long form, which has 53 questions, and this is where the objections arise.
The complaints have been frequent enough that some politicians, almost all of them Republicans, have weighed in. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, has made public-service commercials urging people in his state to return their census forms.
Senator Lott's spokesman, John Czwartacki, said that many constituents had complained that their rights were being infringed and that the senator had encouraged them to skip the questions they objected to and to send in the rest of the form.
Another Republican senator, Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, has prepared legislation that would remove the criminal penalty for failing to answer questions. Mr. Hagel's spokeswoman, Deb Fiddelke, said his office had received about 200 complaints about items being intrusive.
Even Gov. George W. Bush of Texas entered the fray, saying at a campaign stop in Milwaukee this week that he was not sure he would answer all the questions himself. Mr. Bush advised people, "If they're worried about the government intruding into their personal lives, they ought to think about it."
Democrats accused the Republicans of playing politics with an essential element of the American government.
"They don't want people counted," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, "because they think it serves their political purpose."
In his radio address on Saturday, the White House said, President Clinton will encourage Americans to return their census forms.
Bill Beach, a senior fellow in economics at the Heritage Foundation, said the government simply did not need to have so much information about so many people. "The scope is awesome as to what the government is asking you by law to reveal," he declared.
But Stephen Fienberg, a professor of statistics and social science at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, said, "Every question is there because there is a law that cannot be implemented without the data, and the only way we can get the data is through the census."
Questions about race, Mr. Fienberg said, are essential to enforcing voting-rights laws. Questions about language are necessary for various education programs. Questions about plumbing and kitchen equipment are needed for housing programs.
Complaints about privacy arise every 10 years, said Margo Anderson, a professor at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee, who has written a history of the census. But Professor Anderson said she could not recall a time when so many politicians complained at the very time the count was being made.
Across the country this week, census takers went to homeless shelters and soup kitchens in the hope of enumerating people. Over the next month, nursing homes, college dormitories and prisons will be visited. Beginning on April 18, census workers will knock on the doors of households that have not returned their forms.
Half a million temporary workers will be hired for these duties.
To encourage participation, the Census Bureau has run an extensive advertising campaign, much of it on television. The advertising budget, approved by Congress, is $167 million.
As of today, the bureau reported, 50 percent of households had responded. The response rate ranged from 37 percent in Mississippi to 56 percent in Nebraska. Mr. Prewitt, the census director, said the goal was a national response of 61 percent, before census takers began the count of those who failed to return the forms sent to their homes.
State-by-state population tallies will be completed by the end of this year, and they will be used to determine how many Congressional seats are allotted to each state.
If preliminary estimates pan out, New York and Pennsylvania will lose two seats, and Arizona and Texas will gain two. Connecticut, Illinois, Mississippi, Ohio, Oklahoma and Wisconsin will lose one seat each. California, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Montana and Nevada will gain one each.
By April 1, 2001, each state will receive block-by-block counts. These will be used for redistricting within the states and for such decisions as where to build schools, roads and fire stations. More detailed data will then be reported periodically.
The statistics are not used just by governments and social scientists. Businesses rely on them to determine where to advertise, where to invest and where to locate.
When this year's count is complete, the experts say, the population of the United States will be about 275 million. That is 200 million higher than the count at the turn of the last century.
In 1920, the census found that the United States had crossed the divide that separates a rural nation from an urban one. The 1980 census showed that the population of the South and West exceeded that of the North and Midwest. The 1990 census was the first, in asking who lived at an address, to use the term "unmarried partner."
The Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 decision, held last year that the actual head count had to be used for reapportionment of Congressional seats. But this year, for the first time, the Census Bureau is also using a sampling technique to enumerate people who were missed by the head count.
The justices did not rule on what this more accurate count could be used for -- on whether, for example, it can be the basis for drawing the redistricting maps within states.
The result, no doubt, will be a flurry of lawsuits, filed by political parties, civil rights groups, conservative legal foundations, cities and suburban counties, each of them trying to compel or prohibit the government from using the population counts derived from sampling.

HEADLINE: PUTIN VOWS RUSSIA WILL REINVIGORATE ITS NUCLEAR FORCE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: SNEZHINSK, Russia, March 31

 BODY:
In his first official trip since being elected president, Vladimir V. Putin visited one of Russia's leading nuclear weapons design centers and vowed to preserve the nation's nuclear might.
"We must increase the efficiency of our nuclear potential," Mr. Putin said at a meeting at the Chelyabinsk-70 complex near here, where thousands of nuclear scientists live and work behind a barricade of barbed wire. 
 None of this was portrayed by Russia's president-elect as the start of a new arms race. In fact, Mr. Putin emphasized today that he supported ratification of the Start II arms reduction treaty and negotiations to make further cuts in strategic nuclear weapons. And he pointedly said that his goal of a more efficient nuclear program includes consolidating production, not increasing it.
He insisted that his talk of building a stronger Russian state should be taken by the West as a sign that he was committed to protecting property rights and developing a fairer legal system. It is not, he said, an indication that he is looking for a confrontation with the West or planning to crack down on human rights.
When asked today for reaction to Mr. Putin's trip and his proposals, the State Department said it had no comment.
During his visit, Mr. Putin did point out that his decision to attend a meeting here on nuclear energy and weapons issues had been made long ago and that politics were not the point. Still, politics seemed to be very much on the mind of Mr. Putin, who failed to win a convincing mandate in the recent election and is now seeking broader support as he forms his new government.
In fact, the symbolism of today's event, as well as its content, appeared to provide a clue to his agenda. Russia's sizable nuclear arsenal is the Kremlin's last pretension to superpower status. Flanked by his defense and atomic energy ministers today, Mr. Putin signaled that he was prepared to support both the weapons arsenal and the scientists who have developed it.
Set in the town of Snezhinsk, Chelyabinsk-70 is one of 10 closed nuclear cities, where some 700,000 Russians live and which have fallen on hard times.
The fate of the cities has been a growing concern not only for the Russians but also for American policy makers, who fear that economic hardship may prompt Russia's nuclear elite to sell its bomb-making expertise to aspiring nuclear powers.
Chelyabinsk-70, certainly, has seen better days. The nuclear complex was established in 1955 as a backup and competitor to Arzamas-16, the Soviet Union's first nuclear weapons design center.
Its scientists were among the nation's elite. But with the collapse of the Soviet Union, they lost their favored place in the system. Wages were delayed. Many young people left to find opportunities elsewhere.
The work force at Chelyabinsk-70 shrank to its present 9,500 employees from about 15,000 a decade ago. The complex's crisis seemed to be symbolized by the suicide of Vladimir Z. Nechai, the director of Chelyabinsk-70, who shot himself in 1996.
During the recent election campaign, Mr. Putin repeatedly pledged to strengthen Russia's military-industrial complex. For example, he outlined a 10-point plan for improving military production, and he has increased spending for weapons procurement by 50 percent, a development that appears to reflect the strains put on the military by the war in Chechnya.
Scientists here say high-level attention from the Kremlin is already beginning to make a difference at their nuclear center. The average pay of a nuclear scientist at Chelyabinsk-70 is only 3,000 rubles a month (about $106). But at least wages are being paid regularly now.
"We are receiving increased attention," said Yevgeny N. Avrorin, the scientific director of Chelyabinsk-70, who has worked here since the complex was established. "It started when Yevgeny M. Primakov was prime minister and has continued. To compare our situation with the West, we are poor. But things are better than they were a year and a half ago."
At Chelyabinsk-70, for example, there has been talk of redirecting the talents of its scientists and workers to civilian projects. But Mr. Avrorin said only 10 percent of its scientists and workers had shifted entirely to commercial work.
And a much-advertised United States Energy Department program to drum up civilian work for residents of Russia's nuclear cities has been pared back by the United States Congress and provides only a modicum of assistance.
After arriving today, Mr. Putin strode across the main square, which is still dominated by a hulking monument of Lenin, and plunged into the crowd like a veteran politician.
He later held a news conference, at which he said he would move forward with pro-market economic policies and promised to welcome politicians from a variety of parties into his government on the condition that they work as members of his team.
Later he left for the nearby city of Chelyabinsk to preside over a judo tournament and hand out kimonos to the winners -- a convenient photo opportunity for a leader who touts his own prowess at the sport.
For all that, the region is not a hotbed of Putin supporters. Many of the workers at Chelyabinsk-70, for example, are highly educated, and they appear somewhat less impressed than many of their countrymen by the tough image that Mr. Putin has forged by ordering a military campaign in Chechnya.
Mr. Putin, in fact, received 47.5 percent of the vote here, somewhat less than the 52.6 percent he received nationwide. Grigory V. Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko party and a critic of Mr. Putin's Chechnya policy, received about 12 percent here, about double his national average. And while the crowds were friendly, they were surprisingly modest considering the rarity of the event.
A 25-year-old woman who was selling tea, candy and household items in the outdoor market said she had voted for Mr. Putin. Trained as a teacher, she opened a small stall in the marketplace after she got tired of waiting for wages that never seemed to be paid on time.
"Maybe Putin came to see what conditions are like in a closed city," said the woman, who gave her name only as Olga.
Vyacheslav Stepanov, 54, a ballistics expert and director of a military laboratory here, acknowledged that there were many problems at Chelyabinsk-70, including the fact that few young scientists were clamoring to work there. For a while, he said, he was the youngest person in his office.
Still, he did not seem convinced that Mr. Putin would make that much of a difference. Mr. Stepanov said he had voted for Ella Pamfilova, the only female candidate in the election contest, who received a fraction of the vote.
"I thought I should show my support for a female candidate," he said.

HEADLINE: Stand Over Cuban Highlights A Virtual Secession of Miami

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 31

 BODY:
The last time Floridians spoke fiercely about rebellion and secession, they left the Union. Now rebellion is happening again, as political leaders in Miami-Dade County say they plan to defy federal authority in the international custody case of Elian Gonzalez.
But secession, say all manner of people here, has been going on for a long time. The battle over Elian merely shows how far it has come. 
 "This country is going to see now what we're all about," shouted Jose Ramos, an elderly Cuban-American who considers himself Cuban, period, outside the house where Elian lives in Little Havana. One of the many exiles in South Florida whose hatred for President Fidel Castro of Cuba defines his past, present and future, Mr. Ramos said he was ready to give his life to stop the federal government from taking Elian away.
Such passion is expected at the house, ground zero in the four-month confrontation between an overwhelming majority of Cuban exiles here and United States government officials who want to return Elian to his father and to Cuba. But on Wednesday, when 20 elected officials in Miami-Dade County said they would not allow their police to aid federal authorities, it proved that the politicians here would choose their own independent foreign policy over the rule of law, say some legal, political and immigration experts who have followed the Elian case.
To many people here, some who cheered and some who shuddered, it was a declaration of independence for a part of the country that is, increasingly, a nation apart. People have even begun to greet each other with, "Welcome to the independent republic of Miami."
"This is a city that is separate," said Lisandro Perez, the director of the Cuban Research Institute at Florida International University. "We now have our own local foreign policy."
Cuban-Americans make up some 800,000 of the county's 2.1 million people. Latin Americans make up the overwhelming majority, and English has faded from homes, offices and stores. But it is the Cuban exiles who drive the county's economy, politics and culture, and it is Cuba's flag, not the United States', in the windows of shops, on car antennas and on the mural behind the Chevrolet dealership on Le Jeune Road.
Many Cuban-Americans believe they have been strong-armed by the government, and that its leaders have no compassion for Elian or for their view, said Luis Aguilar Leon, Cuba scholar and historian at the University of Miami. "They are thinking of justice," Mr. Leon said. "But justice is not only the law."
"It's hard for them not to get passionate," he said. "Everyone has a brother, sister or family member who has suffered, because of a totalitarian regime."
And that, said political experts, is what drove Alex Penelas, mayor of Miami-Dade County, to say that he would not use the county's resources to assist federal officials if they come for the boy, and to say that he would hold Attorney General Janet Reno responsible if blood was shed.
His language, said experts on exiles and people on the street, reminded them of the way Southern governors talked during the civil rights movement decades ago.
"On Oct. 15, 1996, Penelas executed his solemn oath as Dade County's mayor to 'support, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States,' " said William P. Harris Jr., a lawyer in Miami.
But what Mr. Penelas and others did in front of the federal courthouse on Wednesday afternoon reminded him of George Wallace on the steps of the Alabama State Capitol in Montgomery in 1963, when, "in the face of a federalized force, he violated his oath and disgraced himself," Mr. Harris said.
"I'm still angry," he said. "Everyone refers to Miami as that 'banana republic.' First all the corruption we've had over the years and now this? My God."
Mr. Penelas said he never meant that the police would stand by if violence broke out. "It's unfortunate that my statements were interpreted that way," he said.
What he meant, he said, was that the police would play no role in taking the boy from the home. "If they think our SWAT team is going to go in there and take him out, yelling and screaming," he said, federal officials are mistaken.
But local police often help federal officers in such tense situations, and in choosing not to let his officers assist in this case, Mr. Penelas, and those mayors who backed him, are siding against an unpopular but legal process, say some experts on police actions and crowd control.
Mr. Penelas described the government's actions as "provocations" and "unjustified threats." In Little Havana, exiles applauded Mr. Penelas' words, and took them to mean that he is behind them in their fight to keep Elian in the freedom of the United States, at all costs.
"This country is the land of laws," said Miguel Saavedra, president of Vigilia Mambisa, an exile group here. "But not today. Not with us."
Max Castro, a senior research associate at the North-South Center at the University of Miami, which focuses on immigration and Cuban issues, also said the unrest echoes "state and federal confrontations in the civil rights era. They had the same elements."
But like the people on both sides of that issue, "Cubans are polarized," he said.
Critics of his stand said the mayor's comments, and the comments of others, seemed to excuse disobedience if not invite it. What it shows, said David Abraham, professor of immigration law at the University of Miami, is that "the local political elite said they feel the laws of the United States do not apply to them, when they feel otherwise. People who believe in the rule of law are mystified by this."
"This isn't like some of the other things South Florida has done," he said, referring to years of massive political corruption, police scandal, and legendary drug trafficking -- local politicians once named a street after a drug dealer, a mistake they corrected.
But this, said Mr. Abraham, "is the the most defiant position a public official has taken since the days of Orville Faubus." Mr. Faubus was the Arkansas governor who defied federal orders to integrate schools in 1957, leading to violent confrontations in the streets, and to public dismay.
"Just as President Eisenhower found that only an overwhelming display of force could make clear that the law of land also applied in Arkansas," Mr. Abraham said, "it may regrettably take an overwhelming display to prove South Florida is part of the United States."
The truth is, said many Cuban-Americans here, they do not mind if they are seen as a separate country. Not only do they not want to be part of middle America, they do not care very much what middle America thinks of them.
"I don't understand this country," said Marta Santana, who came to the United States 40 years ago. She was a teacher in Cuba, then worked at a day care center here. "Castro is the devil, and now so is Clinton."
But Miami's national image does matter, to the lenders and corporate decision-makers who would invest in a region where bond ratings seem to sink with every corruption scandal or sensational headline.
"People are going to look down at them around the country after this one," said Mr. Perez of the Florida International University, who is Cuban himself. "It will have a negative implication to those sitting in middle America."
For 40 years, he said, the exiles have been viewed not so much as immigrants as fighters of communism.
"They've been spoiled by the U.S. government in the past. Look at the record. They've gotten television stations, radio stations," to broadcast their message to Cuba.
"This time the government is saying no."
Not all Cuban-Americans want the boy to stay, and even some of those who do say they do not approve of the tactics. But they are shouted down.
Most support the hard-line against the federal government, even if quietly. "If we were African American, no one would be questioning us," said Mazaro Menendez, a salesman who came from Cuba 27 years ago.
Even as exiles vowed to use any means possible to stop the boy from being taken, Joe Carollo, the mayor of Miami, said the Cuban community will not -- even as his own constituents talk of violence -- become violent.
"The Cuban-American community has never been involved in riots," he said. "We have no history of violence."
If the exiles somehow win, and keep Elian here in defiance of the law, it would dismay many people here -- the anglos, blacks and non-Cuban Hispanics, said some political experts.
"They would find someplace else to live," said Mr. Abraham.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
BASIL STREET BLUES, by Michael Holroyd. (Norton, $24.95.) The biographer of George Bernard Shaw turns obliquely to autobiography, confessing that his literary life has been shaped by his efforts to escape from involvement with a family of dreadful, fascinating eccentrics.
 
THE BATTLE FOR GOD, by Karen Armstrong. (Knopf, $27.50.) A scholar's disturbing account of the rise of fundamentalist sects in the great voids left by the retreat of the world's monotheistic religions, and of their potential rise to power in the event of environmental or economic catastrophe.
 
BRUCE CHATWIN, by Nicholas Shakespeare. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $35.) A life of the author of "The Songlines," who died of AIDS in 1989, portrays a man beset with an almost biological lust for loneliness, whose singular genius was for passionate transitory connection.
 
BURT LANCASTER: An American Life, by Kate Buford. (Knopf, $27.50.) The magnetic, acrobatic, left-leaning, leonine, Chiclet-toothed, womanizing actor emerges, by the end of this comprehensive account, characterized by yet another adjective, one less often applied to him: vulnerable.
 
EQUAL LOVE: Stories, by Peter Ho Davies. (Houghton Mifflin, paper, $12.) Short fiction that regards with a kind of awe the comforts and constrictions of family ties as manifest in everyday events like lust, divorce and the sighting of U.F.O.'s.
 
FIVE SISTERS: The Langhornes of Virginia, by James Fox. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) Forebears of the author, the Langhorne girls embodied the Platonic ideal of Southern Belle, collectively bagging more than 70 proposals of marriage (full disclosure: 63 were for one sister alone), a castle, a 55-carat diamond, 8 husbands and a Lady Astorship.
 
HOUSE OF LEAVES, by Mark Z. Danielewski. (Pantheon, cloth, $40; paper, $19.95.) A funny, moving, elaborate first novel in which a common dream becomes the medium of a peculiarly moral confrontation with fear and trembling.
 
IN AMERICA, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) A daring novel in which, off and on, narrator merges with author and history with imagination in the career of a grand 19th-century Polish actress who knocks 'em dead in California.
 
JOAN OF ARC, by Mary Gordon. (Lipper/Viking, $19.95.) A biographical meditation, one of the Penguin Lives series, that construes Joan the maid and saint as the patroness of a commitment that fears no defeat and counts no odds.
 
YELTSIN: A Revolutionary Life, by Leon Aron. (St. Martin's, $35.) An admiring if unadoring biography seeks to reclaim its subject from drunken-clown caricature, arguing that Yeltsin was just what Russia needed at a crucial historical pass.
