SECTION: Section 7; Page 17; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1980 words

HEADLINE: A Symbol in Spite of Herself

BYLINE: By Anthony Heilbut; Anthony Heilbut's books include "The Gospel Sound: Good News and Bad Times" and "Thomas Mann: Eros and Literature."

 BODY:

MARIAN ANDERSON
 A Singer's Journey.
 By Allan Keiler.
 Illustrated. 447 pp. New York:
 A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $30. 
 THE greatest intersection of art and politics in this nation's history was Marian Anderson's concert at the Lincoln Memorial in 1939. She was the most distinguished singer of her day, blessed with a voice that Arturo Toscanini famously called a once-in-a-century phenomenon. She had spent the 1930's dazzling European audiences with her mastery of art songs -- beating them, as it were, at their own game. Yet all these laurels could not persuade the racist Daughters of the American Revolution to allow her the use of their Constitution Hall. This mistreatment of a national treasure outraged the country, and drew 75,000 citizens to the Lincoln Memorial, asserting with their presence that the Civil War had been about completing the American Revolution, so-called Daughters be damned. Anderson herself was a lonely figure on that podium. As Allan Keiler writes in his smart and disturbing biography, it was an accident, never welcomed by Anderson, that her artistic journey so often coincided with high public drama.
Anderson's persona was imperially remote -- she identified herself as "we." This may have been a function of her appearance: she was tall and slim, with features that recalled her African and Native American ancestors. But the posture might have been a response to the naysayers who had dogged her since childhood, the poor daughter of a cleaning lady, already caught in the skein of class and intraracial prejudice. She once wrote her husband, Orpheus Fisher (a man so light-skinned that she was suspected of marrying outside the race), that a "middle way" was "best perhaps, all the while keeping ears, eyes and mouth open." This deeply religious woman believed one must always watch as well as pray.
Her talent alone should have opened all doors. Keiler, a professor of music at Brandeis University, credits Anderson with three octaves; her longtime accompanist, Franz Rupp, said she had four. Classical music has seldom known an instrument like Anderson's, one that could soar to ethereal highs -- she could mimic angels, ghosts, ecstatic maidens and terrified children -- then descend to unearthly, androgynous lows. With baritonal power she could impersonate a brokenhearted suitor, an exhausted slave or the voices of God and Death.
The subtle deployment of vocal dynamics was her joy. Her low notes, sung half-voice, seemed even more cavernous, and the emotions they articulated all the more complex. She had derived this strategy from the great black tenor Roland Hayes, despite the objections of an early coach who wished to cultivate a lusty voice out of Italian opera, not a "pianissimo contralto." She stuck to the sound, a legacy of the black church, as was her magical use of blues notes. Because Keiler is far more interested in her performances of lieder than of spirituals, he glosses over her church background, though it was intrinsic to her art.
The granddaughter of a freed slave, Marian Anderson was born in Philadelphia on Feb. 27, 1897. She was first sponsored by her father's church, Union Baptist, a citadel of the Talented Tenth, where spirituals were sung in a cultivated style. (The word itself was pronounced with a rolled "r.") But John Anderson died when Marian was 12, and the great influence on her life was her mother, Anna Delilah, a former schoolteacher and devout member of Tindley Temple Methodist, a congregation that favored brooding hymns and moans. But the church's founder, C. A. Tindley, would become the first important gospel songwriter, one of whose compositions is now known as "We Shall Overcome." In addition, Marian's grandfather Thomas Anderson was a member of the Church of God and Saints of Christ, a storefront sect that combined a black Jewish identity with Pentecostal rituals, foot washing, dancing in the spirit and speaking in tongues. Long before she began her studies of classical song, Marian Anderson was exposed to the immense range of black sacred music, a fountain that never ran dry.
Keiler traces her artistic journey: her youth spent touring a circuit limited to "the self-nurturing world of the black community"; her 20's and 30's in Europe, where her mastery of the lieder tradition was considered miraculous, particularly in Scandinavia and the Soviet Union; her triumphant return to the United States in her late 30's; the impresario Sol Hurok's subsequent direction of her career, which brought great fame and some fortune but so overtaxed her voice that by 1940 Hurok could promise Franz Rupp, her new accompanist, that she had only a few seasons left in her. Throughout, her repertory kept expanding, hundreds of songs in different languages.
Anderson's favorite genres were lieder and spirituals. Rupp was already a star in the first and her willing acolyte in the second. A refugee from Hitler, married to a Jewish woman, the singer Steffanie Schwarz (herself a mistress of lieder and one of Anderson's many coaches), Rupp was a nonpareil accompanist, commanding a rhythmic and harmonic authority that played to all of Anderson's strengths. Together they recorded several masterpieces. In Schubert's "ErlkRated PG-13nig," while Rupp duplicates the galloping horses, Anderson mimics four characters -- the narrator, the anguished father, the frightened child and the fairy king, whose hypnotic, lilting tones culminate in a fierce cackle. Mortality registers another voice in "Death and the Maiden" -- low, resigned and terminally seductive. The marriage of Eros and Thanatos became a Rupp-Anderson specialty.
Her American songs were no less powerful. Since there was a tradition of formalized spirituals, one that long predated the blues and anticipated the harmonic complication of folklore found in jazz, Anderson's folk tunes did not shock concert listeners. Even so, she hoped to avoid "the character of art songs" in her spirituals, "which is not their nature at all." She graced both forms with a similar range of vocal colors, thereby treating anonymous black lyricists as the peers of Goethe and Schiller. For example, on April 11, 1945, she recorded Schumann's "Silent Tears," basking in its sumptuous harmonies. The next day she recorded the spiritual "Hold On," saturating the lyrics with a blues tonality that would do any gospel singer proud.
Anderson's exclusive interest was her art; she did not marry until she was 46, and even then remained closest to her mother and sisters, Ethel and Alyse. Yet she was frequently viewed in political terms, as a representative of her race -- a deadening role for any artist. During the 1930's, she was condemned in Nazi Germany for performing Aryan music and in the Soviet Union for singing about Jesus. (Keiler contends that a nation enslaved by Stalin identified particularly with her songs of liberation.) The book's most powerful pages recount Anderson's legendary performance at the Lincoln Memorial. Keiler shows that the D.A.R was "not at all compelled by local custom" when the organization turned down Howard University's request to present Anderson in concert. Black artists had performed in Constitution Hall up to 1932; indeed, the practice of segregation in Washington was fitful and erratic, as might be expected with so many Northeastern politicians dependent on the black vote. The D.A.R.'s leaders were political reactionaries who detested feminism and integration as twin evils. Since Anderson was not on record as a political activist, they reserved their greatest hatred for her champion Eleanor Roosevelt -- her savior, her defender in a swirl of ugly events that she did not want to think about or even entirely acknowledge."
But the presiding genius of the Lincoln Memorial concert, one of the landmarks in the civil rights struggle, was Walter White, the executive secretary of the N.A.A.C.P. It was White and not Hurok who solicited the endorsement of artists like Toscanini and other luminaries of classical music in an effort to bring the D.A.R. to its senses, and it was White who chose the Lincoln Memorial as the concert site and dreamed up the most resonant details: the concert programs were distributed by Boy Scouts, black and white, and "America" was selected rather than "The Star-Spangled Banner" because of its spirit of communal engagement. As White intended, the concert was immediately regarded as a world event. Like Joe Louis's victory over Max Schmeling the year before, it was seen as the triumph of American democracy, the actual condition of black people notwithstanding.
The year 1939 ensured Anderson's fame and her place in history. It also exposed her to the liabilities of symbolic status. During the 1940's she toured the South, demanding that audiences at her concerts be integrated, though herself subject to all the indignities of segregation. For insisting on her "middle way," she was criticized by white Southerners as overly confrontational and by civil rights leaders as insufficiently engaged. Called upon to discuss politics -- a huge request of someone with a high school degree in home economics -- she chose to speak in a slow, deliberate, grandly impersonal manner (missionary cadences later echoed by Coretta Scott King, Barbara Jordan and Jessye Norman) that could sound windily officious. In 1957, the United States Information Agency sent her to Asia as a musical ambassador, expecting her simply to sing and be charming. But her first concert occurred the day President Dwight D. Eisenhower dispatched troops to protect the pioneering nine black students at Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., and Anderson found herself obliged to explain Arkansas's Gov. Orval Faubus and American race relations to Asian audiences. Only at home would she express her outrage over the "things . . . required of me as a Negro that would not be required of someone else."
ANDERSON was too big a star not to make a ripe target once age and overwork did their inevitable mischief. After 1950, as her vocal lapses -- an unruly vibrato and wavering pitch, the product of age and overwork -- became more pronounced, many critics, most cruelly in Jet and Ebony, called on her to quit. But she could not, largely because she was the sole support of her mother and sisters. Wonderfully, she kept bouncing back, recovering her voice, though usually on the nights the critics stayed home. Her debut in 1955 at the Metropolitan Opera came too late -- she was nearly 58 years old -- but the chance to work as part of an ensemble thrilled her. In 1964, with a young black accompanist, John Mosley, she recorded a new album of spirituals. Her blues tonalities and rhythmic freedom had never been so unbridled; her moans sounded like a recording of field hands. During her last years, until her death at 96, only Mosley's down-home chords could induce her to sing again.
What kind of career would she have today? Those who lament her late arrival in opera forget that the starring roles usually go to voices significantly higher than hers. She appeared too inbred and solitary a figure for the stage, though she always regretted not accepting Stanislavsky's offer to coach her in the role of Carmen. Her repertories are all out of favor: lieder is the province of connoisseurs; both formalized spirituals and folkloric gospel are now period gestures.
Keiler's impressively researched book supplements and supersedes Anderson's 1956 autobiography, a typically guarded affair. He covers the life chronologically, avoiding psychological analyses. The massively discreet Anderson remains opaque. In public, Anderson did not exude much humor; neither does her biographer. There are no startling revelations. But by putting his emphasis on her career, Keiler gives Marian Anderson the homage she deserves. It is a quietly amazing story.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 4-2-00: The Ethicist;
Census and Sensibility

BYLINE: By Randy Cohen 

 BODY:
When I fill out my census form, I am considering declaring myself poor and African-American. This would be a lie because I am middle class and white, but it strikes me as responsive to a higher ethic. Adding one more tally to a group known to be undercounted would help right the inaccurate figures. Should I suppress my socially conscious concerns? -- J. Sommer, New York
You should express your concerns, but not in the way you propose. While the census is seriously -- and, many say, deliberately -- flawed, it is not so utterly discredited as to justify the small civil disobedience you describe. Instead, write to your representatives and demand the use of sampling techniques that would yield a more accurate count, and urge your local officials to make every effort to see that all are tallied. But when the census form arrives, fill it out honestly. 
 Aside from the legal objection to falsifying the form, it is in everyone's interest to make the count as accurate as possible. If your policy were universally adopted, the census would be discredited as little more than fiction, particularly the part about the 35 Guamanians living in my apartment.
My school's parking lot has only 47 spots for 100 driving students. I asked a school administrator where I could park off campus legally. I parked where he told me, but my car was ticketed and towed because the fire chief thought that the many cars on that street caused a fire hazard. Who should pay for the impound and ticket? Who is at fault? -- Joshua Fink, Englewood, N.J.
Bad advice offered in good faith is not bad ethics. If that administrator says it will be sunny tomorrow, you can't sue him if it rains. He is offering an opinion outside the authority of his office. The responsibility to wear a hat is yours.
If you parked in a legal spot, fight the ticket and ask the school official to help. If the spot was not legal, his opinion doesn't change that, so you're stuck. Tell him what happened so he'll know he is misinformed and stop giving bad advice. And who knows: he may offer to pay part of the ticket to compensate for his bad advice.
At a gourmet market where I shop, more than a few customers help themselves to handfuls of nuts and dried fruits without paying. This is clearly unsanitary. I've mentioned it to the cashiers, who say that no one in charge cares enough to stop it. May I say something to these freeloaders or should I ignore the situation and fume inwardly? -- N. Levy, New York
If you catch people actually napping in the pickle barrel, you may jostle them awake and give them a stern talking to. In the cases you describe, however, I think the health risk is minimal. Perhaps what makes you fume is less a matter of hygiene than moral outrage. However, while the behavior you describe sounds like stealing to me, if the owners of the shop know about it and do nothing to stop it, your ethical imperative is lifted. The store may be willing to tolerate this sampling for the good will it engenders, or at least to avoid the hassle. Their store, their choice. My anti-fuming advice is to tell the owners that you intend to shop elsewhere, and why, and then do so.
About a year ago, a friend borrowed $10,000 from another friend of mine. Not only has the borrower not returned the money, he also shows no inclination of ever doing so. By remaining friends with the welsher without so much as a comment, am I condoning his reprehensible behavior? Am I wrong to remain his friend? -- Lawrence Toffler, Los Angeles
If every time two friends quarreled and all their mutual friends had to choose sides, none of us would have many friends left. Fortunately, you are not obliged to cut off all ties to the deadbeat, but you should not ignore his bad behavior.
Use your continued association to remind the defaulting friend of his obligation -- gently, but persistently -- and make it clear that you do not condone his lapse.
Your situation will become more difficult if the injured party demands that you break off with the deadbeat. Then you may have to take a side. But while there are indeed transgressions grave enough to sink a friendship, for now at least this isn't one of them. Still, I wouldn't lend him any money. Or a cup of sugar. Or a cup.
Do you have ethical queries that you need answered? Send them to ethicist@nytimes.com or The Ethicist, The New York Times Magazine, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: For More Artists, A Fine Old Age

BYLINE: By TERRY TEACHOUT; Terry Teachout, the music critic of Commentary, is a contributor to Time magazine.

 BODY:
SPEND a night at the movies, or channel-surfing at home, and you're likely to come away suspecting that Western culture has been hijacked by a horde of hard-bodied twentysomething clones with very good hair and very moderate I.Q.'s. But there are other entertainment options available to New Yorkers jaded by jejuneness, and those who prefer "The Sopranos" to "Jack and Jill" may have noticed that this has been an exceptionally fine season for older artists. Among other things:
*Paul Taylor, 69, made two strikingly personal new dances, "Arabesque" and "Cascade." 
 *Rosemary Harris, 69, and Lauren Bacall, 75, are starring on Broadway in "Waiting in the Wings," a comedy about old age written by Noel Coward when he was 60.
*Bob Brookmeyer, 70, released "New Works: Celebration," a CD of new compositions for jazz orchestra, and celebrated his birthday in December by blowing the roof off the Village Vanguard.
*The New York Festival of Song released a recording of "Evidence of Things Not Seen," a full-evening song cycle for four solo voices and piano by Ned Rorem, 76.
*Merce Cunningham, 80, choreographed "Biped," a dance that makes bold use of computer-generated digital images.
*The Metropolitan Museum of Art mounted a splendid show of paintings by Hans Hofmann, the most vibrant and passionate of which were done when he was 85.
In recent years, I have had occasion to spend much time looking at and listening to the works of older artists, an experience that has caused me to question the tendency of critics and scholars to partition creative lives into three "periods." This practice was inspired by the way the music of Ludwig van Beethoven changed over the course of his life; brusque and dynamic, even aggressive, during his middle age, it turned inward and became profoundly mysterious in the decade before his death. It is now widely thought that most great artists undergo a similar stylistic evolution in the "third periods" of their creative lives. But Beethoven died at 56, and it may be that the concept of the third period is based on assumptions that no longer hold true now that it is commonplace for artists to outlive the Biblical allotment of three score and ten -- long enough to have a fourth period.
While there have always been artists who remained active into their 70's and beyond, they once seemed slightly freakish, if only because there were never all that many Titians or Michelangelos at any given time. But times are changing, and so are actuarial tables. The average American born in 1920 died at 54. Now he will live to 73 or she to 80. This well-known fact is as applicable to artists -- at least those who take reasonable care of themselves -- as anyone else, but its implications have gone unnoticed by the news media. As any journalist can tell you, today's youth-conscious editors want to run stories about the next new thing, not the last old one. Nor are our trend-mad scholars so very different; "The Artist Grows Old," a thoughtful and provocative lecture by Kenneth Clark published in 1972, is the only monograph of its kind that I know.
Mere survival, of course, is no guarantee that an artist will continue to do good work. Advancing age is especially hard on singers and dancers. The tenor Peter Pears made his Metropolitan Opera debut at 63 in Benjamin Britten's "Death in Venice," while the cabaret singer Mabel Mercer, born in 1900, recorded her last album, the grandly expansive "Echoes of My Life," in 1976. But Pears and Mercer never had any youthful bloom to speak of: the beauty of their voices always contained a larger-than-usual proportion of strangeness. And while opera singers willing to renounce the lead roles of their youth can always switch to character parts (many a superannuated diva is grateful to Tchaikovsky for having done so well by the crotchety countess of "The Queen of Spades"), no such opportunities exist in the plotless works of the modern choreographers. In the world of George Balanchine, everyone is 25.
Conversely, much third-period art has been the work of artists who, like Beethoven, would no longer be generally regarded as old. Many of the novels thought to embody the hard-won wisdom of old age were actually written by men and women in their 50's. Remember Lambert Strether's anguished outburst in Henry James's "Ambassadors"? "Live all you can; it's a mistake not to. It doesn't so much matter what you do in particular, so long as you have your life. If you haven't had that what have you had?" It's an unforgettable utterance, the wrenching cry of an onlooker whom life has passed by, and it was written by a man who was 57 -- old by the standards of 1901, but not today.
WHAT we see in "The Ambassadors," or hear in a piece of third-period music like Beethoven's B Flat String Quartet, Op. 130, is the awesome spectacle of a genius learning to live in the shadow of mortality. Memento mori is the motto of the third period, and it is not necessary to be old to remember that you must die. Indeed, I believe that at least some of the qualities Kenneth Clark singled out as typical of what he calls the old-age style -- "a sense of isolation, a feeling of holy rage, developing into . . . transcendental pessimism; a mistrust of reason, a belief in instinct" -- are in fact an artist's initial responses to the fearful prospect of his own death, and thus more characteristic of what we now think of as middle age.
It is worth noting that a like development can also be seen in young artists who know their time is short. Flannery O'Connor's short stories "Judgment Day" and "Parker's Back," finished days before she died of lupus at the age of 39, are no less wise for having been written by a far younger person than James. I watched my friend, the cabaret singer Nancy LaMott, record her last album, "Listen to My Heart," not long after she learned she had the cancer that would shortly kill her; though she was only 43, she sang of love and loss as if she knew all there was to know about them both. Perhaps she did.
When we speak of the "wisdom" of a work of art, we are talking about a quality accessible only to artists who strive to understand and accept things as they are. One of these things is old age itself. We squirm at the spectacle of an octogenarian father, or a senescent rock star; for much the same reason, it is sobering to reflect on what will happen to the famously self-indulgent baby boomers (of whom I am one) as they grow older. I don't like to think about Bill Clinton at 70, or Mick Jagger at 80. I also wonder whether rock will prove musically and lyrically rich enough to hold the attention of my increasingly anxious generation, though I was pleased to see that "Two Against Nature," the new Steely Dan album, contains a fine song, "What a Shame About Me," in which Walter Becker, 50, and Donald Fagen, 52, cast a cold eye on a once-promising boomer whose life has gone sour: "I'm still working on that novel/ But I'm just about to quit/ 'Cause I'm worrying about the future now/ Or maybe this is it."
Listening to "What a Shame About Me" put me in mind of the dismayingly large number of long-lived artists whose careers go off the rails well before their actual demise. Their work often fractures along existing fault lines of temperament: one thinks of the deliquescence of Renoir's late nudes, the ugly obsessions of Alfred Hitchcock's "Frenzy," the morbid fear of death that poisons Philip Larkin's "Aubade" ("Unresting death, a whole day nearer now,/ Making all thought impossible but how/ And where and when I shall myself die"). They may suffer an enervating loss of energy, as Patrick O'Brian did in the last few of his Aubrey-Maturin novels; they may become foolishly garrulous, like George Bernard Shaw, or dry up, like Aaron Copland. Most often, like Martha Graham, they simply start to repeat themselves, replacing substance with too-familiar style.
Yet once in a while the miracle happens; an artist not only survives middle age, but also remains creatively vital. "Father Time is not always a hard parent," Charles Dickens wrote in "Barnaby Rudge," "and, though he tarries for none of his children, often lays his hand lightly on those who have used him well." To see such folk in the flesh is to be delighted and puzzled in equal measure. I heard the alto saxophonist Benny Carter at Iridium four years ago; he was then 89, but he played like a man of 60, and I could scarcely believe my ears.
Such apparent freedom from the devastation of old age seems to come less easily to those artists who work with words. "To write tolerably over the age of 65 is exceptional," Kenneth Clark rightly notes. That is when painters and orchestral conductors are just getting their second wind. As the 76-year-old Anthony Powell embarked on his 19th novel, "The Fisher King," he ruminated in his journal on the special problems facing the older novelist: "The sluggish imagination of old age makes giving of reality to characters difficult. The story must be seen from the point of view of a writer's own age group, later life being on the whole thin in action of the kind to give point to novels."
This makes sense, and it helps explain why most of the masterpieces of old age have been nonverbal. The best fourth-period art floats free of action and character. Instead, it is about essences, which are notoriously difficult to convey in words, though the Japanese painter Hokusai came close. "All that I have produced before the age of 70," he wrote at 75, "is not worth taking into account. At 73, I learned a little about the real structure of nature, of animals, plants, trees, birds, fishes and insects. In consequence, when I am 80, I shall have made still more progress. At 90, I shall penetrate the mystery of things; at 100, I shall certainly have reached a marvelous stage; and when I am 110, everything I do, be it a dot or a line, will be alive."
What fourth-period art is not about, at least not usually, is death. "Is this, perhaps, death?" sings the soprano in Richard Strauss's "Four Last Songs," to which the orchestra obligingly replies with a quotation from the 84-year-old composer's own "Death and Transfiguration." But such rhetorical gestures are relatively uncommon among artists who have come to terms with their own mortality -- a process that takes both time and unflinching courage. Their interests lie elsewhere, and their art changes accordingly. This is what drives the fourth periods of the greatest older artists: having accepted the inevitable, they are no longer weighed down by it. Hence the surging, staggering vitality of such fourth-period masterpieces as Paul Taylor's "Piazzolla Caldera" or Hans Hofmann's "Lust and Delight," which burn with a passion that is not merely recalled, but actively felt.
Not infrequently, a fourth-period work may epitomize the whole of a long creative life, though there is always something new on display as well. One of my favorite jazz albums is the pianist Marian McPartland's "Silent Pool," which she recorded at 78. It consists of 12 of her own compositions, accompanied by a string orchestra; some are familiar, but Alan Broadbent's arrangements shed unexpected light on their harmonic refinements, and Ms. McPartland responds with spring-fresh playing in which past and present are deftly juxtaposed. The 68-year-old Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater, after the Guggenheim Museum the most celebrated of his buildings, has the same Janus-faced quality. No other architect could have designed it: all his stylistic quirks are on gloriously idiosyncratic display. But the total impression they leave is not valedictory. Instead, like "Silent Pool" or "Piazzolla Caldera," Fallingwater looks straight ahead into the future.
As I settle uneasily into my own middle age, three fourth-period works speak to me with particularly invigorating force. The first, Igor Stravinsky's ballet score "Agon," is a work I hear often (George Balanchine choreographed it in 1957, and the New York City Ballet dances it frequently), invariably marveling at how the 75-year-old composer sought and found stylistic renewal by bending the bristly complexities of Arnold Schoenberg's serial method to his own iron purpose. I have no use for most 12-tone music, but there is something superbly cheeky about Stravinsky's having placed a serial pas de deux at the epicenter of a piece that ends in good old-fashioned C major.
The second, Giuseppe Verdi's "Falstaff," is the most miraculous fruit of extreme old age that any Western artist has yet harvested. I have never seen it without crying, not because it is sad -- I can't think of a more joyous opera -- but because I find it inexpressibly moving that the 79-year-old Verdi should have found within himself the energy and grace to simultaneously portray the vanity of human wishes and what Alexander Herzen so beautifully called "the summer lightning of happy love."
"Falstaff" is a marvel of economy: one wouldn't wish it a bar shorter. But just as marvelously spare is the fourth-period masterpiece I love best, "The Snail." The 83-year-old Henri Matisse made it in 1953, at a time when illness had left him capable only of cutting out and pasting together pieces of colored paper, like a child in kindergarten. That the finest painter of the 20th century should have been reduced to such an extremity is the most terrible of ironies, but Matisse did not waste precious time pitying himself. Instead, he arranged his pieces of paper into a festive exercise in visual shorthand so concentrated and clear that it all but scorches the viewer's eye.
Hokusai, who called himself "the old man mad about drawing," would have understood "The Snail" perfectly. Like all fourth-period art, it penetrates the mystery of things, and in so doing celebrates the ultimate mystery of human life itself. Old men mad about art can give us no greater gift.

HEADLINE: Long Island Journal;
When Medicine's Loss Is the Law's Gain

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER

 BODY:
OTHER fathers taught their sons how to throw curveballs. Leonard Rivkin's taught him to read X-rays. And Mr. Rivkin knew what an articular fracture was before he could roller skate.
Mr. Rivkin's father, Hyman Rivkin, was a physician in Far Rockaway. He believed medicine was more than just a noble profession. It was the only profession. "I ended up becoming a lawyer through pre-med," Mr. Rivkin, 75, said recently. "Fathers who are doctors want their sons to be doctors. I was in pre-med until I decided I didn't like it. I couldn't stand chemistry." 
 Mr. Rivkin didn't particularly have a burning passion for legal matters, either. But he did like the way the law-school building looked at his alma mater, the University of Virginia. And he needed a profession. So he enrolled in law school.
The rest, as they say, is history. Fifty years ago, Mr. Rivkin, the founder of Rivkin, Radler & Kremer, Long Island's largest law firm, opened a solo practice in the back room of an insurance agency in Freeport. Clients visiting the agency had to walk through his office to get to the restroom. It seemed like the perfect marketing strategy.
But during his first three months, Mr. Rivkin earned more as a notary than he did as a lawyer, charging 25 cents a document, enough to cover lunch. He did his own typing. Occasionally, he spent afternoons at the local movie theater.
At first, whatever cases came his way -- wills, closings, accident cases -- were from neighbors, friends and relatives.
But in 1950, there were not many high-profile trial lawyers on Long Island. Few, if any, wanted to take on accident cases for injured plaintiffs. Most law offices belonged to solo practitioners or small firms. And many local lawyers brought in trial lawyers from Manhattan or Brooklyn if they had a case to be tried.
Mr. Rivkin approached the South Nassau Lawyers' Association, a social group of young lawyers (now the Nassau Lawyers' Association of Long Island) and let it be known he was available for "of counsel" work, cases that lawyers give to other lawyers to handle. His strategy worked.
Before long, Mr. Rivkin was so busy he had to hire a typist. He took on one partner, then two. In the 1980's, the practice grew to 250 lawyers. Though the number of lawyers has dropped to 140, the Uniondale firm is believed to be the largest suburban law practice in the nation. It has additional offices in California, Newark and Chicago, but not in Florida, where Mr. Rivkin, an avid fishing and boating enthusiast, retired 10 years ago. He remains an honorary counsel to the firm and spends summers in Dix Hills with his son, John Rivkin, 46, a senior partner.
It was by defending corporations accused of environmental damage and pollution that Mr. Rivkin made his practice a legal powerhouse. He was the lead counsel for the Dow Chemical Company in the Agent Orange case brought by Vietnam veterans. He defended asbestos companies and their insurers against health claims and represented numerous corporations sued for toxic-waste damage.
Mr. Rivkin's experiences growing up as a lawyer on Long Island are chronicled in a book, "May it Please the Court! From Auto Accident to Agent Orange: Building a Storefront Law Practice into America's Largest Suburban Law Firm."
It was Jeffrey Silberfeld, 52, of Point Lookout, a former partner at Rivkin, Radler & Kremer and a visiting professor at Hofstra law school, who told Mr. Rivkin over lunch at the Hofstra University Club four years ago that he should tell his story. Mr. Rivkin agreed. Then he asked Mr. Silberfeld to write it. The book is to be published this week.
A John Grisham novel? No. More like "A Civil Action," Mr. Silberfeld said. But Mr. Rivkin hopes his success story will be used as a how-to manual and resource guide by law schools around the country, the saga of a rainmaker who used his suburban shop to his advantage in the courtroom.
"In litigation, one of the benefits in coming from a provincial Long Island neighborhood is in when you try the big-name case, they don't expect much of you," Mr. Rivkin said. "You can get away with a lot more and you can surprise a lot of people. I used it to my benefit."
The high point of Mr. Rivkin's career, he said, was Agent Orange.
The strategy was classic Rivkin. "Our premise in litigation was take the initiative," he said. "Even though we were a defendant in most cases, we always found a way to make the other side march to our tune, not march to theirs, even if they were suing us. To deflect the anti-Dow sentiment, the firm labeled identifed the federal government as the bad guy and started a third-party action. I always have felt it was so much more fun being a counterpuncher."
By the 1980's, the firm had moved from Freeport to Garden City and, in 1986, occupied three floors in the EAB Plaza. With national stature, it had garnered the cachet of a Park Avenue firm without the commute.
"Our firm wasn't built up from young lawyers out of law school," Mr. Rivkin said. "We picked up a number of lawyers who lived on Long Island who wanted to work on Long Island."
These days, Jerry Kremer, a senior partner and former assemblyman, does a reverse commute from Manhattan. Other partners include John Dunne, a former New York State senator and assistant United States attorney general for civil rights; William Savino, the mayor of Old Brookville; Erica Garay, president of the Long Island Women's Agenda; and Barry Shapiro, president of Channel 21. The firm is now full service.
In the past 50 years, Mr. Rivkin said, the practice of law has changed. But as a sole practitioner and as a senior partner, he always had fun. "Each case has a challenge unto itself, from the smallest to the biggest," Mr. Rivkin said.
 
50 Top Women
"Women are different," Faith Popcorn, the futurist, was telling the crowd of 600 that gathered in the ballroom at the Garden City Hotel on Tuesday night. "They can do two things at the same time. They can do five things at the same time."
The women being honored at the inaugural Long Island's 50 Top Women awards dinner probably can do more than that.
Like Yvonne Pena, who founded the Latina Women's Society for Social Change a year and a half ago. The group, the first Latina professional organization in Suffolk County, she said, is dedicated to eradicating myths about Hispanic women. , Ms. Pena is Suffolk County Human Rights Commissioner. She also produces the only Spanish-language public access program in Suffolk County, "Un Mensaje a La Comunidad."
And Dorothy Tripp, 77, mother of seven, grandmother of seven and great-grandmother of one. As the director of tourism for the town of Hempstead, she helps bring meetings and conventions to town, promoting 31 museums, 19 hotels, the Nassau Coliseum, the most famous beaches on Long Island and the Belmont Stakes Festival. "I'm very active in a lot of organizations," said Ms. Tripp, listing just a few. She is a co-founder of the Women Economic Developers of Long Island, just finished a term with the Long Island Convention and Visitor's Bureau and serves on the boards of the Long Island Center for Business and Professional Women and the Long Island Regional Economic Development Committee.
Picking the 50 women making the greatest impact on the Long Island economy was not an easy task, said John Kominicki, editor and publisher of the weekly Long Island Business News, which asked its readers and those of more than 100 community newspapers to send in nominations. A panel of business and government leaders selected the winners.
As it turned out, most of the women already knew each other. "We all do business with each other; some of us have been friends for years," said Marie Zere, president of the only female-owned commercial and industrial real estate company on Long Island, Zere Associates of Ronkonkoma. "If someone came to me and asked me, I would have picked out 25 women in this room, 25 absolutes who have been known to contribute to the community."
Looking around the room, Sharon Lobel was impressed. "It's nice for people to see there is a driving force of female business owners on Long Island," she said. Ms. Lobel is president of Seal-It, a manufacturer of tamper-evident packaging. "But I've always thought of myself as a business owner who happens to be a woman, not a woman business owner."
Roslyn Goldmacher, another honoree and executive director of the Long Island Development Corporation, said the approximately 35,000 female-owned businesses on Long Island, including some of the largest grossing companies, play a very significant role in the local economy.
"The presence of influential women is increasing all the time," said Christine Conniff Sheehan, honoree and founder of Networking, a magazine geared toward business women. "This is a market of very important people who must be paid attention to. Times are changing. Women know it. Men aren't quite sure."

HEADLINE: Theater;
Despair and Catharsis In O'Neill's Final PLay

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IF you ain't the damnedest daughter in Connecticut, who is?"
"And if you ain't the damnedest father in Connecticut, who is?" 
 Although the battle of insults between a commonly besotted pig farmer and his daughter, a self-described "ugly overgrown lump of a woman" gets worse, it's a mere prelude to a ruse. Phil and Josie Hogan are bent on snaring James Tyrone Jr., their deeply besotted landlord, to spend the night with Josie under a "beautiful moon to fill him with poetry and loneliness."
Few theatergoers need to be told that James was Eugene O'Neill's older brother, or that "A Moon for the Misbegotten," is the playwright's act of expiation, written 20 years after James died. "May you rest forever in forgiveness and peace" is the play's merciful last line, spoken by Josie to James after he has gone off in defensiveness and despair.
And no one needs to identify with O'Neill's lusty, scheming, drug or drink-ridden characters who survive on pipe dreams. After O'Neill's reach for tragedy, power and glory, and an audience's sense of what catharsis and exaltation must have meant in ancient Greek drama, it's no wonder that most other plays seem small. If his stage creations -- the biographical, disguised; the mythical updated, or the fictitious and the wish fulfilling made real -- are larger than life, that is because his vision of theater was, to borrow one of his own titles, beyond the horizon. Leave it to Tennessee Williams, peerless heir to O'Neill's touch of poetry and journey into experimentation, to sum up an eternal force: "O'Neill gave birth to the American theater and died for it," Williams said.
That O'Neill was born in New York in 1888 is a mere statistic; Connecticut has a rightful claim to the last century's mightiest American playwright. He worked as a newspaper reporter in New London at 24 and went on writing plays until his death 41 years later. "Moon" was his last.
The family cottage in New London is a destination for tourists and the O'Neill Center in Waterford is a historic summer nurturing place for new plays, new musicals and cabaret performers. In Connecticut's major theaters, "Moon," a once forgotten, then misjudged work, was last produced in 1989 (Hartford Stage) and in 1991 (Yale Repertory).
The current Broadway success of "Moon" and the lingering high of last season's "Iceman Cometh," is a most reaffirming paradox. "Public Says No, No O'Neill Again," read the headline of a 1988 article in Variety after the abrupt closing of two Broadway imports from the Yale Repertory, "Ah, Wilderness" and "Long Day's Journey into Night," the first lighthearted play about the family of his fantasies; the second, about his real tormented one.
"The evidence is thus conclusive that the work of the playwright usually ranked as America's greatest is unable to prosper or even survive in the harsh Broadway economic climate," Variety's report went on.
In a harsher Broadway climate more than a decade later, O'Neill thrives. A Broadway production of "Desire Under the Elms" is scheduled for October at the Roundabout Theater, which successfully revived "Anna Christie" in 1992. "Ah, Wilderness" was welcomed in a 1998 Lincoln Center production.
More than the exports for which the state's theaters are known, the O'Neill renaissance is Connecticut's ultimate lifeline to Broadway.
As for the customary feeding of New York theater by Connecticut, it has not been as nourishing of late as the transfer of "Wit" from the Long Wharf in New Haven to Off -Broadway, where it is to close next Sunday. "The Clearing" and "Sueno," both from Hartford Stage, and "Red" from Long Wharf, moved to Off Broadway to no avail. But three of Connecticut's important resident playwrights -- A. R. Gurney, Donald Margulies and Arthur Miller -- have effectively kept theater on and off Broadway alive this season. Indeed, Mr. Margulies' "Dinner with Friends," a perceptive and unsettling view of marriage and friendship, perhaps even ostensibly sedate suburban life, may emerge as the season's finest Off Broadway play; it had a tryout run at Rich Forum of the Stamford Center for the Arts in October and has been a hit at Variety Arts Theater in Manhattan.
Mr. Gurney's "Ancestral Voices," a sort of "Love Letters" reading/hybrid play, expanded to five characters, spanning three generations, has been seen two nights a week at Lincoln Center, with stellar casts in intermittent runs.
As for Mr. Miller, "The Price," moved from Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts to Broadway in a fiercely excellent production, by consensus, its best yet.
It was not a Broadway survivor this season, but "The Ride Down Mt. Morgan" is to open, finally, on Broadway next Sunday. When Mr. Miller was out of fashion, that play had to travel for a 1991 world premiere in London, which is always true to Miller in his own fashion. Williamstown produced it in 1996, and the New York Shakespeare Festival in 1998. Both are nonprofit counterparts to regional theater.
Is Miller in or out of the loop? As with O'Neill, it's the fickle commercial theater that decides. Connecticut's regional theaters are conceived to serve and perpetuate the cause of art for real theater lovers, not to indulge and second-guess the faddish tastes of consumers.
A move of another sort, "The Wild Party," at Manhattan Theater Club, one of two versions this season of the same 1928 narrative poem, had its genesis in 1997, at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford.

HEADLINE: 100 Years of the Submarine;
With Most of That Time in Groton, the Ships Have Become an Integral Part of the State

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THE centennial of the Navy submarine force will be marked with observances around the country this month, but few places will be celebrating it more than southeastern Connecticut. In Groton, a large blue plywood cutout of a submarine welcomes visitors to the "Submarine Capital of the World," and few places can dispute that title.
The submarine force got its foothold in Groton in December 1915, when five submarines steamed up the Thames River to their new home at a Navy base in Groton. Through two world wars and one Cold War that saw their importance to national security grow steadily, until today when the base has sprawled over 500 acres, submarines have been an integral part of the region, adding an estimated $1 billion a year to the regional economy, employing thousands of people. 
 Groton's town manager, Ronald P. LeBlanc, said the civilian community appreciated the presence of the submarine force and took pride in it, as well as the workers who build submarines at Electric Boat.
"It's more than the economic impact of the base," Mr. LeBlanc said. "The town's image is wrapped around submarines -- submarine construction and submarine operations. Without submarines, we would lose a big part of the town's identity. They're as much a part of us as we are a home port to the submarine service."
Representative Sam Gejdenson, whose congressional district includes Groton, said it would be impossible to quantify a century of Navy influence on the region, "but certainly it has to be in the hundreds of billions of dollars, particularly when you consider all the indirect impacts."
The influence is always spreading, Mr. Gejdenson said. Recently, he met someone who is marketing fishing poles made of material developed for the Trident submarine. Sonalysts Inc. in Waterford, which started doing work on sonar, now makes movies and music in its recording studio that grew out of its work in acoustics. The Kildare Corporation in New London used what it learned about sound propagation underwater to develop a system to detect dangerous turbulence around airports, a system that is being tested by the Federal Aviation Administration.
"There's an endless part of our economy that really germinated as a result of the dollars that came in from the Defense Department," Mr. Gejdenson said. "Our dominance in marine science and oceanography and a lot of other areas came as a direct result of the technology that the Pentagon invested in to build the best submarines in the world.
"When the woolen mills died in the middle part of the last century, it left behind people who were tied to the technology of the last century," he said. "Submarine technology has provided the seeds for this region's future."
Mr. Gejdenson said that without submarines, southeastern Connecticut would be much more heavily dependent on fishing or farming.
"I think we still have some tremendous assets. We have a great place to live. But there are other places along the water that are in desperate straits, economically," Mr. Gejdenson said.
"Submarines provided an infusion of training and technology that we never could have gotten any other way."
Throughout most of this century, almost everyone in and around Groton had some connection to the Navy, either through the base or the Electric Boat shipyard down the Thames River, where submarines are built.
"If you grew up in the area and you weren't going to college, you either went into the Navy or you went to work at Electric Boat," said Melvin E. Olsson, president of the Marine Draftsmen Association, one of the two large unions at the shipyard. His grandfather was on the crew that tested new construction submarines after World War II, and he recalls waiting on the dock with his grandmother for the boats to return. His father was a rigger, and Mr. Olsson started there in 1960 as an apprentice pipe fitter.
"It was always the best paying job you could get, and the opportunity to get a good, skilled trade, especially for someone who wasn't planning on college," Mr. Olsson said. "Most of your neighbors worked there, your parents probably worked there, it was the center of the community. Electric Boat reached into every neighborhood. Almost everyone in the area has, one way or another, been touched by Electric Boat."
Mr. Olsson said the nature of business has always been cyclical, and it has gotten a bit of a black eye in the last five years or so because as the Navy has ordered fewer submarines after the end of the Cold War, employment has plummeted almost two-thirds, from more than 25,000 to about 9,000.
"But many, many people around Connecticut, and even into Rhode Island and Massachusetts, have made a good living over the years from Electric Boat," Mr. Olsson said.
Electric Boat, which celebrated its own centennial last year, still has one of the largest payrolls in the state, $360 million last year. And the company has a reputation for innovation, a trait that has seen it through some downturns in the past. In the 1930's, when it was reporting $1 million a year in losses, the shipyard agreed to experiment with a welded-hull submarine, versus the riveted boats used in World War I. That work kept it in business until World War II, when it was churning out a new submarine every two weeks for a time.
After the war came another slump, which ended when the yard agreed to build the world's first nuclear-powered submarine, the U.S.S. Nautilus, and a few years later the first submarine that could fire missiles while submerged.
Today, the shipyard is working on the next-generation Virginia-class of submarine, which company officials said will help create a revolution in undersea warfare. In addition, it is involved with two teams chartered by the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to look at completely new roles and capabilities for submarines, such as national missile defense.'
"Where will we be in another 100 years? It depends on whether the U.S. Navy continues to need submarines," said John K. Welch, president of the Marine Group of General Dynamics, the parent company of Electric Boat. "I would guess that with two-thirds of the world covered by water, submarines will continue to play a very vital role throughout the next century."
But the Navy's impact also goes beyond building and operating submarines, even beyond economic issues, local leaders said. Janet D. Pearce, executive director of the United Way of Southeastern Connecticut, said enlisted people and officers are some of the core volunteers for Little League, Boy and Girl Scouts, churches and social service organizations, whether hammering nails for a women's shelter or serving on the board of directors of a local agency.
In fact, Construction Battalion Unit 414 built the conference room at the United Way.
"They've done a lot of work on projects over the years that really put their skills to good use, things that could not have been done without the Navy," Mrs. Pearce said.
Cynthia H. Clegg, president of the Southeastern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce, said the business community is working to establish stronger ties with the military through such efforts as its "Service Person of the Month" and "Service Person of the Year" awards ceremonies, and a "Military Appreciation Month," when members of the military are offered discounts.
"Locally, businesses are very aware of the benefits of having the military here -- they shop in our stores, buy their cars at local dealers -- and they are working hard to nurture that business relationship with the military, and the client relationship with people in the service," Ms. Clegg said. "That awareness is always increasing."
Despite that the attack submarine fleet has been cut by almost half nationwide, from 104 to 57, the Naval Submarine Base in Groton is still the home port of more than 20 submarines, only a few less than its Cold War peak, making it the most active submarine port in the United States. Because those submarines are more sophisticated than in the past, the work force has been fairly steady, with about 10,000 civilian and military employees. And with dozens of construction projects under way, from new piers to a new community center, it is likely to remain that way.
"I'd say, compared to the turmoil we saw during the base closure process in the 1990's, the future looks pretty good for submarines staying in southeastern Connecticut," said John C. Markowicz, executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Enterprise Region, a business development group, and co-chairman of a group that helped save the base from three rounds of closures.
"In any round of base closing, the chief criterion is military value -- it all comes down to, what can you do for the fleet today?" Mr. Markowicz said. "The construction of the controlled industrial facility to handle nuclear waste, and the new barracks, and other new buildings around the base, just means they can do that much more for the fleet, which increases its vibrancy."
There is considerable debate about what date represents the true "birthday" of the submarine force. Some say it was April 11, 1900, when the Navy purchased the Holland VI from Electric Boat and its inventor, John P. Holland. Others contend it should be Oct. 12, 1900, when the Navy put the submarine into commission as the Holland, or SS-1.
Today every Navy submariner has to come to Groton at some point, because of the presence of the Naval Submarine School on the base. Enlisted people and officers all come for basic submarine school before they join the fleet, and for advanced training as they rise in rank.
The region is also the home of the Historic Ship Nautilus, which has been opened to tours since 1986 and hosts some 300,000 visitors a year. The Submarine Force Library and Museum is putting the finishing touches on a $4 million expansion that will almost double its space, with a grand opening slated for April 28.
To celebrate the submarine's centennial, the U.S. Submarine Veterans will host a Memorial Service next Sunday at the National Submarine Memorial East off Bridge Street in Groton. The combined officer and enlisted person Submarine Birthday Ball will be April 28 at Foxwoods Resort Casino, just north of the base. That same day, the Submarine Force Library and Museum in Groton will formally unveil an expansion that will for the first time focus on the Cold War missions of submarines. The Postal Service last Monday also issued a series of five postage stamps during day-of-issue ceremonies at the Dealey Center auditorium at the base, with more than two dozen clerks busily canceling stamps and covers for collectors.
Rear Adm. John B. Padgett III, who is the commander of the Navy's Northeast Region and whose headquarters are in Groton, grew up in the area, graduating from Norwich Free Academy before heading off to the Naval Academy. He returned to Groton two years ago as commander of the Navy's Northeast Region.
"My father was a submariner, and I watched the first ballistic missile submarines make their patrols out of Groton," Admiral Padgett said. "Now, to be back here at a time when we're honoring the first 100 years really is a source of great personal pride."

HEADLINE: Skilled Masons Are in Short Supply

BYLINE: By THOMAS STAUDTER 

 BODY:
ON a bright, breezy March morning, Michael Gualtiere, proprietor of Mike's Masonry, was laying concrete floors with his four-member crew at the New Chalet on the Lake, a condominium development in Mohegan Lake. Less than a mile away, in Shrub Oak, three Ecuadorean brothers and a cousin were fitting together a stone wall along East Main Street.
Warmer weather has awakened the sizable corps of masons in Westchester County from hibernation, and the craftsmen are again hard at work, turning stone, brick and concrete into walls, foundations, walkways and more. The age-old profession is changing, however, as each new season finds fewer and fewer true master masons plying their trade. 
 Booms in the construction and home improvement fields have put a premium on masonry work, even though many builders lament that many of those who call themselves masons are not as skilled as their predecessors, who were mostly Italian and Irish immigrants or their descendants.
"It's much harder these days to find a mason, especially a good one," said Robert G. Chamberlain, a landscape architect who has done extensive work in Westchester. "They're in high demand right now with the warm weather returning."
Young Americans, it seems, are not inclined to enter the field because of its grueling nature, and even with an influx of skilled masons from Central and South America, the demand exceeds the supply.
"I've always had a lot of work and a good clientele, but the last three years it's been super busy," Mr. Gualtiere, a 37-year-old Yorktown resident, said.
While munching on a hard-boiled egg, Mr. Gualtiere directed a concrete-mixing truck toward the foundation he was working on. After the mixer poured out its contents, Mr. Gualtiere, along with another mason, Michael Ryan, and three laborers waded into the half-foot deep expanse of fresh concrete and raked it out.
Then, using a screed, which is like a long, hollow two-by-four, Mr. Gualtiere and Mr. Ryan leveled and smoothed out the concrete, deftly working around dozens of pipes for the plumbing and electrical and heating systems of the building.
Mr. Gualtiere, who said he has been in the masonry business for 18 years, started out as a carpenter but realized "I liked working outside every day better," he said.
He and Mr. Ryan started out as laborers, completed apprenticeship programs and became members of Local 5 of the Bricklayers and Allied Craft Workers' Union. They left to work as independents in the late-80's when the economy slumped. "If you didn't have enough seniority, you didn't get the phone calls," Mr. Gualtiere said. "The union wasn't going to leave the old-timers at home -- and why should they have? We were just kids supporting our cars and drinking habits."
After smoothing out the floor, Mr. Gualtiere used a magnesium bull float, a rectangular metal mat attached to a long handle, to force out the bubbles in the hardening concrete.
"This is hard work," Mr. Gualtiere said, as he pushed and pulled the bull float across the floor. "There's no new generation of American kids who want to do this. They just want to wear baggy pants and play on computers. The Spanish guys really work hard and come to the job ready to go. They're your next generation of masons."
The construction boom has led to an increase in the number of masons in the Hudson Valley, said Rod Fortran, a labor market analyst with the State Department of Labor in Albany. His office projects that the number of masons in the region will rise to 2,400, from 1,800, between 1997 and 2007. But he said those numbers do not distinguish between union members, "master" masons and unskilled workers who simply build stone walls.
The reluctance of young Americans to enter the masonry field is readily apparent in the apprenticeship and training programs here in the county, where the class sizes have been shrinking for 15 years, said Erik Cantamessa, a third-generation mason who teaches at the Northern Westchester and Putnam Board of Cooperative Educational Services in Yorktown. "Right now I have the union and dozens of contractors knocking on my door looking for masons, but I don't have enough people to fill all the slots for the amount of jobs coming through."
The agency's masonry apprenticeship program attracts from 10 to 15 new high school students each year, although many students do not complete the two-year course.
"Moms and dads are giving their kids everything they want these days, and as a result the kids are not so eager to go to work," said Mr. Cantamessa, 37, of Mahopac, who is also a former instructor for the Bricklayers and Allied Craft Workers' Union.
He said the students who join the union "are making more money in two or three years on the job than I am now." The base salary, he said, begins at $10 an hour and climbs rapidly to $25 an hour, with benefits on union jobs totaling an additional $17 an hour.
The work is, indeed, arduous. Masons may profess to enjoy working outdoors, but that does not ease the burden of lugging 100-pound bags of concrete to a job site or unloading a truckful of concrete blocks on a hot, muggy day.
Whether the work is physically too hard or the pay too modest compared with office jobs, the fact is that fewer sons are following their fathers into masonry.
(No one interviewed for this article knew or had ever heard of any women working as masons. All the young women who started the apprenticeship program at the cooperative-education board eventually dropped out, Mr. Cantamessa said.)
"Working with my father gave me a certain level of pride," said David Anderson, the 33-year-old owner of Robert D. Anderson Company of New Rochelle, a business specializing in masonry restoration, which he bought from his father 10 years ago. "I started out at 13 mixing cement and loading bricks for him."
In his experience, Mr. Anderson said, "The younger workers in the field are more obsessed with the pay, and also they see jobs as temporary stopping points before they move on, as opposed to a career they'll stick with for decades."
Nearly all the brick work in the county today is done by union workers on publicly financed projects like government buildings and schools. In many buildings, brick work is being replaced by prefabricated materials that look like brick but come in sheets, and the brick-laying aspect of masonry is fast becoming a dying art.
Frank Capocci, a 55-year-old Port Chester resident and foreman at Robert D. Anderson Company, is representative of the vanishing breed of bricklaying masons. Born in Frosinone, Italy, Mr. Capocci came to the United States at age 17 and started attending the apprenticeship program run by Local 5 of the Bricklayers and Allied Craft Workers' Union.
"I went two nights a week to the union's apprentice school in White Plains," Mr. Capocci recalled, "and I had a terrific teacher, Mr. Palmer, who taught me how to lay bricks, lay steps out, make fireplaces and chimneys and also how to read a blueprint."
Mr. Capocci, a union member for 32 years, said that he does not mind teaching the trade to younger workers, but he added that many of the old-timers in the masonry field do not like to share their knowledge to perceived competitors or to those outside their immediate families.
"It's the same as when I was young, coming up the hard way," Mr. Capocci said. "But with less of the younger generation coming into the field, a lot of the older fellows will be taking what they know into retirement."
At Home Mason Supply Corporation, a family-run business in Peekskill, Keith Bobolia, one of its owners, said: "I've been here 22 years, and during that time the customers have certainly changed. When I came on board there were still a lot of Italians, first- and second-generation Italian-Americans, Irish-Americans from the trade unions and German contractors.
"Today, I'd say 90 percent of our customers are Spanish-speaking Latin and South Americans. I watched a lot of them work their way up after starting as laborers for other masons."
The emphasis at Home Mason Supply, as a result, has shifted toward stone work, Mr. Bobolia said. "The Spanish guys are, for the most part, excellent at building stone walls, patios, any kind of dry work involving stacked stones. You couldn't ask them to build a chimney, though; they wouldn't know how to lay it out."
Over time, he said, his customer base has shifted toward landscapers and away from builders, a trend that is evident in how material is stored in the supply yard: fieldstones and interlocking blocks are up front while bricks are way in the back.
Over in Shrub Oak, a 29-year-old mason from Ecuador who has been in this country illegally since 1991, said, "I knew when I came here that I would have to find a job in construction because I only finished grammar school in my country."
Starting out as a laborer, he eventually learned enough to work as a mason for a general contractor, making around $400 cash weekly.
"I think many American people don't want to get into this business because it's too hard," he said while shaping fieldstone with a mallet. "When I drive around with my boss and see the places where I've worked, I feel proud."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Converting for Dollars: A Co-op Becomes a Condo

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
THE 17-story Stratford House on Overlook Avenue in Hackensack seems no different than it did just 13 months ago, but the 133-unit building has since undergone a transformation from a co-op to a condominium, enhancing its value.
"We wanted to create interest so we could market the units and raise their values as well as increase the level of owner occupancy in the building," said Steven Muhlstock, president of the Stratford House Condominium Association and a 20-year resident. 
 A sales campaign will begin tomorrow at the building, where 119 resident owners converted their units since it became a condo three weeks ago. The conversion allows the remaining 14 owners to make the switch over the next two years.
The Stratford House is one of a small group of co-ops in New Jersey and the nation that have become condominiums in recent years. It is distinct, however, because it was a relatively financially healthy co-op -- unlike most co-ops that have tried the switch -- and as such its progress will be watched closely, industry professionals said. Residential Ownership Alternatives Hutton, a real estate consulting firm based in Iselin, organized the conversion plan.
The 31-year-old building, which contains one- to three-bedroom units plus penthouses, was converted to a co-op in 1980 and most of the units were sold before the real estate market fizzled in 1987. But since then, many owners have been unable to sell their units at the prices they paid. So they rented them instead, leaving the building with a 40 percent owner-occupancy rate.
As recently as eight months ago, units at the Stratford House sold in the mid-$30,000 to the mid-$70,000 range, said Marc Greenberg, executive vice president of the Pellogreen Group of Fort Lee, which manages the building.
Co-op purchasers buy stock in the co-op corporation, which entitles them to a proprietary lease to occupy their apartments. Through the board of directors they elect and the bylaws they adopt, owners control how their building is run, . including accepting or rejecting buyers.
Condo buyers purchase their apartments and an interest in the building's common areas, and can sell or rent their units without the approval of a co-op board. Because of these features, residential brokers said, condos sell for 20 percent more on average than similar co-ops.
At the Stratford House, "the conversion gives unit owners who paid high prices the opportunity to minimize their losses or recoup their investment, and those who paid low prices the chance to maximize their equity," said Jack H. Boyajian, a partner with David L. Muelken in R.O.A. Hutton. He said his company had converted a two-building co-op in Edgewater, was under contract to convert two others and was exploring six more conversions in the state.
In converting the Stratford House, which 80 percent of the unit owners approved, Mr. Boyajian said the building's single tax lot was divided into 133 tax lots, and its $2.7 million underlying mortgage, held by the Republic National Bank, had to be repaid. Owners also had to convert the individual share loans on their co-op units to conventional mortgages, he said, noting that both were accomplished as "a cash-free transaction."
The Columbia Federal Savings Bank, he said, provided owners with mortgages based on the appraised value of their units as condos, which was 30 to 40 percent higher than as co-ops. The Federal National Mortgage Association has agreed to buy the loans from Columbia Federal, he said.
Since the mortgages on individual apartments were larger than the share loans they replaced, the 119 owners who converted immediately were able to pay off their share of the underlying co-op mortgage, their individual end loans, closing costs and R.O.A.'s fee. In doing so, those owners paid down $2.3 million of the underlying mortgage.
Mr. Boyajian said a new $400,000 mortgage was also put in place that allows the remaining 14 unit owners to pay down their share of the underlying mortgage when they convert over the next two years.
Most unit owners will pay the same or slightly less in total monthly carrying costs on their condos as they did on their co-ops. For example, Mr. Boyajian said, a two-bedroom co-op that was bought in 1985 for $87,900 -- a similar one recently sold for $60,000 -- had a total monthly carrying cost of $1,094, made up of real-estate taxes, maintenance, its $25,000 share of the buildingwide mortgage and its payment on its $25,280 share loan. The monthly cost of that unit as a condo, which was appraised at $134,000 and received a new loan of $55,860, is $1,080, with the condo owner taking on about $5,000 in added debt.
Housing analysts cited several reasons why co-op boards in New Jersey have explored converting their buildings to condos. They said financial woes -- from foreclosures by banks to defaults on loans by sponsors -- that arose when the mid-80's boom deflated had negatively affected co-ops, as has the perception that they are more restrictive than condos.

THE co-op form of ownership, though widely used in New York, has also never caught on west of the Hudson River except in Fort Lee, just over the George Washington Bridge from Manhattan, which has attracted many New Yorkers familiar with the concept. There are 3,447 condominium buildings with 260,000 units in New Jersey, compared with 185 co-op buildings with 27,000 units, according to state figures.
Benjamin Lambert, a Woodbridge lawyer who specializes in co-op matters, said buyers "still don't get the concept because they are so used to buying an apartment, not shares in a corporation, and of getting a deed, not a proprietary lease." There is also the perception that condos are easier to finance and sell for higher prices than co-ops, he said.
The co-op market, hit hard by a real estate recession that sent values falling up to 50 percent, has rebounded as a result of the healthy housing market. But generally, co-op prices have not reached the same level as their peak in 1986 or come back as much as condos, brokers said.
In Fort Lee, where co-ops outnumber condos by a 2-to-1 ratio, "prices are close to where they were in '86," said Charles Oppler of Oppler-Ketive Realtors, which specializes in co-ops. Last year, 302 co-ops were sold at an average price of $105,738, compared with 215 units sold at an average price of $76,266 in 1997, he said, noting that in some buildings, "we're seeing prices we haven't seen in 10 years."
That is not the case in Hackensack, said Mr. Muhlstock, the board president of the Stratford House. He said that condo prices in this market were 20 percent higher than for similar co-ops and that over the last three years condo sales were five to seven times higher than co-op sales.
Meanwhile, the building's underlying mortgage was due to expire in 2003, he said, and added, "We knew that with a 40 percent owner-occupancy level, banks would not look at the building as a safe investment and would recast the loan at a higher interest rate." It was, he said, the right time to do the conversion.
Mr. Lambert said he encouraged his clients to examine "the pitfalls and promises of a conversion," which is difficult and time-consuming. A major hurdle, he said, is getting shareholders to agree. Other concerns, he said, are whether the underlying mortgage has a large prepayment penalty and whether more than nine units are still owned by the sponsor, which requires that a new public offering statement be filed with the state. At the Stratford House, the sponsor owned fewer than nine units.
There are also tax issues. With the higher appraised value of condos over co-ops, a conversion will result in higher property taxes. There could also be income tax consequences for the corporation and the shareholders in the form of income tax on any recognized gain resulting from the conversion of units not used as primary residences, he said.
Mr. Boyajian said his company worked with Hackensack's tax assessor to phase in the real estate taxes over four years. As for the federal income tax, he said the co-op corporation could use losses incurred over the years to offset any gains.
The sales campaign to reintroduce the Stratford House as a condominium will be controlled, Mr. Boyajian said. Twelve apartments, he added, will be put up for sale at one time, so not to flood the market, and at prices that are not lower than 90 percent or higher than 110 percent of their appraisals as condominiums, to maximize values.
To date, Mr. Muhlstock, who has no intention of selling his penthouse unit, said he "cannot see a downside to the conversion." The proof, he added, will be in the sales.
