HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Downtown Brooklyn;
Open Only Two Years, a Hotel Is Ready to Expand

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
FROM the time the first discussions began until it opened its doors in July 1998, Renaissance Plaza in downtown Brooklyn was a 15-year undertaking, with much of the uncertainty that delayed the project centered on the 376-room hotel that is part of the 1.4-million-square-foot building, which also contains offices and stores.
But less than two years later, the hotel has been such a success that the center's developer, Joshua L. Muss of Muss Development, is negotiating with the city's Economic Development Corporation to put up a building on an adjacent site that would add 280 rooms to the hotel. 
 "We had thought about doing an addition, but we figured that it would be in the very distant future," Mr. Muss said. "It typically takes 50 years for something to become an icon in Brooklyn, but we seem to have done it in two years."
The hotel, which occupies the lower seven floors of the 30-story tower between Adams and Jay Streets, currently has an occupancy rate of 93 percent, said Ken Schwartz, general manager of the hotel, called the New York Marriott Brooklyn. This is an almost unheard of level of use for a hotel and well exceeds last year's 82.4 percent rate for Manhattan, itself high by historic standards.
"The weekends have been particularly surprising," Mr. Schwartz said. "Usually downtown hotels do not do well on weekends, but we have done well." With business conferences bringing guests into the hotel during the week, he said, social events like weddings and parties have kept it busy on the weekends.
Sean Hennessey, the director of the New York hospitality practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers, agreed that the hotel had been unexpectedly successful. He said part of the reason was the high level of finish of the building and what he called "generous rooms."
But he said the affiliation with Marriott was important as well, both for the name and the operating experience the organization has brought to the management of the hotel.
Room rates have increased as a result of the unusually intense demand. When it opened in July 1998, the typical rate was $179 a night for the slow summer season, with an increase to $225 for the busier fall season.
The current rates, Mr. Schwartz said, are $199 to $259 a night on weekdays, and $149 to $190 a night on weekends.
Mr. Muss said that when the hotel part of Renaissance Plaza was originally designed, public spaces like meeting rooms and ballrooms were deliberately overemphasized, given the number of guest rooms. The building has 28,000 square feet of public space, including an 18,000-square-foot ballroom, the fourth-largest in the city.
He noted that the Manhattan hotels with larger public spaces, like the Marriott Marquis and the Sheraton New York have well over 1,000 guest rooms. "We just didn't have the guts or the financing to build on that scale," he said.
Mr. Schwartz said its relatively small number of rooms has hampered the hotel's ability to attract conventions and meetings with large numbers of attendees from out of town.
"We'll do over 90 percent in guest-room occupancy this year, but the banquet halls will be only about 50 percent," he said. "That's where we have room to grow, and that's why we need additional guest rooms."
One reason for the success of the Renaissance Plaza project, Mr. Muss said, is that it has something that is scarce in all urban locations: parking. In fact, indoor parking, 1,100 spaces in all. He said that most hotel guests who arrive by car are in taxis but that the parking is important for business meetings and social events like weddings.
And the parking is important to the tenants who have filled all but 10,000 square feet of the 825,000 square feet of the office space of the complex. Since the offices are mostly occupied during business hours, parking becomes available for events held during evenings and weekends.
The addition to the hotel would be a freestanding 23- or 24-story tower built immediately to the east of Renaissance Plaza on Adams Street. The city-owned site is currently occupied by low-rise masonry building that once housed an electrical substation.
Although the design for the structure is far from complete -- that is why it is not certain whether it will be 23 or 24 stories -- some concepts are already in place.
One is that there will be no separate entrance to the addition, which will be connected to the main building by a glass-enclosed, two-level bridge over a pedestrian walkway. The concept is to enhance security by directing all guests and visitors through the main lobby.
The reason for a two-level bridge is that one level would be for guests and the other for service operations. The guest-level bridge would connect at the second-story lobby level of the main building, right next to the front desk.
The bridge would take out two guest rooms in the main building, which is why the addition, which will have 282 rooms, will result in a net addition of 280.
The new building will provide guests an experience the existing hotel cannot: views of something other than downtown Brooklyn. The building across Adams Street that now houses the State Supreme Court is about 12 stories tall, so guests in the upper half of the building should have excellent views of midtown Manhattan or in the rooms facing the other way, of Coney Island and Sandy Hook.
BECAUSE the land is owned by the city, the project will have to go through a formal approval process before it is decided whether the site will be sold or leased on a long-term basis, a process Mr. Muss estimates will take from 12 to 18 months.
Michael Carey, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said he supports the project in general, noting that it will bring additional jobs and economic activity to downtown Brooklyn, which has lagged behind the revival of most of Manhattan.
"They didn't open a hotel in Brooklyn in half a century, and a little over a year later these people want to expand," Mr. Carey said. "That's good for Brooklyn."
He added the next step would be for the city to designate Mr. Muss as the developer of the project so he can proceed with his negotiations with Marriott and other sources of financing.
Mr. Muss said that once he has his financing and all the needed permits, the hotel could be built in about a year, which would mean it could open by the summer of 2002. The building, he said, would be "a straightforward accumulation of rooms," with none of the architectural and engineering problems posed by having large public spaces on low floors.
"It would be like an apartment building," he said. "They go up fast."
Mr. Muss, who is active as a developer in the boroughs outside Manhattan, said the performance of the hotel demonstrates that a Brooklyn location is not the drawback some people thought it to be.
He grins broadly as Mr. Schwartz tells about one result of the hotel's high occupancy rate.
"Sometimes we have to tell people trying to book a room here that we are filled up," he said. "We tell them that they will have to go into Manhattan."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Strengthening Retail on Garden City's Franklin Ave.

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY

 BODY:
WHEN Gary Kahres, an owner of the Medical Shop at 949 Franklin Avenue, took over his Garden City store 20 years ago, he recalled recently, business was booming along the avenue, a thoroughfare that stretches southward from Old Country Road.
In late March, as a cold wind whipped down the sidewalk, there were few pedestrians, but still there were signs that the avenue, which began declining in the 1980's and which had major vacancies as recently as two years ago, might be headed for the retail revival that Mr. Kahres and other long-established retailers have been yearning for. 
 Shopkeepers are placing their hopes on several major redevelopment projects that are already luring new retailers, and on a $4 million street beautification project extending from Fifth to 11th Streets that was undertaken by the village last year and that is now receiving its final touches. Street improvements extending north of 11th Street to Old Country Road are scheduled to start this spring.
The Medical Shop, once a general bookstore and now specializing in books and other items for medical professionals, is a diehard on the street that once called itself the Fifth Avenue of Long Island but that began losing its luster because of competition from the nearby Roosevelt Field Shopping Center and other large retail centers.
The departure by Bloomingdale's to the Roosevelt Field mall in 1995 was a major blow to the street's upscale shopping image. Sears took over the vacant Bloomingdale's space. Lord & Taylor, Saks Fifth Avenue and Talbot's still anchor the north end of the shopping district, but last year Saks announced that it was planning to relocate to Roosevelt Field. The plan was unsuccessful only because because Simon Properties, the mall's owner, failed to receive the special-use permit it needed from the Town of North Hempstead for additional construction to accommodate Saks.
Mr. Kahres, busy with a stream of customers, said people who shopped at his specialized store would find it inconvenient to go to a mall, so that he never considered moving there. "Still," he said, "I would like to see the street loaded with people the way it once was." Many view the renovation by Renaissance Development of 833-55 Franklin Avenue, with a total of 75,000 square feet, as the catalyst of a retail revival. The building was once occupied by the Abraham & Straus department store, which moved out in 1995.
Renaissance, which is a joint venture of the Albanese Development Corporation of Garden City and the Castagna Realty Company of Manhasset, bought the handsome brick building in 1998. Its $9 million gut rehabilitation has created 40,000 square feet of office space on the upper two floors and 20,000 square feet of retail space on the ground level.
The building, which also has a 16,000-square-foot basement, has a new lobby and new elevators. The exterior has been restored and large new windows were installed on the ground level for new stores. Bentel & Bentel of Locust Valley and Angelo Francis Corva of Manhasset were the architects for the renovation.
The office space on the upper floors has been leased: Salomon Smith Barney took 35,000 square feet in September and the Silverberg & Hunter law firm will soon move into the remaining 5,000 square feet.
The building also has its first retail tenant, New York Sports Clubs, a health club, which has leased 21,000 square feet including the entire basement and is scheduled to open for business in May.
If discussions with two potential tenants -- one a casual clothing store, the other a home furnishings store -- are successful, the remaining 14,000 square feet of retail space will also be leased, said Russell G. Matthews, executive vice president at Albanese Development.
Across the street at 888 Franklin Avenue, Renaissance has taken what were formerly four storefronts, three of which were vacant, and is combining them as 11,500 square feet that have been leased to Kings Super Markets. The chain, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., specializes in gourmet foods and other specialty grocery products.
The block occupied by the two Renaissance properties, between Stewart Avenue to Ninth Street, was considered the most distressed on Franklin Avenue because of its almost 90,000 square feet of vacant space.
"Franklin Avenue is the face of the village and as people drove by and saw these empty stores the perception was that all of Garden City was undergoing some sort of economic decline," Mr. Matthews said. "That was not the case because each building had its own story and reason for being vacant."

LARGE vacancies still exist. Of the 1.5 million square feet of retail space along Franklin Avenue, which includes the three big department stores, 90,000 square feet in the smaller locations is still vacant, according to the Garden City Chamber of Commerce.
However, other players in addition to Renaissance are buying properties with plans to renovate. A partnership of Vincent Polimeni of Garden City and Edward Kalikow of Westbury has bought the 47,000-square-foot three-story-and-basement office building at 1000 Franklin Avenue and is planning to convert the street level to retail space once a lease held by the Astoria Federal Savings Bank expires next year.
"We bought our building six months ago perceiving an opportunity," Mr. Polimeni said. "We intend to complement what Renaissance has done and to revive Franklin with quality retail."
Some of Franklin Avenue's older office buildings will also be refurbished. Renaissance is in contract to buy a 50,000-square-foot building at 1122 Franklin Avenue that had been the headquarters of the Roosevelt Savings Bank. It plans to renovate the building to multiple offices and has already started marketing the space.
A 33,000-square-foot building at 901 Franklin Avenue vacated by Salomon Smith Barney for its move to the Renaissance building has been acquired by TDK Electronics of Port Washington for its new headquarters.
Another pending office renovation is at 501 Franklin Avenue, a 150,000-square-foot building modeled on Hampton Court in England, built by Doubleday, Page & Company, the publishing house, in 1910 and now boarded up. Doubleday & Company was bought by Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, in 1987 and was renamed Doubleday Direct.
The Bertelsmann subsidiary, whose editorial offices are in Manhattan, occupies 100,000 square feet at 401 Franklin Avenue next door to the 501 Franklin Avenue building, which it owns. Doubleday Direct is now known as Bookspan, reflecting its joint-venture partnership with Book-of-the-Month Club Holdings, which is owned by Time Inc., a unit of Time Warner. The 501 Franklin Avenue building will be renovated, but plans are still indefinite, said Malka Margolies, a spokeswoman for Bookspan.
Even though 501 Franklin Avenue is south of the shopping area, the looming presence of a major empty building did not help the business district, so its future renovation is an important component of any turnaround, said Bertram Donley, president of the Chamber of Commerce.
In a 1997 report issued by the Garden City Planning Coalition, a group organized by the village to come up with strategies to revitalize the business district, recommendations included beautification of Franklin Avenue, adding public parking spaces to the village's current 5,200, forming a business improvement district, and recruiting retailers that would complement the existing stores. A street beautification project completed by the village in 1986 on Seventh Street turned it into a bustling shopping street with no vacancies. Village officials now hope that the Seventh Street success story will spill over to Franklin Avenue.
"We have done our part in improving the public properties and making them pedestrian-friendly and I am very encouraged by the activities we are seeing," said Robert L. Schoelle Jr., the village administrator.
Many visualize Garden City as becoming the role model for other downtowns that have seen an economic decline. "I believe the concept of the mall is wearing off a little bit and people would just like to have the experience of strolling through a quaint village with upscale stores," Mr. Kalikow said.
William B. Kuhl in Manhattan was the landscape architect, designer and planner for Franklin Avenue's street revitalization project, as well as for Seventh Street's.
"The major element that makes malls attractive is a lot of stores in one spot, but pleasant they are not," Mr. Kuhl said. "The downtown experience becomes more of a social event in enjoyable surroundings."
For Franklin Avenue, Mr. Kuhl designed a series of elements. At the intersection of Stewart Avenue, he placed a gazebo at one corner, a fountain at another and a rose garden at a third. Alleyways leading to public parking were given hanging vines.
With a 25-foot wide sidewalk to work with, Mr. Kuhl indented some areas to provide parallel parking. The on-street parking has two purposes, he said: encouraging passing motorists to pull up and shop and helping to slow traffic as cars pull out into the traffic lanes. Decorative lampposts, lighting, benches, street trees, and extensive landscaping are other highlights of the beautification project.
"We like to think that with our design we have set the table and now it's up to the Chamber of Commerce to bring the guests to dinner and get the businesses into town," Mr. Kuhl said. "Designing a beautiful streetscape won't have everyone banging on your door, but with some new businesses already moving in, results can already be seen."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3832 words

HEADLINE: In All 5 Boroughs, High Goes Higher

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
NO getting away from it: everywhere in New York City home prices just keep climbing -- from the rarefied heights of Manhattan where 11 apartments have sold for $10 million or more so far this year, compared with just six in all of 1999, to every single ZIP code area in the city's other boroughs.
A studio in Manhattan costs 31 percent more than it did only a year ago, one survey says; a one-bedroom, 29 percent more. A family's income now needs to exceed $100,000 to cover the costs of a well-kept brownstone in Harlem, according to the president of the neighborhood's real estate board. 
 The cost of a one-bedroom condominium in Astoria, Queens, which was $95,000 in 1998, climbed to $120,000 in '99. And a detached colonial in Forest Hills that sold for $267,000 in 1996 went for -- "Are you ready?" the broker said -- $417,000 last year. Even in struggling East New York, Brooklyn, the average price for a single-family house rose 8.4 percent in 1999, from $140,789 to $152,585.
One family tried to get away, however briefly, from this frantic house-buying scene, said Susan Goldy, the president of the Bronx brokerage company that bears her name, and it cost them their dream house.
Nestled into a hillside in Riverdale, the Mediterranean-style three-bedroom with a terrace and sunken living room had been snatched up -- verbally -- for $515,000. "Then the couple went on vacation," Ms. Goldy said.
"They came back a week later, and there were three offers beyond theirs," she said, "and now the house is selling at $565,000" -- a $50,000 leap in only two weeks.
"The last people, the ones accepted at $565,000, told the seller that they were going on vacation," Ms. Goldy said. "He, in turn, told them they had to sign the contract, have everything done, before they left or no deal."
And it's a good thing, Ms. Goldy said, "because there are now other interested parties."
Oh, so many interested parties -- particularly in buyer-maddening Manhattan -- are bidding with abandon. "The bidding is where the rubber meets the road, a hint of where we're going," said Barbara Corcoran, the chairwoman of the Corcoran Group. "We have dozens of buyers for every good apartment and a half dozen for every one that's not so good."
"Six months ago," Ms. Corcoran said, "our average overbid was 8 percent, meaning the offer over asking price. Since January, that has jumped to 14 percent. To me, overbids tell more of the story than the sales prices."
Kirk Henckels doesn't quite know what tale is being told by the prices in his stratospheric market niche. Mr. Henckels is the director of Stribling Private Brokerage, specializing in homes selling for at least $3 million, "but given the increases of the last three years," he said, "we're probably going to have to double that."
Especially puzzling is a sudden burst of ionospheric activity. "All of last year, there were six prewar co-ops in Manhattan that closed at $10 million or above," Mr. Henckels said. "Now, in the first three months of 2000 there have been 11," the highest about $35 million for the 17,000-square-foot apartment at 740 Park Avenue once owned by John D. Rockefeller.
"Who knows?" Mr. Henckels said when asked why there is suddenly so much rare-air movement. "This very high end of the market is usually conservative, even though the expenditure is a relative pittance to them. When this group buys, they seem to do it en masse, as if they'd gotten on the phone the night before and said, 'Let's go shopping tomorrow.' I've watched this for 20 years."
But even for regular folks, housing costs keep climbing. For the second straight year, according to the repeat-sales survey conducted by Case Shiller Weiss, a real estate statistics company, prices appreciated last year in every one of the 130 ZIP code areas in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island (the survey does not include Manhattan). In 1997, by comparison, 14 areas saw prices drop, and in 1996 that number was 30.
New York City's house-price picture is not all that different from that of the nation and the rest of the region, except for one significant aspect. In 1999, for the fourth straight year, the national median price for an existing single-family home set a record, rising to $133,300 from $128,400 in 1998. In the region, the median price hit $208,000 last year, up from $187,400 in 1998.
The difference, said Rae Rosen, the senior regional economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is that, even more than its suburbs, the city is "pretty much landlocked, so we're bidding up a fixed supply."
At the same time, with the economy in its 109th month of expansion (the longest in history), with the stock market pumping out bonuses and dividends and with consumer confidence strong, buyers are out in force.
To be sure, more and more of them are out there because more people are working. "The job picture in New York City has been exceptionally strong in recent years," said John Weiting, the regional commissioner of the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, "and in 1999 employment in the city's private sector gained more momentum."
The city added 81,000 private-sector jobs during 1999, raising the total to 3.1 million. "The 1999 increase topped the 76,000 gain in 1998," Commissioner Weiting said, "with the number of jobs added the largest for any year in nearly half a century." Between 1989 and 1992, during a deep downturn, the city lost 321,000 private-sector jobs. But by last December, the unemployment rate was 6 percent, down from 7.6 percent the year before and down from 11.3 percent in 1992.
Rising mortgage rates might be expected to take some of the house-buying steam out of that expanding work force, and financing costs have certainly risen recently. "We are at about four-year highs for the standard 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage, hovering near 8.3 percent," said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage statistics company in Butler, N.J. "But as you might expect, a steady rise in fixed rates has given resurgence to adjustable-rate mortgages," which offer a lower-cost alternative to traditional fixed-rate financing, at least for a time -- usually 3, 5, 7 or 10 years -- before they are adjusted downward, with any luck, but quite possibly up.
"Some 30 percent of mortgages being originated right now have some form of adjustable rate, up sharply from 10 percent in January '99," Mr. Gumbinger said. "And part of the reason home sales have done so well is because there are these alternatives to rising fixed rates."
Another part of the reason, in Ms. Corcoran's view, is that the rising rates "have only added fuel to the fire and increased the urgency to buy."
"People are asking, 'If not now, when will I buy?' " she said.
All of which leaves Ms. Rosen of the Federal Reserve duly optimistic about the city's housing prospects. "You know what's exciting?" she said. "Twenty years ago, it used to be that 96th Street in Manhattan was sort of a cut-off, and now you can keep going, and the health of the area is clear for almost another 30 blocks. Storefronts are no longer closed up. There are new window frames all over."
"If you go right outside Forest Hills in Queens, it looks like a mini-United Nations," Ms. Rosen continued. "It's astounding how various groups have migrated to the United States and invigorated communities. There's a similar robust Russian community that has created million-dollar homes in parts of Brooklyn."
Prof. Michael Schill, the director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law, is a little less sanguine. Given recently released data from the city's 1999 Housing and Vacancy Survey, he said, "one might be surprised by the rapid increase in prices over the past few years."
The survey shows that between 1996 and 1999 the rate of increase for the city's housing supply outpaced population growth. Over those three years, housing units rose by 1.5 percent while the city's population went up 0.8 percent.
"Yet, despite the fact that housing supply was increasing faster than population, vacancy rates actually declined," Professor Schill pointed out, from 4.01 percent in 1996 to 3.19 percent in 1999. Five percent is the statutory benchmark for declaring a housing emergency, allowing rent regulations to be continued.
There has been considerable increase in residential construction. In 1999, building permits for 12,421 housing units were issued, according to the Department of City Planning, a 19.6 percent increase over the 10,387 units authorized in 1998.
Professor Schill offers several reasons why the housing crunch has continued, even though construction outpaced population growth. Pointing out that between 1996 and 1999, the city's median household income rose by 11.5 percent, from $29,600 to $33,000, he said: "First, families were able to pay more for housing and, therefore, bid up sales prices and rents. Second, households that were doubled up with friends and relatives are now be able to move into their own homes."
At the same time, the Census Bureau may be underestimating population growth. "This seems likely," Professor Schill said, "given that we are experiencing extremely high levels of immigration, a substantial portion of which is probably illegal."
Other causes for the crunch: most of the new construction is luxury rental apartments, not co-ops or condominiums, and conversions of existing buildings to co-ops and condominiums are, at best, rare.
All of which pushes up prices.
DIVINING real estate trends by the numbers is, at best, a murky exercise. To begin with, co-op sales are not officially recorded because, technically, they are securities transactions involving the selling of shares, and not transfers of title. Condominium sales, however, are officially recorded. As a result, studies of co-op data compiled by brokerage houses and appraisal concerns do not claim to include all transactions in the market. At the same time, some market surveys report average prices, while others use a median -- meaning half the prices are above that figure and half below. Still, the numbers, along with anecdotal impressions, can serve as barometers of market patterns.
In Manhattan, the median price for all residential sales -- combining co-op and condominium transfers -- from the Battery north to West 116th Street and East 96th Street was $320,000 in 1999, up 14.3 percent from $280,000 in 1998, according to Jonathan Miller, the president of Miller Samuel, the appraisal company that prepares perhaps the most comprehensive sales survey, the Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report. The number of sales for the same area of Manhattan was 8,154, up 8.1 percent from the 7,542 transactions in 1998.
For studios, the Elliman report said, the median price was $136,000, up 12.4 percent from $121,000 in 1998. For one-bedrooms, it was $260,000, up 10.6 percent from $235,000. The median for two-bedrooms was $595,000, up 9.2 percent from $545,000; for three-bedrooms, $1,595,000, up 25.1 percent from $1,275,000. And for four or more bedrooms, it was $3.4 million, up 13.1 percent from $3,006,145.
The Real Estate Board of New York offers a localized assessment.
The median price for prewar apartments on the East Side, between 42nd and 96th Streets was $632,500, up 7 percent from $592,500 in 1998. For postwar apartments on the East Side, the median was $350,000, up 40 percent from $250,000. On the West Side, from 42nd Street up to 110th Street, prewar apartments sold for a median of $432,500, up 31 percent from 1998, when it was $329,000; and for postwar apartments it was $316,000, up 36 percent from $232,000.
Gregory Heym, the chief economist for the real estate board, explained that according to the board's guidelines, a studio usually contains 1 to 2 1/2 rooms with, perhaps, a separate kitchen and an alcove. One-bedrooms run from 2 1/2 to 4 rooms with a living room, a kitchen and, perhaps, a dining area. Two-bedrooms run from 4 to 7 rooms; three-bedrooms, from 5 1/2 to 10 rooms including, perhaps, a maid's room and a library, and four-bedroom apartments contain 11 or more rooms.
For everything south of 42nd Street, pre- and postwar combined, Mr. Heym said, the median price was $264,500 up 30 percent from the 1998 figure of $202,800.
It is certainly a seller's market. "There's one thing holding people back when you talk to them," Mr. Heym said. "They say, 'I'd love to sell, but then where am I going to go?' "
Mr. Miller pointed out that the overall numbers -- that 14.3 percent rise for all co-ops and condos -- may be misleading. "Because the economy is so good, due to Wall Street, Silicon Alley and the entertainment sectors, there's a lot of entry-level younger buyers moving into the market," he said. Those buyers tend toward studios and one-bedroom apartments.
"Because so many more smaller apartments are transferring," Mr. Miller said, "they pull the overall prices down so that a reader of the statistics may not fully appreciate how much prices have actually increased."
Ms. Corcoran appreciates it. "We had, last week, a large two-bedroom on Fifth Avenue that every broker agreed was grossly overpriced," she said. "It was overbid by three buyers, 33 percent over asking, from $1.8 million up to $2.4 million."
"Everybody was stunned," Ms. Corcoran said, "including the hard-to-shock seller."
Clark Halstead, the founder of the Halstead Property Company, tried to put it in perspective. "Take a Park Avenue building in the high 80's, a distinguished prewar where there are numerous six-room apartments," he said. "Classic Sixes" are considered the prototypical family apartments in Manhattan: living room, dining room, kitchen, two bedrooms and a maid's room.
"Our records show that four sales of this six-room type in 1990 averaged $606,000," Mr. Halstead said, "and in 1999, four more sold -- not the same ones -- for an average of $1,320,000. That's a 120 percent increase."
"The hue and cry of the cocktail party circuit is that apartment prices have gone berserk," Mr. Halstead said. "But compare that 120 percent to financial assets, like the Standard & Poor's 500, which went up 400 percent over the decade."
Andrew Heiberger is the president of Citi Habitats, which focuses on the expanding downtown market. "My average number of calls for people willing to spend $1 million or more has doubled, to two a day," he said.
The tight rental market is driving up sales prices, Mr. Heiberger said, as is "the fact that many proposed conversions from commercial to residential were canceled because the commercial market went so crazy."
According to Citi Habitat sales, the median price for a studio below 14th Street was $165,000 last year, compared with $135,000 in 1998, a 22.2 percent increase. For 1-bedrooms, it was $260,000, up 20.9 percent from $215,000. Two-bedrooms climbed to $462,000, up 21.9 percent from $380,000. And 3-bedrooms were $720,000, up 9.1 percent from $660,000.
The upper uptown market is getting pricey.
"Just this winter," said R. Kenyatta Punter, the president of the Greater Harlem Board of Realtors, "a one-family, three-story brownstone at 416 Convent sold for $660,000." In 1998, it would have sold for $600,000, he said.
Other than in dilapidated buildings requiring renovation or government-subsidized new construction, "it's becoming increasingly difficult for persons making $50,000 to $70,000 to find home-ownership opportunities in the Harlem community," Mr. Punter said. "Your income really has to exceed $100,000 in order to make the kind of purchase I cited."
There is no central source for price data, by the dollar, for Brooklyn. But by another measure of the market, the Case Shiller Weiss repeat-sales index, the direction is clear: every one of the borough's 36 ZIP code areas saw prices rise last year.
THE survey is based on a table showing the average price for all single-family homes sold by ZIP code area, year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 1999, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each ZIP code area during the year, compared it to the price the house brought the last time it sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the earlier price to what it likely would have been had it sold in 1998. The 1999 prices for homes within each ZIP code area were then compared with the estimated 1998 prices to compute the change.
Of the 36 Brooklyn areas, 1 increased by up to 4 percent, 34 by 4 to 8 percent and one -- Bay Ridge -- by 8 to 12 percent.
"While the rise was universal over all the areas that we deal with," said Christopher Thomas, the William B. May Company's senior vice president for Brooklyn, "there are certain areas with houses at the lower end of our price spectrum that rose higher than those in more established communities." Mr. Thomas's company specializes in the more affluent areas of the borough, like Brooklyn Heights, with neighborhoods like Fort Greene at that lower end of the company's spectrum.
"Where in late '98 a four-story town house in Fort Greene was selling for $635,000," Mr. Thomas said, "there's one currently in contract for $850,000."
In Brooklyn Heights, a year ago, he said, at least half a dozen brownstones were listed for under $2 million, while now all but two are listed between $2 million and $3 million. "Last year, you could still buy one-bedroom apartments in the $150,000 to $200,000 range; now they go for closer to $300,000," Mr. Thomas said.
Brooklyn's less affluent communities are also appreciating. Jacob Shayovitz, a certified appraiser and the president of the Brooklyn Board of Realtors, cited one section of East New York where the average price last year was $140,789, up 8.4 percent from $152,586. "It shows that people are taking more pride in home ownership, maintaining them better," Mr. Shayovitz said. In one area of middle-income Midwood, he said, "homes sold for an average of $299,231 in 1998; in 1999, for $301,729."
In Queens, according to the Long Island Board of Realtors, which covers the borough, the median price in December was $190,000, up 2.7 percent from $185,000 in 1998. And according to the Case Shiller survey, 13 of the borough's 57 ZIP code areas experienced increases up to 4 percent, 24 by 4 to 8 percent, 18 by 8 to 12 percent and two -- Fresh Meadows and Howard Beach -- by 12 percent or more.
Barbara Frechter, the president of Glenjay Realty in Forest Hills, said she sold a three-bedroom detached colonial between Austin Street and Queens Boulevard for $267,000 at the end of 1996, "and in '99 it sold for -- are you ready? -- $417,500."
"The same person we sold that house for bought in Cord Meyer, the north side of Queens Boulevard where there are large, beautiful homes," Ms. Frechter said. "That house had five bedrooms, a kind of custom-built split, and it sold for $550,000."
A two-bedroom co-op on Queens Boulevard that sold for $85,000 in 1998, she said, "would now be $95,000 to $100,000, absolutely."
In Astoria, "because it's so close to the city," Ms. Frechter said, a one-bedroom condominium that sold for $85,000 to $95,000 a year ago "is now selling for $120,000."
And a three-family, semidetached house in Astoria that sold for $270,000 in 1998 "went for $370,000 in '99," Ms. Frechter said, a whopping 37 percent jump.
The statistics kept by the Bronx Board of Realtors are incomplete. But the Case Shiller report indicated that all 25 of the borough's ZIP code areas saw prices increase: 1 by up to 4 percent, 23 by 4 to 8 percent and 1 -- Throgs Neck -- by 8 to 12 percent.
One broker, Haniff Baksh, the vice president of ERA Besmatch, conducted his own survey, based on deed transfers recorded by the Department of Buildings. For Throgs Neck, Pelham Parkway and Mosholu in the northeast Bronx, 1999 prices averaged $180,000 for a one-family home and $230,000 for a two-family. "In '98, those numbers were slightly less, about $170,000 for a one-family and $220,000 for a two-family," Mr. Baksh said. In the once-desolate South Bronx, single-family homes now average $150,000, compared with about $135,000 a year ago, Mr. Baksh said, while two-family homes average $200,000, up 10 percent from $180,000 a year ago.
"There's a lot of investor activity helping to revitalize these areas," he said. "There's some subsidized housing, of course, but that's not the bulk of it; this is private activity."
Ms. Goldy, the broker in Riverdale, cited rapid-fire price rises in her neighborhood. "We closed on a combination apartment -- two one-bedrooms -- in July at $250,000," she said. "And the very same apartment, for unusual reasons, came back on the market in January and sold for $275,000."
A one-bedroom co-op on Kappock Street sold for $50,000 in December 1998, she said, "and we closed on another one-bedroom in the same building in January 2000 for $74,000."
On Staten Island, said Sandy Krueger, the executive vice president of the borough's Board of Realtors, the median price for single-family homes was $177,000 in 1999, a 7.3 percent increase over 1998's $165,000. For two-family homes, it was $250,000, up 14.7 percent from $218,000. And for condominiums and co-ops, the median was $107,000, an 18.9 percent jump from $90,000. According to Case Shiller, all 12 ZIP code areas on Staten Island saw prices increase by 4 to 8 percent last year.
Getting site-specific, Mr. Krueger said that "in West Brighton, on the north shore, the median for single-family homes was $151,500," a 25.2 percent increase over $121,000. For two-families, it was $159,900, 10.3 percent over 1998's $145,000.
For Heartland Village, in mid-island, the single-family median was $202,000, 12.2 percent over $180,000; and for two-families, it was $279,900, a 14.2 percent increase over $245,000 in 1998. And in Huguenot, on the south shore, the median for single-family homes hit $355,000, up 8.7 percent over $326,500 in 1998.
Mr. Thomas of William B. May in Brooklyn proffered perhaps the only sure-fire solution for price-battered buyers.
"We had a couple selling a co-op in Brooklyn Heights who signed a contract to purchase a town house in Prospect-Lefferts for $325,000," Mr. Thomas said. "The house closing took longer than expected because they had to sell their co-op."
"If they didn't go through with the deal they would forfeit their 10 percent deposit," he said. "Then, coincidentally, during that delay, they inherited a house in Westchester."
Even though they were not going to live in the Prospect-Lefferts house, the couple decided to go through with the deal, and then put it on the market. "We sold it immediately for $375,000 -- a $50,000 profit," Mr. Thomas said. "It just indicates the degree to which the market rose over just that four-month period."
A postscript: The couple had purchased their Brooklyn Heights co-op in 1996 for $120,000. They sold it for $320,000. "They made out pretty well," Mr. Thomas said.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 12; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1011 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Urban Renewal, on Canvas: Camden Sits for a Portrait

BYLINE: By FRED B. ADELSON 

DATELINE: HADDON TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
SINCE the 17th century, artists have been interested in painting city views that are topographically and architecturally accurate. Images of Rome, Venice, Paris, or New York may easily come to mind. But Camden?
For more than 25 years, William M. Hoffman Jr. has been painting portraits of Camden. What he has created is an engaging series of approximately 60 images in oil or casein paint as well as watercolor that depict a variety of buildings and street scenes from all sections of the city. Twenty-two of these urban subjects, dating from 1979 to 1999, are on view here at the Hopkins House Gallery. 
 Artistic activity in Camden has long been documentary and illustrative. A year after the city's incorporation in 1828, John James Audubon was the first professional artist to work in the newly established city. He settled there to observe the springtime migration of warblers and other birds that were traveling north. A period of rapid growth soon took place, changing the city from what was a rural 19th-century ferry stop on the Delaware River to a major industrial center of the early 20th century.
Even before the construction of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge in the 1920's, everything from soup to paper boxes to battleships was manufactured in Camden. "On Camden's supplies the world relies" was the slogan of the city's Board of Trade. Many of the architectural subjects painted by Mr. Hoffman date back to this period of booming economic prosperity.
It was not until 1974 that the artist started to make charcoal drawings of sites near the Camden campus of Rutgers University, where as a professor of art he has been teaching painting since 1967. Mr. Hoffman lives in the suburb of Woodlynne and occasionally rides his bicycle to class. Familiar with the back roads of the neighboring city, he has roamed all over Camden to find subjects that interest him. None of his images are based on photographs. Mr. Hoffman is dedicated to painting en plein air, which means working outdoors.
"It is much more interesting and immediate to work directly on the site," he said. "I see the place more clearly. I feel more a part of the community and its people. Things are always changing; the weather and light conditions; the blowing canvas." His small strokes of loose brushwork enhance the naturalism and immediacy that he effectively captures.
Mr. Hoffman flatters Camden. The sun always seems to be shining. Like John Constable, he is fascinated by cloud-patterned blue skies that add a nonthreatening sense of drama to what are essentially idyllic images of the cityscape. He sees a place where there are no abandoned houses, graffiti or litter. In addition, he eliminates most of the telephone poles, traffic lights and fireplugs.
Two of Mr. Hoffman's very successful and most panoramic images are "View of Camden with City Hall" and "View of Philadelphia from Camden." The former was painted in 1983 from the roof of Victor Hall, a seven-story RCA building that was given to Rutgers but has subsequently been torn down. The elevated point of view allows the artist to present the city's eclectic mix of architecture, while he also creates a composition of geometric forms and patches of contrasting pink and green colors. The other image is a view looking from the eastern shoreline toward Philadelphia; the Benjamin Franklin Bridge looms up from the right side. Working on a pathway that is used by residents of Camden to pick wild berries and to fish in the Delaware, Mr. Hoffman includes the foreground vegetation and the boating activity on the river.
This scenic vista is a bittersweet one. The loss of manufacturing jobs and the closing of factories has been devastating to the city. On the other hand, new construction, like the towers of Liberty Place, is an obvious sign of the healthy economy of nearby Philadelphia.
Mr. Hoffman steadfastly refuses to depict Walt Whitman's house, one of the city's most historic properties. Because the celebrated residence is on the south side of Mickle Street, it doesn't receive direct sunlight preventing the artist from representing an aesthetically pleasing image. In addition, he feels that the widening of the street into a major thoroughfare has destroyed the original 19th-century village ambiance of the neighborhood.
"I want to emphasize the vitality of a community," Mr. Hoffman said. The painter, who is essentially a realist artist, has depicted several street scenes populated with groups of people enjoying their surroundings. "Helene Apartments," the largest canvas in the show, is a slice-of-life view at the intersection of Third and Cooper Streets. The foreground tree trunk is a classic framing device and contrasts with the vertical stacks of the Campbell Soup factory in the distance. The artist's brushwork nicely suggests the gray stonework of the castellated building with corner towers. This was one of the first apartment houses in the city. Although it may seem hard to believe, the painter maintains that the boy on a pony (cropped at the far right) did ride by while he was working on the canvas in 1983.
Mr. Hoffman will have an additional selection of works from his Camden series on display at the Markeim Art Center in Haddonfield from Wednesday through May 17. An opening reception will take place there on April 8 from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. Like a preservationist, Mr. Hoffman documents an ever-changing urban landscape. In an illustrated booklet to accompany the two exhibits of the Camden series, Roberta K. Tarbell acknowledged that Mr. Hoffman "offers us his interpretation of Camden, New Jersey, a city often maligned . . . He challenges us to recognize the rich tapestry of architectural history that exists and urges us to build what time and indifference have destroyed in the once radiant city."
 
 CAMDEN:
HISTORICAL IMPRESSIONS
Hopkins House Gallery

Haddon Township
Through April 20. Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays noon to 4 p.m.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 734 words

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE;
Reasonable and Customary, But in Whose Eyes?

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care will appear the first Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to
jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
OPENING an "explanation of benefits" letter from a health insurance company is a little like playing blackjack in a casino: Chances are you're going to lose; the question is how much.
While the majority of Americans insured through their employers are now enrolled in H.M.O.'s, and thus make minimal co-payments on doctor's visits, a lot of us -- me included -- still get medical care the old-fashioned way, paying the doctor up front, filing a claim and waiting for reimbursement. The same system applies to patients in preferred provider plans who choose to see doctors outside the network. 
 What makes this seem like a losing gamble is that reimbursement checks rarely come close to covering the doctor bill. Rather, the insurance company pays some portion of what its explanation-of-benefits form calls a "reasonable and customary" fee.
Meaning what, exactly? I doubt that "reasonable and customary" is the $95 that my pediatrician (who is outside my preferred provider network) charges for a hepatitis B vaccine; my informal survey indicates that this is high, even by Manhattan standards. I also suspect that it isn't the $17 my insurance plan deemed "reasonable and customary" for the polio vaccine he billed at a fairly typical $40.
Conspiracy theorists might conjure images of nurses sitting in a wood-paneled study, eyeballing claims in a sinister way -- and paying 40 percent of whatever a doctor charges.
In fact, the process is a lot more complex, even if the results are equally unsatisfying.
 MOST insurers rely on data produced for years by the Health Insurance Association of America. (It recently sold the operation to a company called Ingenix.) Doctors are surveyed by region to see what they will accept as payment for procedures. That data is organized into percentile groups; "H.I.A.A. 80," for instance, is the fee that 80 percent of doctors in a region will accept for a service. Many also factor in Medicare reimbursement rates.
But you can't assume that anything close to H.I.A.A. 80 is what your insurance means by "reasonable and customary." Instead, insurance companies present the data to employers, who choose the level upon which they wish to base reimbursements.
In other words, "reasonable and customary" is very much in the eye of the beholder.
To you and me, the costs of those calculations can add up quickly. Say your eye doctor charges $500 for a comprehensive exam. Now assume that your employer has opted for H.I.A.A. 80 as its "reasonable and customary" rate, and that the surveys peg that fee for the exam at $200. If your benefits cover 80 percent of "reasonable and customary," you get a check for $160. You were holding 12; you've just drawn a queen.
Now, you probably want someone to blame. Obviously, your boss or union is a good place to start. "Most people don't understand that it is their employer who sets their reimbursement rate," said Edward Kaplan, a vice president at the Segal Company, a benefits consulting firm. "I have seen some set it at 50 percent of H.I.A.A."
Then there is your doctor, who may be inflating rates to help keep the H.I.A.A. averages high. The doctor will argue that costs are rising by the minute, but you end up having to bridge the gap.
Whoever is at fault, there still are times, experts say, when explanation-of-benefits forms are just crazily out of whack. Reimbursements like the $13.60 I received for that polio vaccine -- 80 percent of $17 -- are probably worth challenging.
"Never underestimate incompetence," said Helen Darling, a senior consultant at Watson Wyatt, another benefits consultant.
Or you could just give up and join an H.M.O. The reason I haven't is that I like having an attentive pediatrician five minutes from my apartment who doesn't make me wait. To help contain the costs of such luxuries, I may establish a flexible medical spending account -- a plan that lets pretax dollars be set aside for paying medical bills. Check to see if your employer offers one.
The accounts are ideal for people who can roughly predict their medical costs. The tax advantage lets your money go further; you can even use the account for over-the-counter goods like contact lens cleaner. The catch is that if you don't spend every cent you set aside, you lose it at the end of the year.
"It is a great thing that most working people do not take advantage of," Ms. Darling said.

PUB-DATE: April 2, 2000

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2896 words

HEADLINE: Great Expectations;
Money Has Poured Into Atlantic City. But a Second Wave, Ever Poised, Still Hasn't Broken.

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
THREE more years, if everything falls into place, and this city can have a new casino. The Borgata, looking as much as it can like a Tuscan village, will open its doors on an expanse that used to be a city landfill, putting 3,000 more people to work and paying more than $10 million a year in property taxes.
Yet Atlantic City is disappointed. There were supposed to be at least two more casinos, a plan deferred and downsized when the company that had promised to build one of them announced last month that it was buying the company that had promised to build the other. There were supposed to be 20,000 more jobs. 
 But more important, there was supposed to be a transformation of Atlantic City from a giant bus terminal to a vacationland -- a "destination resort," in tourism parlance -- for millions of fun-seeking, free-spending, hotel-staying visitors.
This was, after all, the path of Las Vegas. And when Las Vegas's flashiest operator, Steve Wynn, said five years ago that he would bring his Mirage Resorts here, Atlantic City thought it could follow. The goal, in addition to acres of sheer fun by the sea, was to make good on the State Legislature's original mandate to make gambling "a unique tool of urban redevelopment."
Atlantic City still needs redevelopment desperately. It is reeling from the devastation of its small-business sector, visible on the Boardwalk in a line of pizza stands, T-shirt shops and for-rent signs. Its schools, despite a surge of casino dollars, are among the worst in the state. Its old housing is increasingly crowded with immigrants struggling in low-wage casino jobs, and its new housing is virtually all subsidized.
Steven P. Perskie, an Atlantic City lawyer who as an assemblyman wrote the legislation that allowed gambling 25 years ago, spoke recently with a tone of wonder about the $7 billion that the industry has sunk into the city: The money, he said, has exceeded the wildest expectations.
Yet, he added during an interview in his office here, "We had this notion of a spillover effect that didn't happen."
The revenue, $55 billion since 1978, has been by any measure a torrent of money. Why, some wonder is it not more visible?
"It's over $1 billion for every man, woman and child in the city," said Robert Goodman, director of the United States Gambling Research Institute in Northampton, Mass. "No city in history has had that kind of money poured into it. Now look at what exists, what it accomplished. There are parts of the city that look like Bosnia. To me that's the measure of it."
Nonetheless, everyone still dreams of a spillover effect. The catch is that for now, the only visible means of floating all boats is more dollars from more casinos -- casinos to expand entertainment offerings, to build hotel rooms, to draw ancillary businesses.
In short, the second wave -- a term now embedded in the vocabulary here -- is ever poised and never breaking.
No new casinos have been built since 1990. Last year, the Las Vegas strip surpassed Atlantic City in revenue. And since the day in June 1995 when Mr. Wynn said he would build a resort "the likes of which Atlantic City has never seen," employment in the industry has barely budged.
LAST month, Mr. Wynn exited Atlantic City. Mirage is being acquired by MGM Grand, which had its own plan for a Boardwalk casino. And while MGM is expected to proceed eventually with Mirage's plan for a $1 billion casino-hotel in the marina district, where it would share an enormous tract with the Boyd Gaming Company's Borgata, the Boardwalk project looks distant at best.
That is a splash of cold ocean water for this city of 38,000, which depends on its 12 casinos more than ever. And they account for 80 percent of the property tax base, up from 67 percent only 10 years ago.
Casino money, fed into Atlantic City's redevelopment in accordance with the state's grand design, has financed, among other things, the convention center and baseball stadium, a marine museum and thousands housing units. And it is not as if the money is running out. Through the 1990's, revenue rose an average of 4 percent a year, and many of the casinos expanded.
Tired of the tale-of-two-cities theme, Mayor James Whelan insists all of this spending really does show. "We've had tremendous economic development over the last five years," he said.
"Take Atlantic Avenue," he said, ticking off the bank and stores, the supermarket, the new bus terminal. "There isn't a single block on Atlantic Avenue that hasn't seen significant investment. But because there isn't a Bergdorf-Goodman, there's no ta-daaaa, it doesn't get focused on."
"For us," he continued, "economic diversity is not for us to go out and become a manufacturing center or a mini-Silicon Valley. For us, diversity is still in the realm of tourism and entertainment. That's an economic reality."
But Mr. Goodman, among others, points to the addictive nature of gambling revenue. "If the Legislature or the voters were to decide, let's shift away from gambling and toward some other enterprise, you'd see it's very difficult to change. You can't just turn the spigot on and off."
Indeed, Atlantic City is struggling to open the spigot wider. It must shore up its market position in gambling, not only against Las Vegas but against more local poaching: the giant Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun casinos in Connecticut, slot machines at Delaware race tracks and the threat of a new casino in Monticello, N.Y.
Moreover, only the casino companies are likely to build what everyone here wants: more hotel rooms. There are now 11,600 rooms in the casino-hotels, plus 2,500 in non-casino hotels, and the generally agreed-upon number needed to attract big conventions and major airline service is 20,000.
And if a turn away from gambling revenue is difficult in new casino cities like Detroit or Biloxi, Miss., it is all but impossible here.
By law, the city is a preserve governed largely by interlocking agencies charged by Trenton with regulating the casinos and feeding tax coffers from the income.
Chief among them is the Casino Control Commission, which tracks the industry's every dime and collects the state's 8 percent tax. The city's face is primarily the work of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, created in 1984 to invest funds from casino revenue. The Atlantic County Improvement Authority also finances housing and public projects.
The first decade of gambling overwhelmed a city government famous for corruption and ineptitude, and business opportunities, along with the middle class, leached to the suburbs. The state authorities on the scene were groping.
Michael Pollock, the publisher of Michael Pollock's Gaming Industry Observer, recalled that "the view from Trenton was, we legalized casinos, we wrote the law, and now our job is to sit back and spend the revenues."
In the 1990's, "the public sector really got its act together," Mr. Pollock said. The lesson, he said, was that "if you want to redevelop Atlantic City to give it a middle-class housing base, it takes very deep subsidies and years and years of commitment."
The deepest subsidies have gone to housing. The casino reinvestment authority, determined to create middle-class neighborhoods where tenements were razed, is underwriting blocks of neotraditional houses with porches and gingerbread. Hundreds of townhouses fill the once-depleted Inlet section.
Jim Kennedy, the authority's executive director, said that when land costs are included, the subsidies average $250,000 per unit. "The thought was that Atlantic City needed a lot of help in the early years," Mr. Kennedy said. "It needed a lot more help than anyone thought."
While no one is complaining about new housing, many doubt that the much bigger infusion of money has benefited the people left here. The city's black political leaders, in particular, have been pessimistic and so far mostly accurate about the development schemes offered through the years.
Councilman Lorenzo Langford said that "we were sold a bill of goods" on Mr. Wynn's plan to touch off a burst of development near the marina, where Trump Marina and Harrah's had staked out a small casino district next to an old landfill.
For lack of bidders, the 150-acre city property, known as the H-tract, was given to Mirage in exchange for a development plan; Mr. Wynn proposed a resort to be called Le Jardin-Palais and carved out a piece for a partnership with Boyd Gaming, to become the Borgata complex. Then the State Legislature enacted a bill sponsored by Bill Gormley, the area's Republican state senator, to reimburse developers up to three-quarters of the cost of cleaning up old landfills. Mirage was the only apparent beneficiary.
The state also undertook a $330 million road and tunnel, paying two-thirds of the cost, to direct traffic from the Atlantic City Expressway to the marina district. A block of homes in a middle-class black neighborhood was razed for the project, which is now well under way.
Now that Mr. Wynn has withdrawn, "I get no pleasure in standing on a soapbox and saying I told you so," Mr. Langford said. "I think it's a tragedy that we as residents got snookered."
Fights on the council, where Mr. Langford and other minority members often clash with Mayor Whelan, have confounded some smaller development proposals. But most proceed through the Republican-dominated state agencies that direct casino tax dollars.
The casino reinvestment authority has provided millions for the huge new convention center, the Sandcastle baseball stadium, an ice rink and a marine museum, called the Ocean Life Center.
The agency is also helping to finance a shopping and entertainment complex in the gaping blocks between the convention center and the Boardwalk, where visitors are now greeted by a McDonalds and a Gulf station.
The project's developer, the Cordish Company of Baltimore, plans a 500,000-square-foot retail and entertainment complex. The company president, David Cordish, noted that with 425,000 square feet of retail space, Atlantic City is, to put it mildly, underserved; Las Vegas and Orlando each have 20 million square feet.
"With 37 million visitors," Mr. Cordish said, "shame on me if we can't give them something to do."
Mr. Cordish, who specializes in old urban sites resuscitated for tourism, said: "Baltimore's Inner Harbor took 25 years. For 20 years every dealing here was subsidized by the public sector. In the last five years private developers have moved in to do it themselves."
For businesses here, 25 years has imparted the lesson that Mr. Wynn himself once delivered to small-business owners in Bridgeport, Conn., where he had proposed a casino. "There is no reason on earth," he told them, "for any of you to expect for more than one second that just because there are people here, they're going to run into your store, or restaurant, or bar."
Todd Lovitz, who runs a T-shirt shop on the Boardwalk, knows that. Mr. Lovitz traces the decline to the mid-1980's, and when the new convention center opened in 1997, he said, his Pier 21 shop lost 40 percent to 50 percent of its convention business.
There were good years, and Mr. Lovitz's family opened successful shops in casinos. But on the Boardwalk they took hits: the $17,000-a-year rent on their women's clothing store doubled with the coming of the casinos, and they closed it.
The old Boardwalk Convention Hall is under renovation, but Mr. Lovitz wonders why the city let the retail climate deteriorate. "The Boardwalk should have been a priority," he said. "This is what people know, what people see.
"It's not that the people aren't here with money," he went on. "It's that people don't come out of the casinos. There's nothing for them to buy. If these were upscale stores, like in South Beach in Miami, it would work."
Ira Zelden, the owner of a pricey women's clothing store called Jules of Margate, ran shops at the Showboat and the Tropicana, then retreated to his suburban niche.
"You can't get them in a cocktail dress when they come in a nylon jogging suit," Mr. Zelden sighed. "Theres no marketing of this town. They want a working-class market, which is ridiculous. That is not who's spending the dollars, spending $7 or $8 a drink in bars."
From the beginning, the small-business owners were casualties. The Atlantic County Division of Economic Development charted one awful period, from December 1979 to September 1981, when the number of apparel shops in Atlantic City fell to 62 from from 116 and restaurants and bars to 191 from 240.
Mr. Persie said the casinos provided plenty of openings for those who adapted and got creative. But those who tried to market themselves to gamblers, he said, "got slaughtered."
Doris Grabel, who runs a supper club with here husband, Harry, and son, Mark, said, "I don't know if there's an answer to this," considering what gambling had done to and for her city. Grabels has survived and even expanded in its quiet residential corner of the city while the casinos raked in customers with free meals.
"When the first casinos came in, this place was dynamite," said Mrs. Grabel. "We were jammed with the executives and everything."
While the casinos still closed at 4 a.m., the workers poured in, but that business withered when they became 24-hour operations.
At the same time, the cost of doing business went up. With rising land values came rising taxes -- "they went up, way, way, up, and everybody still wants to know what they did with the money," Harry Grabel said. And there was a new 3 percent luxury tax on liquor.
The Grabels recovered, in part by starting a banquet business, and Mrs. Grabel does not regret the whole gambling experiment. "It brought a lot of people here," she said. "But I'm not talking about Atlantic City itself. Atlantic City is not booming."
While the bar filled with the Saturday-evening crowd of locals, Mrs. Grabel commiserated with Lois Saltzberg, whose children own a pharmacy nearby.
"It's a heartache," Mrs. Saltzberg said.
"It's a heartache," Mrs. Grabel echoed. "You have no nucleus; everybody moved out."
Christine Brown's view is different. Atlantic City is "absolutely" better than it was 10 years ago, said Ms. Brown, who runs a broadcast and video production business with her husband, Benjamen.
IT is so much better, she said, that two years ago they moved from Egg Harbor Township into the Ocean One mall, on a pier across from Caesars. The cost of space was half what it was in their old quarters, but their business quadrupled.
"You're just more visible being here, working here," said Ms. Brown, who is always darting into the casinos on business.
Like everyone else, though, she is antsy for the broader-based tourism that she says is incubating. "Starting with the convention center, things started to move on," she said. "If the city brings in non-casino hotels and family entertainment, I see a big boom here."
The Convention and Visitors Authority reports that about 20 percent of tourists stay overnight, a figure the authority desperately wants to increase. A survey it commissioned showed that about half of the total visitors came mostly to gamble, one-third to vacation and less than 10 percent to attend conventions.
The convention-goers are by far the most demographically desirable, with an average income of $71,300, compared with the gamblers' $46,800. And they are far more likely to pay full rates when they do stay in hotels.
But "there is a room issue," said Sarah Lindkrantz, the authority's vice president for marketing. "We need more rooms to expand the market."
The chairman of the Casino Control Commission, James R. Hurley, pays close attention to the hotel question, since, he said, the redevelopment of Atlantic City "is one of the reasons were here."
"Until they build more rooms here, the economists and analysts who look at it say it's not going to change much," Mr. Hurley said. "Las Vegas has more hotel rooms than New York and San Francisco put together."
He said he expected the marina district to eventually yield two new hotels. But, nodding over his shoulder, he added: "We used to have pictures all along the wall -- all the plans people talked about and never built."
James Crawford, the director of the South Jersey Transportation Authority, which is responsible for the tunnel project, said that the state's projections for development in the marina district were entirely on track.
He also defended the pace of building. "We will have gone from a raw concept to an open highway in six years," Mr. Crawford said. "That will be the fastest project undertaken in New Jersey in at least 30 years."
Mr. Perskie said the public sector's reconstruction of the city should pay off handsomely in the next decade, after "the languor of the 1980's came back to bite us in the backside in the 1990's."
But the industry that is supposed to return the favor is largely unimpressed.
"There are a lot of places competing for your capital," said Al Luciani, president of the Sands Casino Hotel. Mr. Luciani, who recently returned to Atlantic City after a decade, said it was still a "very difficult" place to do business.
And he, too, is waiting for something to tip. "It needs to be broadened," he said. "It needs to clean itself up, it needs broader attractions than just a dozen casinos."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Sara Wolfensohn, Carl Mayer

 BODY:
Sara Rachael Wolfensohn, a daughter of Elaine and James D. Wolfensohn of Washington and Manhattan, was married last Sunday to Carl Joseph Mayer, a son of Nancy Grant Mayer of New York and Prof. Arno J. Mayer of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan.
Miss Wolfensohn, who will continue to use her name professionally, is a concert pianist who performed most recently as a soloist with the American Youth Philharmonic with Leonard Slatkin at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. She graduated from the Juilliard School of Music, from which she also received master's degrees in music and in professional studies. She is the director of the Wolfensohn Family Foundation, a charitable trust based in Manhattan. 
 The bride's father is the president of the World Bank in Washington. He founded the Wall Street investment bank bearing his name and is a former chairman of Carnegie Hall and the Kennedy Center. Her mother is an educational adviser.
Mr. Mayer is a special counsel to the state attorney general in Manhattan. He graduated magna cum laude from Princeton University, received his law degree from the University of Chicago and a Master of Laws from Harvard University. His father is an emeritus professor of modern European history at Princeton and the author of a Holocaust study, "Why Did the Heavens Not Darken? The 'Final Solution' in History" (Pantheon Books, 1989). The bridegroom's mother is a freelance writer and author.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Atsuko Horiguchi, Ivar Andersen

 BODY:
Atsuko Horiguchi and Ivar Jorstad Andersen were married yesterday at Woodend, the headquarters of the Audubon Naturalist Society in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. George W. Evans, a Lutheran minister, officiated.
Ms. Horiguchi, 38, is keeping her name. She is a freelance consultant for Forum One Communications, an Internet company in Alexandria, Va. She received a bachelor's degree in international relations from Johns Hopkins University and a master's degree in public policy from Harvard University. She is a daughter of Reiko and Minoru Horiguchi of Kobe, Japan. Her mother teaches English and Japanese there. The bride's father retired as the managing director of Tomen, a multinational trading company, in Tokyo. 
 Mr. Andersen, 37, is the operations officer in the fund-raising department of the World Bank in Washington. He received a bachelor's degree in political science and journalism from the University of Minnesota and a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia University. He is a son of Ingeborg and Richard Andersen of Oslo. His parents are retired. His mother was a nurse, his father a chief engineer at the Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation in Oslo.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1094 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Zero Down, And Maybe Something To Gain

BYLINE: By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
WHILE house-hunting in Fayetteville, N.C., a few months ago, Suzanne and Curtis Walker found themselves in an enviable quandary: they had discovered the expansive ranch house they were dreaming of, yet were reluctant to sell their investments to buy it because the stock market was performing so well.
They managed to hang on to both the house and their portfolio -- by qualifying for a 30-year loan without having to put a penny down, aside from closing costs. 
 "We wanted to keep our money invested in a vehicle that we knew could appreciate at a better rate," said Mrs. Walker, 39. The couple's mutual fund portfolio has tripled in value in the last decade, to around $200,000.
With the economy strong and housing prices rising, more lenders have started offering mortgages that do not require down payments, though with rates a half to a full percentage point above those of conventional loans. The lenders also demand somewhat higher incomes and credit ratings, and some limit the loans to $600,000.
The lenders, facing more competition and a dwindling refinancing market because of higher interest rates, see zero-down loans as a way to attract a broader array of customers. Many of the borrowers are starting out in careers or, like the Walkers, have most of their assets tied up in investments.
Just a couple of years ago, zero-down loans were virtually impossible to find, aside from those offered through the Department of Veterans Affairs or a few brokerage firms willing to take securities as collateral. Although they remain chiefly a niche product, they are expected to be more prevalent during the spring and summer, said Keith Gumbinger, a vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage research firm in Butler, N.J. Already, they have been well-received in the secondary market, where mortgages are grouped and sold as securities by companies like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, experts say.
Mr. Gumbinger said that 62 percent of the 250 lenders that HSH surveyed in March had such loans, usually with a fixed rate for 15 or 30 years. The average rate on a 30-year zero-down loan was 9.05 percent, versus 8.42 percent on a conventional loan, according to the survey. Most banks also demand that borrowers putting less than 20 percent down buy private mortgage insurance.
Among major lenders now offering the zero-down loans are Countrywide Home Loans, GMAC Mortgage, Bank of America and Norwest, according to HSH, which provides a list on its Web site, www.hsh.com.
Dorcas Helfant, who runs Coldwell Banker-Helfant Realty in Virginia Beach, Va., estimates that about 3 percent of the buyers who deal with her office choose zero-down loans. "It's not a huge market program, but it's picking up steam," she said.
Down payments are typically the biggest barriers to home ownership, said Robert Brown, an executive vice president at Countrywide, which began offering zero-down mortgages in January, and where the Walkers obtained their mortgage. "The borrower may have the ability to make a mortgage payment," Mr. Brown said, "but coming up with the cash up front may be a problem."
Countrywide, based in Calabasas, Calif., markets three zero-down mortgages: a standard 30-year fixed-rate loan; a 103 percent loan, which finances the full purchase price plus 3 percent for closing costs; and an 80/20 loan, in which 80 percent is financed with a first mortgage and the remaining 20 percent from a second mortgage (or home equity line of credit), eliminating the need for private mortgage insurance.
THE Walkers, who got a 100 percent loan for $150,000 from Countrywide, at 8.5 percent, are among a growing number of borrowers with higher incomes who prefer to keep their wealth in stocks, bonds or options. Their household income is close to six figures; Mr. Walker is a command sergeant major in the Army, and Mrs. Walker is a mental health therapist.
"Someone may be worth hundreds of millions of dollars on paper but have no savings," Mr. Gumbinger said. "There's a lot of people who fit into that category in the Silicon Valley; the Internet made them rich."
Although not rich, Brian and Tanya Daniels had some money available to put down on an 1880 two-story farmhouse they bought recently in Bristolville, Ohio. But they chose instead to obtain a zero-down loan and use their savings for renovations. "It needed to be completely redone -- new electricity, new plumbing. We're tearing out walls," said Mr. Daniels, 27, a machine repair apprentice for Delphi Packard Electric Systems. He and his wife, a schoolteacher, received a 30-year, 103 percent loan for around $50,000, at 8.25 percent.
For Linda Bumpas, 32, a hospital office manager in Virginia Beach, the zero-down mortgage she received last spring enabled her and her two daughters to move out of a two-bedroom apartment and into a roomier, $69,900 town house. "The money that I saved allowed me to make home improvements and to buy furniture," she said.
Starting out with no home equity does not bother the Daniels couple or Ms. Bumpas. They expect to derive what mortgage experts call "instant equity" from their neighborhoods' rapid appreciation.
But what happens if housing values or the economy head south -- particularly if a homeowner has a huge mortgage and no appreciable equity? Experts like Peter G. Miller, author of "The Common Sense Mortgage" (Contemporary Books), warn that buyers who suddenly need to sell will face brokerage fees and related costs that they will have to pay out of pocket. "Where do you get the cash?" he asked.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, recently warned banks against risky loans, reminding them of losses that savings and loans and banks suffered in commercial real estate in the late 1980's.
Lenders say they impose tighter credit standards on borrowers who put nothing down. "We're not in the business to own property," said Mr. Brown at Countrywide, which looks for customers with slightly higher overall credit ratings and solid employment histories for zero-down loans.
James Grant, publisher of Grant's Interest Rate observer, has noted that lenders have become less risk-averse, a reflection of the healthy economy. But he said he was not concerned about zero-down loans posing a systemic risk to the banking industry, because they were still just a small market.
Besides, he said, 'people will do almost anything before losing their homes. That's not to say that this is a prudent method of proceeding for a bank, but a house is a pretty good collateral in all except the most severe downturn."
