HEADLINE: The Face of Teenage Sex Grows Younger

BYLINE: BY ANNE JARRELL 

 BODY:
ON the Upper West Side, Dr. Marsha Levy-Warren, a psychologist, said she is seeing more and more preteenagers who are going on junior versions of dates in fifth grade, at 10 or 11 years old. By seventh grade, they have graduated to sex.
"I can't tell you how many girls come in who are bereft about having had sex too soon," she said. "They went to a party, met a cute guy, he seemed to like them, they hooked up and did what they assumed everyone was doing. Then, they feel awful." 
 On the Upper East Side, Dr. Cynthia Pegler, a specialist in adolescent medicine, sees girls brought in by their mothers when they outgrow the pediatrician. These sophisticated young women may not be having intercourse at 13, but they are having oral sex. "They tell me oral sex is no big deal," Dr. Pegler said. "They don't see it as sex, but as safe and fun and a prelude to intercourse, where before, it used to be the other way around."
And in the suburbs, on Long Island, Dr. Wayne Warren, a psychologist, said groups of seventh and eighth graders rent limousines to take them to clubs in Manhattan, where they get drunk, grind on the dance floor and have oral sex in dim corners.
In a society that is always pushing the envelope, the age at which sexual experimentation begins is speeding up, too, say psychotherapists, health professionals and school officials, who are concerned about the health and emotional ramifications for young teenagers.
"There are significant numbers of youngsters who are engaging in sexual activity at earlier ages," said Dr. Robert W. Blum, a physician and the director of the division of general pediatrics and adolescent health at the University of Minnesota, which analyzes data on teenage sexual activity for the federal government. "Besides intercourse, they are engaging in oral sex, mutual masturbation, nudity and exposure as precursors to intercourse."
In data published by Dr. Blum and his team in the Journal of the American Medical Association in 1997, 17 percent of a national sample of thousands of seventh and eighth graders had had intercourse. Other, smaller studies put the percentage even higher.
"I see no reason not to believe that soon a substantial number of youths will be having intercourse in the middle-school years," said Dr. Richard Gallagher, director of the Parenting Institute at New York University's Child Study Center. "It's already happening."
Experts of all political and philosophical bents give many reasons for this phenomenon, including the rising divorce rate, inattentive parents, the availability of condoms and the earlier onset of puberty. But the most frequent explanation is that today's culture sends a very mixed message to its young.
On the one hand, bombarded by warnings about AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, adolescents are taught abstinence, the sole contraception method taught at one-third of all public schools across the country, according to a recent poll by the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a private research organization.
On the other hand, teenagers are confronted daily with a culture that has become a very sexy place indeed in which to live. "Sex is everywhere, and it's absolutely explicit," said Dr. Allen Waltzman, a psychiatrist with practices on the Upper East Side and in Brooklyn, who sees many adolescents. "There's hardly a film that doesn't show a man and a woman having sex. There's MTV, lurid rap lyrics, and now we've got technosex on the Internet."
None of this is lost on young adolescents, Dr. Waltzman said. "Kids always push to the limit of what's permitted in a society."
One 13-year-old boy at a junior high school in Manhattan said he first had oral sex at 12 and has had it about eight times at parties and in the hours between 4 p.m. and 7, before parents come home from work. The sex was never with a steady girlfriend, because he has never had one. "It's something to do with someone," he said. "I think it's curiosity. I don't think that's bad."
An eighth-grade private-school boy said that he and his friends know that oral sex "is not perfect," but that they believe there is less likelihood of picking up a sexually transmitted disease than with intercourse. "The schools tell us to refrain, they tell us you get S.T.D.'s from both, but no one believes it," he said.
Dr. Warren, who practices in Manhattan as well as in Suffolk County, said: "Before, the dialogue was, 'I love you and care for you, so let's experiment.' Now, the dialogue is, 'This is safe and fun and O.K., and you have nothing to worry about.'
"I see girls, seventh and eighth graders, even sixth graders, who tell me they're virgins, and they're going to wait to have intercourse until they meet the man they'll marry. But then they've had oral sex 50 or 60 times. It's like a goodnight kiss to them, how they say goodbye after a date."
There are no in-depth studies showing national trends in sexual activity in middle school, ages 10 to 13. No one will finance such studies, Dr. Blum said, because of fear of the outcry from politicians who embrace an abstinence-only message and from parents wanting to protect their children's privacy.
The studies of national trends that do exist look only at high school students. These show a striking drop decade by decade in the age at which teenagers first engage in intercourse. A December 1999 study by the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University noted that in the early 1970's, less than 5 percent of 15-year-old girls and 20 percent of 15-year-old boys had engaged in sexual intercourse. By 1997, the figures were 38 percent for girls, 45 percent for boys.
In the wake of AIDS and of abstinence advocacy, statistics from the 1990's analyzed by the Guttmacher Institute show that the age by which a majority of teenagers had engaged in intercourse has not continued to fall. The teenage birthrate has been falling since 1991, in part, experts say, because of decreased sexual activity. (It is still the highest for the developed world.) The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta reports that among high school students of all ages, those who have had sex declined from 53 percent in 1995 to 48.4 percent in 1997, the latest year for which figures are available.
But Dr. Gallagher said that the apparent diminishing of high school sexual activity masks a more insidious development: some older teenagers may be extending their years of virginity, but some younger teenagers are having sex earlier.
"You can get 16- to 18-year-olds who will be very conservative sexually," Dr. Gallagher said. "And then you can get right below them a group of 14- to 16-year-olds who say those older students are too conservative, let's party."
Despite the paucity of data about young teenagers, educators say that the anecdotal evidence points to increased sexual activity, often of a detached, unemotional kind.
"The kids are overwhelmed with sexual messages, and we're seeing a younger and younger display of not only precocious sexual behavior but also aggressive sexual molestation, like holding down a student and forcibly pulling down his or her pants," said Dr. Frederick Kaeser, the director of health services for District 2 of the New York public school system, covering much of Manhattan.
"We do a terrible job of teaching sex education," he added.
One boy, 13, who attends a private school in Manhattan, said his interest in sex began in the third grade, watching "Beverly Hills 90210," the television show that portrayed teenagers from well-off families in the boom economy behaving like adults. "I was interested," he said. "The people were cool. I wanted to try what they were doing on the show."
He, along with half a dozen of his friends, described a timetable for sexual initiation. By third grade, they knew the slang for activities from masturbation to oral sex. By fourth grade, they had girlfriends and were playing kissing games. By fifth, they were going on dates. In sixth, they were French kissing and petting. In seventh and eighth grades, they tried oral sex, and some had intercourse.
By ninth grade, one boy said, "it's just one big spree of going all the way."
The head of their school said she thought they were accurate in their timetable.
Asked if they felt things were going too fast, the boys shrugged. "It has to happen sooner or later," the 13-year-old said. "Sex is pleasurable. Why not now? Sometimes people get hurt. Sure. I've been hurt. But that's going to happen at any age."
Psychiatrists and psychologists, however, say that most young teenagers cannot handle the profound feelings that go with early sex. "Developmentally, they just aren't ready," Dr. Levy-Warren said. "They're trying to figure out who they are, and unlike adults who obsess first and then act, kids do the opposite -- they act and then obsess. They jump into this, and are left with intense feelings they're unable to sort out."
What's most troubling to Dr. Levy-Warren and others is a new casual, brazen attitude about sex. "I call it body-part sex," she said. "The kids don't even look at each other. It's mechanical, dehumanizing. The fallout is that later in life they have trouble forming relationships. They're jaded. "
While New York middle-school educators and counselors say they are increasingly concerned about earlier sexual activity, particularly oral sex, no one is clear on what to do about it. After Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez was fired in 1993, in part for introducing a condom-distribution program, the New York public schools have settled into a sex education curriculum that's a mixed bag of preaching, basic anatomy and, in high school, condom distribution, though parents can choose to keep their children from participating.
Even at New York's private schools, not concerned with federal guidelines, which since 1996 have allocated millions of dollars to sex education programs that teach only abstinence, ambivalence reigns. At Friends Seminary in downtown Manhattan, parents were called to a meeting two years ago after students in a fifth grade class began pairing off and breaking up, and "the misery factor was high," said Pamela Wood, the head of the middle school. There was no consensus among the adults. Half were appalled at the prospect of 10-year-olds dating. The other half thought it was cute.
"In elementary school, everyone pretty much has the same agenda," Ms. Wood said. "By middle school, no one agrees on what is appropriate. As for parents, their egos can get entangled. They want their kids to be liked, and if dating is what it requires, then they're for it."
The sex education curriculum at Friends includes practice exercises in how to put on a condom for eighth graders and free condom distribution in high school, but there is disagreement about distributing condoms with fruit flavoring, for use during oral sex.
At the Dalton School on the Upper East Side, concern about the precocious sexual climate led this year to starting a sex education program for the fifth grade, where none had existed so early before.
Dr. Glenn Stein, the middle-school psychologist, said that the program is mostly anatomy. "A little inoculation, I would call it," he said. "It's not enough, but it's a start."
What the fast-sex scene means to girls, as opposed to boys, is of particular concern to school psychologists, who mentioned holding discussions and seminars on gender issues. Deborah Tolman, a director at the Wellesley College Center for Research on Women, points out that anecdotal evidence indicates that when it comes to oral sex, "the boys are getting it, the girls no."
"It's the heterosexual script that entitles boys and disables girls," she said.
Most psychologists say that what is needed is not just to supply youngsters with facts and information about anatomy, but also to provide them with forums to explore their feelings and to digest the proliferation of sexual messages they receive. As Francesca Schwartz, a school psychologist at the Brearley School, a private school for girls on the Upper East Side, put it: "Do I really like this person? Or am I just doing this to be popular? These are the questions the kids need to learn to think about and ask."
Such discussions should come sooner rather than later, educators say. "Preteens in our culture are 8 and 9," said Dr. Ava L. Siegler, a psychologist and the author of "The Essential Guide to the New Adolescence." "We shouldn't wait to talk to them about AIDS, sex and violence until they are 12."
Dr. Waltzman added: "To kids, their crushes and loves are the most important thing. Adults may see it as silly or irrelevant, but the kids don't. It does no good to leave them to figure it out on their own."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Jackson W. Robinson;
Green Century Balanced Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
WHEN he's not at work, or sailing in Maine's Penobscot Bay in a Wianno Senior -- a 25-foot-long wooden-hulled sloop -- Jackson W. Robinson tends to the organic vegetables in his garden.
That is no surprise, given that he is the child of "green" parents, Ed and Carolyn Robinson. During World War II, they wrote "The Have-More Plan," a back-to-nature tome that is still in print. (Storey Books, $9.95) 
 Mr. Robinson, 57, is manager of the $50.1 million Green Century Balanced fund, which invests only in companies that he deems to be environmentally friendly. But that is not all. Profits from the fund are passed on to a consortium of advocacy groups -- mostly public interest research groups -- that own the fund's adviser, Green Century Capital Management, through a partnership. The money is used for litigation, research and educational programs.
Investors, meanwhile, are rolling in green. The fund returned 42.2 percent a year, on average, for the three years through March 24. That compares with 36.8 percent for one of its peer groups, small growth funds, and 13.6 percent for balanced funds, according to Morningstar Inc.
Mr. Robinson divides the universe of 10,000 publicly traded United States stocks into three categories -- what he calls "the greens, the cleans and the dirties."
"A green company is part of the environmental solution," said Mr. Robinson. "Clean companies, like those in financial and health care, don't contribute either to the solution or the problem. Dirty companies have high levels of waste streams, Superfund sites or environmental litigation."
He avoids companies associated with fossil fuels, tobacco, weaponry and nuclear power.
To pick the fund's three dozen or so stocks, he looks for small- to mid-cap growth companies with returns on equity of more than 15 percent and annual earnings growth of at least 20 percent. These companies tend to be market leaders, he said, and tend to have successful new products, services or technology.
Mr. Robinson likes to examine a company's ratio of sales to capital expenditures. The multiple varies by industry, he said, but big ratios flag companies that tend to use capital efficiently.
He also seeks earnings catalysts like new management or products, heavy spending on research and development or a shift to higher-growth businesses. He is de-emphasizing quantitative measurements like price-to-earnings ratios, he said, "because we have such major deviations in the market."
The fund's prospectus states that the portfolio will generally keep at least 25 percent of its assets in bonds or cash. It now holds 16 fixed-income issues, mostly junk bonds. He favors short-term issues, because interest rates are rising; the average duration of the fund's bonds is just under five years, and they yield 9.5 percent, on average.
Mr. Robinson sees value in what he calls the emerging energy group, companies that make and service solar and wind power projects and fuel cells. The group's revenue and profits are growing at 20 to 40 percent a year, he said. He is also bullish on the natural and organic food industry, which is seeing sales and earnings growth of 15 to 20 percent a year, versus 3 to 4 percent for traditional grocery stores.
ONE favorite is United Natural Foods of Dayville, Conn., a rapidly growing distributor of natural and organic foods. Mr. Robinson bought shares at $10 to $11 in December; the price had tumbled from nearly $30 in February 1999 because of what he called an ill-managed acquisition.
In early 1999, he said, the manager in charge of the company's successful Western division, Michael S. Funk, became chief executive. Mr. Funk, he said, had already fixed many problems arising from the merger, so Mr. Robinson has confidence in him.
Mr. Robinson expects shares to trade in the $25-to-$30 range over the next 12 to 18 months; he predicts earnings growth of 16 to 17 percent a year, on average, over three years. The stock now trades at $15, or 13 times his earnings estimate of $1.15 a share for 2001.
Another favorite is Astropower of Newark, Del., an independent manufacturer of solar modules and panels and photovoltaic cells. The company has cut production costs, Mr. Robinson said, by building modules on an assembly line; it uses silicon discarded by semiconductor makers.
About 80 percent of the company's sales are overseas. "Europe is far ahead of the U.S. in terms of alternative energy and wind," he said, adding that the company is working on new applications like solar-powered cellular phones and hand-held computers.
He bought shares at $6 at the initial offering in March 1998. The stock now trades at $32.3125, or 42 times his 2001 earnings estimate of 75 cents a share. He predicts earnings growth of 50 percent, annualized, over three years; his 12- to 18-month price target for the stock is $50.
Mr. Robinson bought shares of Uniroyal Technology of Sarasota, Fla., at $36 in January. The company, spun off from Uniroyal Tire, sold a business that produces high-quality plastics in February and plans to divest its remaining small plastics operations. It makes bright, long-lasting light-emitting diodes, or L.E.D.'s, that are replacing incandescent bulbs used in traffic lights because they use less power, Mr. Robinson said. "Ultimately," he added, "we will see L.E.D. used in buildings, significantly decreasing the demand for electricity." The devices can also be used in flat-panel computers and home electronics, he said.
He expects the company to break even in 2001 and sees earnings of $2 to $3 a share in 2003. The stock trades at $47; his 12- to 18-month price target is $100.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
Where the Armorers No Longer Thrive

BYLINE: By PETER S. GREEN 

DATELINE: VODOCHODY, Czech Republic

 BODY:
THE roar of a jet engine rumbles across the stubbly wheat fields near Boeing's Aero Vodochody factory here on the outskirts of Prague, as a Czech test pilot puts an L-159 fighter-trainer through its paces.
The Czech Republic is a new NATO member, and the L-159, a product of Czech engineering and labor, is equipped to NATO standards, carrying the latest electronics and weapons. By all accounts, it is a good, inexpensive plane. 
 But despite a multiyear, multimillion-dollar sales drive, Aero has orders for just 72 planes, all from the Czech Air Force. The spacious production hall that once assembled 30 fighters a month now turns out just 4.
The Czechs have a long tradition of military manufacturing. After conquering Czechoslovakia, Hitler used Czech tanks made at the Skoda works in Plzen to invade France. In the Communist era, some of the Warsaw Pact's best weapons were made in Central Europe. When the Warsaw Pact collapsed in 1990, though, so did the markets for Eastern arms makers, as the world was flooded with surplus East bloc weapons and the East lowered its defenses.
Even the entry last year into NATO of the Czechs, Poles and Hungarians has failed to revive the fortunes of the local manufacturers.
"There was a misapprehension at the end of the cold war that these industries would become engines of growth," said Michael Brzoska, research director at the Bonn International Center for Conversion, which studies the effects of Europe's military cutbacks. Instead, he said, shrinking economies and smaller armies gave the manufacturers no chance to retool.
"I don't see any good prospects for any of those countries," said Clifford Beal, editor of Jane's Defense Weekly, noting that exports to Soviet-era allies have also dried up.
Nor can the manufacturers find markets at home. NATO wants new members to concentrate on matters like computers and teaching NATO tactics to soldiers. Fancy weapons can come later. And with reason: the Czechs have only three combat-ready battalions, the Hungarians two and Poland about five.
Changing sides after the cold war also hurt. Tesla Pardubice, a Czech electronics company, developed a passive radar to detect American stealth bombers. But with the United States no longer a threat here, the only potential buyers were countries like Iran, Iraq, Libya and Yugoslavia, and now Tesla is in bankruptcy.
"Whenever we wanted to sell it, our American friends were against it," said Jiri Pisklak, managing director of the Czech Association of Defense Producers.
MOREOVER, while military industries in the West have diversified into civilian production, there have been few spinoffs here. Despite a wealth of engineering talent, Mr. Beal said, the Easterners lack home-grown business skills. "In the era of leveraging brain power into business power," he said, "they can't make the jump."
The Bonn Center estimates that arms employment in Poland fell from 260,000 in 1985 to 70,000 in 1998, and in the Czech Republic from 30,000 in 1993 to 18,000 in 1998.
"The question for these countries is: Do they pick up as a supplier, a link in the chain, or do they go bust? They cannot stand alone," said Digby Waller, defense economist at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.
At Aero, Boeing has chosen the supplier route. Over 70 percent of the L-159 comes from outside the Czech Republic, mainly from the United States, and today the plant assembles airframes out of components made elsewhere.
"Realistically, companies of our size need to be involved in joint development and production," said Aero's president, Scott L. White. "Our niche is airframe structure -- from design through the delivery of parts."
But even with American management and marketing skill behind it, the L-159 is a tough sell. Britain, Italy, Russia, China and Brazil all build similar planes. In recent months Aero has lost contracts to Britain's BAE Systems and to the Chinese.
Those deals, however, were lost for precisely the same reasons that Boeing bought Aero.
To secure sales, manufacturers routinely promise vast investments in local industry or local production to help client states offset the cost of the weapons. In South Africa, BAE not only offered its Hawk trainers, but also promised to build a deep-water port and to construct water filtration plants in black townships.
Mr. White says there is a worldwide market for 100 planes a year like the L-159. But the Czech government, short of cash, is unable to help underwrite deals like BAE's sale to South Africa. And as a Boeing subsidiary bound by American laws on business deals, Aero shies away from offsets that may appear unrelated to building airplanes.
"Our key frustration and our key problem is that we can't promise things we can't fulfill," Mr. White said.
With Western companies close to selling jet fighters to the Czechs, Poles and Hungarians to replace their aging MiG's -- a multibillion-dollar prospect -- those local manufacturers that can fit into the supply chain may see some new orders; those that cannot will see sales slide further.
The fighter sale is largely why Boeing bought 35 percent of Aero for about $30 million last year, in a deal that also won Boeing a contract to supply more 737's to Czech Airlines.
"Boeing did not come to the Czech Republic to make a return on investment," Mr. White said. "It was looking instead toward opportunities for other commercial and military sales."
The Czechs alone want up to 36 supersonic fighters, worth a potential $2 billion. Poland could buy up to 72 planes and Hungary about 30.
Lockheed Martin wants to sell the F-16, the workhorse of the United States Air Force; Boeing wants to sell the F/A-18, used primarily by the Navy and Kuwait; and BAE and Saab want to sell their Gripen fighter, so far used only by Sweden.
That has left NATO authorities slightly dismayed. "We are not telling them to buy aircraft," an officer from a NATO country said. "We say first fix things like personnel."
But like Boeing, the other Western fighter builders are sweetening their offers to Eastern European defense ministries with promises to bail out local arms makers. All are looking at ways to make parts locally, and BAE is offering to fully offset the cost of a fleet of Gripens by investing an equivalent amount in the purchasing country.
Does that mean the jets are free, as many East Europeans seem to think? No, said BAE's regional director, Julian Scopes; the offsetting investments must make sense on their own, and though they will benefit the host country's economy, they generally will not put anything close to the cost of the jets back into government coffers in the short term.
Mr. White, meanwhile, faces another challenge: competing with bargain-basement equipment available on the secondary market, including his own company's unsold inventory.
Russia, he said, is selling used jet trainers similar to Aero's L-39, the L-159's predecessor, for less than $100,000. By contrast, L-159's cost $12 million to $15 million apiece. Behind the Aero factory, Mr. White shows a visitor an L-39 painted in desert camouflage. Twenty-nine L-39 jets were built for Nigeria, which never took delivery of them. Twelve were eventually sold to Yemen, but 17 more sit in hangars, awaiting a new buyer.
"I'll sell it to you for a half a million dollars," Mr. White offers, only half-jokingly.

HEADLINE: REPORT ON EXECUTIVE PAY;
J.C. Penney Bosses in Stock Bind

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
MANAGEMENT experts and institutional investors constantly lobby American executives to own more stock in the companies they run. Unlike options -- which, at worst, are worth nothing -- ownership of actual shares brings a downside. When investors lose money, so do the people running the company.
In a year when many old-economy stocks declined, that danger became real for top executives. Few lost as much as the bosses at J.C. Penney, the giant retailer, whose stock lost more than half its value during 1999. 
 Most companies require chief executive to own stock worth three to five times their annual salary, said James A. Hatch, an executive vice president at the Compensation Resource Group, a pay consulting firm in New York. Penney is more aggressive. Its chief executive, James E. Oesterreicher, must own seven times his annual salary, according to the company's most recent proxy. The ratio declines for lower-level executives, down to one and a half times salary for store managers.
In 1998, the most recent year's proxy available for Penney, Mr. Oesterreicher made $612,000. He did not own quite seven times that in early 1999, but he did hold about 80,000 shares, worth about $3 million at the time. (The shares had been worth about $4 million only a few months before.)
Today, however, with J.C. Penney's stock trading at $14.875, 80,000 shares would be worth just $1.19 million. If Mr. Oesterreicher received no raise last year and still holds 80,000 shares today, he would have to buy an additional 200,000 to comply with the company's policy. Through a spokeswoman, he declined to comment.
Many other chief executives find themselves in similar predicaments. Coca-Cola, Eastman Kodak, Sara Lee and Sears, Roebuck all have stock ownership policies, and all saw their price drop in 1999. To follow their own rules, executives there would have to do some serious value investing -- or persuade their boards to hand over thousands of free shares. DAVID LEONHARDT

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Filling Seats With Online Discounts

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
TICKET discounts for online customers, already favored by the airlines for filling empty seats, are rapidly spreading to sports -- and entertainment might be next. But the same technology that allows discounts is also likely to allow higher prices for some of the sports and entertainment seats that everyone wants.
The New Jersey Nets of the National Basketball Association offer discounts to anyone who signs up for "Nets News" online bulletins. Last week, the team offered $50 seats to today's Detroit Pistons game for $20, and $25 seats for $17. 
 Since last season, Texas Rangers followers who signed up on the Web for the baseball team's fan club, Inside Pitch, have received e-mail offers of steep discounts. Hockey fans get similar breaks from the Dallas Stars.
"It's incredibly successful," said Jeff Cogan, executive vice president of the Southwest Sports Group, a company led by the Dallas investor Thomas O. Hicks that owns the Stars and Rangers. Aided by data from online sales, Mr. Cogan is also considering higher ticket prices for games on weekends or against popular rivals for the Stars this fall and for the Rangers next year.
The rapid growth of online ticket sales makes it much easier for sports teams or entertainment companies to gather data and set prices according to demand. The newest technology will let online buyers print their own tickets rather than having to wait for them to arrive by mail or pick them up at box offices.
Later this month, fans attending sports events at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, the First Union Center in Philadelphia and 22 other sites will be among the first in the nation to use tickets they printed on their own computers. Within a year, that capability is likely to spread to wired patrons of most major theater chains, stadiums, arenas and performing arts centers. The resulting convenience is expected to help raise online ticket sales from $300 million last year to $4 billion by 2004, according to Forrester Research.
Sports and entertainment executives are already debating whether they are entering a new era of pricing seats according to demand. W. Thomas Gimble, chief executive of Tickets.com, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., which has formed partnerships with the Stars and the Rangers, has no doubts. "When you can print your own tickets, it busts apart the old rules of selling," he said.
But sports teams, promoters and entertainers, fearful of alienating their fans, are proceeding cautiously, especially in raising prices. In November, Tickets.com began auctioning some prime seats for Elton John and Backstreet Boys concerts at an average of 45 percent over face value, but the extra proceeds go to charity.
Operators of movie theaters and some concert halls are openly skeptical. Mark Pascucci, a senior vice president of Loews Cineplex Entertainment, which has 2,900 screens, says that discounted movie tickets for some shows would only steal audiences from others. "There's no practical reason for this," he said.
Loews is joining Regal, Edwards and other theater chains to begin an online ticketing service this summer. Movietickets.com, based in Boca Raton, Fla., and owned by the National Amusements theater chain, AMC Theaters and CBS, plans to begin selling movie tickets online over Memorial Day weekend. Both groups intend to let filmgoers print their tickets at home, beginning in December. To attract customers, they will forgo service charges for at least six months.
Tickets printed at home on standard paper and printers will include bar codes that can be scanned by readers at theaters and stadiums. The printouts might also include driving directions, seating charts, parking coupons or restaurant advertisements.
THE Rangers and the Stars, however, intend to go a step further, using software from Talus Solutions of Atlanta that helps airlines and hotels gauge demand and set their rates. Marriott International uses Talus software to set as many as 10 different rates for identical hotel rooms.
Stadium and team owners are especially eager to fill empty seats, because so much of their revenue comes from food, drink and souvenirs. "To those owners, it's a big deal, regardless of what patrons pay for the tickets," said Tom R. Madison, president of Talus Solutions.
The Rangers, wanting to fill some of the 15,000 seats that, on average, remain empty in their stadium, are also offering breaks like free extra tickets or coupons for discounted food and beverages to frequent ticket buyers. "Baseball is the perfect opportunity to introduce dynamic pricing because so many seats go unsold," said Mr. Gimble of Tickets.com.
Mr. Gimble's company also expects to allow ticket buyers to print their own tickets beginning this summer for some of its 4,100 other sites, which include the theaters at Lincoln Center. But sports teams are more likely to adopt variable pricing than the entertainment industry, Mr. Gimble said.

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
Bewitched and Bothered by an Oil Cartel

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AT first I thought it was just a silly infatuation -- you know, the thrill of forbidden love in an age when hardly any love is really forbidden. But I couldn't get it out of my head, and I grew tired of hiding it. Now I want the whole world to know that, for a brief shining moment, I was in love, madly in love, with OPEC.
I know it seems crazy, a middle-aged American with a gaping gas tank hankering after a profit-hungry oil cartel. Keeping a long-distance relationship vital and fresh is no picnic, and heaven knows OPEC has never been much for sweet talk. 
 In the end, of course, my friends were right. The whole thing ended in tears when my beloved oil ministers caved in at their meeting last week and agreed to increase production, leaving shards of my broken heart on the conference table.
Oh, OPEC, how did I love thee? Let me count the ways.
Your most endearing quality was your power. You're the only force on earth strong enough to make Americans ease up on a fossil-fuel habit so severe that it threatens the planet with ruinous global warming. (This, though, you dismiss so charmingly on your vain little Web site, www.opec.org.)
If you had just kept the lid on, higher gas prices might finally have made some of us park our bloated sport utility vehicles and rethink our plans to live in 5,000-square-foot houses. At the very least, you might have inspired enough energy conservation to make a dent in the air pollution that kills 50,000 Americans a year. And by making us drive less, your tough love might have saved some of the 41,000 who die on the roads.
That is to say nothing of what your tough love might have done for Americans' fitness. I don't mean that we would have worked out and slimmed down just to please you; we're much too lazy to do that for anyone. But if you had made gasoline expensive enough, some of us might at least have started walking more (remember walking?), even if only to McDonald's.
I dreamed of a long-term commitment. I wanted to be able to trust you to reduce output permanently and thereby help stop all the terrible sprawl we're always complaining about. The whole pattern of land use in this country is based on cheap energy, and whatever we may say about it, we really have no plans to stop randomly replacing bucolic vistas with strip malls. You could have been our knight in shining armor, the one who saved us from the suburbs that ate civilization.
Your pattern of secretiveness, always thrilling in an affair like ours, was another plus. Love means never having to tell the American people that, adjusted for inflation, gas is actually cheaper today than it was in 1960. Americans need something to get worked up about; faced with seven long months of Bush vs. Gore, pump prices make a wonderful diversion.
Ah, but dearest OPEC, you have already betrayed my hopes, so I might as well confess. Before I fell for you, my heart used to go pitter-patter for a certain Federal Reserve chairman who seemed to have the whole economy in his hands.
Sorry, Mr. Greenspan, but you're nothing next to these exotic oil men. All you can do is fiddle with short-term interest rates. By raising oil prices, my favorite cartel can fire a laser-guided smart bomb precisely at the most tax-worthy part of the economy this side of cigarettes. Because we lack the discipline to impose sharply higher taxes on gasoline, the most socially destructive fossil fuel, we were lucky to have OPEC to do the job for us.
Of course, the cartel kept the money -- it was entitled to something for playing the bad guy, no? But at least we got the economic benefits, which ought to have included the slower economy that you, Mr. Greenspan, have been pining for. If only OPEC had stayed the course. (Sigh.)
Now it looks like prices will flatten out and that the gas tax will stay as it is. But I haven't given up all hope. Sometimes, when I remember the land yachts of my youth arrayed in block-long gas lines, I think wistfully of what might have been. I dream again that my wild and crazy energy hegemonists will take up the lance anew, twisting down the wellhead valves and rescuing us from our own worst enemies -- ourselves.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Asian Values, Trumped By the New Economy

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
WHATEVER happened to "Asian values?"
With the unexpectedly rapid revival of most of the economies in East Asia, you would think that there would be a lot more talk again in the region about the hardy superiority of Asia's often more authoritarian and centralized approach to fostering economic growth and running governments. 
 But the avatars of Asian values -- Lee Kuan Yew, the patriarch and former prime minister of Singapore, and Mohathir Mohamad, the prime minister of Malaysia -- who were once so outspoken about the dangers of individualism and the cultural failings of the West, have barely been heard from lately. And few in Asia are listening these days to sermons on "Asian" virtues of thrift, strong extended families, personal connections and deference to elders. Instead, the continent has fallen in love with the Internet.
On a recent trip to Tokyo, Shanghai, Hong Kong and Jakarta, I was struck repeatedly by the widespread enthusiasm for doing business on the Web. The mania for the few dot-com stocks aimed at the Asian market is just the most visible sign. More profound is how quickly Asia's leaders are realizing that they can't flourish in the new economy by doing business as usual.
"We have no choice but to adapt an Asian version of the American model of openness and entrepreneurialism," said Victor Fung, chairman of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council. "Fortunately, that's where Hong Kong already has an advantage."
Yet even in China, where the freewheeling Internet threatens the monolithic power of the Communist Party, the government solidly backs building the infrastructure of a wired economy.
"China needs the Internet more than any other country in the world," said Peter Yip, chief executive of China.com, a Hong-Kong company of which the Beijing government is part-owner. "It's the only way to catch up with the rest of the global economy."
Indeed, the emergence of the Internet is empowering a new generation of Chinese entrepreneurs and luring home some of China's best and brightest who have been studying and working abroad. One evening in Shanghai, at an upscale Western-style restaurant called M on the Bund, I had dinner with three young Chinese entrepreneurs involved in various online ventures. From our table on the seventh floor of a neoclassical stone office building built by foreigners before World War II, we were able to look across the Huangpu River to dozens of modern glass skyscrapers in the sprawling Pudong industrial and commercial area.
The conversation, ranging from media gossip to contemporary art to business strategies, could as easily have taken place in Manhattan, London or Tokyo. Yes, these Web pioneers represent only a thin slice of a tiny elite, but they are likely to be a wedge that helps open China to the wider world.
"In the United States, I'm just another smart tech guy," said Bo Y. Shao, founder and chairman of Eachnet.com, which is trying to introduce a new form of person-to-person e-commerce to China. "Here in Shanghai, my skills are unique."
Mr. Shao, 26, a Shanghai-born math whiz, went to Harvard to study, but returned to China last year to build Eachnet fromscratch. While he adapts his business model to the vagaries of what is still a primitive economic environment, he is raising money abroad and planning a public offering.
EVEN more than in America, the online explosion in China is a challenge to the Asian business establishment, which has been on the defensive since the Asian financial crisis broke in 1997. In the mainstream economy and to some extent online, many leading businesses -- and some spectacular failures -- are little more than the long shadows of powerful families. Ownership and responsibility is closely held at the top, mostly by fathers, sons and brothers. "Guanxi," or connections that sometimes spill over into corruption, are an essential element of the complex dance between business and government elites.
"Family businesses, crony businesses -- they all have to share power and be restructured to be competitive," said Jimmy Lai, chairman of Next Media, a publishing company that is becoming a multimedia content provider and e-commerce vehicle. "The Internet has democratized business. It will inevitably democratize Asian economies."
There is a lot of hype associated with Internet ventures in Asia, of course, just as there is in the United States. And there are plenty of places in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand where basic development remains frozen and the Web is a distant dream.
Still, as the region resumes its economic race, the idea that Asia is fundamentally different has lost its resonance. The information technology revolution is liberalizing an already liberal West; the more traditional East seems destined for the same.

HEADLINE: REPORT ON EXECUTIVE PAY;
In the Options Age, Rising Pay (and Risk)

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
BY any reasonable measure, the final year of the 1900's was a fantastically lucrative time to be the chief executive of a major American corporation.
After a decade of seemingly limitless pay increases, the average compensation for chief executives shot up an additional 23 percent, to $11.9 million, last year. Valuing stock options in the most widely used way, a chief executive now makes more in a single day than the typical American worker does in a year. Thanks to stock and options from previous years, the average corporate leader has squirreled away holdings worth an additional $75 million, at recent market prices. 
 It is said virtually every spring, as public companies publish the documents detailing their senior executives' pay, but it bears repeating: These numbers are enormous, far higher than anything any society has ever paid a group of employees.
And yet there is one comparison that makes the average chief executive look practically bourgeois.
That, of course, is the pay of the people at the helm of the smaller, younger and generally far less familiar technology companies at the heart of the so-called new economy. On average, they made $27 million last year, including salary and the estimated current value of the stock options they received. They have accumulated $720 million more in equity, on average -- almost 10 times the holdings of the bosses of old-line companies, according to an analysis conducted for Money & Business by Executive Compensation Advisory Services, an Alexandria, Va., publisher of pay data.
The study examined the pay of the chief executives of 100 of America's largest nontechnology companies and 60 of the leading new-economy concerns, from America Online to PurchasePro.com, an operator of business-to-business Web marketplaces. Unlike most studies of executive pay, the survey also compared the most common method of estimating the value of stock options with the one that arguably influences executive behavior the most: the options' value based on the current stock price.
The results, along with interviews with pay consultants, executives and recruiters, point to the single largest force shaping compensation at the top of the economy today: the dichotomy between old-economy and new-economy stocks.
Technology shares are notoriously volatile, and they have cratered in the last few days. But their gains over the last year remain stunning, with the Nasdaq composite index up 83 percent. Much of the rest of the market, over that period, has stalled. As a result, hundreds of executives at some of America's best-known companies, like J.C. Penney, Xerox and Mattel, find the bulk of their recent stock option grants worthless -- "under water," in the parlance of executive pay -- at least for now.
And that, as the headlines announce daily, has created an executive class more receptive than ever to the lure of the digital economy. "The giant sucking sound you hear is all of the talent in America rushing to the Internet," said Alan M. Johnson, the president of Johnson Associates, a New York pay consulting firm.
THE exodus has left many companies desperate to retain top managers. It has also given executives -- whether in the new economy or the old, at companies with soaring or plummeting stock prices -- more leverage to demand unheard-of sums.
Traditional companies are increasing how much pay they package in the form of salary, bonus and restricted stock -- or anything else that, unlike stock options, still has value when a share price declines. "When the market is up, executives all want equity," said James A. Hatch, an executive vice president at Compensation Resource Group, a pay adviser. "When the market is down, they all say, 'The market has nothing to do with the performance of this company.' "
New-economy companies, meanwhile, have found that piles of options are no longer enough, as sought-after executives have become savvier about the high failure rates in the dot-com world and the unpredictability of Internet stock prices. At public Internet companies, the salary and bonus of chief executives who are hired hands, not founders, rose about 15 percent last year, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers -- a gain that put their cash pay at about $450,000.
Occasionally, top executives who bolt to dot-coms can even get guarantees protecting them against reversals of fortune. Joseph Galli, who left Black & Decker in June to become president of Amazon.com, received almost two million stock options -- and a promise that Amazon would make up the difference if they were not worth at least $20 million by 2003.
All in all for top executives, 1999 became an updated version of the old saw about the coin flip: Heads, I'm really wealthy; tails, I'm fabulously wealthy.
To be sure, much of that wealth remains on paper, particularly for the Internet bosses. If the Web market is truly a bubble, and if that bubble is near the point of bursting, many could find themselves deep under water without a lifeline. But the lure remains for old-economy executives. Just last week, Patricia Fili-Krushel left as president of the ABC television network to join Healtheon/WebMD, an Internet health care company. In August, Daniel H. Schulman jumped from AT&T to Priceline.com as president; in February, he was joined by Heidi G. Miller, who defected from Citigroup to become chief financial officer. Andersen Consulting, Federal Express and Nike have lost high-profile managers, as well.
The departures have left old-economy companies looking for pay strategies to help them stem the tide and motivate the people left behind. "There's a lot of panic out there," said Ira T. Kay, who oversees the executive compensation group of Watson Wyatt Worldwide. "Morale at these companies is just in the toilet."
Even with the revival of interest in many old economy stocks in recent weeks, some 54 percent of companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 closed on Friday at prices lower than a year earlier. The market in old-economy stocks has been so bearish, in fact, that the median estimated value of the options granted last year to the 100 old-line chiefs in the Money & Business survey, based on their companies' recent stock prices, was zero.
"The primary retention device -- option vesting -- is not working," said George B. Paulin, president of Frederic W. Cook & Company, a pay consulting firm.
Few have seen their holdings plummet more than Geoffrey Bible, the Philip Morris chief executive. When 1999 began, Mr. Bible had accumulated a pile of options worth $94 million. During the year, he received an additional one million options and cashed in $7 million worth of his original stash. Yet by the time the world rang in 2000, Philip Morris's stock had fallen by 56 percent -- and all of Mr. Bible's remaining options were worth less than $1 million.
What's an old-line company to do? Some are reaching back to resuscitate pay strategies last in vogue during the bear market of the 1970's. They are basing raises, bonuses and incentive payments for chief executives and other top talent susceptible to dot-com fever on company earnings, rather than on stock performance, for example. For the 100 old-economy executives in the Money & Business study, bonuses rose almost 30 percent last year, largely because of the companies' strong profits.
More companies are also giving raises to their most productive managers, even if it means creating disparities among workers with the same title. "We're making sure a larger percentage of our pay goes to the very best performers," said Rick Martino, I.B.M.'s vice president for talent.
In the highest corporate ranks, companies are increasingly granting restricted stock to executives . These are real shares -- not options -- that hold value even if the stock is falling, though the executive must hang onto them for a designated period. Thirty-nine percent of large companies gave their chief executives such awards last year, up from 33 percent in 1998, according to a sampling of proxies by Pearl Meyer & Partners, compensation consultants in New York. The average grant size shot up 25 percent, to $1.2 million. Not one of the 60 new-economy chief executives in the Money & Business study received a single share of restricted stock.
Owens Corning, the building materials maker, was typical of old-economy companies that turned more toward cash and restricted stock. Its shares lost more than 40 percent of their value in 1999. But its chief executive, Glen H. Hiner, saw his salary and bonus jump 38 percent, to $4 million. And he received a $2.3 million grant of restricted stock, 10 times what he got in 1998.
"We were intentionally more aggressive in awarding equity in 1999," said Dennis Vereb, the company's vice president for compensation, both to reward executives for record earnings and to motivate them to lift the company's share price.
A growing number of companies seem no longer to care about the effects of a 1993 law -- the one pay initiative that grew out of the Bill Clinton's 1992 presidential campaign -- that limits the maximum amount of base pay they can deduct from taxes for their top five executives to $1 million each. (The law exempts any amount above $1 million that is tied to performance, or that is deferred.)
Archer Daniels Midland, for example, paid its chief executive, G. Allen Andreas, a base salary of $2.4 million last year, costing the company as much as $490,000 in deductions. In its proxy, the company says that limiting pay to $1 million would be "inadvisable."
Another approach to retention is to give employees access to investments that companies hope will mimic the rise in Internet shares. Dozens of companies, including The New York Times, have said they will issue tracking stocks or set up separate divisions for their dot-com operations. Andersen Consulting, meanwhile, announced a $200 million venture-capital fund last month, the proceeds of which will go to selected employees.
Health care and pharmaceutical companies are studying similar plans, said Pearl Meyer, who runs the pay advisory firm bearing her name.
"They're playing defense," Ms. Meyer said.
OF course, companies continue to hand out enormous option grants as well, but the erratic stock market, combined with a new accounting rule, has altered the specifics.
In past years, companies responded to stock weakness by repricing old options -- canceling a $30 option if shares were trading at $20, for instance, and replacing it with one that had an exercise price of $20.
The practice angered shareholder groups, which said it undercut the entire premise of rewarding managers for good performance and punishing them for mediocre results. The Financial Accounting Standards Board, deciding that repricing violated the spirit of its guidelines, ruled last month that companies engaging in the practice would have to take a charge against their earnings.
So now some companies are changing the other variable in the options equation -- time -- by awarding options with longer terms.
At Reebok, for example, the chief executive, Paul B. Fireman, held some 500,000 options that were on the verge of expiring worthless, until Reebok's board extended their term by 10 years, according to the company's recent proxy. Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble, both suffering from swooning stocks, are issuing options with 15-year exercise terms, instead of 10 years.
Some observers worry that the extensions might let executives off the hook for poor performance.
"Ten years seems like an appropriate long-term horizon," said Ann Yerger, director of research at the Council of Institutional Investors. Extending that period, she added, "is sort of a way of repricing and increasing the value of awards."
"I don't think that's the kind of behavior that is going to be applauded by institutional investors," she said.
Companies say they have little choice but to sweeten the deals they offer top management: executives are exploiting to the hilt the power that a tight labor market gives them.
THEIR increasing leverage has rewritten the rules for salary negotiations that were once often a good-natured give-and-take between a board and an executive who had probably spent most of his career at the company, pay experts say. The dynamic began to change in the early 1990's, when corporate governance advocates lobbied directors to show more independence and as a recession prompted companies to dismiss even senior employees. Now that the economy favors the executives, it is their turn to play rough.
"All across American industry, we have a much harder, tougher relationship," said Mr. Johnson, the New York pay consultant, adding that some executive salary negotiations now resemble talks with organized labor. "It has a very different feel to it than five years ago."
Today, executives are getting everything from Mr. Galli's multimillion-dollar guarantees to multiple country club memberships to security details.
"Perks really started to go out of fashion 10 to 15 years ago," said Carol Bowie, the director of research at Executive Compensation Advisory Services. "They're coming back."
Honeywell, for example, pays for Michael R. Bonsignore's wife to travel with him -- and then picks up the taxes they would otherwise have to pay on that income. The company also gave Mr. Bonsignore the lifetime use of security guards and clerical support, and it picked up the fees of the lawyer who negotiated his contract.
"It's a feeding frenzy," Mr. Hatch said. "Everybody's looking at each other's proxies and saying, 'They get more; I want more.' "
One thing that the Money & Business study makes clear is the through-the-looking-glass nature of executive pay. Who's on top depends very much on how the numbers are added and on the assumptions behind them.
By one measure, for example, the old-line executives appear to outgun their upstart rivals even in the value of their stock options, still the largest component of executive pay. Using the simplest formula for valuing options, which assigns each option a value of roughly one-third of its exercise price, the 60 upstarts received options worth an average of $3.4 million, while the 100 old-economy chiefs got an average of $4.6 million.
Elevating the old-economy average were a handful of windfalls: American Express granted Harvey Golub options valued at almost $45 million. At Alcoa, Paul H. O'Neill got more than $32 million in options and at General Electric, John F. Welch Jr. got almost $25 million worth. (Bank of America granted Hugh L. McColl Jr. options valued at nearly $35 million, but for now those options are under water.)
Almost none of the new-economy executives could boast of such packages. But that is largely because the most common methods of valuing options often badly understate their value, Ms. Bowie said.
How? Many technology executives receive options before, or just as, their companies go public, and so the options' exercise price -- generally the market price at the time the options are granted -- is a faint shadow of the price assigned the shares by rabid investors in initial public offerings.
Consider Charles E. Johnson Jr., chief executive of PurchasePro.com, which went public last September. At one-third of their exercise price, his 1999 options were worth less than $400,000. However, at the options' estimated current value in the study -- an average of the stock's price at the end of December, January and February -- Mr. Johnson's options are worth $54 million. If he is keeping an eye on the stock's price, that is what the market is telling him his pay package is worth.
The current valuation method yields an average of $27 million each for the total pay packages of new-economy executives, vaulting them well past their old-economy counterparts. Of course, as the last few days' trading underscores, technology stocks also fall, making the Wunderkinds' options less valuable, or even worthless. But others will soar further -- and make the executives' 1999 pay look even better in retrospect.
AT recent values, the billionaires club is expanding beyond well-known figures like Bill Gates of Microsoft and Jeff Bezos of Amazon.
Joining them this year are Henry T. Nicholas III of Broadcom, a maker of communications chips, who owns $4.8 billion in stock and options; JoMei Chang of Vitria Technology, a maker of e-commerce software ($2.3 billion); and Scott Kriens of Juniper Networks, which makes Internet routers ($1.1 billion).
"People are ending up with levels of wealth far beyond what could have been created even five years ago," said Carl Schmitt, a vice president of WestWard Pay Strategies in San Francisco.
The great majority of that wealth, like the wealth of so many investors and new-economy workers, depends on the Internet remaining in the good graces of Wall Street. Old-economy executives, on the other hand, get to take home much of their earnings immediately.
Even Mr. Bible at Philip Morris didn't have such a bad 1999, by that standard. He received $6.3 million in hard cash, thanks to a $4.4 million bonus largely for meeting the company's earnings goals. And the one million options he received were double the number in his 1998 grant.
If Philip Morris's stock rebounds, he -- like many executives at large companies -- will have the best of both worlds: a big paycheck to make up for the volatile 1999 stock market and the gains from all of the options still being handed out.
Oh -- and the average full-time worker's income? It increased about 3 percent in 1999, to roughly $33,000.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TREND;
Greenspan Feels the Earth Shake

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN is among the most powerful men in the world. As chairman of the Federal Reserve, he can alter the course of the economy by moving interest rates up and down. His pronouncements can send shudders through markets around the globe.
Wrong. 
 Or so it seems as Mr. Greenspan tries, with little success so far, to cool off an economy that is threatening to overheat and impose a degree of temperance on Wall Street's long-running party.
It is not just Mr. Greenspan whose clout is in question. Given that companies, consumers and investors have proven largely impervious to a series of rate hikes by the Fed, economists are wondering whether monetary policy still works, or at least whether it works the same way it used to.
The Fed has pushed interest rates up five times since June. In the meantime, the economy has continued thundering along at a pace well above what most economists think is sustainable over the long run without generating inflation. The government reported last week that the economy grew at a 7.3 percent annual rate in the last quarter of 1999, its fastest pace in 16 years, and all the signs are that growth has moderated only slightly so far in 2000.
Although stock prices have taken to gyrating wildly, and the high-flying technology stocks in the Nasdaq index have been hit hard, the trend on Wall Street has remained upward. And long-term interest rates have not risen nearly as much as would be expected when the Fed is driving up the official short-term rates it controls.
Higher interest rates take time to filter through the economy, and their full effect may not be felt until later this year. But the economy and the markets are clearly absorbing the Fed's rate hikes with a somewhat perplexing equanimity.
"Monetary policy usually works with a lag of six to nine months, so you shouldn't really expect the rate increases that occurred starting in mid-1999 to have a noticeable impact on the economy before the second quarter of this year," said L. Douglas Lee of Economics from Washington, a consulting firm. "Having said that, the economy is not as sensitive to interest rate increases as it used to be. This makes it tougher for the Fed to slow things down by raising interest rates."
In textbooks, monetary policy sounds pretty simple. Fed officials make a judgment about how fast the economy can grow without igniting inflation, based on the growth of the working population and improvements in productivity. (Over the last few years those estimates have risen to nearly 4 percent, from just over 2 percent.)
When growth exceeds that rate over a sustained period, the Fed drives up the short-term interest rates it controls. Banks then charge more for loans. The bond market pushes up corporate borrowing rates. Stock prices come under pressure.
With mortgages and auto loans more expensive, and people feeling less wealthy, consumers buy fewer houses and cars. With their costs rising and sales slowing, companies might choose to close a plant, or not to open a new one. Jobs become less plentiful. The economy slows and inflation fades.
In the real world it is more complicated.
For one thing, although growth rates are well above what almost anyone thinks is sustainable over the long run, there is almost no inflation. Moreover, the economy and the markets are changing in ways that tend to dampen the effect of rising rates.
TAKE mortgages. Rates on traditional fixed-rate mortgages have shot up over the last year. But homebuyers have learned to maintain their purchasing power by shifting into adjustable rate mortgages, which initially carry lower monthly payments. Mr. Lee said that at the beginning of 1999, while rates were quite low, only about 10 percent of homebuyers were choosing adjustable mortgages. By the end of last year 30 percent of homebuyers were choosing adjustables. As a result, home sales, a key driver of economic growth, have kept running at a brisk pace.
Moreover, much of the economic growth in recent years has come from advances in technology, and technology companies carry relatively little debt compared with their "old economy" cousins in capital-intensive fields like manufacturing. Companies with little debt are less sensitive to rising rates than those with big debt loads, and are therefore less likely to cut back as the Fed tightens policy.
The difference between old and new economy companies is just one reason the financial markets have not reacted much to the Fed's tighter monetary policy. Another is psychological: investors have become so conditioned to Mr. Greenspan keeping the economy on an even keel that they are concentrating not on the pain he is seeking to inflict on them through rate increases but on the presumed outcome of his efforts -- an economy that continues growing steadily with little inflation. Mr. Greenspan is in some ways a victim of his own success.
Much the same phenomenon is at work in the bond market. Because the government is running huge budget surpluses, the Treasury is paying off the national debt. In doing so, the government is creating a shortage of Treasury bonds, driving up the price of those bonds and driving down the interest rate they carry. In effect, the Treasury and the Fed are working at cross purposes.
One result has been a call for the Fed to reexamine the tools it uses. If the key to bringing the economy's growth down to a sustainable level is reining in the stock market, as Mr. Greenspan says, then perhaps he should consider aiming his fire directly at Wall Street.
In Congress, pressure is mounting on Mr. Greenspan to tighten the rules on buying stocks with borrowed money. But Mr. Greenspan has repeatedly replied that such a move could not be counted on to have any effect on stock prices.
So the Fed will no doubt continue using its imperfect though not impotent interest rate tool. And Mr. Greenspan may find that he has to raise rates further, and in bigger increments, than he would prefer.

PUB-DATE: April 2, 2000

SECTION: Section 3; Page 16; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1486 words

HEADLINE: REPORT ON EXECUTIVE PAY;
What the Numbers Mean, and How They Were Calculated

 BODY:
IN examining executive compensation, Money & Business sought this year to capture the differences between the pay practices of companies in the old economy of industrial, service and financial concerns and those in the new economy of Internet and related businesses.
After all, one of the biggest worries today of managers at established companies is the flight of workers to Internet jobs that promise unprecedented wealth. And one of the great concerns of economists and market watchers is that the new economy's pay practices -- especially its generosity with stock options -- may be contributing to a casino mentality, blind to business fundamentals.
To gauge the divide, Executive Compensation Advisory Services, an Alexandria, Va., division of Harcourt Inc. that collects, analyzes and sells information on executive pay, collected data on pay at 160 companies among the early filers of proxies for 1999, the documents in which compensation details are reported. 
 Representing the old economy in the survey were 100 of the largest nontechnology companies (as measured by sales) that had filed their proxies by March 23.
The 60 new-economy companies had the same proxy deadline and appeared on one of 10 widely watched indexes of technology stocks: the Dow Jones Internet composite index; the Fortune e-50; the Interactive Week Internet index; the USA Today Internet 100; internet.com's Internet Stock List and ISDEX Internet Stock index; the Wall Street Research Net e-tailers index; and TheStreet.com's Internet Sector, e-commerce and e-finance indexes.
(A company in one of these indexes that would also have qualified, by size, for inclusion in the old-economy list -- Microsoft, for example, or I.B.M. -- was considered part of the new economy in the study.)
All 160 chief executives had to hold the job for their company's entire 1999 fiscal year. (That period varied widely, with the fiscal year for a few companies ending as early as March 1999.) Several of those listed -- like Bill Gates of Microsoft and Dale F. Morrison of Campbell Soup -- are no longer chief executive today.
Pay can be added up any number of ways. Pay critics -- and corporate recruiters -- tend to cite the biggest possible numbers, while executives and company directors may have an interest in minimizing the size of pay packages. In any event, the biggest differences stem from the way stock options are valued.
Any value assigned to an option is a guess; the real worth of a chance to buy a stock four years from now at, say, $10 a share depends on the trading price of that stock in four years. The data in the tables on these two pages represents an attempt to recognize this uncertainty, and to take into account how people think about options in real life.
Options granted in 1999 are valued two different ways. One method, using a widely accepted guideline of 33 percent of the price at which the options were granted, takes into account the volatility of stock prices. The other method estimates the value of options based on recent prices for each company's stock -- the value that an executive would have in mind if he was keeping one eye on the stock ticker.
Neither of these numbers appears in corporate proxy statements, which use one of two other methods for valuing options. Simply using the companies' values would make it impossible to compare various executives' options grants.
Given the complications, the tables do not try to total cash and options pay into a single number. Income from exercising options granted in past years is also reported separately, as it can be viewed as compensation for previous years' work.
Here are definitions for the columns in the tables.
 
Direct Compensation
 
SALARY -- Base annual pay that does not directly depend on company results.
 
BONUS -- A cash payment that can very widely depending on the company's performance.
 
LONG-TERM INCENTIVE AND OTHER -- A combination of two categories. The first covers incentive payments that most companies set approximately three years in advance and pay out depending on the company's performance. The second includes miscellaneous items like moving expenses, insurance payments or fees covering personal use of a corporate jet.
 
TOTAL DIRECT COMPENSATION -- The sum of the three previous categories.
 
At-Risk Compensation
 
RESTRICTED STOCK -- The value, as reported by the company, of shares conditionally granted to an executive. Typically, executives get to keep these shares only if they remain with the company for a predetermined period.
Values are shown only for executives who received restricted stock. None of the new-economy executives in the study received restricted stock, so the column does not appear on the new-economy table.
 
1999 OPTIONS, GRANT-DATE VALUE --An estimate of the value of the stock options granted to an executive in 1999, based on the price of the company's stock when the options were granted. (The exercise price of all options in the study is the same as the market price on the grant date.)
One of the most common methods for valuing options is the Black-Scholes formula, which takes into account the exercise price of the option, the time before it can be exercised, the time before it expires and the volatility of the company's stock. A widely used approximation of the formula simply takes one-third of the exercise price. This is the method that Money & Business used.
For example, if an executive received 100,000 options on a stock that was trading at $30, the study estimated the grant to be worth 100,000 multiplied by $10, or $1 million.
 
1999 OPTIONS, ESTIMATED CURRENT VALUE -- An estimate of the value of the stock options an executive received in 1999, based on recent prices of the stock.
The study found the average of the company's closing stock prices at the end of December, January and February. The exercise price of the option was then subtracted from that average to arrive at a current value for the option.
Consider again the executive who received 100,000 options on a stock that was trading, on the grant date, at $30. If the average recent stock price was $50, each option would be valued at $20, and the 100,000 options would be worth $2 million. If the stock was trading at $29, the options would have no current value.
 
Accumulated Wealth
 
OPTIONS PROFITS REALIZED IN F.Y. 1999 -- The gain that executives saw in the 1999 fiscal year by exercising options from previous years. For each option, this number is the difference between the price of the stock when the executive exercised the option and the price at which the option was granted. In some cases, executives immediately sell the underlying shares, and in other cases they hold onto the stock. Values are shown only for executives who realized profits during the fiscal year.
 
VALUE OF STOCK BENEFICIALLY HELD -- The value of shares held outright by an executive, based on the closing stock price at the end of the company's fiscal year. In some cases -- because, for instance, shares are held in trust for a child -- executives may disclaim beneficial ownership of a portion of the shares they are reported as owning.
 
VALUE OF OPTIONS, F.Y. END -- Value, at the end of acompany's fiscal year, of both exercisable and nonexercisable options held by the executive.
 
TOTAL VALUE OF EQUITY -- The sum of the previous two numbers.
 
OWNERSHIP STAKE -- Beneficial stock holdings, plus exercisable options and options exercisable within 60 days, as a percentage of the company's total shares outstanding, as reported in the company's proxy.

Performance
 
STOCK PERFORMANCE VS. S.& P. 500 -- The amount, in percentage points, by which the company's performance trailed or exceeded the stock index during the period through the end of the company's 1999 fiscal year.
Performance comparisons are for a one-year period for new-economy companies and a three-year period for old-economy companies.
For those new-economy companies that went public during the 1999 fiscal year, performance is measured against the index for the portion of the year that they were publicly traded.
Some new-economy companies went public after the end of the fiscal year; they are shown as N.A.
 
Averages and Medians
For each column, these figures take into account only executives for whom values were reported. For example, the averages for restricted stock grants to old-economy executives include only the 34 executives who received restricted stock. "Average" is the arithmetic mean; "median" is the figure in the middle of the series of numbers.
The performance statistics were calculated by Money & Business, based on data provided by Factset Research Systems, a research firm in Greenwich, Conn., and Bloomberg Financial Markets. All other data was calculated by Executive Compensation Advisory Services.
