HEADLINE: Robust Sales Push U.S. Auto Industry to Its Best Quarter Ever

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 3

 BODY:
Americans bought new cars, minivans and sport utility vehicles at a sizzling pace last month, closing out the best quarter ever for the auto industry as the nation's economy appeared to be following up a winter of brisk economic growth with a springtime of continued strong expansion.
Ford Motor said today that its sales in the United States leaped 7.2 percent from a year earlier to the highest level ever for a single month. Four other big automakers had their best March ever: DaimlerChrysler, up 4.4 percent from last year; Toyota, up 16 percent; Honda, up 20.3 percent; and Mitsubishi, up 25.4 percent. 
 The industry's overall pace of sales rose nearly 9 percent from a year earlier, but did not set a record and was a little weaker than in February. The reason was simple: General Motors offered generous discount coupons in February which produced a sharp jump in sales then, followed by weaker sales last month. G.M.'s sales climbed just 1 percent in March from a year earlier.
Ward's Auto Infobank, a data research firm, estimated that G.M.'s market share fell last month to 27.4 percent, well below the company's target of 30 percent. Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director for global market and industry analysis, said that sales last month suffered because of the marketing campaign in February. The campaign was aimed at existing owners of G.M. automobiles, who tend to buy G.M. models sooner or later and sometimes time their purchases to take advantage of discounts.
The automakers' announcements today of robust auto sales coincided with the release of a national survey by the National Association of Purchasing Managers, which also showed that the economy continued to grow vigorously last month.
Auto sales and the purchasing managers' survey are usually the first statistics released each month about the strength of the economy the month before. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has long watched auto sales particularly closely, having first earned his reputation as an economic forecaster in the 1950's and 1960's while specializing in the steel and auto industries.
Diane C. Swonk, a senior vice president and chief economist at the Bank One Corporation, said that rising interest rates and higher gasoline prices seemed to be having little effect so far on the auto industry, traditionally a sector particularly sensitive to rates and gas prices. Battling for market share, automakers have been offering low rates on auto loans, thereby insulating their customers so far from the Fed's attempts to raise short-term rates and slow economic growth to a more sustainable level
"Vehicle sales are one of the primary reasons why consumer spending seems to be accelerating even from the frenzied pace of the fourth quarter," Ms. Swonk said. "It does up the ante in terms of how far the Fed has to go when the automakers are offering 0.9 percent financing."
Mark M. Cornelius, the president of Morgan & Company Inc., an auto forecasting and consulting company in West Olive, Mich., estimated that for March alone, the industry's sales rose 8.3 percent from a year earlier, running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 17.8 million.
The overall first quarter was even better. Mr. Ballew, G.M.'s senior market analyst, said that the seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales for all of the first quarter was about 18.5 million automobiles, beating the previous record of 18.2 million, set in the third quarter of last year. He predicted that sales would moderate somewhat by the end of this year, particularly because of the Fed's actions, but said that the moderation would not turn into a sharp downturn.
The steep increase in gasoline prices during March appeared to have little effect on the types of automobiles that Americans wanted to buy. Sales of minivans soared while sales of full-size sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks were fairly strong. There was some weakness in sales of small pickups, which tend to be the most fuel-efficient light trucks, although they still get much worse gas mileage than cars.
Mr. Ballew said that gains in market share would slow somewhat for these vehicles over the next few years, as most automakers, with the exception of G.M., have slowed their introductions of such models. "Some of the extraordinary shifts we've seen in the last 10 years are beginning to ebb a bit," he said.
Nissan's sales rose 23.4 percent last month from a year earlier, although it was not the company's best March ever. Subaru posted its best March since 1989, with a 4.7 percent gain, while Volkswagen had its best March since 1979, with a 19.6 percent increase.

HEADLINE: U.S. Ready for Much Larger Security Council

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 3

 BODY:
After years of trying to hold the 15-member Security Council to what it considers a manageable size, the United States is prepared to drop its insistence that the limit should be 20 or 21 seats in any expansion, Richard C. Holbrooke, the American ambassador to the United Nations, told a General Assembly working group today.
Mr. Holbrooke, who did not suggest an upper number, is facing an uphill battle to reduce American dues to the organization. And the issue of Security Council size is important for dozens of new members, whose ambassadors here contend that the council no longer represents the world. 
 The five permanent members -- Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States -- have held those positions since 1945, when the United Nations had 51 members. The 10 rotating seats are shared by 183 other countries, some of which are unlikely ever to have a chance at council membership. The rotating seats are held for two years, with five new members elected each year to maintain overlap.
The council, something of a United Nations cabinet of countries, is the only body that can call for enforcement of its decisions by military means, if necessary.
Several years of sometimes rancorous debate in an open-ended working group -- envoys call it the "never-ending working group" -- have failed to bring any voluntary changes in membership. Europe, for example, can also hold one or two rotating seats in addition to its three permanent ones, if Russia is counted. And many nations say the time has come to discuss one or two permanent seats for the European Union, to be apportioned as they choose. France and Britain are resolutely opposed.
The situation is further complicated by German and Italian demands for permanent seats, which carry veto powers. Japan is also campaigning for a permanent place, citing its high level of contributions and the need for a democratic free-market Asian voice among the most powerful nations.
Most delegations say the council is out of date in not giving enough seats -- and no permanent seats -- to the developing countries that form a substantial numerical majority in the General Assembly. Those nations themselves are a long way from deciding which would hold seats if the number is increased.
India desperately wants one. But Indonesia and maybe even Korea may also still be in the running from Asia. Africa has an abundance of candidates, among them Egypt, Nigeria and South Africa. In Latin America, Brazil and Mexico, and possibly Argentina or even Chile, would be among the competitors.
When Bill Richardson, now energy secretary, was the ambassador here, he suggested an additional five seats, for Germany, Japan and three developing nations. That would put the membership at 20.
Now members are proposing a body as large as 28 members, nearly double its present size.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Market Intervention by Japan Sends Yen Down vs. Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Japanese yen posted its biggest decline in 10 months against the dollar and sank against the euro after the nation's central bank sold yen in an effort to keep exports competitive and a modest economic recovery on track.
The bank's move followed a surge of nearly 4 percent against the dollar last week and came after the bank's quarterly survey of business confidence, the tankan, showed somewhat greater optimism. 
 The currency sales drove the yen as weak as 105.65 to the dollar compared with 102.64 late Friday, and to 100.7 to the euro, from 98.19. In New York trading, the yen rebounded somewhat, settling at 104.85 to the dollar.
David Durrant, a currency strategist at Bank Julius Baer, said of the Japanese central bank: "The message is definitely that rapid appreciation is not in their best interest. There's no question they were not appreciative of what had happened on Friday."
The yen surged then on speculation that the tankan survey would point to a pickup in growth in Japan's economy in coming months, drawing investors.
The survey's headline number, which gauges confidence among big manufacturers, matched expectations today and showed improvement from the previous report in December. Yet it remained negative, at -9, from -17 in December, meaning that more businesses were pessimistic about their prospects than optimistic.
The disclosure that Japan's prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, was in a coma after having suffered a stroke had little immediate effect, but the political uncertainties could hurt the yen in coming weeks, traders said. The chief cabinet secretary, Mikio Aoki, is serving for now as acting prime minister.
The developments could hurt the yen if they make it more difficult for Japan to introduce new spending in case the economy slows, Mr. Durrant of Bank Julius Baer said.
The central bank began the new fiscal year by selling an estimated $5 billion worth of yen immediately after it released the tankan survey. A sharp rise in the currency's value is unwelcome as it could slow the economy by making exports more expensive and eroding returns on overseas securities held by Japanese investors.

HEADLINE: No Signs of Slowing Economy As Manufacturing Expands

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
Manufacturing expanded for a 14th consecutive month in March, while rising costs for oil and other raw materials pushed an index of prices paid by factories to its highest in five years, an industry survey showed.
"There's no evidence of slowing in the economy," which entered a record 10th year of expansion in April, Tim O'Neill, chief economist at Harris Bank and Bank of Montreal, said today. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly factory index was 55.8 last month, as gauges of production and inventories rose. While the March number was down from 56.9 in February, any index reading above 50 indicates an expansion.
A separate report from the Commerce Department showed that construction spending rose 1.5 percent in February, to a record annual rate of $758.7 billion.
Together, the reports add to evidence that five Federal Reserve interest rate increases since June have not yet slowed growth, analysts said. "When the economy's on a roll, you're going to have to put down more than a couple of rate increases to slow it," Mr. O'Neill said. "There's no question the Fed's got its work cut out for it."
The purchasing managers' prices-paid index rose to 79.8 in March from 74.1 during February -- mostly reflecting oil costs, which have declined since midmonth. The March reading was the highest since 81.7 in February 1995.
Overall readings above 50 mean the number of manufacturers saying business improved is greater than the number saying it deteriorated. The index has now been at 50 or higher since February 1999. Asian and Latin American economies have recovered from a currency crisis that began in 1997, and that has led factories to crank up to supply overseas buyers in addition to United States consumers.
The new-orders index, a gauge of current demand, fell to 56.9 in March from 60.5 in February. The employment index also fell, to 51.5 from 53.2.
The production index increased, with a reading of 61.8 the highest since June. The index had been 61.3. The inventory index, a measure of pent-up demand, rose to 48.4 in March from 45.2 during February.
The February increase in construction spending reflected stepped-up work on new single-family homes and office buildings. In January, spending rose a revised 2.2 percent, to a $747.6 billion annual rate, previously reported as a 2.7 percent gain. Analysts expected February spending to fall 0.1 percent, to $751 billion.
The level of the prices-paid index suggests that companies are still being affected by higher oil costs. Crude oil futures for May delivery traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange surged to $32.48 on March 7, the highest since November 1990, though futures have been below $30 a barrel since March 13.
The report also noted increases in metals, chemicals and plastics. "Those are also influenced by demand," said Norbert Ore, chairman of the purchasing managers' group.
Even so, "it's kind of hard to say" when consumers will be paying more, Mr. Ore said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Competitors of Telmex Say It Still Acts Like a Monopoly

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 3

 BODY:
If any company represents the marriage of Mexico and modern business, it is Telefonos de Mexico, the telecommunications giant that towers over its industry at home and is the Mexican stock that Wall Street investors love to own.
Since it was sold by the government a decade ago to a private consortium headed by Carlos Slim Helu, now Latin America's wealthiest man, Telmex more than any other enterprise has symbolized Mexico's passage from an inward-looking state-controlled economy to a thriving globalized free market. 
 And since the former monopoly was forced to face competition in both long distance and recently in local service, the government has cited the opening as an example of its commitment to free trade and attracting foreign investment.
But United States companies that took Mexico at its word and tried to challenge Telmex in long distance say they have hit a wall raised by a powerful conglomerate that presses many lingering monopoly advantages and subdues the regulators who are supposed to impose discipline. This clash has forged an improbable alliance between two of the biggest phone competitors in the United States, AT&T and MCI Worldcom, which find themselves underdogs in Mexico.
In a report released on Friday, the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said she was seriously concerned about what she called regulatory failures in Mexico, and she said that Telmex was "inhibiting the creation" of telecommunications competition.
Because Telmex is the flagship of this country's privatization process, its apparent reluctance to play on a level field, and the soft-spoken approach of Mexican regulators to the problem, have cast a shadow on President Ernesto Zedillo's often-stated pledge to honor open-border economics.
Telmex has also provided a close-up view of Mr. Slim's business style. As a financier he is an acknowledged master of bargain spotting and management turnaround, recently demonstrated by his purchase of Prodigy, the foundering American Internet service provider, which he transformed in two years into a booming Latin American Web channel. But his competitors say that with Telmex, the heart of his empire, Mr. Slim has proved to be a hardball tactician who exploits the advantages afforded by the company's holdover monopoly status.
Telmex officials reject suggestions that the company does not play fair. They attribute their long-distance competitors' hardships to less-than-expert management and inexperience with the Mexican market.
"We have made concession after concession to create a healthy market," said Arturo Elias Ayub, a senior official and the company's spokesman. "But they are never happy. They always want more."
Telmex and top regulators agree that Mexico has opened itself to telecommunications competition at unusual speed. "Given the progress of regulation and the penetration of the competitors," said Jorge Nicolin, director of the Federal Telecommunications Commission, "our opening compares very favorably with other countries. The competitors are here. They're working."
This is not a dispute between a leading Mexican company and foreign interlopers, although it is often presented that way in the Mexican press. While Mr. Slim and a small group of other Mexican investors control 51 percent of Telmex, much of the rest is evenly divided between SBC International, a subsidiary of SBC Communications, and France Telecom.
Avantel, MCI Worldcom's long-distance company in Mexico, is 55 percent-owned by Banacci, a large Mexican bank. AT&T holds 49 percent of its Mexican affiliate Alestra, while 51 percent is split between Grupo Alfa, a manufacturing conglomerate, and Bancomer, another large Mexican bank.
The confrontation is drawn between an alliance of newcomers to Mexico's telecommunications industry and Mr. Slim, an established figure with a broad hold on Mexican business. Mr. Slim's properties now account for more than half of the value of the companies in the main Mexican stock index.
After three years of competition, Telmex still has about 75 percent of the $4.4 billion long-distance market while eight competitors share the rest. Avantel and Alestra each have about 10 percent. Between them, they have invested more than $2 billion.
The core dispute is over the cost of linking calls from Telmex's local lines to the competitors' long-distance networks. The cost of these connections has continued to rise while the rates companies charge have slid. "They caught us in a pincer action," said Francisco Gil Diaz, the chief operating officer of Avantel. Both Avantel and Alestra said they pay about 60 percent of their revenue directly to Telmex.
Connection costs keep rising because they are pegged by regulation to inflation. In addition, the smaller companies argue that the rates they pay to Telmex were set at artificially high levels by regulators. Mexico pledged, when it first set the rules for long-distance competition, to promptly bring those rates down, close to the cost of providing the service. That has not happened.
The competitors contend that Telmex has pushed down rates to its own customers by subsidizing its long-distance service with the generous cash flow from its local business and with discounts written into big commercial contracts.
They also say that Telmex has subjected its competitors to crippling failures of service. Both Avantel and Alestra rely on Telmex to provide special high-traffic lines that carry Internet and corporate data. For nine months, Telmex stopped providing these lines, on the grounds that the competitors had failed to pay back bills. The Mexican regulator took no effective action. In January, the Federal Communications Commission levied a $100,000 fine on Telmex based on the damage to customers in the United States.
At one point, Mr. Gil Diaz said, Telmex disconnected 40 of his best business customers to force Avantel to pay disputed bills. Two years ago, Avantel tried to introduce a service allowing Mexicans to make long-distance calls from public phones using prepaid cards. Telmex refused to give Avantel a free number for the calls to go through.
Mr. Nicolin, the regulator, agreed that the competitors' costs are too high. But he said that his agency had been restrained from acting by aggressive legal challenges from Telmex.
Last week, at least a year after he was expected to act, Mr. Nicolin issued special rules governing Telmex, intended to bring down costs and improve service. Mr. Elias, the phone company's spokesman, said Telmex will "fight very hard" in the courts against the regulator's new rules, which he said were intended "to tie Telmex's hands and feet."
But Frank Voytek, AT&T's representative on Alestra's board, sees matters differently. "Our expectation when we made our investment," he said, "was that the regulator would enforce the regulations."

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: THE GOVERNMENT;
U.S. to Examine Remedies That Fit the Offense

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
Ebullient over their legal victory against Microsoft, Justice Department antitrust officials said today that they would examine possible remedies to put an end to what a federal judge described as the giant software company's monopolistic practices.
In his ruling, United States District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson wrote that Microsoft violated the Sherman Antitrust Act. His decision will provide the basis for further court hearings -- and possibly settlement negotiations -- to determine what legal remedies to impose on Microsoft. The company said it would appeal. 
 At a news conference, Joel I. Klein, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, offered little indication of what specific steps government lawyers would recommend to Judge Jackson, who must decide on any sanctions against the company.
"While no final decision has been made," Mr. Klein said, "the department is committed to finding a remedy that will protect consumers, innovation and competition by putting an end to Microsoft's widespread and persistent abuse of its monopoly power and to rectifying its unlawful attempt to monopolize the Internet browser market."
At the news conference, Attorney General Janet Reno expressed satisfaction over the ruling. "We are pleased," she said, "that the court agreed with the department that Microsoft abused its monopoly power, that it violated the antitrust laws, and that it harmed consumers. Microsoft has been held accountable for its illegal conduct by a court of law."
The decision, in a case argued by a team of lawyers headed by David Boies, the Justice Department's special counsel, was the culmination of the Clinton administration's most ambitious antitrust effort.
A spokesman for Vice President Al Gore, the likely Democratic presidential candidate, said that Mr. Gore had no comment on the ruling. The vice president received an icy reception when he visited the company's headquarters in Redmond, Wash., last November. Mr. Gore did not explicitly embrace the antitrust action, but said then that "the values that are inherent in the antitrust laws are ones that are sound."
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the likely Republican candidate, said that as president he would "fully enforce antitrust laws," but he declined to discuss specifics of the case because it remained in litigation and would be appealed by Microsoft.
Mr. Klein said the ruling would bring positive change, adding, "It will benefit America's consumers by opening the door to competition, increased innovation and increased consumer choice in the software industry." He said the ruling "demonstrates once again that no company, no matter how powerful or how successful, can refuse to play by the rules, and thwart competition for America's consumers."
"Competition has been at the heart of America's economy," Mr. Klein added, "and protecting competition at the heart of antitrust enforcement for a long time."
Attorneys general for some of the states that joined in the federal government's case said they favored strict sanctions, which might include the breakup of Microsoft. Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, urged Judge Jackson to "adopt remedies that are as far-reaching and fundamental as Microsoft's abuses of its monopoly."

HEADLINE: Bickering in Albany Over Budget Grows on News of $1.6 Billion Surplus From the Last Year

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 3

 BODY:
Fighting over state spending and tax cuts escalated today after the New York State comptroller's office released a report showing that the state finished its fiscal year with a surplus of $1.6 billion.
The report on the fiscal year that ended on Friday was the latest evidence that the state's economy continues to grow at a strong pace, and generated nearly $750 million more in tax revenues than budget officials for Gov. George E. Pataki had originally predicted. 
 Republican and Democratic lawmakers welcomed the news, although it was not completely unexpected. Lawmakers from both parties argued that it bolstered their contention that the economy was robust enough to warrant spending more than the $76.8 billion that Mr. Pataki proposed in the budget he released earlier this year.
The report came as Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders from both parties remained deadlocked in negotiations over a new state budget. Adoption of the budget was due on Saturday, but Mr. Pataki and the leaders have been divided over how much money should be spent.
Days ago, the Republican governor was said to have reached an agreement with his chief Democratic rival in the Legislature, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, on an overall spending figure. That figure was $1.4 billion more than the governor originally proposed, though Mr. Silver was said to be asking for more money this evening.
But Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the Senate, has refused for days to agree to the apparent deal, saying that none of the additional $1.4 billion would further one of his priorities for the year: tax cuts.
Mr. Bruno, who was the governor's main ally in the Legislature until a few months ago, when the two had a falling out, is pushing a plan to enact an array of tax cuts that would total $1.2 billion when phased in over the next four years.
Mr. Pataki, a strong proponent of tax cuts himself, is generally supportive of the tax-cut plan. But the governor's aides say he is concerned about the impact the cuts would have in future years on the state's finances, particularly if there is an economic downturn.
Republicans who control the Senate renewed their call for tax cuts today, saying that the numbers released by the comptroller's office show that the economy is strong enough to enact their tax plan without creating long-term problems for the state.
In releasing the report, the comptroller, H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, assailed Mr. Pataki and the Legislature for failing to enact a timely budget. He said the strong economy, along with the unanticipated revenues, should make it easier to reach a timely budget deal.
Mr. McCall also said the additional money should not be spent hastily, suggesting that it be set aside to hedge against a slowing of the economy. "Sooner or later, the Wall Street-generated surpluses will end," he said. "This year's surplus must be used wisely to promote fiscal stability for the future."

HEADLINE: Despite a Stricken Leader, Japan Keeps a Level Head

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, April 4

 BODY:
The reaction to news that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi was in the hospital was testament to the Japanese determination to maintain the "wa," the social harmony that this country so greatly prizes.
Although Mr. Obuchi lay in the hospital in serious condition, various economic developments caused the stock market to roar ahead to its highest level in three years. The benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index rose 1.9 percent to close on Monday at 20,726.99, and companies continued to churn out news releases outlining their plans for alliances, investments and new products. 
 Indeed, there was no panic when the market opened today, as investors seemed ready to continue their recent strategy of shifting money out of stocks tied to the "new economy" and into some of the lumbering giants that, by some measures, are undervalued. At midmorning, the Nikkei had given up almost half of Monday's gains, but that was attributed to the fall in the Nasdaq market in the United States.
That was in stark contrast to the gyrations that roiled the stock market in America when there was even a remote possibility that President Clinton might be impeached.
"The general view of the business world is that if the political vacuum is short, the influence on the economy will be limited," said Yotaro Kobayashi, chairman of the Fuji Xerox Corporation and leader of the Japan Association of Corporate Executives, one of the four large business lobbies here.
To be sure, the government was careful to keep news that Mr. Obuchi was hooked up to a respirator to itself until well after trading stopped on Monday, making sure that investors focused on the good news emanating from the currency market and from a survey of business confidence released on Monday rather than on the prime minister's illness.
He had not designated a successor before his stroke, which occurred in the wee hours of Sunday morning, and that lapse also contributed to the delay in announcing the severity of his medical condition.
"I think there was a very cautious calculation made by the party bosses in the Liberal Democratic Party not to disclose everything at once," said Shigenori Okazaki, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read in Tokyo, referring to the governing party. "Instead, they released the news gradually, and the shock was mitigated."
There was no sign of panic in the markets this morning, either. The party already seems to be lining up Yoshiro Mori as Mr. Obuchi's successor. A colorless party loyalist, Mr. Mori is unlikely to change the policies Mr. Obuchi pursued. Japan changes its prime ministers almost as often as Italy does.
"The common wisdom among Japanese and foreign investors I talked to yesterday was that his replacement is unlikely to hammer out a different policy course," said Kathy Matsui, chief strategist at Goldman, Sachs (Japan) Ltd. "The post tends to change hands rather often here without any serious consequences."
The normal ebb and flow of funds has also helped to cushion the market. Many companies and banks, which typically have an investment portfolio, tend to have hoarded cash prior to the close of the fiscal year on March 31, in an effort to improve the look of their balance sheets.
They traditionally open the fiscal year by redeploying that cash in the stock and bond markets. The quarterly survey of business confidence, or Tankan, which was released yesterday, showed business confidence rising for the fifth consecutive quarter, another sign that corporate investment is picking up.
"I hope both the ruling party and the opposition parties will work to make the political situation stable so we can quickly take measures to compile a domestic and foreign agenda for the country as quickly as possible," said Hiroshi Okuda, chairman of the Toyota Motor Corporation.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Wipeouton Nasdaq Goes Well Beyond the Pummeling of Microsoft

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It wasn't just Microsoft.
The Nasdaq composite index endured one of its worst days ever yesterday, as technology stocks broadly sold off. The decline, 7.6 percent, was the worst daily performance for the index since the summer of 1998. 
 Microsoft, which is just one of the 4,827 stocks in the Nasdaq composite but makes up 8.5 percent of the index's value, was responsible for only about a sixth of the 349.15-point decline, which was a record in terms of points. Its shares fell $15.375, to $90.875 -- shaving $80 billion off the company's market value -- as investors waited for the ruling that the company had violated antitrust laws, a ruling made after the end of regular trading.
But the Nasdaq wipeout was far broader than Microsoft's plunge. Of the 100 stocks in the Nasdaq 100 -- generally the largest companies in the composite index -- 86 fell in value. They included some of the highest flyers heretofore, like Cisco Systems, which for a time last month was the most valuable company in the country, and Qualcomm, the mobile phone technology company that is now down nearly 30 percent from the peak it reached in the first trading day of this year.
Over all, it was the fifth-worst day ever for the index, measured by percentages, trailing just the 8.6 percent fall of Aug. 31, 1998, and three days during the 1987 stock market crash. The 1998 fall came amid worry that the world's financial system was crumbling, and the 1987 declines came as the entire American stock market seemed to be collapsing.
By contrast, yesterday's move came on a day when many stocks were doing quite well, thank you. The Dow Jones industrial average leaped 2.7 percent -- and would have been up 3.7 percent had it not been weighed down by the changes Dow Jones made last November, when it added Microsoft and Intel to the list.
Just what the Nasdaq plunge means -- or whether it means much of anything at all -- is not easy to analyze because volatility in the Nasdaq market has been running at record levels this year, and big falls have often been followed by equally large rebounds. The Nasdaq composite is down 16.3 percent from the peak it reached on March 10. But it is still up 3.8 percent since the end of last year. The Dow, by contrast, is up 13 percent since March 10, but is down 2.4 percent in 2000.
That kind of opposite movement for the Dow and the Nasdaq is far from common. The Nasdaq index, which dates back to 1971, has seen 41 daily declines of at least 3 percent before this year. The Dow declined on 40 of those days, the only exception being on Oct. 20, 1987, the day after the market crash. That exception reflected not so much investor sentiment about the relative weakness of the Nasdaq issues but a quirk of the previous day. The decline in Nasdaq the day before had been smaller than the Dow's because many of the brokers that made Nasdaq markets chose not to answer their phones, and thus kept reported prices artificially high.
But as the Nasdaq has gyrated wildly this year, the Dow has often moved to a different drummer. Of the 11 days in 2000 on which the Nasdaq has fallen at least 3 percent, four of them have seen the Dow go up.
For now, at least, it appears that the new-economy stocks that zoomed last year and early this year are falling. Meanwhile, the old-economy stocks that did not rise much if at all in that period are gaining ground.
It used to be that when panic struck equity investors they bailed out of stocks in general, putting money into cash. But these days it appears that they are more likely to buy other stocks instead. The belief in technology stocks is being challenged, but not the faith over all in the stock market.
General Electric, which rose $3.3125, to $158.9375, yesterday, is again the most valuable company in the land, with a market value of $527 billion, compared with $506 billion for Cisco and $473 billion for Microsoft, according to Bloomberg Financial Markets. A week ago, G.E. was in third place.
Microsoft is among the most widely held stocks in the country, both in individual portfolios and in mutual funds. But the extent to which holders were hurt yesterday depended largely on what else was held. Diversified funds with many large stocks were not badly damaged, while funds concentrated in technology stocks were. The Fidelity Magellan Fund, for which Microsoft was the largest holding at last report, was off just 0.3 percent yesterday, in part because G.E. was the fund's second-largest holding. But the Fidelity OTC Portfolio and the Fidelity Select Technology Fund, for which Microsoft was also the largest holding, fell 7.8 and 9.2 percent, respectively.
The easy-come, easy-go nature of this market is illustrated by the PBHG Technology and Communications Fund, which fell 13.6 percent yesterday. At its peak on March 9, the fund was up 71.5 percent from the end of 1999. Now its gain for the year has been cut to 7.9 percent.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Hurricane Hugo

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
One of the newest government office buildings in Caracas is the marbled-sided Ministry of Finance. Walking through the lobby there the other day I noticed that the huge clock overlooking the reception desk was either (a) broken or (b) 20 minutes slow. I didn't stay long enough to see which. But I did stay in Venezuela long enough to realize that many people were asking the same thing about President Hugo Chavez's leadership.
Is it broken? Or is it just a little late in blooming? Is he leading Venezuela in a transition, the exact direction of which will emerge after the May 28 presidential elections, or is he leading Venezuela into a dead end? 
 Who is Hugo Chavez? You hear that a lot here, and not just from the corrupt politicians who ruled Venezuela for four decades before the populist Mr. Chavez ousted them in a vote last year that amounted to an electoral revolution. With unemployment here at 20 percent, and with the economy having shrunk by 7.2 percent last year, even some of the poor have turned against Mr. Chavez with graffiti: "He feeds us rhetoric to fill our minds, but our stomachs are empty."
Maybe the best description of Mr. Chavez was from a diplomat here who said: "Hugo Chavez is a work in progress -- and a piece of work."
The Hugo Chavez who is a piece of work is the Chavez who ordered U.S. military ships steaming to Venezuela -- on an emergency aid mission to rebuild the vital coastal highway destroyed by mudslides -- to go away. Mr. Chavez, a former army colonel and pal of Fidel Castro, didn't want to look too dependent on the U.S. He recently described Mr. Castro's medical-welfare system as a "sea of happiness" -- ignoring how many Cubans were risking their lives to swim away from that sea.
But the Hugo Chavez who is a work in progress is equally interesting. Venezuela's political system needed a radical overhaul, and Mr. Chavez is doing that. But so far his biggest reform has been to rewrite the Constitution to widen his powers and lengthen his potential time in office.
If Mr. Chavez is re-elected in May -- he is being challenged by Francisco Arias Cardenas, a former comrade who has charged Mr. Chavez with incompetence -- the big question is, what will he build on his new foundation, and with whom? Frankly, his team has a certain Keystone Kops, not-ready-for-prime-time quality to it.
The challenge is obvious. Venezuela is a country that has been cursed with oil. The reigning assumption in this nation, which sits atop some of the world's richest oilfields, has been that Venezuela is naturally rich and if it is getting poorer it is because someone in power is stealing. So politics has tended to be about whom to lynch, not what to build. The truth is, though, that with 85 percent of its foreign currency coming from oil sales, Venezuela is a country that has forgotten how to create wealth. It only knows how to distribute it. First the oligarchs distributed it to their cronies. Now Mr. Chavez wants to give more to the underclass.
But there isn't enough oil money anymore, and Mr. Chavez has not detailed any credible plan for creating new wealth -- by attracting non-energy-related foreign investment and building globally competitive companies -- so that one-fifth of the country doesn't have to work for the government. Today, the biggest export of Venezuela's private sector is itself; the managers and scientists who have global skills are leaving, frightened by the rising crime wave and the Chavez populism that suggests that anyone here who has money must have stolen it.
Hugo Chavez ran for office as Robin Hood in a country that needs Bill Gates -- someone who not only redistributes wealth but knows how to create it. Mr. Chavez came into office with a deep suspicion of globalization. But on his recent trip to Beijing it was the Chinese who told him to pay more attention to developing a globally competitive private sector.
Mr. Chavez deserves a chance to prove himself as something more than Robin Hood. If he can use his credibility with Venezuela's underclass to lead it to a more modern economy, he will become one of the most important figures in Latin America. If he doesn't, Venezuela, which is America's largest supplier of oil, is going to witness some really explosive and destabilizing politics.
Time is short, and, somewhere at least, a clock is ticking.

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: THE HOMETOWN;
Reaction in the Northwest Favors Gates and Company Even as the Stock's Value Falls by Billions of Dollars

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., April 3

 BODY:
When Microsoft got its legal thrashing from a federal judge today, the Seattle area's roaring economy got a bit of a jolt, too. With about 40 percent of the company's stock in the hands of people who live in the region, roughly $32 billion, on paper anyway, vanished here between the time William H. Gates and Steve Ballmer, the company's two top leaders, rose this morning and the time they stepped to a podium here to respond to the judge's finding.
But sounding no less self-assured than they have throughout their antitrust battle with the government, both men calmly defended the software giant's actions, predicted vindication in both the marketplace and the legal arena, and reiterated a through-the-looking-glass depiction of how government prosecutors had misunderstood the company. 
 "This ruling turns on its head the reality that consumers know -- that our software has helped make PC's more accessible and more affordable to millions," said Mr. Gates, Microsoft's co-founder and chairman. "Innovation will continue to be the No. 1 priority at Microsoft."
And while Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson concluded that the company had violated antitrust laws and kept "an oppressive thumb" on the competition, Mr. Ballmer in effect insisted that Microsoft's legal and image problems stemmed from the fact that it had never been able to shed its little-guy mentality.
"We've spent the past 25 years thinking of ourselves as a small, aggressive company playing catch-up to industry giants even though at some point along the way we became a large company," said Mr. Ballmer, the chief executive. "Our intense focus on moving forward has at times been seen as threatening and our passion for being the best has been misinterpreted. We can do better. But that doesn't mean innovating any less or delivering any less value to consumers."
If such a view may inspire derision from competitors in Silicon Valley, it still has considerable resonance in the Seattle area, where today's news did not seem to generate any large sense of panic. In fact, it prompted many people in the street to express anger that -- as more than one person put it -- their taxpayer dollars were being spent to "harangue" the company.
"When the government typed up the indictment, what did they use to type it up with?" said Selah Houdin, a student at Seattle Central Community College. "They used Microsoft. They had the option to use other programs to type it up. They chose Microsoft because it's best."
Money managers who are heavily invested in Microsoft stock were clearly not happy, but most said they considered the company's long-term prospects excellent and were not inclined to sell off now.
"I really don't think the outlook is much different than it was Friday," said Bill Whitlow, manager of the Safeco Northwest Fund, a mutual fund with roughly 6 percent of its $152 million in holdings in Microsoft stock. Like many other analysts here, he noted that the stock had actually enjoyed a run-up recently, built in part on unrealistic expectations that a settlement was at hand. And several noted that even if the company was broken up, a prospect they still considered unlikely, the sum of its parts might well be worth more than its current whole, as was famously the case with John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil trust.
Glenn Pascall, a senior fellow at the Institute for Public Policy at the University of Washington, who has studied the company's impact on the local economy, said many people here viewed today's ruling as an "interim legal event" in a long-running fight.
"I'm just not sure you're going to see a lot of gnashing of teeth in response to this," said Mr. Pascall, who is also a columnist in The Puget Sound Business Journal. Asked to characterize the fallout from today's ruling, he said: "I would say that a small number of people with large holdings of Microsoft stock suffered a large one-day paper loss because of an overreaction to the end of an unrealistic expectation of an early resolution. The market has totally discounted the fact that Microsoft would have had to make significant concessions to resolve the process through negotiation."
If such sanguine reactions were typical here, they may themselves wind up being overly optimistic.
Microsoft's role in the Northwest economy is obviously huge, and the company now accounts for nearly 60 percent of the total market value of all publicly traded companies in the Pacific Northwest, according to Mr. Whitlow at the Safeco fund.
As big a hit as its stock took today, the company could be battered even more severely if the case drags on for months or years, or if today's ruling, as many analysts predict, prompts a flood of new lawsuits from competitors or even disgruntled individual customers. Such lawsuits would drain more resources of the company and bring more bad publicity, regardless of whether Microsoft prevails in the courts. And the whole case has arisen at a crucial juncture in the development of software, which is rapidly being fused to the Internet.
While some people faulted the company for failing to strike a deal with the government, others applauded Microsoft for resisting that option, and Mr. Ballmer hardly appeared in a conciliatory mood.
"Until the appeal's over, nothing's settled -- we've learned that through experience," he said. "I couldn't be more proud of this great company, its incredible employees and its breakthrough products." And, he added, "I believe in this company more today than I ever have."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Carmakers' Post Records With Strong March Sales
Five leading automakers posted record sales for the month of March, topping off a quarter that was the best ever for the American automobile industry. 
 Ford, DaimlerChrysler, Toyota, Honda and Mitsubishi all reported record sales for the month while G.M., which had had a special promotion in February, was up only slightly and continued to lose market share. Page C8.
 
CBS Morning Show Is Struggling
CBS spent $30 million to revamp its morning program, brought in one of its pre-eminent stars, Bryant Gumbel, left, and one of its most experienced producers, Steve Friedman, to make a push to become a serious competitor on the morning television lineup. But in the months that have followed, the program's ratings have been falling. C2.
 
Biotech Companies Plan Promotion
Responding to a backlash against genetically engineered crops, some of the world's biggest biotechnology companies are planning a $50 million campaign to convince consumers that the products are safe. C6.
 
New Data Show Economic Growth
A monthly report from the National Association of Purchasing Management said manufacturing expanded for a 14th consecutive month in March, while the Commerce Department said construction spending rose 1.5 percent in February, to a record annual rate of $758.7 billion. The two reports added to the evidence that the nation's economy has not slowed down despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases over the last year. C18.
 
Mattel to Sell the Learning Company
Mattel said that it would seek a buyer for the Learning Company, the educational software unit that it bought in May for $3.6 billion and which has been in a slump ever since, leading to $300 million in losses and the resignation of its chief executive. Analysts think Mattel will get only a fraction of the price that it paid for the company. C10.
 
Bell Atlantic-GTE Picks a New Name
Trying to trade their somewhat stodgy images for that of a young technology dynamo, Bell Atlantic and GTE said that they would call their combined company Verizon after their merger deal is completed. C6.
Aurora Foods Restates Its Profit
Aurora Foods, owner of well-known brands like Duncan Hines and Log Cabin, named a new chief executive and restated its earnings for 1998 and 1999. The moves come in response to an investigation by the company into how it accounted for promotional spending and follows the resignation in February of four of its top executives. C2.
 
Telephone Competition in Mexico
Telephone companies struggling to make inroads in the Mexican long-distance market say Telefonos de Mexico still benefits from monopoly advantages and friendly regulators, but the Mexican company says inexperience with the Mexican market is partly to blame. C4.
 
USA Today Gets a Makeover
Almost two decades after the splashy birth of USA Today, with its vivid colors and snappy graphics, yesterday's issue introduced a makeover with pages and sections designed to present a more sober image. Among other changes, the newspaper reduced the width of its pages. C10.
 
Adviser to Celebrities Is Charged
Federal authorities have charged Dana C. Giacchetto, an investment counselor to actors, rock bands and other artists, with stealing $6 million from his clients. B3

HEADLINE: Lagging in Education, the South Experiments

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 3

 BODY:
The states of the South, long home to the nation's poorest and worst-performing students, have desperately begun to experiment with education theories and school reform plans in ways that are drawing national attention.
While experimentation is going on in a few states in other regions, almost every Southern governor, Republican or Democrat, is either hunting for new school money or trying combinations of familiar and occasionally untested ideas for improving student achievement. Some of the plans mix new spending for large state education agencies and teacher salaries with conservative proposals like vouchers and an end to teacher job protection. 
 "The Southern states have really been pushing the envelope," said Kathy Christie, who runs the information clearinghouse at the Education Commission of the States, a nonprofit policy group based in Denver. "They may be low in achievement, on average, but they have a number of high-quality proposals out there that may start to change that in the next few years."
Gov. Paul E. Patton of Kentucky seemed to be speaking for the entire South earlier this year when he informed state lawmakers of his top four priorities: "Education, education, education and education." Not all his colleagues have been quite so wry about it, but in virtually every statehouse in the South, the priorities are essentially the same.
Georgia is about to become the first state in the country to wipe out all job protection for teachers, a measure Gov. Roy Barnes pushed through the state legislature over the objections of teacher organizations as a message that the world had changed. The end of tenure is the most attention-getting element of Mr. Barnes's sweeping education overhaul, approved last month, which mandates smaller class sizes, bonuses for teachers in good schools and a new education bureaucracy to monitor annual testing.
South Carolina has been spending more than $70 million a year to raise teacher salaries above the regional average and provide scholarships for future teachers, and it has established a new training institute for principals.
A Texas approach begun in the early 1990's and enhanced by Gov. George W. Bush has put a strong emphasis on testing, breaking new ground in the close monitoring of low-income and minority students.
North Carolina -- hailed along with Texas in a 1998 study by the National Education Goals Panel as having made among the largest gains in reading and math scores in the first part of the 1990's -- is tightening the licensing of both new and experienced teachers. At the same time, it is offering substantial bonuses for teachers in high-performing schools.
Florida has pioneered a program to provide private-school vouchers for students in poorly performing public schools. The program was recently ruled unconstitutional by a state judge, but the state is appealing the decision.
As the region with the lowest per-capita income, the South has always lagged the rest of the country in educational achievement, burdened by its former reliance on low-skill jobs and the residue of segregated school systems. Forty percent of Americans without high school diplomas are in the South, twice the percentage of any other region, according to the Southern Regional Education Board, a cooperative compact to improve the public schools.
The South was slower than the rest of the country to begin its school reform, and for all the recent years of innovation, performance has just barely begun to move up. The Southeast is still the lowest-ranking of the nation's four regions on the federal government's National Assessment of Education Progress tests.
Of the 16 states that belong to the regional board, only 6 meet the national average for proficiency in fourth-grade reading (although others have shown some improvement), and only 3 do so in eighth-grade reading. In the Deep South, only North Carolina meets the national proficiency averages for both grades.
"We've lagged behind the rest of the country for so long that there is a much greater receptivity to experimentation," said John Dornan, executive director of the Public School Forum, a nonprofit public policy group based in Raleigh, N.C. "The states are trying a lot of high-stakes programs, but we're just now starting to fight our way up to average."
As in most states, the effort to improve public schools began in the South with the dire warnings published 17 years ago in "A Nation at Risk," a federal commission's report attacking the quality of American education, and was prodded by business leaders who said the regional economy was at stake. But the South had much further to go than the rest of the country. It spent less on education than any other region, and had by far the largest number of dropouts and failing students. Nowhere was the connection between student poverty and school performance more evident.
"We just didn't put importance in the state of public education until the last few years," Governor Barnes, of Georgia, said in an interview last week, riffling through bulging folders of education statistics. "Because in the South you didn't have to. You had manufacturing concerns -- kids could drop out in high school and go to work at a mill. Well, the mills are no longer there; the mills are in Mexico or Asia. The economy has changed, and we've got to improve our standards or we won't have the smart people to fill those jobs."
Governors of the New South like Lamar Alexander in Tennessee and Richard Riley in South Carolina first began talking like this in the 1980's, trying to repair their states' reputations with the first wave of school reforms like testing and improving teacher quality. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina, one of the earliest and most successful education advocates among the governors, was the founding chairman of the national standards board that certifies teachers in their fields, and his state now leads the nation in board-certified teachers.
Other states, particularly in the Deep South, moved more slowly, but now it is no longer possible to be a Southern governor without a similar agenda. In Mississippi, which has the nation's lowest-performing schools, Gov. Ronnie Musgrove promised in his inaugural address in January to find $286 million to raise teacher salaries to the regional average over the next five years (although he has not yet persuaded legislators).
Next door, in Alabama, Gov. Donald Siegelman has also proposed substantial raises for teachers, in exchange for making it easier to dismiss them without a lengthy procedure. But after his plan for a state lottery to support education failed last year, he said the money would have to come out of the same pot as is used for higher education, and now university administrators have come out against the proposal.
In any case, it is the South's wealthier states, like Georgia, Florida and the Carolinas, that are setting the pace for innovation. Georgia's plan, centering on school accountability, is typical of what other Southern states are approving or considering, and Governor Barnes frankly admits that much of it was borrowed from North Carolina.
The Georgia plan, passed overwhelmingly in the state legislature last month and set to be signed into law in a few weeks, is based on annual tests in Grades 1 through 12 in reading, writing, mathematics, science and social studies. If students meet the goals set by a new State Office of Education Accountability, the teachers in their school will get bonus pay. If students in a school fail repeatedly, they will be allowed to move to a different school, and teachers and administrators can be disciplined or dismissed.
At the same time, class sizes will be limited to 21 students in first through third grade, down from the current maximum of 33; in later grades, class sizes can grow to 28. School councils of parents, teachers and business leaders will be set up to work with principals.
Any teacher dismissed will be given a written reason but will not have the right to a hearing. Although a few other states have shortened the hearing process, none of them have eliminated it entirely.
The larger of two state teachers organizations, the Professional Association of Georgia Educators, eventually dropped its opposition when Mr. Barnes agreed that the dismissal rule would be applied only to teachers hired from now on, not to existing faculty. But a smaller teachers group, the Georgia Association of Educators, remains opposed; its executive director, Drew Albritton, said the provision would drive away good teachers by permitting arbitrary dismissals.
Mr. Barnes, a Democrat who ran the risk of alienating a crucial constituency of his party with the measure, acknowledged that there was no statistical link between teacher tenure rights and student achievement. But he said the move sent a message to educators that change would be pronounced. "Tenure is an outdated concept," he said, "born of a time when we treasured process over performance."
Georgia's consensus is not always easy to come by, however, especially in states that passed the first reform measures some time ago and are now coming to realize that the costs only go up. In Kentucky, which has seen steady improvement since passing a school reform bill in 1990, legislators have been unable to agree on Governor Patton's proposal to pay for enhanced teacher training programs. Gov. Mike Foster of Louisiana has not been able to find the $220 million he wants to raise teacher salaries to the Southeastern average, and the state's teachers groups are murmuring about an autumn strike.
"We've actually made a lot of progress, considering where we were," said Mark Musick, president of the Southern Regional Education Board. "But we had a lot of room to make progress. The next steps are going to be even harder."

COMPANY: EDUCATION COMMISSION OF THE STATES (56%); EDUCATION COMMISSION OF THE STATES (56%); 

ORGANIZATION: EDUCATION COMMISSION OF THE STATES (56%); EDUCATION COMMISSION OF THE STATES (56%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: SOUTHERN STATES (US); GEORGIA; ALABAMA; MISSISSIPPI; KENTUCKY; UNITED STATES (93%); GEORGIA, USA (93%); ALABAMA, USA (92%); SOUTHEAST USA (92%); MISSISSIPPI, USA (92%); SOUTH CAROLINA, USA (79%); NORTH CAROLINA, USA (79%); ATLANTA, GA, USA (79%); 

SUBJECT: EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; REFORM AND REORGANIZATION; FINANCES; BUDGETS AND BUDGETING; TEACHERS AND SCHOOL EMPLOYEES; WAGES AND SALARIES; VOUCHERS; TENURE TEACHING & TEACHERS (92%); EMPLOYMENT (91%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (90%); TEACHER COMPENSATION (90%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); EDUCATION REFORM (90%); US STATE GOVERNMENT (90%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (90%); SCHOOL PERFORMANCE (89%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (89%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (78%); SCHOOL VOUCHERS (78%); PRIVATE SCHOOLS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); GOVERNORS (78%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (78%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (77%); US DEMOCRATIC PARTY (76%); BUDGETS (76%); MATHEMATICS (74%); NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS (73%); SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS (73%); LOW INCOME PERSONS (73%); APPROVALS (70%); PERSONAL & FAMILY INCOME (60%);
