HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Williams Designated To Take a Back Seat

BYLINE: By Harvey Araton 

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif.

 BODY:
WHO said the Yankees didn't have a left-handed designated hitter? As long as Bernie Williams's throwing shoulder hurts, they've got the best one they've ever had.
"A dull ache, but it doesn't hurt when I swing," Williams said in a clubhouse charged with the anticipation of a new season, another one promising to last into October, no matter what those Grapefruit League standings said. 
 Somehow, the Yankees survived another Darryl Strawberry walk on the wild side, and Ed Yarnall's lack of control and a few Florida afternoons when George Steinbrenner was about to burst. That's what spring training is for, working out the kinks, weeding out the kooks and getting your serious lineup together and intentions in order just in time for opening day.
Speaking of serious and well-intentioned, here's Williams on the eve of the Yankees' 2000 debut last night -- on American soil but past everyone's bedtime back East, and how come Mark McGwire doesn't sound off about that?
"It's not that we want to win more than anybody else," Williams said before the Yankees used a familiar formula -- solid starting pitching (by Orlando Hernandez) and timely hitting -- to defeat the Angels 3-2 at Edison Field. "It's what we're playing for, the generations."
If that sounds hokey, then go explain the amazing century not long ago concluded with the Yankees' third World Series title in four years, the last two in four-game sweeps, for a 20th-century grand total of 25, or the most glorious .250 batting average there'll ever be.
Explain Williams entering a 10th season in a Yankee uniform and a 15th year at work for one organization, which is so much against the odds of modern sports economics that Williams's face must be on a dartboard somewhere in Marvin Miller's basement.
Oh, it's an old story how Williams was so close to signing with the Red Sox in November 1999 that he could smell the Fenway Park sausage. The point is, he didn't, because Steinbrenner coughed up $87.5 million (over seven years) and Williams weighed a few extra Boston millions against center field in Yankee Stadium and all that interlocking history stitched into his cap and shirt.
New York being New York, Williams heard that although he was a wonderful guy and that old softie Steinbrenner had made the sentimental decision, maybe Albert Belle would have been a better idea, given Williams's visits to the disabled list. Then the verdict came in, and the contemporary notion that long-term security is the death of motivation, especially for a player like laid-back Bernie, had been debunked.
"I'm proud of the fact that I played 158 games, despite the fact that my left shoulder was killing me in the second half of the season," he said.
He more than played; he produced. Career highs in hits (202), runs batted in (115) and runs scored (116). Yes, there were times in the early months last season when Williams seemed to be on cruise control, but, as Manager Joe Torre said, "He's one of those guys who's struggling, and you look up and he's hitting .330."
For the record, Williams hit .342, another career best. "He's our superstar on a team that supposedly doesn't have superstars," David Cone said. "Derek Jeter is the de facto captain, the guy we look to as a leader. But Bernie is the guy who can really carry us, with those power numbers."
Of course, Williams not only played down Cone's assertion that he is the difference between very good and great, but almost looked baffled by it, before deferring to his elders, like Paul O'Neill. "He's 37 and he's got 6 percent body fat," Williams said. "Being around guys like Paul motivates me."
Williams, hitless in four at-bats in his d.h. debut, should be plenty fired up after watching O'Neill's 430-foot, two-run clout over the center-field fence give the Yankees a 2-1 lead in the sixth, minutes after Hernandez fanned Mo Vaughn with the bases loaded.
You could almost smell opportunity at that point and the Yankees, as is their trademark, did not waste it. They played it training-camp cool down in Florida, but the exhibitions ended, mercifully, and the Yankees did have a better record than the Red Sox, so how bad was it?
Everybody should have the Yankees' problems. Ramiro Mendoza will cover the No. 5 spot until Steinbrenner's baseball people figure out a permanent solution. And as for the d.h., that's where Williams started last night -- with Ricky Ledee in center field -- and is likely to remain for a while.
Williams took a back seat last night. He used the extra time on the bench to hit off the tee, watch some video, root El Duque through on a night he didn't have his best stuff. All those exciting pastimes that come so naturally for a star who hides in the clubhouse, strumming his guitar. Then you look up, and he's hitting .342.

HEADLINE: Computer Scientist Picked As President of Stanford

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 3

 BODY:
Underscoring Stanford University's deep relationship with Silicon Valley, John Hennessy, the provost and a professor of electrical engineering and computer science who founded a semiconductor company, today was named president of the institution.
A well-known computer architect who has taught at Stanford for 22 years, Dr. Hennessy, who is 47, was appointed provost in July. 
 Within months he had secured a $150 million donation to the university, the largest since its founding, from James H. Clark, a former colleague in the computer science department who went on to found the Netscape Communications Corporation. The money is being used to develop Dr. Hennessy's pet project, an interdisciplinary program in biomedical engineering and sciences.
In addition to founding the semiconductor company, MIPS Technologies, Dr. Hennessy wrote with David Patterson, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, a seminal textbook on designing computers, "Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach" (Morgan Kaufmann Publishers, 1990).
Despite Stanford's connections to the very start of Silicon Valley -- when the former Stanford students William Hewlett and David Packard began an electronics company in a garage in Palo Alto -- Dr. Hennessy is the university's first president with an engineering background.
Before becoming provost, he was the popular dean of the school of engineering, where he developed its first online degree program -- a master's in electrical engineering -- and increasingly offered online classes.
His appointment as president was expected; Stanford has a long history of appointing leaders from within.
Dr. Hennessy will succeed Gerhard Caspar, a constitutional law scholar who announced his retirement in September after eight years. Dr. Caspar, who said he planned to take a sabbatical and then return to teaching, transformed Stanford into one of the most effective fund-raising universities in the world, stabilizing a university that had been accused of bilking the federal government for research. Dr. Caspar directed Stanford's most comprehensive cost-cutting efforts in 30 years, remade the undergraduate curriculum and oversaw a $1 billion construction, preservation and restoration program.
In an interview this afternoon, an ebullient Dr. Hennessy said he planned to continue to "build on the foundation" that Dr. Caspar created.
One issue Dr. Hennessy faces as a Silicon Valley president is assuaging concerns that Stanford is becoming a "techie" paradise at the expense of its humanities and social science departments. An editorial in today's Stanford Daily urged him to make a special commitment to the humanities.
Dr. Hennessy said he intended to devote attention to the fields, including using his connections in Silicon Valley to help the humanities and social science departments secure more support for their programs.
"I think there are a lot of entrepreneurs who come from these backgrounds and appreciate their importance," he said.
Another challenge, Dr. Hennessy said, is keeping and recruiting faculty members in the most expensive housing market in the country. The university must also keep students from being lured away by the high-paying Silicon Valley companies before earning their degrees, he noted.
The university is finishing a housing study he commissioned as provost, he said, to address ways to develop housing that faculty members can afford. As for retaining staff and students, he said: "We're in the heat of the gold rush. After a little while it will calm down a little bit. There will still be a lot of students interested in entrepreneurship and the new economy. But they'll want to get their graduate studies done first. I fully believe that."

HEADLINE: Start-Up Need Help? Hire Dad Or Mom

BYLINE: By AMY ZIPKIN 

 BODY:
Fifteen months ago, 34-year-old Gregory P. Sullivan enlisted a retired financial executive in Lancaster, N.H., to help start an Internet company called Flagship Communications that specialized in e-support and telemarketing services.
The older man, a one-time division controller at the James River Corporation (now the Fort James Corporation) in Deerfield, Ill., became Mr. Sullivan's first employee and, overnight, his workplace confidant. He accepted a board position and even traveled to Portland, Me., and stayed in his new boss's guest house while the two worked around the clock on the project. 
 "When your child comes to you and has a need, you go," said Kevin Sullivan, 58, who is Gregory's father.
Bill Gates isn't the only Internet entrepreneur to put his dad on the payroll. (He appointed the elder Mr. Gates co-chairman of the $21.8 billion Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation last year.) In the dot-com world, peopled largely by 20-somethings and 30-whatevers, an increasing number of chief executives are turning to their fathers and mothers to tap into the one qualification the whiz kid lacks by definition: experience.
"It's amazing how common it is," said Bruce Tulgan, president of Rainmaker Thinking, a New Haven, Conn., consulting firm. "People come up to me at conferences all the time and say, 'I'm working for my child, or my dad is working for me.' "
Experts cite a variety of factors for the trend, starting with the youthfulness of dotcom chief executives. One 1998 study by the Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco and the National Federation of Independent Business in Washington, showed that people under 35 were responsible for 42 percent of all business start-ups.
Perhaps the biggest motivator is an intangible: the desire to have older people around with old-economy skills, sound judgment and an unquestioned commitment to the boss's well-being.
"Children tend to trust their parents more than they could trust someone else," says Linda Dash, 52. Her son Darien, 28, founder of DME Interactive Holdings, a New York company that provides Internet access and customized content to minority households, hired her last May as general manager to oversee operations after it began trading publicly. "I never in a million years expected to be doing this," Ms. Dash said. As a self-described "do-everything person," she said she became computer-literate on the job. One of only two employees over 35, she dispenses motherly advice to co-workers by stressing the importance of education. "I'm having a ball," she said.
While parents like Ms. Dash bring enthusiasm and energy to their new jobs, others have resumes that would make them a catch almost anywhere.
Martin Kogon, 59, who was hired to run a unit of his son's dot-com business last year, holds an M.B.A. from Wharton and owned four businesses the last three and a half decades, including National Dynamics, Management Ventures and Central Metals Recycling, all based in Atlanta.
Since he took over as president of Websiteforfree.com, a division of Definition 6, a Web development and design company in Atlanta that his son Michael, 30, started in his garage in 1997, Mr. Kogon has helped assemble a board and taken a leading role in contract negotiations. In early January he relinquished the title to become director of special projects for the entire company.
His co-workers affectionately call him "gray matter," a reference to both his hair color and his experience, and seek his advice about everything from reading a person's character to making a home purchase. The father, though, takes care to rein in his opinions about the business. Otherwise, he said, his fellow employees would take his comments to mean, "Marty said to do it that way, either because I'm older or have more knowledge or I'm Michael's dad."
At most, his son Michael says, he might tell a midlevel manager, "If the vote were mine, this is what my suggestion would be."
Father and son have an informal strategy for resolving disagreements. "I say if you're not nice to me, I'll tell your mother," jokes the elder Mr. Kogon. In response, he says, Michael usually says: "Be nice to me, or I'll tell my mother."
For all the jesting, reversing the traditional power relationship in an office setting can be tricky. "Misunderstandings arise when roles aren't clearly defined or when parents are used to telling the child what to do," said Ross W. Nager, executive director of the Arthur Anderson Center for Family Business in Houston.
Other specialists issue even direr warnings. Paul Karofsky, executive director of Northeastern University's Center for Family Business in Boston, says he can guarantee that going into business together won't strengthen the bonds between parent and child and might weaken them. "When there's stress in the business, stress in the family comes to the fore," he said.
The elder Mr. Sullivan, the retired executive who helped his son start Flagship Communications in Maine last year, found that out. When he switched from reporting to his son's former partner to answering directly to his son, he found himself wanting to march in and issue reprimands. "The most difficult thing was the role reversal," he said. "In the office, you're Kevin, not Dad."
The younger Mr. Sullivan said he, too, had his doubts. And so, shortly after a joint venture in which Flagship Communications was a partner was spun off last January, Kevin Sullivan jumped ship and became a partner at the new company.
But Gregory Sullivan apparently could not get enough paternal advice. Three weeks before his father left, he hired his stepfather, Bob Gilbert, 64, to fill the newly created position of executive vice president for operations.
"I'm doing it because I love Gregg," said Mr. Gilbert, who has 23 years of experience in selling and establishing fulfillment and lead distribution systems. Another reason for choosing Flagship Communications over several competing offers, he said, was that it did not require relocation.
So far, he has no regrets. "I've told the human-resources guy: get a mix of people in here," he said. If I'm having this much fun, why shouldn't other people?"

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Thenew economy causes a shift in the way two Madison Avenue agencies serve clients.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TWO well-known agencies based in New York are reorganizing in ways that are indicative of the substantive shifts taking place along Madison Avenue to try matching the pace of change in cyberspace and at client companies.
One agency, Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/ Euro RSCG, is combining under one roof a variety of services outside the realm of traditional advertising that include interactive marketing, sales promotion, retail advertising, data base management, direct marketing and design. 
 Those communications services are being offered by Messner Vetere, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, under the name Fuel North America. That had been the name of a unit devoted to handling the retail account of a large client, Volvo.
And Mezzina/Brown, an agency that has added a skein of dot-com accounts to a client roster that includes DuPont; Goldman, Sachs; and R. J. Reynolds, is being reorganized under the name Mezzina Brown & Partners. The goal of the principals of Mezzina Brown, who are teaming up with outside companies that include Netcentric Partners, a venture capital firm, is to place additional emphasis on business development for so-called new-economy marketers.
Ron Berger, chief executive and chief creative officer at Messner Vetere, offered an explanation of the shifts at his agency that described the motivations of both shops.
"We want to design and evolve the agency's offerings to reflect where the world is today," Mr. Berger said, "building on our experience with brands and our clients' needs."
Fuel North America has about 140 employees handling assignments with billings estimated at $100 million, which include the Volvo retail account, creating campaigns for the automaker's dealer associations, as well as for other Messner Vetere clients like Intel, MCI WorldCom, J. P. Morgan, New Balance, Philips and Schering-Plough.
Among the operations being combined under the Fuel North America banner, in addition to the Volvo unit, are the New York office of Cohn & Wells Partners, which specialized in direct marketing; Compelling Content, an interactive agency acquired in September by Cohn & Wells; and the Messner Vetere divisions focused on design, sales promotion and Internet ad work.
Fuel North America, which reports to Mr. Berger, has four partners, headed by Beth Waxman, 37, managing director, who continues as a partner at Messner Vetere, where she had been overseeing the Intel account. The other partners at Fuel North America, all creative directors, are: Bertrand Garbassi, 40; Marshall Karp, who declined to give his age; and Paul Trantanella, 37.
At Mezzina Brown, which has about 120 employees and billings estimated at $145 million, a highlight of the restructuring is the formation of a specialty division, MB Capital and Consultancy, "devoted to helping pre-I.P.O. dot-coms identify business models, determine efficient revenue streams and even if necessary write their business plans," said William G. Brown Jr.
Mr. Brown, 52, becomes senior partner and chief executive of the agency after serving as president before the reorganization. John Mezzina, 51, shifts from chairman and executive creative director to senior partner and chief strategy officer. Mark A. Morrissey, 41, executive vice president and client services director, becomes partner and chief operating officer. And David Frutko, 49, continues as chief financial officer while moving from executive vice president to partner.
Mr. Brown said that Mr. Mezzina would take "a temporary leave of absence" from the agency to focus on Freeride.com L.L.C., an Internet company spun off from Mezzina/ Brown in 1996 that offers computer users rewards meant to strengthen their ties to companies with which they do business.
"John's leave is to shepherd that business to the next level," Mr. Brown said, smiling. He declined to elaborate.
Can you say initial public offering?
Among the dot-com clients of Mezzina Brown, which started an interactive division in 1993, are Freeride.com, NexGenix, Newsweek magazine, Real Media, VarsityPlanet.com and Wit Capital.
"In response to the new economy, we've created our consultancy group," Mr. Brown said, "which can also help source capital through Netcentric Partners," with a war chest planned to reach $200 million.
Cheryl L. Benton is joining Mezzina Brown as managing director for interactive services, overseeing the MB Interactive division. Ms. Benton, 49, had been executive vice president at JMCP Touch Interactive, a division of Jordan McGrath Case & Partners/Euro RSCG, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas.
In another change, seven top executives at Mezzina Brown are being promoted because, Mr. Brown said, "with the dramatic shift in the marketplace for key talent, it's important to offer partnerships to our key players."
The new partners are: Jean Andrews, 38, manager for strategic support services; Robert Earl, 58, managing director for direct marketing creative services; Robert Moore, 47, managing director for account services; Clark Moss, 38, managing director for creative services; Donna L. Walters, 36, managing director for graphic services; Gary Watson, 40, managing director for client services; and Margaret A. Williams, who declined to give her age, managing director for administrative services. The majority shareholders are Messrs. Brown, Frutko, Mezzina and Morrissey.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE;
An Entertainment Titan Finds a Home Where the Action Is

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
The initials SFX may not be as well known in the theater district as TKTS, but just give them time. Say, about six months.
That is when SFX Entertainment Inc., which has quickly become the nation's largest provider of live entertainment, plans to move into the Candler Building, 220 West 42nd Street. Across the street is the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, one of 120 theaters, amphitheaters, arenas and concert halls that SFX controls in the United States. 
 "A lot of our business is right there in the neighborhood," said Michael G. Ferrel, president and chief executive of SFX Entertainment.
The company is leasing the entire 24-story Candler Building for 20 years from Cornerstone Real Estate Advisers of Hartford, a subsidiary of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.
Cornerstone, meanwhile, is close to finishing the Muse, a 200-room hotel that has been created by remodeling and expanding the former Leavitt Building, a 12-story manufacturing loft at 130 West 46th Street.
On the ground floor of the hotel, which is to open in July, will be a 75-seat restaurant designed by David Rockwell, of the Manhattan firm Rockwellgroup, and managed by Gino Diaferia, a partner in the Veritas restaurant, 43 East 20th Street.
Rates at the Muse will run from $250 to $350 a night for rooms and $450 to $600 for suites. It is to be operated by Interstate Hotels of Pittsburgh and was designed by Perkins & Will/Lapidus.
"These two properties are indicative of our philosophy -- doing sound research about markets and where growth lies," said Thomas G. Dudeck, a managing director of Cornerstone. But the rebirth of Times Square, he acknowledged, occurred "with more velocity than we thought."
So has the growth of SFX Entertainment, which Robert F. X. Sillerman spun off in 1998 from SFX Broadcasting. (In radio jargon, "SFX" stands for "sound effects.") The company has consolidated the live-entertainment industry by acquiring companies including Delsener/Slater Enterprises, Bill Graham Presents, the Pace Entertainment Corporation and Livent Inc., builders of the Ford Center. SFX produces everything from Broadway shows to monster-truck events.
SFX plans to merge later this year with Clear Channel Communications Inc. of San Antonio, which operates 867 radio stations, 19 television stations and 550,000 outdoor advertising displays. Corporate headquarters will be in Texas, but the SFX unit will stay in New York, Mr. Ferrel said.
The Candler Building can accommodate 500 to 600 employees, said Peter A. Strauss, vice president and assistant general counsel of SFX.
SFX now has 13 offices in New York, including space in 650 Madison Avenue, at 59th Street; 150 East 58th Street; 888 Seventh Avenue, at 56th Street; and 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street. Many of these offices will be consolidated in the Candler Building.
The company is to receive $3.5 million in tax breaks, tied to job retention, relocation and creation, from the New York City Industrial Development Agency. It will also receive a $500,000 grant from the Empire State Development Corporation.
"SFX is one of the premier -- if not the premier -- entertainment booking agencies," said Michael G. Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "To have this sort of company on 42nd Street is a tremendous accomplishment."
As 42nd Street reached its nadir, the fortunes of the Candler Building also ebbed. In the 1980's, its occupancy rate dropped to zero, it figured in a municipal corruption scandal and it went into foreclosure.
But there was no discussion of demolishing the building, because zoning rules would have prohibited anything larger on the site, said Stephen J. Schofel, executive managing director of GVA Williams, the leasing and managing agent since 1992.
Instead, Cornerstone renovated the exterior and rebuilt the interior, going so far as to move all four passenger elevator shafts to create more efficient layouts. "The floor slabs and the steel are the same," Mr. Schofel said. "Everything else has been upgraded."
Neither Cornerstone, GVA Williams nor SFX would disclose the rent. And it is difficult to assess independently, because the building includes highly desirable retail frontage, oddly shaped midrise floors and upper stories with such sweeping panoramas that they seem to be suspended in space.
According to Julien J. Studley Inc., the New York brokerage firm that represented SFX, the average annual rent in mid-Manhattan at the end of 1999 for other than Class A office space was $44 a square foot. That suggests that SFX is paying around $10 million annually for its 227,000 square feet in the Candler Building, but this could not be confirmed.
Cornerstone invested about $40 million redeveloping the tower, constructed in 1913 by Asa Griggs Candler, who built the Coca-Cola Company into a national giant. The renovation is by the Manhattan architectural firm Swanke Hayden Connell. The original architects of the white terra-cotta tower were Willauer, Shape & Bready.
Ornamenting the arches in the fourth-floor windows, above an entablature inscribed "Candler," are the state seals of his native Georgia, followed by Alabama, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee.
The base of the building will probably have three floors of retail space. No tenant has been signed yet, Mr. Strauss said, but whoever takes the space could build a five-story sign outside.
It will be a challenge to design such a sign without obscuring the facade of the building, which is not a city landmark but is on the National Register of Historic Places, a status that allowed the owners to claim a tax credit for the renovation.
"We and SFX are fully aware of the architectural significance of the building," said Mr. Dudeck of Cornerstone. "The historic tax credit and the historic character of the building have to be taken into account."

HEADLINE: A Peru 'Phenomenon': Rags to Presidential Bid

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru April 4

 BODY:
Alejandro Toledo grew up shining shoes in the grimy port city of Chimbote, one of 16 brothers and sisters whose father was a bricklayer and whose mother sold fish in a street market.
It is an unlikely background for a would-be president in class-conscious Peru. But today Mr. Toledo is doing something that Mario Vargas Llosa, this century's most prominent Peruvian author, could not do in 1990 and that Javier Perez de Cuellar, the former United Nations secretary general, could not do in 1995. 
 Mr. Toledo is giving President Alberto K. Fujimori, the "giant killer" in those two previous runs for the presidency, the toughest political battle of his life. Mr. Toledo is attracting votes from disaffected urban lower-class voters who are rejecting the traditional ruling elites.
Only five weeks ago, Mr. Toledo was a little known business school professor, one with a remarkable rags-to-middle-class story but no credible chance of defeating Mr. Fujimori. His extraordinary political climb -- leapfrogging over several formidable opposition candidates, including the mayor of Lima and a former director of the social security system -- has been called the "Toledo phenomenon" by the press here.
The polls indicate that he will probably stop Mr. Fujimori from winning a first-round victory in the presidential election on Sunday unless there is fraud and that he could even beat Mr. Fujimori in a runoff, which would be in May or June.
The "Toledo phenomenon" represents the coming of age of a huge class of Peruvians: the more than eight million people who have migrated from mostly Indian villages in the Andean highlands to cities across the country in the last 30 years. These Peruvians have given up their little plots of land to work in factories or on fishing boats or simply to beg in the streets.
Mr. Toledo has strong Indian physical traits, making him popular with Indians and those of mixed race, who are known as mestizos or, in Peruvian slang, "cholos." And at 54 he has accomplished the cholo dream of achieving an education, rising from poverty and marrying a woman of higher social status.
Mr. Toledo earned a doctorate at Stanford University, where he met his wife, Eliane Karp, a Belgian-born naturalized American citizen who is an anthropologist and consultant.
"When these people see that I can become president, they realize they can become president too," said Mr. Toledo, seated with his legs intertwined comfortably with his wife's in their rented campaign plane. "It is a matter of hopes and dreams. I'm an example of what people can do who have good health care and an education."
As Mr. Toledo travels across the country, the enthusiasm surrounding his candidacy has grown from week to week even though he has never held high office and who might make up his future cabinet is a total mystery. Hundreds, sometimes thousands, of people block his campaign caravans along roads and jump on top of his "cholomobile" van in what sometimes appears to be mad, uncontrolled excitement.
On the stump, Mr. Toledo mixes moving accounts of his youth with a centrist message that promises more government loans for small businesses and farmers and a gradual phasing out of government handouts of milk and cereal. He takes the time to explain the importance of balancing the government budget and attracting foreign investment -- and in a break from customary Peruvian politics, makes a point of saying that he cannot promise easy, instant solutions to this country's vast social problems.
"I didn't bring you rice or cooking oil because votes cannot be bought," he said, in a pointed criticism of President Fujimori's campaign tactics, before a screaming crowd of 25,000 in the agricultural center of Ica last Friday night. "I've come to bring my talents to bear to offer you jobs, jobs, jobs. I know my people and my people don't want charity. They want jobs."
The crowd responded by chanting what has become the unofficial slogan of Mr. Toledo's campaign, "Cholo si, Chino no!" a reference to Mr. Fujimori, who is popularly known as "El Chino" even though he is of Japanese descent.
Mr. Toledo went on to invite everyone to his inaugural party, where he promised to serve local favorites like fermented corn juice, sweet potatoes and ceviche, marinated raw fish. The crowded responded robustly, chanting, "Toledo is justice!" and "The dictatorship will fall!"
Many of those same people had turned in the past to Mr. Fujimori -- who comes from an immigrant family of fairly modest means -- as an alternative to Mr. Vargas Llosa and Mr. Perez de Cuellar, representatives of the traditional light-skinned Lima elite who are the descendants of the Spanish colonial power structure. But now an increasing number of Peruvians are choosing someone whose features and background more closely resembles theirs.
"From the submissive cholo, Toledo has risen to the sure-footed cholo, and that automatically makes him a leader -- and with a blonde, gringa wife to boot," said Raul Vargas Vega, director of Radioprogramas, Peru's leading radio network. "He has a story that is similar to hundreds of thousands of Peruvians but with a successful ending."
So far, Mr. Fujimori remains ahead in Lima, where he controls most of the news media and has delivered an array of social programs to the shantytowns, as well as in the rural Indian areas, where his free milk and cereal programs still benefit hundreds of thousands of poor people.
But about half of the population of Peru now live in middle-sized cities where people have given up their Indian ways but now appear to have a renewed respect for their ethnic identity. It is in those places, cities like Ica, Iquitos and Arequipa, where Mr. Toledo's campaign has taken off.
The crowds seem not to care that Mr. Toledo is entirely untested as a leader and that he is viewed, perhaps unfairly, as an untrustworthy opportunist by other opposition leaders. Those leaders have openly attacked Vladimiro Montesinos, Mr. Fujimori's intelligence chief, for engaging in dirty campaign tricks. Mr. Toledo has not been spared, but he has responded differently.
Newspapers that are said to take directions from Mr. Montesinos have bombarded Mr. Toledo with charges that he was an adviser to a shady financier whose pyramid scheme collapsed a few years ago and that he has an illegitimate daughter he does not support. But Mr. Toledo, who denies the charges, has quietly sent emissaries to aides of Mr. Montesinos to open talks with him. And with Mr. Toledo's poll numbers continuing to move skyward, he attributes his ability to overcome the attacks to his innate toughness, his wife's support and his ethnic appeal.
Mr. Toledo got his big break in life at 16 when Peace Corps volunteers helped him obtain a one-year scholarship to the University of San Francisco. He managed to continue his studies by pumping gas and getting a soccer scholarship.
He went on to earn two master's degrees and a doctorate in the economics of human resources. He eventually became chief economic adviser to the president of the Central Bank and the minister of labor during the Fernando Belaunde government of the early 1980's. He has since worked for the World Bank and directed research at a prestigious Lima business school.
"I'm a dreamer," Mr. Toledo said, "and I don't apologize for it."

LENGTH: 384 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. TradeRepresentative May Take Action Against Mexico

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 4

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said today that Mexico was failing to support competition in telecommunications and warned that she might take action against Mexico before the World Trade Organization.
"In Mexico, it appears that progress towards a level playing field for telecommunications carriers is now stalled," Ms. Barshefsky said, calling the situation "extremely serious." 
 The United States will decide by July 28 whether to lodge a formal grievance against Mexico with the W.T.O., the Geneva-based group that makes the rules for global commerce. If the W.T.O. were to rule in favor of the United States, Mexico could face punitive sanctions.
The notice to Mexico was part of an annual United States review in which Ms. Barshefsky also threatened to file W.T.O. complaints against South Africa because its telecommunications monopoly had refused to provide high-volume private circuits to competitors.
 AT&T and MCI WorldCom have pressed the trade representative to take Mexico to the W.T.O., arguing that Telefonos de Mexico has abused its advantages as a former monopoly to suppress competition in the Mexican telecommunications industry. Telmex stopped providing dedicated lines for Internet and business service to competitors and charges high rates to complete long-distance calls carried by other companies, the competitors said.
Between them the two international telecommunications giants have invested more than $2 billion in building new networks in Mexico.
The trade representative also criticized Mexican regulators for not bringing Telmex into line. On March 27, only days before the United States' report was due, the Mexican regulatory agency announced new rules to force Telmex to bring down costs and provide services to its competitors. But Ms. Barshefsky's report noted that "Telmex has frustrated similar efforts over the past two years." Telmex has vowed to challenge the regulator's new rules.
The report also criticized Israel for imposing extra charges on calls to the United States and Canada that it did not charge for any other country. Israel has announced that it will cancel the surcharges by Dec. 31, 2001. The trade representative said she could go to the W.T.O. if Israel did not eliminate the charge.

HEADLINE: NFO Worldwide Accepts New Bid

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
NFO Worldwide Inc., the world's No. 3 custom market research company, agreed to a revised offer of $611 million from the Interpublic Group of Companies after rejecting a higher, unsolicited cash bid from an undisclosed bidder.
Interpublic, the No. 2 advertising company, will pay $26 a share. It will also assume $176 million in NFO debt. Patrick Healy, NFO's chief financial officer, said the company had rejected the unsolicited bid of $27.50 a share because some terms were not acceptable. 
 Interpublic, based in New York, owns McCann-Erickson WorldGroup and other ad agencies. It first agreed to buy NFO, based in Greenwich, Conn., in December to bolster its Internet marketing efforts.
NFO, with 1999 revenue of $457.2 million, tracks brands, polls consumers on the Internet and provides panels to help companies test and introduce products. It is the world's largest provider of Internet-based custom marketing research.

HEADLINE: A Key Economic Forecasting Gauge Declined Slightly in February

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators fell in February for the first time in five months as factory orders for capital goods, building permits and stocks declined, a private research group reported yesterday.
The Conference Board's index decreased 0.3 percent in February, after rising 0.2 percent in January. The drop in the index, a gauge of future growth, comes after three successive monthly increases and because of that it does not signal that the record economic expansion is in jeopardy. 
 "We don't think the decline in February indicates any economic softness," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York. "We will probably see some rebound next month."
That suggests that a series of five rate increases by Federal Reserve policy makers since June has yet to slow growth as intended. Even the rate-sensitive housing industry is still showing signs of strength.
Homebuilders completed work on more houses in February than they had in a year. Housing completions rose 7.5 percent that month, to an annual rate of 1.712 million after falling 4.9 percent to a pace of 1.593 million units in January. Housing construction has not slowed in the first two months of the year from last year's pace, when 1.636 million houses were completed.
The February drop in the leading indicators index was the first since a 0.1 percent decline in September. Yesterday's report showed 8 of the 10 index components were negative contributors in February, and 2 had positive effects. Negative contributors were a narrower spread between 10-year Treasury notes and the Federal Reserve's overnight bank lending rate, drops in building permits, orders for nonmilitary capital goods, stock prices, money supply and consumer expectations, faster supplier deliveries and a rise in jobless claims. Increases in factory worker hours and consumer goods orders were positive contributors.

HEADLINE: Sears Agrees to Change Sabbath Work Policy

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company has reached a settlement with the New York State attorney general's office that will bar its stores from firing employees or rejecting job candidates because their religion forbids them to work on certain days.
The agreement stems from a Sears policy that required repair technicians to work on Saturdays. The policy was challenged by Orthodox Jews, who observe the Sabbath on Saturdays, and will also apply to Seventh-day Adventists and other groups. 
 The settlement, which was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, comes after five months of negotiations between Sears and the state attorney general's office.
The agreement applies only to Sears operations in New York State, but the attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, said in an interview that "any company that sees our agreement with Sears should understand that if we hear of evidence of them acting similarly, they will be getting a call from us."
Peggy Palter, a corporate spokeswoman for Sears, which is based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., denied that it had discriminated against anyone but acknowledged that its schedules might have been limiting to some workers.
Ms. Palter said the company had agreed to an 18-month trial period in which its New York State repair operations will be open on Sundays to accommodate schedules of those who observe the Sabbath on Saturdays.
She said the agreement allowed the company to return to the state attorney general for further negotiations if being open on Sundays proved to be an economic hardship for the company.
According to the agreement, Sears must provide back pay and hire the initial five complainants and pay their legal fees, create a work schedule to accommodate those who observe the Sabbath on Saturdays, and train all company employees involved in hiring and training to deal with religious accommodations.
The agreement also allows anyone who comes forward with a similar complaint in the next 90 days to take it to arbitration. The company also has to pay $100,000 for the cost of the attorney general's investigation, $225,000 for the American Law Institute to establish additional training materials on religious accommodations, and 10 scholarships for Sabbath-observant people to attend technical school.
The case began in December 1998, when Richard Katz, an Orthodox Jew from Borough Park, Brooklyn, applied for a job as a repair technician at the Sears office at 4701 Glenwood Road. Mr. Katz said that he was told that he had scored high on the test but that the managers told him that he would not be hired because he was unable to work on Saturdays. Mr. Katz said he offered to work on Sundays or nights but was rebuffed.
Sears officials, in interviews and court papers, repeatedly asserted that the reason for this problem was because Saturdays were the busiest days, but state law enforcement officials said that was untrue. The attorney general's office began investigating in October of last year and started negotiations with Sears, which were completed last week.
In 1972, Congress amended the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to require employers to accommodate reasonably an employee's religious practice or observance, unless to do so would impose an undue hardship on the company. This standard applied to scheduling of work on Sabbath days, as well as accommodations for those required to wear religious garb.
But legal experts said a series of later Supreme Court rulings set the financial standard of undue hardship so low that it had made it difficult for employees, especially when dealing with scheduling, to win such cases.
Since 1997, dozens of religious organizations have been lobbying Congress to pass a workplace religious freedom act, which would more strictly define and raise the undue-hardship standard.

HEADLINE: Newark's Rebirth Pushes Westward;
On a Clear Day, Future Is Visible From the City's Tallest Building

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 4

 BODY:
On any given day, as many as 250 construction workers, plumbers, electricians, restoration specialists and elevator mechanics buzz like bees in and out of the city's tallest building, a 34-story Art Deco confection on the main downtown street.
For the last 18 months, they have been remaking the 70-year-old building at 744 Broad Street, a sentinel on the farthest outpost of Newark's revival. 
 Just about everything these days is viewed as a test of the city's rebirth: from the large, like the March announcement that the New Jersey Nets and Devils teams would be under the same ownership, making a new downtown arena more likely; to the small, such as the prospect of the city's first Starbucks.
So, what happens with 744 Broad is a test of the demand for office space; specifically, whether it can move beyond the Gateway complex, the safe haven of glass and steel built from 1971 to 1988. Clustered around Pennsylvania Station, the four block-shaped structures are connected, fortresslike, by pedestrian bridges. They have been the most marketable and indeed the only prime office space in the city, in large part because of fears about street crime.
But now, just three blocks away, 744 Broad beckons potential tenants to the grand, weathered structures on the old boulevard that have spanned the boom, bust, riot and decay of New Jersey's largest city.
"Perception is as important as reality for places like Newark," said Donald Eisen, executive managing director of Cushman & Wakefield of New Jersey. "And every success to a place like Newark is outsized and has a big impact."
Completed in 1930 as the Newark and Essex National Bank Building, the tower at 744 Broad was a showpiece. With its interior gilding, intricate molding, classical touches and massive murals depicting high points in the city's history from Colonial times onward, it was the apotheosis of Newark as the banking and legal center of New Jersey.
After the city's fortunes sagged, and then plummeted in the 1960's, the building's blue chip tenants left the city. Neglected for two decades, the building sits amid a hodgepodge of sidewalk merchants hawking umbrellas and handbags, as well as sneaker emporiums and cheap retail shops that serve the city's mostly poor, black residents.
The Cogswell Realty Group bought the skyscraper in 1998 at a fire-sale price of $7 million, with plans to invest $50 million into refurbishing it. The investors are restoring the gold leafing and plaster molding to its grand, vaulted entry and are repointing the brickwork. They are refitting the building with 144 strands of fiber optic cabling per floor, T-1 lines for high-speed Internet access throughout, and new coaxial cable.
Arthur Stern, the group's president, said Cogswell was marketing the office space, with some modest success, to high-technology businesses. The space rents for $23 to $33 per square foot, depending on the floor, compared with rents of $28.50 per square foot for the limited available space at the Gateway Center.
Fittingly, a large retail space under renovation on the ground floor is planned as the home of Newark's first Starbucks, Mr. Stern said. A Starbucks spokesman said it did not comment on new outlets until leases were signed.
"If Starbucks comes, can the Gap be far behind?" asked Florence Reichenberg, a partner in a California interiors company, Space Design, which recently signed a lease.
Cogswell is about to close on the purchase of another building across the street at 765 Broad Street, which it plans to refurbish. The company also owns a 30-story downtown office building at 1180 Raymond Boulevard, which it is trying to retrofit as dormitories for students from nearby Seton Hall University Law School, Rutgers Law School and the University of Medicine and Dentistry.
But the new buoyancy on Broad Street has its limits, as well as its skeptics. When Cogswell bought the old bank building, about a quarter of it was occupied. That has risen to 75 percent, but the space remains a difficult sell, some real estate analysts say.
Mr. Eisen of Cushman & Wakefield said the building's layout was too idiosyncratic to qualify as "Class A office space," but that it had charm for renters who did not want "plain vanilla." Many new e-commerce companies and Internet start-ups like such space, he said, and it is even more in demand because the prime space at Gateway is all leased.
There have been difficulties. In January, a leaseholder that planned to operate a restaurant on the restored mezzanine was ousted in a dispute with the building's management. Mr. Stern has renewed the search for a restaurateur willing to take on the conspicuously ornate space, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, that once housed banking cages and was the building's prosperous face in its heyday.
Some of the building's neighbors are ambivalent, hoping for its success but wondering what that may mean for them. "I'm for anything that improves the city's image," said Carmine Masullo, who with his sister, Maria, owns and operates Jim's Tools a block away on Market Street.
But, Mr. Masullo said, "We have been here in the lean times, and there is a chance that we may not be here for the fat times."
Looking around his narrow, cluttered hardware store, he said it was the antithesis of a fancy franchise store, adding, "I now find myself wondering how this place will look as a Houlihan's or a T.G.I. Friday's."
Irvin McKnight, the owner of Heaven on Earth, a men's clothing store that has been three blocks to the north for 28 years, was bitter but resigned. He said that he and several other minority-group business owners who had done well with low rents and a loyal clientele, despite years of being redlined by lenders, feared that "gentrification on a large scale" would shut them out.
"There is no doubt in my mind that Newark is coming back," Mr. McKnight said. "The question is whether it is coming back black."
Not all black business owners feel that way. Feldman Middleton, a partner in the Commerce Food Court, a downtown lunch spot that caters to office workers, is cheered by the resurgence and said the new tenants at 744 Broad were "redefining Newark."
Other second-tier cities in the Northeast are searching for ways to revive their central business districts, but Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University, said Newark has unique features at its disposal: the three-year-old New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts; the determined faithfulness of some large corporations like Prudential Insurance, which kept its headquarters here; and a major airport 10 minutes from downtown.
"It took years for Newark to decline, and it will take years to come back," Mr. Moss said. "And one Starbucks doesn't do it."
Mr. Stern of Cogswell talks about his building with a pioneer's zeal, saying he has taken advantage of the extensive fiber optics network installed in Newark by Bell Atlantic, which has its state headquarters here.
"The challenge here was to take all of the original elements like moldings, architectural touches, mahogany-paneled elevators, and restore them, while supplementing the building with new technology and bandwidth capability," he said. "We think it is the combination of these things that make the difference."
His tenants share his zeal. Ellen Traberman, president of Quickcut, a software company that moved from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., said it was important for her company to have high-speed Internet connections. And, she said, "I'm an Art Deco fan." She acknowledged that Newark's checkered past had been a concern. "But we saw a resurgence here, and wanted to be a part of it," she said.
A bit of nostalgia caused Gerald Krovatin, a well-known criminal defense lawyer, to move his law office from the suburbs to the building's 19th floor in December. He said his first job out of law school was at a firm that had offices in the building until the mid-1980's. "I was where the action was," he said, and he said he felt a bit like that again.
"We all wondered what Cogswell would do with this great old lady that had gone to rack and ruin," he said. "But there is scaffolding and plaster dust everywhere, and things are happening here again. I think I'm catching the wave and even getting a little ahead of it by being here."
Ms. Reichenberg of Space Design said the company chose Newark because of a northern New Jersey market that included clients like Microsoft, Lucent and AT&T. She said the company's West Coast growth had tracked the blossoming of dot-com culture in aging urban settings like Oakland, Calif.
"We tend to go where that kind of growth is taking place and where everybody is looking for that new frontier, that new value," she said. "And Newark is that new frontier."

HEADLINE: 2 Phone Giants Said to Be Near Deal to Merge Wireless Units

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Hoping to create a national giant in wireless communications, BellSouth and SBC Communications are near a deal to merge their North American wireless operations, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.
The companies' boards were scheduled to meet last night to approve the deal, the executives said, and the companies hope to announce the agreement as soon as today. 
 BellSouth and SBC, which does business as Ameritech, Pacific Bell and Southwestern Bell, declined to comment.
After years of fragmentation, the wireless communications business is now in a period of furious consolidation. As wireless companies merge and form wide-ranging joint ventures, they are searching mostly to expand their geographic reach.
Controlling a national network allows a wireless carrier to attract customers looking to use their cellular phones across the nation. But at least as important, a nationwide system also allows carriers to achieve economies of scale in advertising and marketing and allows them to reduce the "roaming" fees they pay when their customers use other carriers' systems.
BellSouth and SBC, both created in the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984, are each titans in the local telephone business. SBC, the No. 1 local phone company, is the main local carrier from Illinois to Texas and also in California. BellSouth is the dominant local phone company from the Carolinas to Florida to Louisiana.
But neither company's wireless operation yet enjoys national scope. By merging, the combined BellSouth-SBC wireless unit, concentrated in the fast-growing Sun Belt, would be able to serve more than half the nation's population.
The combined wireless unit would serve more than 16 million total subscribers and would have annual revenue of more than $8 billion. Based on the valuations that investors have given other wireless companies, the combined unit would probably have a market value of at least $60 billion were it publicly traded.
People close to the deal said that BellSouth and SBC do intend to offer stock in the new unit to the public, though perhaps not until early next year.
Last year, Bell Atlantic and Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. reached a similar deal to merge their United States wireless operations and on Monday, Bell Atlantic announced that it would call the new venture Verizon Wireless. Yesterday, the new Bell Atlantic-Vodafone operation said it would sell stock to the public but did not say when the initial offering would take place or how much stock would be put up for sale.
In any case, the numbers are likely to be big for both Verizon and the combined BellSouth-SBC unit. Last week, AT&T said that it intended to raise up to $13.2 billion when it sold new shares meant to track its national wireless operation. AT&T's offering will probably take place late this month.
Because federal rules do not allow one company to own multiple major wireless licenses in any given market, Bell Atlantic, Vodafone and GTE, which has agreed to be acquired by Bell Atlantic, have faced the prospect of shedding broad swaths of their overlapping wireless properties. SBC dealt with the same issue after it agreed to acquire Ameritech; SBC and Ameritech were wireless competitors in markets including Chicago and St. Louis.
It would take months for SBC and BellSouth to win regulatory approval for their joint venture, but they would not face nearly as much of a divestiture problem because the two companies' wireless units do not overlap much, analysts said.
What will overlap, however, are the two companies' management roles. According to executives close to the talks, SBC and BellSouth will have equal power over management decisions in their new venture, overseeing a single chief executive.
That is something of a departure for SBC, which has traditionally preferred to control its ventures outright. But BellSouth insisted that it not be a junior partner to SBC, executives close to the talks said, and in the end SBC agreed to share control.
That was not the first time the two companies had had that discussion. Before SBC agreed to acquire Ameritech in 1998, SBC had in fact preferred the idea of acquiring BellSouth, according to people close to those discussions. But BellSouth would not sell and Ameritech would.
In the new wireless venture, SBC will control 60 percent of the economic interest while BellSouth will control 40 percent, reflecting the fact that SBC's existing wireless business is bigger than BellSouth's, according to an executive close to the talks.
One person close to the deal said that SBC and BellSouth had not yet decided on a chief executive for the new operation. The person added that SBC and BellSouth intended to form a new brand for the new unit, but said the companies had not yet created it.
The new wireless venture, which is to involve the companies' wireless holdings both in the United States and the Caribbean, is set to include not only wireless telephone systems but also wireless data networks. BellSouth controls the national network used by the new Palm VII handheld computer.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices on Treasury Issues Rise For Seventh Consecutive Session

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices bolted higher for their seventh consecutive session yesterday as a huge midday sell-off in stocks sent investors racing to the safety of government securities.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond gained 20/32to 10627/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell from 5.81 Monday to 5.77 percent, its lowest since May 25 when it was at 5.74. 
 Wall Street dealers said the 13.6 percent midsession decline on the Nasdaq index set off a rush into Treasuries just as dealers were scrambling to find securities after the Federal Reserve reportedly bought nearly $10 billion in bills and notes for the Bank of Japan.
"People misjudged the magnitude of nearly $10 billion of securities and you throw in a stock market which was down more than 10 percent at one point. That's a pretty strong cocktail thrown at the market," said Bill Kirby, head of governments trading at Prudential Securities.
"There was definitely some panic buying," said one trader at a primary dealer.
Analysts said while shorter-dated issues benefited from a flight-to-quality asset allocation out of stocks, longer-dated Treasuries were also lifted by hopes that stock declines would reduce the need for significantly higher interest rates to rein in the still-booming economy.
"You're having a reversal of the wealth effect, which should impact consumer confidence and consumer demand, which should help stay the Fed, which should be good news for yields," said Bill Hornbarger, fixed income strategist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
Analysts said Friday's government report on employment, which usually adds a cautious tone to trading, would return to the forefront but took a back seat to gyrations in equities yesterday, as it did in Monday's session.

HEADLINE: Bill to Raise Basic Wage Advances In Hartford

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 4

 BODY:
A bill to increase Connecticut's minimum wage to $6.75 an hour was approved today by a key legislative committee, a measure that, if approved by the General Assembly, would give the state the highest minimum wage in the nation next year, along with Massachusetts.
Despite today's vote, it remains unclear whether the bill will be approved by the House of Representatives and the Senate before this year's extra-short session ends on May 3. It is also uncertain whether the full 60-cent increase will be enacted. 
 The bill's prospects were complicated by today's vote in the General Assembly's Joint Appropriations Committee, which eliminated a provision to tie any future increases in the state's minimum wage to the annual rate of inflation.
That amendment was approved by the Appropriations Committee chairman, Senator Joseph J. Crisco Jr., a Democrat from Woodbridge, despite an oral vote by committee members that appeared to defeat it. It could damage the bill's chances by effectively delaying its time-sensitive path to the House, which must approve the bill and send it to the Senate. In Connecticut, all amended bills are rerouted back to nonpartisan analysts who change the bill's language and cost estimates, a process than can eat up weeks of time and make it difficult to get a vote before the session ends.
"I'm of the mind that some increase in the minimum wage will pass this year," Representative Christopher G. Donovan, a Democrat from Meriden and the co-chairman of the Labor and Public Employees committee that sponsored the bill, said after the committee vote. But he said the bill could still be changed to reduce the amount of the proposed increase.
In each of the last two years, the General Assembly voted to increase the state's minimum wage. In January 1999, it went to $5.65 an hour from $4.25, the rate established in 1988. On Jan. 1, the wage was raised to $6.15 an hour for most jobs, second-highest in the nation behind Oregon and Washington State, where the minimum is $6.50.
If the bill is approved with its current language, Connecticut, which has the highest per-capita income of any state, will join Massachusetts with the highest minimum wage. The $6.75 wage in Massachusetts goes into effect Jan. 1.
The increase in Connecticut would affect only a small fraction of the state's 1.68 million workers. Those affected would include retail and service employees in areas like sales, fast food and janitorial services.
On Friday, New York State raised its minimum wage to $5.15 from $4.25, the level since 1991. New Jersey's minimum wage has been $5.15 since 1998. Federal law mandates a minimum wage of $5.15 an hour but allows states to create lower minimums for certain employees, like farm and food-service workers.
While most Democrats and labor unions argued for the need to increase the state's minimum wage, Republicans and even some conservative Democrats said it would be an unnecessary burden on employers, especially small-business owners.
"Connecticut is arguably the highest-cost state in which to live, and it has one of the fastest-growing gaps between rich and poor," said Larry Dorman, a spokesman for the AFL-CIO in Connecticut. "One way to close that gap and to promote living-wage jobs is to enact a higher minimum wage."
Senator Edith Prague, a Democrat from Columbia and one of the bill's most ardent advocates, said the extra $24 a week the minimum wage raise represents would make a "big difference" in the lives of workers coming off the state's welfare rolls. And Senator Toni Nathaniel Harp, a Democrat from New Haven, noting that most people living in poverty are women, called the proposal "a pro-women-who-have-to-work bill."
But Senator William A. Aniskovich, a Republican from Branford, said raising the minimum wage would cause a spate of job cuts that would penalize low-income workers the most.
"Many of the people who work for minimum wage are not trying to make a living off minimum wage," Senator Aniskovich said. "To do this, I think, causes more dislocation and harm than good."
Bonnie Stewart, a lobbyist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, said increasing the minimum wage would only drive up the price of goods and services, and drive customers out of state.
"When you have a state as small as Connecticut," she said, "it's a real problem increasing the minimum wage because it's just too easy for people to cross the border to purchase products and services that are cheaper."

HEADLINE: U.N. Says Bad Government Is Often the Cause of Poverty

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 4

 BODY:
After years of treading carefully around the issue of why so many countries stay poor or become poorer, the United Nations put a lot of the blame in a report today on bad government, a message many leaders seeking more aid and debt relief will not want to hear.
The report from the United Nations Development Program, the world's largest aid agency, calls for rethinking traditional ideas about battling poverty in the third world. It reflects the debates in many nations, including the United States, about why poverty persists even in regions of substantial economic growth and political freedom. 
 The report makes "good governance" the top priority in poverty-fighting by the development program under a new administrator, Mark Malloch Brown, whose organization supports a range of governance projects. Without good governance, reliance on trickle-down economic development and a host of other strategies will not work, the report concludes.
Mr. Malloch Brown, a Briton who came to the United Nations last year from the World Bank, has drawn hostility from developing countries. They accuse him of interfering in the internal affairs of governments, a criticism also leveled at Secretary General Kofi Annan for suggesting that nations with human rights abuses can no longer hide behind their borders, claiming national sovereignty.
"This report is particularly important for me in terms of skewering a particularly odd U.N. debate which flourishes in this curious greenhouse at the East River," Mr. Malloch Brown said at a news conference today, "which is that somehow the U.N.D.P. was getting out of poverty and into governance work. What this report clearly demonstrates is that governance is a critical building block for poverty reduction."
Embracing democracy is often not enough, and certainly not a panacea, the report found.
"Having regular elections -- free and fair -- contributes to accountability, especially if they are also held at the local level," the report says. "But such democratic forms are no vaccination against poverty."
Development experts now accept the idea that local governments, often neglected or nonexistent in the developing world, must play a crucial role in poverty reduction. Historically, foreign aid has gone to central governments. When donors could no longer ignore how much aid was being siphoned off in corruption or misuse of funds, nongovernmental agencies, not local governments, were given the money or goods.
A growing number of development experts now believe that this shift bred its own problems as the private agencies invented projects to get more money or funneled aid in line with their own priorities, making national efforts disjointed.
Big, expensive surveys of poverty are not much good either, the report says. It recommends frequent and rapid monitoring studies to assess programs and policies.
The United Nations Development Program's report is being published as the General Assembly prepares to review progress since the 1995 international conference on social development in Copenhagen. At that conference, nations made three commitments: to estimate the incidence of poverty within their borders, to set targets for reducing or eliminating poverty and to introduce anti-poverty plans.
Surveying 140 of the United Nations' 188 members, the report found that 77 percent of countries had estimated their incidence of poverty -- including extreme poverty, measured by the inability to buy enough food for daily needs -- but that only 40 percent had incorporated anti-poverty measures into national planning and 29 percent had dedicated anti-poverty projects.
Countries with the most active and focused measures against poverty were found in the Caribbean, Latin America and Africa, with Asia and the Pacific falling behind sub-Saharan Africa. The survey highlights some of the successful projects found around the world.
The new report from the United Nations Development Program -- "Overcoming Human Poverty: UNDP Poverty Report 2000" -- builds in some ways on the agency's pioneering annual human development reports, a creation of the Mahbub ul Haq, a late Pakistani expert who shifted criteria for measuring development away from per capita income figures to aspects of human life that play a role in social and economic growth.
Three factors used by the human development surveys -- adult illiteracy, the proportion of children under 5 who are underweight and the probability of dying before 40 -- are also assessed in the new report. It shows most regions lagging on all three fronts, and sometimes moving backward, even as democracy spreads and economic growth rates rise.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ISSUES;
Bitter Partisan Fight Brewing Over Medicare Drug Benefits

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Seven months before Election Day, the struggle over expanding Medicare to cover prescription drugs for the elderly is escalating, with both parties maneuvering furiously on an issue that matters, deeply, to a critical group of voters.
As the debate over the Republican budget resolution began today in the Senate, for example, Democrats were pushing for an amendment that would require the creation of a Medicare drug benefit before any tax cut could take effect. 
 President Clinton declared that the amendment was "good policy, the will of the American people and addresses a longstanding unmet need."
Republicans asserted that, as a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, put it, "Republicans are committed to providing this benefit," and would reserve the money to do so.
In poll after poll, expanding Medicare to cover prescription drug benefits for the nation's elderly -- a third of whom lack any drug coverage at all -- ranks near the top of the voters' agenda.
Border wars over prescription drugs are erupting to the north. Democratic candidates for Congress have been traveling to Canada to underscore its lower drug prices; a coalition led by the pharmaceutical industry is countering with a major advertising campaign on the failures of the Canadian health care system.
"They wait longer for new cures," an announcer warns, in television advertisements that began running last week across the northern United States -- a clear reaction to the public's concern over drug prices.
In short, the political pressure for legislation this year is great, a variety of analysts and politicians say. But so is the level of partisan mistrust on the issue, as well as the philosophical disagreement over how to deal with it.
As a result, many politicians say the odds are still against a benefit being enacted this year, but as one administration official put it, "It's such a hot issue, and in an election year on a hot issue things can change."
Congressional Democrats, President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore have been campaigning for prescription drug benefits for more than a year now, and the rhetoric is expected to escalate, with a series of speeches and events planned for this month's Congressional recess.
"It may be the single most potent issue we have back home," declares Representative Martin Frost of Texas, who heads the House Democratic Caucus. "People really do care about this and the Republicans are clearly not going to do anything of consequence."
For their part, leaders in the Republican-controlled House are scrambling to produce a prescription drug plan of their own, having already set aside $40 billion over five years in their recently passed budget resolution for Medicare "reform" and a drug benefit.
The Senate Finance Committee, whose Republican chairman, William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, is in a tough race for re-election, is in the early stages of writing a bill to tackle the issue. And the campaign of Gov. George W. Bush promises to address prescription drugs when Mr. Bush gives a series of health care speeches this spring.
In their more partisan moments, Democrats assert the Republicans are simply looking to neutralize the prescription drug issue, not solve the problem; Republicans counter that some Democrats want a political weapon, not a law. Representative J. C. Watts Jr. of Oklahoma, who heads the House Republican Conference, declared of his Democratic colleagues, "I'm afraid this is another one of those issues where they don't want good policy, they want politics," adding that he nevertheless remained optimistic that a law would pass.
The politics are, in fact, compelling to both parties. In the last presidential election, Americans over 65 years old voted at twice the rate of 18- to 24-year-olds. They are heavily represented in the big states that are expected to be battlegrounds this fall, including Pennsylvania, Illinois and Florida. Their concerns are important to their middle-aged children, many of whom not only worry about their parents but are close enough to their own retirement to take the issue personally, pollsters say.
And neither party can take the retiree vote for granted. Long considered a dependable part of the Democratic coalition, the over-60 vote was carried by the Republicans in the last three Congressional elections -- by a margin of 10 percentage points in 1998, according to exit polls. (Democrats have done better in recent presidential elections, carrying the votes of older Americans in the last two elections.)
When a net pickup of just six seats could give the Democrats control of the House, some strategists say they cannot afford to lose the elderly vote again -- certainly not by the margin they lost it in 1998, when it may well have kept them from regaining control of the House, said Mark Gersh, a Democratic analyst.
The economic and health policy implications of the issue are also powerful, at a time when both the costs and the use of pharmaceuticals keep climbing. Prescription drugs have become a prime tool in treating many of the ailments of aging, from high blood pressure to osteoporosis; the elderly account for 13 percent of the population but more than a third of the nation's drug expenditures. Yet Medicare, developed 35 years ago for a profoundly different era of medicine, generally fails to cover outpatient prescription drug costs.
While two-thirds of the elderly have some form of drug coverage through employer-sponsored plans, health maintenance organizations, or other means, such coverage "varies widely across plans, is often limited, and is expected to decline in the future," as the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, a health research group, recently put it. Lawmakers say they routinely hear of elderly constituents straining -- and often failing -- to meet their drug bills, as well as the other normal costs of living.
The pressure to enact a prescription drug benefit was also increased by last week's rosy report on the financial health of the Medicare hospital trust fund; one of the major arguments against new benefits has been that Medicare could barely cover the existing ones.
"I think the report yesterday adds a great deal of momentum for a prescription drug benefit within Medicare," said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, a Maryland Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee.
For all these reasons, the prescription drug issue is no longer simply a sideshow to the debate over restructuring and modernizing Medicare, which it appeared to be 18 months ago. In fact, some lawmakers worry that it will be far easier and politically appealing to enact a new drug benefit than to restructure Medicare, and thus the effort to make Medicare more efficient and financially solvent before the baby boomers retire will be left to languish.
"If you do prescription drugs and don't do reform, you'll never get reform," said Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who headed a bipartisan commission on Medicare that ended in a deadlock last year. "It's the classic dessert before the meal analysis." The administration's plan links drug benefits with a broader restructuring of the program, and Republican officials have long been committed to "modernizing" Medicare, although those elements could be pared down in the legislative process.
Despite the forces pushing legislators to act this year, there are huge hurdles. The task of creating a prescription drug benefit touches on some of the most profound disagreements in health policy: Should the benefit be universally available and subsidized, as other core benefits are under Medicare, or essentially directed to low-income people, as some Republicans have suggested? How much of a role should the federal government play in designing, delivering and regulating the benefit -- and how much of a role should the private insurance industry play?
"I think there will be legislative action this year," said Mr. Cardin. "Whether it will be enacted into law is unlikely."
Privately, some Democratic strategists say that with the House so close within their grasp, it does not make sense to settle this year for a bare-bones benefit. The political calculus, though, is complicated: Mr. Clinton, looking toward his legacy, has one set of interests when it comes to the decision to compromise. Mr. Gore and House Democrats, looking toward the potential of a new administration, may have different views. "This is not the year when Democrats ought to be accepting half a loaf on any important policy prescription," said one Democratic strategist on Capitol Hill.
Another big variable is the pharmaceutical industry, which has been warning for months now that any new prescription drug program that relies on government to hold down prices will have dire consequences for research. Now, in the face of all this momentum in Congress to act, the industry not only has to decide what the best deal is, but when to try to strike it, which means assessing the odds of a Democratic House and a Democratic administration next year.
Industry spokesmen assert that Democrats have been trying to "demonize" them for political gain. In their campaign to highlight the burden of prescription drug costs on the nation's elderly, some House Democrats have begun issuing studies suggesting that pets get a better deal than retirees on the cost of some medications. Such efforts clearly touch a nerve.
Alan F. Holmer, president and chief executive officer of Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, said, "The sponsors of this so-called study know that it costs far more to develop a drug for a person than for a dog."
In short, the political wars over prescription drugs rage on, with an avid audience.
"This is an extremely important reference point to older voters, and remember, it's a big change in the debate," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. "For the better part of the last decade, we've been talking about how to cut back on benefits to seniors in terms of Medicare and Social Security. This is the first debate in a while about how we extend new benefits to older Americans. And seniors are very receptive to that."
