HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Judge in Microsoft Case Hopes for Swift Conclusion
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson told lawyers he wants to finish the remedy phase of the Microsoft case within 60 days. 
 The judge proposed a "fast track" proceeding that would give the Justice Department 30 days and Microsoft 60 days to propose their remedies. He also said he would ask the Justice Department to file for an expedited Supreme Court hearing, which would bypass the appellate court that overturned him in an earlier Microsoft case. Page A1.
 
Icahn Bids for Nabisco Group
Nabisco Group Holdings is reviewing the latest bid by Carl C. Icahn to buy the company. Icahn, who already owns about 9 percent of the company, bid $5.2 billion, or $16 a share, to buy the rest. Nabisco had rejected Icahn's earlier offer to buy 30 percent of the company for $13 a share, but in response to the new offer Nabisco has hired investment bankers to consider its options. C6.
 
Coke Sees Profit and Sales Growth
Coca-Cola told investors that it expects long-term sales growth of 7 percent to 8 percent and profit growth of 15 percent a year, but its optimistic presentation was tempered by news that first-quarter growth will be only about 1.5 percent and that the company will take a $400 million charge in the period to close poorly performing plants. C6.
 
How Does the Fed Read Wall Street?
Wall Street's gyrations must have left Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan wondering just what it will take to keep the stock market under control. Investors will be listening intently today when he speaks at a White House conference on the economy. C11.
 
Bond Yield Reaches 10-Month Low
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond slipped to 5.77 percent, its lowest since last May, as the sharp midday decline in the Nasdaq stock index sent investors scurrying to the safety of government securities. C11.
 
Leading Economic Indicators Fall
The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators fell 0.3 percent in February, its first decline in five months, as factory orders for capital goods, building permits and stocks declined. But analysts expect the index, a gauge of future growth, to rebound in the next report. C6.
 
Reno to Speak in Silicon Valley
In a speech at Stanford University and in talks with executives of technology companies, Attorney General Janet Reno will extend an olive branch today to Silicon Valley companies over issues like digital surveillance and will offer the government's support in fighting computer crime. C2.
 
A Champion for Adoption Benefits
Dave Thomas, founder and senior chairman of the board of Wendy's International, the fast-food restaurant chain, talks about his experience as an adopted child, how he tried to cope growing up but failed to finish high school and about his work in Washington to encourage companies to provide benefits for families that adopt children. C10.
 
U.S. Threatens Mexico Trade Action
The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said that Mexico was failing to support competition in telecommunications and that she might take action before the World Trade Organization. C4.
 
Investors Favoring Japanese Shares
Japan's stock market and its currency are showing strength as buying by mutual funds and a penchant for high-technology companies is overcoming a host of negative factors. C4.
 
An Inflight Cineplex in First Class
Singapore Airlines is setting the pace in providing inflight entertainment in first and business class, with a wide array of movies, short films and audio cds and viewing screens at each individual seat with controls that have all the features of a VCR. C8.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Fed Likely to Stay Its Course Despite Gyrations in Stocks

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
For a while today, Alan Greenspan got just what he wanted: a sharp break in the stock market's ever-upward psychology and a broad downturn in prices that took a big chunk of wealth out of investors' bulging pockets.
But then the markets snatched it right back. After a stomach-churning plunge, stock prices rebounded smartly in the afternoon, closing with losses that, while not trivial, were hardly paradigm changing. The prevailing assumption -- that every dip is a buying opportunity -- held more or less intact, though day traders no doubt ended the session wondering whether investing was still as easy as it had been last year. 
 And Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve were left to wonder anew what it would take to rein in Wall Street, which they have come to view as the channel through which inflation is most likely to infect the economy.
True, technology stocks have taken a battering over the last week. But most of the wealth created in the market over the last few years is still intact, fueling consumer spending and a general sense of economic invulnerability. And by some measures, stocks are still grinding their way upward.
Mr. Greenspan's preferred measure of market performance, the Wilshire 5000, which captures the movement of nearly all stocks, is still up about 1 percent so far this year, and up 10.9 percent since last June 30, when the Fed began its current round of rate increases. For all its troubles in the last few weeks, the Nasdaq index is still 54 percent higher than it was on June 30.
All of which suggests that nothing that happened today will deter the Fed from continuing to raise rates. The very resiliency of the markets might even lead the central bank to conclude that it needs to raise rates further, and in bigger increments than it has so far, to grab the attention of investors.
"Right now we have neither a sustained correction in the stock market nor a significant slowdown in the economy," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at Norwest Bank in Minneapolis. "To keep the market contained will require at least a couple more interest rate hikes and a continued open mouth policy on the part of Chairman Greenspan."
Investors will no doubt be listening intently when Mr. Greenspan speaks on Wednesday afternoon at a White House conference on the economy. Mr. Greenspan is expected to discuss technology's effect on the economy, a subject that would give him ample opportunity, if he chooses, to assess the markets and signal his intentions for the next Fed policy meeting on May 16.
There are many reasons the economy continues to stampede, not least that low unemployment and rising wages are making most people feel confident and willing to spend. But Mr. Greenspan has repeatedly emphasized the potential for the wealth generated by the market to be the force that leads the economy to overheat and start throwing off inflation.
The Fed chairman has said repeatedly that he is not aiming at the stock market per se. But he has also made clear that, absent a pronounced slowdown in some other sector of the economy, the market's sustained rise would have to slow considerably to allow the economy to remain on an even keel.
Mr. Greenspan has even set out a speed limit for the market: asset values should not rise faster than household income. His equation roughly implies that stock prices should not rise at more than a 6 percent annual rate.
Measured from the start of this year, the markets are generally within the speed limit, at least as measured by the Wilshire 5000.
But over longer periods the upward surge in equity prices remains too rapid for Mr. Greenspan's taste. And with markets so volatile, it is hard to say whether there is a sustainable trend of deceleration.
"If you look at where we are today relative to the beginning of the year, you'd say we're not too far from the beginning of the neutralization of the wealth effect," said Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities. "But since the market is so volatile, your perception can change substantially in a couple of weeks."
Ian Shepherdson, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm, said the decline in the Nasdaq had only taken the index back to where it was two months ago, "and we don't recall seeing much evidence back in February that the economy was slowing down."
If stock prices stabilize where they are now, "we think there will probably be some measurable impact on consumer confidence over the next month or two," Mr. Shepherdson said. "But it will not be enough to slow the economy as much as the Fed wants."
The next big indicator of the economy's performance will come Friday, when the Labor Department reports on job creation and the unemployment rate for March. If the economy continues to create jobs at a robust pace, and if the unemployment rate falls back to 4 percent or below, it would be another sign that economic growth remains at a level far beyond what the Fed considers prudent.

LENGTH: 1459 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq Goes Into Free Fall Before Making A Recovery

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL and KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
On their roller coaster ride yesterday, investors and executives in technology companies traded on the Nasdaq market could be expected to feel a little queasy.
A co-worker approached Dr. Pehong Chen, chief executive of a software company called Broadvision, based in Redwood City, Calif., and asked him how he was early in the morning. "He saw me standing at the trash can and thought I was throwing up," Dr. Chen said. In fact, "I was peeling an orange." 
 Though he said he had lost about $2.5 billion on paper over the last two weeks, Dr. Chen seemed calm yesterday. Then again, his stake is still worth at least a couple of billion dollars since the stock was one of the best performers on Nasdaq last year.
Other executives punished by the stock market also sounded philosophical, suggesting that they had hit a speed bump -- and nothing more. Their comments were echoed by many smaller investors, who continue to sit on profits after a year of tremendous gains. Some even find the rapid decline an encouraging sign because excesses are being quickly wrung out of the market.
"The valuations were such that this was a balloon looking for a pin," said Kent Simons, manager of the $2 billion Neuberger Berman Focus fund. "Things that used to take six or seven weeks are now over in six or seven days."
And what a few days it has been. A rout that began in the Nasdaq market early last week picked up steam on Monday as investors braced for the ruling that Microsoft had violated antitrust law. After falling 14.5 percent on Monday, shares of the company fell an additional $2.3125 yesterday, or 2.5 percent, to $88.5625.
Yesterday, stock prices plunged in the morning and early afternoon in what some traders described as panic selling by individuals and hedge funds forced to unload shares to meet margin calls. At one point, the Nasdaq composite index was down nearly 575 points, or 13.6 percent. That spilled over to the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell as much as 504 points, or 4.5 percent.
The panic lifted soon afterward as one market participant said mutual funds began buying. The major gauges then retraced much of the lost ground.
By the end of the day, the Nasdaq and the Dow had recorded their largest point swings ever. Though the main gauges closed only moderately lower than they had on Monday, the final numbers do not convey the volatility, nor the pain and psychological damage inflicted on investors.
"The only positive thing you can take away from this is that you did see almost capitulation selling," said Rob Cohen, co-head of block trading at Credit Suisse First Boston.
By the close, the Nasdaq was down 74.79, or 1.8 percent, to 4,148.89. The 634-point swing in Nasdaq from its peak to its trough yesterday was its biggest ever in a single day and was twice the previous record of 328 points on March 30.
At its low point, the Nasdaq was down nearly 28 percent from its peak on March 10. By the end of the day, it was about 18 percent off its peak. For the year, it is up 1.9 percent.
For the day, the Dow slipped 57.09, or 0.51 percent, to 11,164.84. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index shed 11.24, or 0.8 percent, to 1,494.73.
Perhaps it is just wishful thinking, but stock analysts said some of the speculative excess that has been building in technology stocks has now been purged.
"A lot of people who thought the market owed them a living now realize that the market won't go up forever," said Laszlo Birinyi, who runs his own stock market research firm in Westport, Conn.
William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald, said "a lot of speculators have either seen the light or run out of cash."
Shares of highly speculative companies in the technology and Internet world suffered the most and could fall further.
Alan F. Skrainka, chief market strategist at Edward Jones, a St. Louis-based brokerage firm, said stock values have been totally out of whack. "We have a new economy, but the same old rules of investing still apply," he said. If you buy companies with no earnings, "you're going to get burned."
"We think this is the beginning of the end of the wild, wild West style of investing."
Mr. Skrainka pointed to a joint study by Edward Jones and Ned Davis Research, a securities research firm in Venice, Fla., on the stock performance of companies whose shares reached levels equivalent to 100 times their annual earnings. Among the resulting 1,780 Nasdaq stocks since 1972 (ending in 1995), the five-year median return was just over 10 percent, or 2 percent a year. And the risk was 17 times more for these stocks than for the S.& P. 500 and 100 times more than for Treasury bills.
Edward Kerschner, chief market strategist at PaineWebber, issued a warning last week about the values of what he called the "new, new industrial" stocks trading at high multiples of earnings, if they have earnings that is. As of yesterday morning, the stocks on his list, including Ciena, Akamai and Juniper Networks, were still about 40 percent overvalued, Mr. Kerschner said. By midday, those stocks "were down another 15 percent to 20 percent," he said. "That means they need to fall another 20 percent."
Even as he called for a sharp correction in these stocks last week, Mr. Kerschner reiterated his generally positive outlook for stocks.
"I don't think you will see a widespread correction, but a cleansing action in the frothier parts of the Nasdaq," he said.
Investors who have ridden the technology wave in recent years cannot be easily shaken from their seats. Howard Appel, 43, of Merrick, N.Y., said yesterday that he had a big loss in his 401(k) retirement account because it was invested in technology stocks. "If I was retiring in the next few years, I'd be in a panic," he said. "It's not fun losing $50,000 in a week.
"Now I'm going to be able to buy a lot more shares at a lower price," he added. "I expect in the near future, technology and the Nasdaq are going to come roaring back."
Robert Hopkins, a 68-year-old retired publisher of trade magazines who lives in Keswick, Va., said he remained on the sidelines yesterday. "I was tracking it all day long," he said. "I don't think anybody could watch it and not be concerned."
But he said he did not sell anything in his portfolio, which has fat profits from recent years. "I'm still playing on house money," he said.
Throughout Silicon Valley, where so much wealth has been minted in the last few years, there is plenty of ticker checking going on in the hallways at work. And the tension is heightened at companies whose insiders will soon get their first chance to sell after the lock-up period imposed following a public offering. More than half the initial public offerings this year are now trading under their offering price, challenging the market wisdom that getting into a hot initial public offering is easy money in the bank.
Michael Beindorff, president and chief operating officer of PlanetrX.com, an online pharmacy in South San Francisco, said that the volatility is "not terribly surprising."
Still, "It's scary for everybody," said the executive, whose stock went public in October, peaked around 36, hung around 20, but then slid steadily. It finished yesterday at a new low of 5 11/16, down from its offering price of 16.
The stock had been under pressure because its lock-up period ended on Monday, Mr. Beindorff said. In recent days retail investors sold the stock in anticipation that company insiders would do so when they could, he explained.
Despite the demoralizing dips, executives at some of these technology companies said it was premature to consider buying back company stock or repricing options granted to employees. The message they are trying to send to employees is that if they keep the company on track, valuations will follow.
Chris Slatt, 41, chairman and chief executive of WatchGuard Technologies, an Internet security company in Seattle whose stock has fallen 30 points in the last several weeks, to 75 1/2, but which remains far above its opening price of 13 last July, sent an e-mail message intended to bolster employee morale 10 days ago.
"With these fluctuations, you'll literally drive yourself mad looking everyday" at your personal worth, said Mr. Slatt, whose said his own net worth had fallen some $500 million in the last two weeks.
Yet he and other executives of public companies say they are keenly aware of one benchmark: how their own company's stock is doing relative to that of direct competitors. In short, executives say they have learned to live with wild drops they say are largely beyond their control, but are far less comfortable when their stocks fall in percentage terms more than that of business rivals.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1375 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Stock Strength Defies Bad News

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 4

 BODY:
Japan's languid economy slid into another recession late last year, companies are struggling to overhaul themselves, the government's debts are piling up and the prime minister is comatose with a stroke.
None of that news seems to have fazed the Japanese stock market, which has outperformed the United States market over the last year. On Monday, even with word that the condition of Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi was grave, investors bid up share prices, and the benchmark Nikkei index reached the highest level since late 1997. 
 The market demonstrated its resilience again today, retreating only modestly despite the political uncertainties. Much of that weakness was attributed to the carry-over effect of the Nasdaq market's severe drop the day before in the United States. At midday on Wednesday, stocks were a little more than 1 percent lower. The yen weakened against the dollar.
The Japanese market's recent strength does not necessarily signal a better future for this country's economy, the world's second largest, which has been struggling for years to recover from the bursting of the speculative bubble a decade ago.
The forces that have been driving the market higher reflect some trends that have not been seen before. A flood of new Japanese mutual funds, for example, has reversed a prolonged contraction in the industry. Mutual fund activity, in turn, has spurred buying by momentum investors, who hope to profit by purchasing shares that big investors are buying.
Moreover, people have been moving their money into stocks that reflect a modest boom in information technology, telecommunications and the Internet, at the expense of traditional Japanese companies.
Their moves are intensified by a shortage of stocks in those sectors; only 12 Japanese stocks are pure Internet investments.
"There's the feeling that the worst of the economic news is behind us," said Ichizo Takeuchi, marketing director at the Kokusai Asset Management Company, which supervises 11 trillion yen in assets -- currently $105 billion. "Investment in information technology is growing," he said, "and the structure of the economy is changing." Mr. Takeuchi added that the market this year had been driven by Japanese investors, rather than the foreigners who piled in last year, and by more individual investors than in the recent past.
The Japanese are among the world's great savers, so any indication that they are beginning to risk some of that money in the stock market, where many had been badly burned in the early 1990's, could represent a new source of demand for shares. "Because of the large pool of savings here," Mr. Takeuchi said, "once households begin to share risks in the capital markets, that will in turn contribute greatly to improvement of the Japanese corporate sector in which they are investing."
His opinion is not necessarily shared by other money managers here. Some worry that individual Japanese investors may be stepping back into the market just in time to be wiped out again, as was their experience when the asset bubble burst. "My sense is that those hurt when the bubble popped are not part of this thing," said Craig Chudler of Nikko Salomon Smith Barney. "But new companies that are listing and seeing their shares bid up very, very rapidly -- you hear the 'bubble' word come out of their mouths. They're dumbfounded by the rise in stock prices."
Just in the last few weeks, a bit of air has come out of the market. While the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues is up 8.77 percent since the beginning of the year, the Topix index, a much broader piece of the market, is off 0.9 percent after having been up 2.3 percent less than a month ago.
Gary Evans, strategist at HSBC Securities here, said: "I asked two of my analysts the other day to tell me how the market had performed without looking at their numbers, and both of them said it was up somewhere in the range of 15 percent. That's not the case, but their perception is one that is widely shared by many investors, who are enthusiastic about Japan and its future."
That is most apparent in the mutual fund industry. The funds, known here as investment trusts, having been net sellers of stocks for much of the last decade, have been piling into the market. From the beginning of the year through the second week of March, funds made net stock purchases of 671 billion yen. They were exceeded only by foreign investors, who were net purchasers of 991 billion yen in stock, though most have been investing in Japan at a much slower pace than last year.
It is not surprising that mutual funds account for a large part of recent investment in the equity market, since there are so many new ones. The most prominent so far is Nomura Securities' Big Project N, the largest Japanese fund ever. Its success in attracting one trillion yen to the stock market, a good chunk of it from Nomura's own bond funds, helped expedite the creation of other stock funds. From mid-January through mid-March, 62 stock funds have been introduced, according to Morningstar, the mutual fund research company.
And that does not include three new funds announced a few weeks ago by Fidelity Investments. "We've seen a significant increase in our business almost across the board," said Robert H. Auld, chief investment officer at Fidelity Investments Japan. Like others, Mr. Auld sees differences between the stock market and the economy. "Certainly, Japan has stumbled about from a macroeconomic policy point of view, and everyone knows that," he said. "But a lot of companies are starting to restructure their businesses and in ways that are independent from what the government is doing."
This makes it easier to distinguish winners from losers. "There's a little more divergence in the fortunes of individual companies," Mr. Auld said. "Where historically all companies tended to rise and fall with the overall movement of the tide, there are now companies able to determine their own fortunes independent of whether the tide is moving in or out."
Ahead of the funds are the momentum buyers, who seek to exploit the links between the funds and the indexes they use as benchmarks. Trading volume exploded earlier this year after Nomura announced Big Project N, and momentum investors rushed to buy shares ahead of the fund, hoping to profit from its need to hold certain stocks.
Among those must-have stocks are NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile telephone company and the first company anywhere to commercialize Internet access over a phone, and Sony, which has sought to convince investors, with some success, that it is transforming itself from a consumer electronics manufacturer into an Internet company.
As had been the case in the United States, the most tenuous connection to the Internet has commanded a high premium in the market. Thus, shares of the Itochu Techno-Science Corporation, the company that developed a wildly popular system for tapping the Internet using a mobile phone, have risen 330 percent since they were first floated in December on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
CJK, which sells and services imported information-processing and telecommunications equipment, has risen more than 150 percent since its shares were offered a month and a half ago. Even the Meikyosha Company, a retailer that sells games, software and electronics, is up nearly 20 percent from its offering price since it went public in February.
The voracious appetite for these stocks and others like them, combined with their limited availability, has created risks for investors. Of the 70 companies with the biggest market capitalizations, the seven largest funds devoted to investing in the domestic market hold shares in only 27, and only 3 are not related to technology or information services: the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi; Takeda Chemical Industries, a drug and vitamin company, and Seven-Eleven Japan, modestly higher because of its plans to link its business to cyberspace.
Mr. Evans said he thought that concentration was too heavy and had probably hurt fund performance so far. Of the 10 stocks that have risen the most this year, half are old-line electronics companies, like Mitsubishi Electric and Sanyo Electric, or pharmaceutical companies.

SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: REIT Considering a Sale

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: EMERYVILLE, Calif., April 4

 BODY:
Western Properties Trust, an owner of shopping centers on the West Coast, has hired the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. to advise it on a possible sale or merger. The company, a real estate investment trust, owns 62 properties and has a market value in stock and debt of about $425 million. It made the disclosure in a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The shares of such trusts, known as REIT's, have slumped for two years on concerns about earnings growth, rising interest rates and overbuilding.

HEADLINE: Expedited Appeal Proposed by Judge in Microsoft Case

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY and STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The presiding judge in the Microsoft antitrust case, meeting with lawyers for both sides in Washington yesterday, said he wanted to put the remedy phase of the case on a "fast track" and consider encouraging the litigants to appeal the outcome directly to the Supreme Court, according to a transcript of the meeting.
One day after he issued his judgment that found Microsoft in broad violation of the nation's antitrust laws, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson laid out a tight schedule for filings from both parties every 10 or 15 days "under a genuine fast track which would enable us to conclude the remedy phase within 60 days" of Monday, he said. 
 No decisions were made, and at one point Judge Jackson discussed possibly bypassing the appeals court and encouraging the Justice Department to take the case directly to the Supreme Court, under a law that allows that procedure in antitrust cases of national importance.
"I would be remiss if I didn't tell you that I will be inviting from the government a motion to provide for direct review in the Supreme Court," he said.
Lawyers for both sides raised questions about the various ideas, suggesting that they were not sure what the law permitted.
At the same time, Microsoft faces the threat of a rising wave of consumer class-action cases and other private lawsuits.
During the meeting, Judge Jackson said: "My transcendent objective is to get this thing before an appellate tribunal -- one or another -- as quickly as possible because I don't want to disrupt the economy or waste any more of yours or my time on a remedy if it's going to come back here."
In the remedy phase, the court will decide what penalty, or remedy, is assigned to Microsoft. Ideas range from moderating the company's conduct to breaking the company up.
The judge issued his verdict on Monday, just 48 hours after settlement talks broke down. In his conversations with the lawyers yesterday, he asked them to give him the last offers each side had made in the talks, an idea that both sides resisted. David Boies, the lead government lawyer, noted that offers discussed in mediation talks are often of a different character than those offered to a trial judge.
Both sides were also concerned about making their last offers from the settlement talks part of the public record of the trial, to which Judge Jackson said he would be willing to take them under seal.
No decisions were made, and the lawyers left to discuss the questions with others at the Justice Department and Microsoft.
If the case were sent directly to the Supreme Court, the court could presumably refuse to accept it, thereby sending it to the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Apart from the appeals process, Microsoft could face a raft of suits from the private sector. With Judge Jackson having ruled on Monday that Microsoft was a "predatory" monopolist that repeatedly violated antitrust laws, private plaintiffs have a far less daunting challenge in suits already filed -- and in actions being considered by companies that believe they have suffered from abuse of Microsoft's market power.
"This is now an awfully big invitation to plaintiffs' lawyers," said John C. Coffee Jr., a professor at the Columbia University law school. "We may have reached a point for Microsoft, as there was in the tobacco cases, that basic attitudes have shifted, and a powerful defendant is no longer seen as invulnerable."
Some of Microsoft's leading rivals, and even its biggest customers, could bring private suits, according to legal experts. But they will almost surely hold off, at least until they see what sanctions the courts approve against Microsoft -- sanctions that could, among other things, limit its ability to retaliate.
Judge Jackson's judgment was not surprising, after his findings of fact in November sided with the version of the case presented in court by the Justice Department and 19 states. But this week's ruling was a crucial step because it means that many of his findings -- that Microsoft is a monopoly, for example -- may be accepted as proof by other courts in private suits.
Several companies that could now step forward as plaintiffs sent witnesses to Judge Jackson's courthouse to testify on behalf of the government, including Netscape Communications, America Online, Sun Microsystems, Apple Computer and I.B.M. In his ruling, the judge cited those companies as suffering from Microsoft's "oppressive thumb on the scale of competitive fortune."
The judge ruled, for example, that the company not only used its market power to defend its monopoly in operating systems but also illegally tried to monopolize the market for Internet browsing software. The principal victim of that tactic was Netscape, the pioneer in the browser market, which was acquired by America Online in late 1998. That judgment makes it far easier for America Online to sue for damages.
Because the judge ruled that Microsoft's monopoly power allowed it to overcharge for Windows, the big personal computer makers including Dell, Compaq, Gateway and I.B.M. could have cause to file suit. If they won, such judgments could yield hundreds of millions of dollars each for big PC makers that use Windows. The treble damages in private antitrust cases would cover every PC a company sold over four years, the statute of limitations in such cases.
"Microsoft could find itself in a very tight pincer here, since these companies could regard it as being in their fiduciary interest to file private suits," said Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor at the University of Iowa law school.
Sun Microsystems, lawyers say, is probably the most likely to file a private suit against Microsoft. It is a bitter direct competitor and has little to lose. For all the others, the calculation would be more complicated because they rely in one way or another on Microsoft's cooperation.
Most of the companies named in Judge Jackson's ruling declined to comment yesterday on the possibility of private antitrust suits against Microsoft. Still, an executive at one of the companies said, "It is clearly something we will consider, but there has been no substantive internal discussion of that yet."
And the companies may decide against suing Microsoft for other reasons. First, parts of Judge Jackson's legal conclusions -- though not his findings of fact -- could be reversed on appeal. And second, the companies may not see it as in their long-term interest to bring suit against Microsoft, even if they do not fear retaliation from Microsoft.
RealNetworks, which makes software for playing multimedia programming on personal computers, was mentioned by Judge Jackson as among the targets of Microsoft's tactics. Yet Rob Glaser, chairman of RealNetworks, said yesterday that he had no plans to sue.
"While I think Microsoft has behaved unethically at times and this judge found that it broke the law, my focus is going to be on doing everything I can to make sure RealNetworks remains ahead of Microsoft in our business," Mr. Glaser said. "The government was absolutely right to prosecute Microsoft. But it doesn't make sense for us."
But companies are not the only potential litigants. More than 100 class-action suits have already been filed against Microsoft in two dozen states, nearly all in the aftermath of Judge Jackson's powerfully worded findings of fact last November. Those suits, legal experts say, were the early starters as plaintiffs' lawyers maneuvered for leadership positions in what are likely to become a broader class-action assault.
More consumer class-action suits are expected, and lawyers involved in the early cases said Judge Jackson's rule was a significant victory.
"We're very pleased with the way the government case came out," said Leonard B. Simon, a partner at Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach in San Diego, whose firm has brought many prominent class-action cases. "This is very good news for the consumer class-action cases."
But while the ruling in the government case makes things easier for private antitrust plaintiffs, it by no means ensures that they will win in court. The consumer class-action suits mainly contend that Microsoft, as a monopoly, was able to overcharge for its industry-standard Windows operating system, which runs the basic operations of nearly 90 percent of all PC's sold today.
Judge Jackson ruled that Microsoft had the ability to "price substantially above the competitive level." And in his November findings, he noted an internal Microsoft pricing study that said the company could have charged $49 for a retail upgrade from Windows 95 to Windows 98 but that the company chose to charge $89 instead because it was the "revenue-maximizing price."
Microsoft replies that the numbers cited in the study were arbitrary numbers, and that it could have also charged far more for the Windows upgrade.
In the class-action confrontation, Microsoft says it has the money and the patience to withstand what it regards as an opportunistic assault on a deep-pocketed corporate target. In addition, the company's executives express confidence in their legal position.
"These class-action cases are just piling on," William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, said in an interview over the weekend. "There is no economic theory to show that ours was not the aggressive price for Windows."
Indeed, while Judge Jackson's ruling places Microsoft's liability firmly into the legal record, the class-action suits must still prove damages -- that is, what impact Microsoft's abuse of its market power had on consumers. And even the class-action advocates recognize that.
"The ruling in the government case simplifies our job, but it does not make it easy," said Terry Gross, a lawyer in San Francisco. "We're up against one of the most powerful defendants in the world."
The private litigation promises to be a marathon effort. A group of seven federal judges, called the Multi-District Litigation Panel, held a hearing last week in Palm Springs, Calif., on where to combine all the federal class-action suits. That initial decision is expected soon. But it is only a starting point.
California is the leader among the states in class-action cases. The more than two dozen cases filed to date have been consolidated in the San Francisco Superior Court.

HEADLINE: WATER POLO;
From the Ruins of Sarajevo to Stardom at Princeton

BYLINE: By SOPHIA HOLLANDER 

 BODY:
Goga Vukmirovic heard a strange noise. It was a Monday morning, April 6, 1992, the day of a dreaded biology test that the Sarajevo seventh grader had spent the entire weekend studying for furiously.
She heard voices from outside her room, which made her pause, because her parents were normally at work by the time she crawled out of bed. 
 Trodding tentatively into the living room, she saw her parents gathered on the couch with her older sister Maja, watching scenes on CNN -- scenes they had seen for weeks in Croatia, other places. Not in Sarajevo. She sat on the couch and saw the war blowing apart in her city.
"Your first instinct is hey, no school today!" Ogjenka Vukmirovic said ruefully, sitting in her dorm room at Princeton University where she is a senior, captain of the nationally ranked women's water polo team and known to everyone as Goga. "But it hits you pretty quick when the bombs start exploding that it may not be such a good bargain."
Vukmirovic, now 21, never went back to school in Bosnia, never went back to seventh grade, or eighth grade for that matter. After fleeing from the war with her mother and sister, she enrolled as a high school student in Venezuela. The next year she was at a Connecticut boarding school to finish high school, where she was introduced to the sport of water polo.
Now she lives in a neat, white-walled room with typical college decorations: post cards on the wall, shelves of academic books, a poster of the music group U2. But the books on the shelves are mostly on the war in Bosnia, research for one of two senior theses she is writing. She will point out the postcards that picture places bombed and destroyed in the war, use her mouse to diagram shelling trajectories on her screen saver of the mountains outside of Sarajevo. Next to a box of computer disks sits a small clear glass container, filled with bullets that she picked up from the floor of her room in Sarajevo.
"Is that strange?" she asked, smiling. "It keeps you motivated to write your thesis, I'll tell you that."
It doesn't seem as if Vukmirovic needs motivation. A founding member of Princeton's varsity water polo team, which is 18-3 this season, she was the 1999 Ivy League and Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference most valuable player, and a 1999 all-America goalie. She is the only senior in the four-year-old program and was the most valuable player in the E.C.A.C. championships which Princeton won last weekend. The nationals are May 5-7 in Bloomington, Ind.
Women's water polo is an emerging collegiate sport. Thanks to Vukmirovic's efforts, Princeton was ranked in the top 10 for the first time in its history earlier this season and remains, after traditional West Coast powers, a national contender.
"She's kind of a legendary kid here," said Bill Berghoff, her high school coach at Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, Conn. "She'll come to visit a practice and she'll walk on the deck and all these little high school girls will collect around her. She's very embarrassed by it."
At Choate, there is the "Goga defense," where the goalie glides out of the goal into the center of the pool to help defend, the "Goga save" -- anything spectacular -- and the "Goga cap," which she wore at Choate and is now ratty and falling apart.
She does not talk with teammates about her experiences unless somebody asks, but it is always there. In the mornings at Choate, she would rush to check her e-mail messages, the only way she could communicate with her parents. When an e-mail message wasn't there, she wondered why, and would check compulsively until it came.
"It was actually my lifeline which helped me a lot in this period of separation," Vukmirovic's mother, Svjetlana, said recently in an e-mail message from Sarajevo, to which she returned after her daughters came to the United States. "The situation in Sarajevo was so difficult in that time, that we were actually happy not to have them with us in that hell."
It has been a series of missions for Vukmirovic, some seemingly impossible. Lead a normal life without being able to hear or see your parents for years, learn water polo, a sport she had never seen until she started to play it. In Venezuela, where she lived with her mother's family for 18 months, she attended school where everything that was taught was in English and all she knew were basic phrases. The first book she was assigned was "Great Expectations" by Charles Dickens.
But there was something to make her feel at home.
"Right as we went to Venezuela, they had a coup," she said. "You saw all these people who are shocked that there are airplanes flying over their homes and we were like, 'oh, been there, done that.' It's a sink-or-swim situation."
So she swam and followed her older sister to the United States when a Choate representative visited her school. "The progress as a water polo player through her senior year was because she made it a priority to learn," Berghoff said. "When she commits to something, she's just a hard driver. She does what she intends to do. And she does it well."
After spending three years at Choate, Vukmirovic was accepted into Harvard, Princeton, Yale and M.I.T. She chose Princeton because she was offered an opportunity to work in a lab her freshman year even though Princeton offered only a club water polo team.
"She's the backbone of our team because you can always count on the big save," Coach Luis Nicolao said. "She has a very good perspective on life, her priorities and the way she carries herself. She's beyond her years."
"When you're not given a choice, you deal with things much better because you can't second-guess yourself," she said. "You can roll up and die and be depressed and sit in your room all day, or you can figure out a way to go and deal with it. A lot of my papers and a lot of the work that I've done relates to Bosnia. My thesis right now kind of brings a closure to scattered years of thinking about some of these issues."
At first, Vukmirovic hoped that it would do more than provide a personal closing. She considered returning to Bosnia after graduation to try to implement her ideas for a truth commission to promote ethnic reconciliation. She has since abandoned that idea, stunned at the lack of support among her people, hurt that some now view her as an international, someone too removed from the problem to understand its solution.
"I'm a typical Bosnian; I thought that I was," she said (her father is Serbian, her mother Muslim). "Even at Choate, I thought my views on reconcilliation were something that 99 percent of the Bosnian population would agree with, but they're absolutely not. I'm a huge minority view, which was completely discouraging and disheartening."
So instead, Vukmirovic will live in New York, and work at the private-equity group J. H. Whitney in Stamford, Conn.
"I have no econ background," she said, grinning. "But I'm very excited. It will be a challenge to me to learn it, to fit in. This is going to be a sink or swim."
Been there. Done that.

HEADLINE: Budgeting for New York State

 BODY:
With unexpected speed, Gov. George Pataki and the New York State Legislature have agreed on a framework for a new $77 billion budget. Producing a framework does not mean the Legislature has actually produced a budget on time -- a feat that has not been achieved in Albany for the last 16 years. This budget was officially late last Saturday. But the agreement on a budget outline is definitely a sign of progress for legislators prodded by an election this fall and the loss of their paychecks until the budget is officially finished. Last year the Legislature reached this point in its budget negotiations in mid-July.
At press conferences in Albany, state leaders promised an enticing list of possibilities like reduction of school class sizes and low-cost prescription drugs for the elderly. Still, this general agreement must be greeted cautiously until the details emerge in the coming weeks. Despite the surge in state revenues, primarily from taxes on Wall Street profits, the governor, the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver must be careful not to endorse either tax cuts or obligations that would expand the deficit later. 
 The leaders have identified an additional $1.4 billion available for spending since the governor announced his budget, and want to apply some of this to $1.2 billion in new tax cuts phased in over the next five years. Some of the newly identified money is expected to be used to cut the gross receipts tax on energy, which falls heaviest on struggling upstate businesses, especially as energy costs increase. There are also promises of earned-income tax credits, an important way to help the working poor.
The centerpiece of a separate agreement on transportation is a proposed $3.8 billion bond issue for next November, half going for highways and the other half for mass transit. The bond issue has been seized upon by state leaders as their part of the capital plan of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, particularly a $3 billion proposal to build a full Second Avenue subway and a link between the Long Island Rail Road and Grand Central Terminal.
Bond issues have been a tough sell in recent years, and voters in November may well be concentrating more on Senate and presidential races than on increasing the state's debt. They will certainly be skeptical of authorizing more borrowing by the state without a full explanation of how the money will be spent and when these projects will be finished. Meanwhile, serious questions remain about where the M.T.A. will get the remaining funds -- whether from city or state coffers, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey or perhaps even an unpopular fare increase.
This fat-year budget wisely offers at least some cushion against leaner times, adding a reserve fund of $750 million as a hedge against an economic downturn. Such measures will help shore up New York's budget status even more than this sudden surge of timeliness.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
NASDAQ RECOVERS AFTER A FREE FALL IN A WARY MARKET

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
There was sound. There was fury. But what stock market investors wanted to know after yesterday's frightening bungee jump in share prices was, what does it signify?
Midway through one of the weirdest and wildest days in stock market history, the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index had plunged 574.57 points from its close the day before, shearing 13.6 percent off its value. Had it ended there, it would have been the worst one-day decline in Nasdaq history. But a flood of buying rescued the index, propelling it up almost 500 points, to close with a loss of only 1.77 percent on the day. In one trading session, the index traveled on extraordinary 1,074 points. 
 As the Nasdaq plummeted, the more established gauges fell alongside it. About 1:15 p.m., the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 4.5 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had lost 5.9 percent. But these gauges bounced back as well, with the Dow closing the day down 0.51 percent and the S.& P. 500 ending with a loss of 0.75 percent. Page C1.
Even though the markets recovered by the end of the day, traders and investors were shellshocked by the extraordinary moves. Trading ranges of 10 and 15 points were commonplace among even established companies like American Express, Intel, General Electric and Cisco Systems.
The selling seemed to represent the first serious threat to the all-technology-all-the-time market investors have come to love. Technology stocks have dominated investors' psyches in recent years and have been responsible for titanic gains among those buyers willing to suspend their disbelief about what the future may hold for these companies. As a result, investors bid up the prices of both untested companies with no sign of profits and established companies with enviable earnings growth to levels that were never seen before.
"These stocks are trading on psychology, and ultimately markets are efficient," said Edward Kerschner, chief market strategist at PaineWebber. "Our view is that part of the excesses have been corrected, but not all of them." Mr. Kerschner thinks that the 20 most popular technology stocks with no earnings, like Amazon.com and Juniper Networks, have to go down another 40 percent before they can begin to be considered for purchase.
Many strategists think yesterday's mood shift among investors has staying power. "Panic is setting in among people who have big gains," said David Eidelman, money manager with Eidelman, Finger & Harris in St. Louis. "At first, when stocks go down, you have complacency among investors. Then people start to wonder, 'Can I lose everything I've made?' In a lot of these stocks" with high price-to-earnings ratios, "you don't really have a comfortable feeling for where the bottom is."
The upheaval in the market yesterday acted to level out some of the peaks and valleys seen in the main market gauges this year. The Nasdaq, which had been up 28 percent at its March 10 peak, is now up 1.96 percent on the year after closing yesterday at 4,148.89, down 74.79 points. The Dow, which had lost 14.8 percent in early March, is now down only 2.89 percent this year.
Brokers said that yesterday's selloff accelerated when calls for additional money went out from brokerage firms to their customers who had borrowed to buy shares.
One employee at a large online brokerage firm who declined to be identified said the firm made a record number of margin calls yesterday, four times what is typical. Almost none of the customers put up the additional money, this person said, and were therefore forced to sell some or all of their holdings. This accelerated the declines in already weak stocks.
Seeking cover from the carnage in stocks, investors fled to the traditional safe haven of United States bonds, driving their prices up. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction from it price, fell as low as 5.65 percent from 5.81 percent on Monday before finishing at 5.77 percent.
Over the last two sessions, the Nasdaq composite index has lost 9.3 percent. While it remains up 1.96 percent on the year, it is down 17.8 percent from its March 10 peak. Volume was heavy. More than 1.5 billion shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange, the biggest day ever. It was also the busiest day on the Nasdaq market.
While the rout in the Nasdaq started early in the day, the Dow and S.& P. 500 held up until late morning. Then, traders said, large investors began to experience trouble getting out of their Nasdaq shares and started selling the stocks they could. This meant many of the big stocks that make up the Dow and the S.& P. 500.
"The institutions we deal with are extremely calm, but they're frustrated because there is a ton of volume, but no natural liquidity," said Bill Schneider, head position trader at Warburg Dillon Read. "To some extent we have seen some buyers. But buyers who have bought the dip are a little more cautious this time, particularly in Nasdaq."
One reason for the lack of liquidity in Nasdaq stocks is that the traders acting as market makers in these shares are only required to buy or sell 100 shares at their specified price. In the 1980's, market makers had to buy or sell 1,000 shares at their quoted prices. A market maker acts as an intermediary, easing the buying and selling of stocks between investors and stepping in when others are unwilling to buy and sell.
As a result, traders said that many dealers yesterday bought 100 shares from a customer, as they were obligated to do, and then posted their next price so far below the prevailing market that few investors would be interested. This essentially guaranteed that dealers would not be stuck buying shares in a falling stock. Traders also said that the differences between what dealers were willing to pay for a stock and what they were willing to sell it for -- called the spread -- widened significantly as the Nasdaq plummeted, driving away all but the most desperate investors.
While yesterday's gyrations in the Nasdaq broke records, they are a continuation of extreme swings seen in that market for months.
"In January and February, 70 percent of the trading days qualified as high volatility moves of 1 percent or more, day to day," said Steven Leuthold of Leuthold Weeden Research in Minneapolis. "In March, we probably kicked this up to 75 percent of trading days, the highest we've seen in the history of the Nasdaq index." As for the broader market averages that have been around longer, volatility is higher than it has been since the 1930's.
Mr. Leuthold said that in addition to breaking records, the swings were scary. "High volatility normally indicates a market in transition" he said, in this case further toward a bear market. "I wouldn't be surprised if that is the message we're getting right now."
Unfortunately, the increasingly volatile Nasdaq is where many investors have placed their bets. According to AMG Data Services, more than half of the $113 billion investors have put into mutual funds this year has gone into those that specialize in technology stocks and higher-risk shares. "This is the most focused the flows have ever been," said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services. "The point is technology and all bets are pressed."
In addition, technology stocks have become much more popular among hedge funds, investment vehicles for wealthy individuals. According to the Hennessee Hedge Fund Advisory Group, new capital earmarked for technology funds this year is four times the capital going into the average hedge fund.
Peter Schwab, director of shareholder communications at Strong Funds in Milwaukee, reported that investors who called into the fund's headquarters were concerned but not panicked. Those who did sell shares shed technology funds and went into safer, but less lucrative, money market funds, he said.
One trader said that when Nasdaq had given up all of its gains for the year yesterday, the selling seemed to increase, reflecting the desire of investors to keep the market's rout from cutting into 1999 gains. Further selling pressure in Nasdaq stocks probably came from executives of companies that recently went public, eager to nail down some of their gains. Because these executives typically agree to hold off selling months after an offering, selling pressure does not emerge for a while.
Now, however, many of these so-called lockup periods are expiring and stock is coming on to the market. Indeed, according to Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a research firm in New York, over the last two weeks stocks with coming lockup expirations are down more than 24 percent, almost three times the overall Nasdaq's decline.
The good news in yesterday's decline, some strategists said, is that it could ease some of the Federal Reserve's worries about increasing demand for goods driven by an overheated stock market. "We think this decline in the stock market, if it persists, could change the Fed's thought process radically," said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities. "The plunge today is serious enough that any thought of wealth driving the economy is going to be tempered at a minimum, and unless there's a reversal right away, the Fed is more inclined to be more mild with their actions."
Jeremy Siegel, professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and author of "Stocks for the Long Run," argued that yesterday's move was healthy because it took some of the speculative fever out of Nasdaq stocks.
"This should surprise no one," he said. "There's no way you can make these valuations reasonable. When you have that sort of market, when it finally falls you get tremendous gaps."
Some investors who have watched the technology craze from the sidelines see a return to sanity among investors.
"We sense some sort of balance may be coming back into the market," said Anthony M. Maramarco, portfolio manager for the Babson Value Fund in Cambridge, Mass. "Gradually, people will come to their senses and realize that there's more out there than just technology."
"The market is fundamentally strong," Professor Siegel said. "But I think there's going to be a lot of unfulfilled hopes and expectations among people who thought they were entering the new world and are now finding it's a pretty harsh reality."

HEADLINE: Microsoft Decision: In Whose Interest?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Microsoft makes for an inviting target. But lost amid the glee over the prospect of bringing the giant to its knees is a careful consideration of the wisdom of doing so. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, at the government's behest, is seeking to reverse a remarkable American success story. 
 Your April 4 editorial notes that "the government has failed to produce decisive evidence that Microsoft's tactics have harmed consumers." Yet it must be said that Microsoft's growth has paralleled a growth in the American technology sector, in the American economy and in the computing power of PC's everywhere.

HEADLINE: On College Basketball;
Michigan State Adds Symmetry to the Chaos

BYLINE: By JOE DRAPE 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, April 4

 BODY:
Magic Johnson watched from the floor, barely a one-handed bounce pass away, as Mateen Cleaves stood on a stepladder and snipped down the nets. There they were, two Michigan State point guards separated by 21 years, but connected by a common accomplishment: they took national championships to East Lansing, Mich.
It is a tenuous line, but about the best you can do in trying to link this National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament with those of the past. Johnson, after all, cut down his souvenir as a sophomore in 1979, headed to the National Basketball Association draft as the overall No. 1 draft pick and then changed the professional game forever. 
 Cleaves is a senior. He will be drafted somewhere in the first round, but odds-on it will be behind some high-school player no one but hoops newsletter writers, scouts, agents and their surrogates ever heard of. Still, at least for 40 minutes on Monday, Cleaves and two senior and two junior teammates made sense of a tournament, of a college basketball season, that did not make much sense at all.
The Spartans were more experienced, played better defense and thoroughly handled a young Florida team, 89-76, at the RCA Dome. They were the lone No. 1-seeded team standing in the field of 64 -- two others, Arizona and Stanford, did not make it out of the first weekend.
Michigan State had won an ugly contest, 53-41, in the semifinals Saturday against a Wisconsin team that transported basketball aficionados back in time -- to 1941 when the Badgers' deliberate style sedated Washington State and, you have to believe, anyone who was watching, 39-34.
Wisconsin was the biggest surprise in a tournament full of them. Its coach, Dick Bennett, wears a red sweater vest and has earned a reputation as a genius among his peers after 35 years of taking players who would be hard pressed to make an All Ivy team of any year and turning them into giant killers. To borrow a term from the business world, this "old economy" team may not have been fun to watch on the basketball ticker, but Wisconsin earned its way here.
Michigan State earned the national championship in much the same fashion. It was more talented than Wisconsin, but nearly as short of marquee names. After Cleaves, who scored 18 points to go with 4 assists in the championship game, the Spartans were carried by two other seniors: Morris Peterson, whose 15 second-half points buried the Gators, and A. J. Granger, who had an unobtrusive 19 points and 9 rebounds.
Still, Florida, the "new economy" team, managed to generate all the buzz before and, to some extent, after the Spartans made them 2000's N.C.A.A. runners-up. Their 34-year-old coach, Billy Donovan, lured a collection of seven blue-chip freshmen and sophomores first to Gainesville, Fla., a football stronghold, and then to the title game.
They pressed full court, they bombed from 3-point territory and one of them, Udonis Haslem, banged inside for a career-high 27 points on 10-of-12 shooting.
Next week Florida's sophomore forward Mike Miller will decide whether he will return to school or turn professional. On the eve of the Final Four, Miller confirmed what documents reviewed by The New York Times had shown, that he had spoken extensively with a sports agent who was unregistered in Florida and who did not inform university officials of the conversations, as the state's strict agent law requires. The N.C.A.A. said the player had done nothing wrong, but the agent, Andy Miller, is now under investigation by Florida law-enforcement authorities.
It was yet another strange twist in a strange season that, unfortunately, perhaps upstaged Michigan State's title run. In the weeks leading up to the tournament, a series of N.C.A.A. investigations and player suspensions for everything from who paid prep school tuition to improper contact with agents, prompted some of the biggest names in college coaching to call college sports' governing body names.
In New York, such disparate people and institutions as a basketball enthusiast implicated in a recruiting scandal at Syracuse nearly decade ago, a Manhattan lawyer, a church with a distinguished history earned in the civil-rights era and a famed modeling agency have all been mentioned in connection with Erick Barkley and a continuing investigation of St. John's basketball team.
That is only one part of the tattered mosaic of college basketball that turned the N.C.A.A. president's state-of-the-game address here into a bitter call for change. The president, Cedric Dempsey, barely concealed his disdain for "the culture" of college basketball and vowed to "wipe it out."
So what should have been a celebration of coaches in sweater vests with overachieving players and a senior-laden team persevering to achieve a goal, or even a young, exciting troop full of possibilities, was broken up before it got started.
Magic the person might have been on the court when Cleaves and his Michigan State teammates cut down the nets, but little was magical throughout the final months of college basketball season.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1714 words

HEADLINE: ALBANY'S LEADERS REACH AGREEMENT ON SPENDING PLAN

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 4

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature agreed today on the outlines of a roughly $77 billion spending plan that generously finances education, health care, transportation and tax cuts, clearing the way for one of the earliest budgets in a decade.
With the state running a large surplus, the accord sets the boundaries for a budget that is all but certain to include an array of programs that the governor did not call for in his original budget proposal -- from expansion of prekindergarten classes and reductions in class size to low-cost prescription drugs for the elderly. And state leaders also agreed to let voters decide in November whether to spend money on a host of transportation projects, including a new Second Avenue subway line. 
 The deal calls for spending $1.4 billion more than the governor proposed in January. It propels the budget talks further along than they have been at this date in most recent years, and it places Mr. Pataki and the Legislature on a course to enact a final budget by the end of the month.
The deal also calls for $1.2 billion in new tax cuts. But the cuts are not expected to have a significant impact on this year's final budget because they will be structured to take effect in future budget years, legislative aides said.
The agreement frees Governor Pataki from dealing with business in Albany and allows him to turn his attention to campaigning for Gov. George W. Bush and in the process possibly secure a place in a Bush administration for himself.
The budget was due on April 1, but for the 16th consecutive year, the governor and the Legislature failed to meet that deadline. Last year's budget was adopted on Aug. 4 -- 126 days overdue. With today's agreement, the action shifts to the Legislature, where rank-and-file members of both houses will have to negotiate the final details publicly in conference committees.
The swiftness of the budget negotiations this year has been propelled by the legislators' desire to get home early to campaign for re-election, and by a continued surge in tax revenue that allows lawmakers to avoid having to make many of the hard choices of the past. It has also helped that Medicaid spending, traditionally one of the most contentious areas of the budget, was determined in a separate agreement in December.
Lawmakers and their leaders faced another incentive for a timely budget: a one-year-old law that withholds their pay for as long as the budget is late.
Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the Senate, predicted today that the budget, the main business of Albany, would be completed in slightly over a week. "Today we have come together and resolved the differences that have separated us these last few weeks on a budget that will ultimately provide investments in education, transportation and other essential needs," he said in a statement.
The accord announced today calls for $1.2 billion in new tax cuts to be phased in over the next five years, including tax credits for low-wage New Yorkers, as well as a reduction of a tax that adds several dollars a month to the average utility bill.
Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders also agreed to place a $3.8 billion bond act on the November ballot that would help, among other things, to pay for a new Second Avenue subway line -- demanded by the Democratic Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver -- as well as repairs to highways and bridges upstate and in the New York City suburbs, a demand made in turn by Mr. Bruno and his Republican colleagues.
The agreement also adds $750 million in a reserve fund to hedge against an economic downturn and to make up for revenue lost to future tax cuts that the governor and the Legislature had enacted in previous years. Mr. Pataki had insisted that the money be placed in reserve.
In the past, agreement on how much to spend above the governor's proposal has been the most difficult part of the budget negotiations. But with tax revenue streaming in, it was hard for Mr. Pataki to resist the Legislature's call for more spending. Mr. Pataki had proposed spending $76.8 billion in the budget he released earlier this year. But lawmakers said he had overestimated the cost of some programs, so that the $1.4 billion of new spending in the budget accord would actually raise total spending by a lesser amount.
As part of the deal, Mr. Pataki has promised that he will not attempt the sort of widespread vetoes he made in 1998, when he cut more than $1 billion in programs, mostly Democratic, from the budget lawmakers sent him. But Mr. Pataki has privately warned Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver that he will abide by the deal only if they do not spend any more than the $1.4 billion that they agreed to add to his original budget proposal.
The deal reached today by Mr. Pataki, Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver settles the main issue that had held up negotiations for weeks: an overall spending figure that all sides could accept. But aides to Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders cautioned that some details still had to be worked out before the budget was completed and then submitted to lawmakers for approval. Conference committee hearings to consider the budget will start as early as Wednesday.
The additional spending that Mr. Pataki, a Republican, and the leaders agreed upon for the 2000-2001 fiscal year will largely finance programs that both houses of the Legislature have been seeking in recent months. In that respect, the deal allows all sides to claim victory.
The governor and legislative leaders tentatively agreed that some of the new money would finance a program that Democrats who control the Assembly had sought: expanding prekindergarten classes statewide and reducing classroom size over the next few years.
The deal also calls for setting aside part of the additional money for a program that is strongly supported by the Republicans who control the Senate: expanding a state subsidy of prescription drug purchases for elderly New Yorkers, along with expanded tuition assistance for college students and their families.
While the deal calls for spending significantly more than Mr. Pataki had proposed, it allows him to achieve one of his main objectives this year: saving $750 million to help balance the budget in future years, particularly if the economy slows.
Mr. Pataki and the leaders agreed to set aside roughly $950 million for several tax cuts that rank-and-file members will specify. But aides to the governor and legislative leaders said that much of that money would be used to scale back the so-called gross receipts tax, which adds several dollars a month on average to New Yorkers' utility bills.
Mr. Pataki and the leaders also agreed to earmark $125 million to expand the earned-income tax credit, a break to the working poor. The deal also calls for setting aside at least $120 million to provide tax credits to businesses with high utility costs, according to aides to the three leaders. But Republicans said they would also push for a plan to make college education fully deductible as part of a final agreement.
The deal to provide $3.8 billion for transportation projects will not have an impact on this year's budget either. That is because leaders plan to ask voters in November to let the state borrow the money by issuing bonds. The last time such a measure went before voters was in 1997, when state leaders put a $2.4 billion school construction bond act on the ballot. The measure was defeated.
One crucial part of the budget that has not been decided is how much will be spent on school aid. But legislative aides say they expect that the budget will increase overall aid to school districts by at least $1 billion, which would be largest annual increase ever for education spending.
 
HIGHLIGHTS
Proposed State Budget: Few Sacrifices
Legislative leaders in Albany have agreed to spend $1.4 billion more than what was proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki, though that is offset somewhat by reducing the governor's estimates of what some programs will cost. In all, they estimate that the final budget will be $77 billion to $78 billion, an increase of 5 to 6 percent over last year.
 
EDUCATION -- Legislative leaders said the state would increase school aid $900 million to $1.2 billion over last year, with the exact figure to be negotiated in conference committees. The state would continue the planned expansion of its program to provide prekindergarten classes to all 4-year-olds, and to reduce class sizes in the early grades, at a cost of $190 million.
 
TAXES -- Officials agreed to tax cuts that, when fully enacted in a few years, would be worth more than $1 billion -- the exact figure has not been decided -- but would most likely be worth a small fraction of that in the first year. Most elements of the tax cut package still must be negotiated, but the lawmakers have agreed to expand the earned income tax credit for the working poor by $125 million a year, matching the increase enacted last year. One issue still undecided is whether to reduce or eliminate what amounts to an income tax on electrical utilities, one that raises power rates. The budget also reflects $2.3 billion worth of tax cuts enacted in past years that will take effect this year.
 
HEALTH CARE -- State leaders remain undecided about two contentious items sought by the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. Mr. Bruno wants to expand the program that subsidizes prescription drugs for the elderly poor, and to have the state pay for all of a new effort to provide health coverage for the uninsured, rather than pass on part of the cost to local governments. Officials say the lawmakers are likely to accept the prescription drug subsidy, but insist on passing on some new costs to cities and counties.
 
TRANSPORTATION -- The lawmakers agreed that apart from the budget, they would approve two $17 billion capital plans, one for mass transit and one for highways and bridges, with a $3.8 billion bond act going before the voters in November to help pay for them. As part of that deal, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will plan for a Second Avenue subway line the full length of Manhattan, rather than from 125th Street to 63rd Street, as the M.T.A. had proposed in its capital plan.

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
Port Traffic Sets Records

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
The robust economy propelled record levels of passenger and cargo traffic into the metropolitan region by air and sea last year, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey reported yesterday.
The 89.1 million passengers who flew in and out of Newark, La Guardia and Kennedy Airports in 1999 was a record, the agency said. And increases in exports and regional demand produced a record shipping volume of 17.9 million tons at the Port of New York and New Jersey. Traffic on the agency's six bridges and tunnels increased by 2.2 million trips, or 1.8 percent, to 126 million. PATH ridership rose 3.5 percent. 
 The agency said the high volumes, plus reduced staff levels, helped it achieve a record surplus of $191 million last year, up from $166 million in 1998. STEVE STRUNSKY

HEADLINE: SCREEN GRAB;
Bursting Bubbles: Web Tales of Speculation

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAK 

 BODY:
FOR some, the bubble was the great uranium land rush of the 1950's. When it burst, most Colorado desert turned out to be Colorado desert. For others, it was the great coin craze of the 1960's, when new Lincoln pennies were sold for dollars as great investments. Guess what they ended up being worth? Those who plunged into wine futures in the 1970's drowned their sorrows in style.
Financial bubbles, those dangerous combinations of crowd psychology and alluring, wispy investment offers, have a long and painful past. Today's dot-com investors may get an education from three of history's hottest deals: tulipmania, the South Sea bubble and the Mississippi scheme.
All three are in an 1841 classic that is as current as today's stock quotes: Charles Mackay's "Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds." It is online at www .bibliomania.com, and at sailor .gutenberg.org. 
 Mackay traces the tulip from Turkey to its introduction into the Netherlands in the mid-16th century. "In 1634, the rage among the Dutch to possess them was so great that the ordinary industry of the country was neglected, and the population, even to its lowest dregs, embarked in the tulip trade." One would-be buyer offered 12 acres of land for a rare bulb. A single example of the Viceroy variety fetched 4 fat oxen, 8 fat swine, 12 fat sheep, a bed, a suit of clothes, a silver drinking cup and large quantities of wheat, rye, wine, beer, butter and cheese.
One common thread in these accounts is that when the bubble bursts, it bursts quickly.
"The cry of distress sounded everywhere, and each man accused his neighbor." Alas, Mackay wrote, the courts refused to interfere, ruling that tulipmania debts were gambling debts, and unenforceable.
A shorter account that focuses more on the tulips themselves, "A Rambling Romp Through Tulip History," can be found at www.bulb .com/historymyth/romp.html.
The South Sea Bubble, which caused the first great British stock market crash in 1720, began in 1711 with a plan for a private group of merchants to enrich the public treasury by trading British goods to the Spanish colonies in America. All they needed was an exclusive trading right and a large loan from issuing stock, according to Mackay's account.
"Everybody had heard of the gold and silver mines of Peru and Mexico; every one believed them to be inexhaustible and it was only necessary to send the manufactures of England to the coast to be repaid a hundredfold," Mackay wrote. Never mind that Philip V of Spain had no intention of allowing the English free trade with Spanish America -- the rumors were irresistible. "Visions of ingots danced before their eyes," and warnings in Parliament were drowned out.
Perhaps the oddest and most instructive outgrowths of the South Sea Bubble were the unrelated stocks that were issued just to take advantage of the frenzy. Mackay lists four pages of them: for insuring horses, for rebuilding parsonages, for a perpetual motion machine, for trading in hair, and the piece de resistance: "for carrying on an undertaking of great advantage, but nobody to know what it is."
There is a well-illustrated account of the South Sea Bubble in an online Harvard Magazine reprint at www.harvard-magazine.com/issues /mj99/damnd.html.
The Mississippi Bubble, which occurred in France about the same time, owed its origin to a Scotsman with the magnificently inappropriate name of John Law. A mathematical genius and bon vivant, according to Mackay, he developed a winning gambling system that got him kicked out of a number of countries until he ingratiated himself with the Duke of Orleans, who became regent to Louis XV. Law issued notes based on the profits to be made from the gold and silver of the Mississippi and the Louisiana Territory. (Gold? Mississippi? Hey, it sounded good in 1718.)
Speculation in Mississippi bonds was so great that space on Law's street in Paris was rented for a fortune to traders. "The story goes that a humpbacked man who stood in the street gained considerable sums by lending his hump as a writing desk to the eager speculators."
Law was not entirely to blame, Mackay wrote: "He did not count on the avaricious frenzy of a whole nation; he did not see that confidence, like mistrust, could be increased almost ad infinitum and that hope was as extravagant as fear."
In his epitaph for Law, Mackay compares the bubbler to the first unsuspecting canoeist down the Niagara River: "He was dashed to pieces with his bark, but the waters, maddened and turned to foam by the rough descent, only boiled and bubbled for a time, and then flowed on again as smoothly as ever."
