HEADLINE: Hispanics Are Narrowing the Digital Divide

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
OF all the attention paid to the so-called digital divide lately, little of it has been devoted to the topic of Hispanics in the United States and their computer and Internet usage.
A 150-page report released today by Cheskin Research, a market research firm in Redwood Shores, Calif., says that the gap is narrowing for Hispanics and that the rate at which Hispanics in this country are buying computers far outstrips that of the general population. 
 The Cheskin study, titled "The Digital World of the U.S. Hispanic," was based on a telephone survey of 2,017 Hispanic households in February. The survey found that 42 percent of the nation's 9.3 million Hispanic households had a computer. That represents a 68 percent increase over 1998, compared with a 43 percent increase in computer ownership for the general population.
Economics still plays a large role. The median income for Hispanic households is $28,300, compared with $38,900 for the general population, said Felipe Korzenny, a principal at Cheskin Research and the main author of the study.
According to the Cheskin study, 25 percent of Hispanic households with annual incomes between $10,000 and $20,000 have a computer. Another recent study of the gap between the computer haves and have-nots, conducted by National Public Radio, the Kaiser Family Foundation and the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, showed that in the general population where household income is less than $20,000, 31 percent of households had computers.
"Considering that gap in income, the degree to which the Hispanics are adopting the technology is beyond expectations," Mr. Korzenny said.
Part of the reason for the large increase in computer purchases among Hispanics, Mr. Korzenny said, is "a very strong motivation of not being left behind."
Mr. Korzenny said that although the perception of high cost was still a strong barrier to computer ownership, lack of information about technology was an impediment that loomed just as large.
"The kids get it," said Rochelle Newman, president of Enlace Communications, an advertising firm in Los Angeles that focuses on the Hispanic market. "They see that it will get them to the next level. The kids are the ambassadors for the technology experience."
Ms. Newman said that in all the years she had been marketing to Hispanics, she had not seen anything as strong as Hispanic consumers' interest in being online. In focus groups she has conducted on the topic of health care, she said, "the respondents still don't know what an H.M.O. is, but they do know the Internet could help them find out what an H.M.O. is."
Another problem in the past, Mr. Korzenny said, has been the dearth of Hispanic-oriented Web sites. But now, sites like quepasa.com, Latino.com and Yupi, to name a few, are beginning to appear on the Web.
"It's been interesting watching it develop from a very small group of Hispanic-oriented sites to all the new sites like quepasa.com and Espanol.com," said Ernest Bromley, president of Bromley Communications, an advertising firm in San Antonio that focuses on the Hispanic market. "Plus there are all the companies coming in from Latin America launching their portals. It's just going crazy."
Surprisingly, however, Mr. Korzenny said, most Hispanic Internet users prefer the Spanish-language versions of Yahoo and America Online to the Hispanic-specific sites. One possible explanation, Mr. Korzenny said, is that the Hispanic sites do not do enough to distinguish themselves from the AOL's of the world. "These sites, though they're very nice, look like replicas of Yahoo, AOL and Netscape Navigator," he said. "The point of differentiation might not be strong enough. My guess is that the Spanish sites have focused on being sophisticated portals without customizing themselves to the culture or the needs of the culture."
Whatever the reason for the greater popularity of the mainstream portals' Hispanic versions, the situation could soon change because Quepasa.com recently began offering free, advertising-supported Internet access through NetZero.
Ms. Newman said the next big challenge was to get computers into more Hispanic households. "There is still the economic divide," she said.
Mr. Korzenny said that one way he saw to increase computer ownership among Hispanics was with innovative sales methods. He pointed to retailers like La Curacao, in Southern California, that have succeeded by going door to door, offering credit to low-income Hispanics with no credit history.
"These are people with relatively low income but they would pay," he said.
"I tell computer executives that if they would partner with these companies and sell computers that way," he added, "they could sell hundreds per day."

HEADLINE: Tommaso Buscetta, 71, Dies; First Italian Mafia Informer

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, April 5

 BODY:
Tommaso Buscetta, the first important Italian mob leader to break the Mafia oath of silence and whose testimony helped convict hundreds of Mafia leaders in Italy and the United States, died of cancer on Sunday, his Italian lawyer, Luigi Liggotti, said. He was 71 and lived at an undisclosed location under the American witness protection program.
Italy's best known "pentito," the Italian word for a penitent is now used to describe Mafia informers, Mr. Buscetta was an early, ruthless pioneer in the Sicilian Mafia's turn to drug trafficking. His decision in 1984 to cooperate with Italian and, later, American prosecutors changed the course of a dark chapter of modern Italian history. 
Mr. Buscetta's testimony about heroin smuggling in the "pizza connection" case in the mid-1980's won him American citizenship, a place in the witness protection program and the gratitude of Italian and American officials. Notoriety gave him a forum for disingenuous expiation.
"Over the years, I have seen our organization change from within," Mr. Buscetta, speaking behind a screen, told senators at a hearing on organized crime in 1988. "I have seen money, drugs and greed corrupt and destroy the cosa nostra code of honor and loyalty to the families."
His career as a mobster-turned-state's witness spanned the highs and lows of Italy's long bloody battle against organized crime. The government's reliance on pentiti culminated in 1993 with the arrest of Salvatore Riina, whom Mr. Buscetta identified as the head Sicilian Mafia.
But it reached its nadir in August 1995, when Mr. Buscetta, under Italian government protection to testify against former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, was photographed by a journalist on a Mediterranean cruise ship, sunbathing and mamboing in the ship's ballroom.
Mr. Andreotti was found not guilty of colluding with Mafia chieftains in two trials last year, partly because the testimony of Mr. Buscetta, who mentioned Mr. Andreotti's reported intimacy with mob leaders eight years after he had entered witness protection was hearsay.
Mr. Andreotti, seven times prime minister and one of Italy's most powerful postwar politicians, noted Mr. Buscetta's passing with his customary dryness.
"I was pleased the state helped him try all the cures," he told reporters on Tuesday. "It would have been very serious if his illness had stopped him from attending my trials."
Mr. Buscetta, a son of a Sicilian glazier, began his criminal career in the black market after World War II, moved to Argentina in 1948 and then back to Sicily to join the Mafia in 1957. He fled mob turf wars and local law enforcement in 1962 and was on the lam for 10 years, until he was arrested in Rio de Janeiro on international drug-trafficking charges and extradited to Sicily, where he served eight years in jail.
His release coincided with a fierce power struggle between his clan and Mr. Riina's mob, a bloodbath that cost him many relatives, including two sons. Mr. Buscetta again fled to Brazil, where he was arrested in 1983. Learning that he was about to be extradited back to Italy, Mr. Buscetta made an unsuccessful suicide attempt by swallowing strychnine.
In 1984, three days after his plane had landed here, he told a top Mafia prosecutor, Giovanni Falcone, words that quickly became famous: "I am a mafioso." He began talking and did not stop for 45 days.
Mr. Buscetta, a self-described "man of honor" in the Mafia hierarchy, did not provide investigators just names and dates. He painted an intimate portrait of the means and mores of the cosa nostra, explaining the sometimes complex, often feudal rituals, codes and castes below the surface of organized crime.
Two years later, Mr. Falcone and a fellow prosecutor, Paolo Borsellino, won the first "maxitrial" in Sicily, putting hundreds of mobsters behind bars. But that victory unleashed a decade of unbridled violence, as the Mafia brazenly challenged the state, killing judges, prosecutors and local officials. Mr. Falcone and Mr. Borsellino, two highly most respected magistrates, were assassinated within two months of each other in 1992.
In 1996, Mr. Riina was convicted of conspiring in the murder of Mr. Borsellino and five bodyguards, and the next year he was convicted of ordering the assassination of Mr. Falcone, his wife and three bodyguards.
Mr. Buscetta, who had three wives in three countries and seven children, was so famous here that he earned a certain cachet. In 1994, the design house Dolce e Gabbana brought out a men's spring collection inspired by the mobster. It featured black pinstripe suits, shiny pointed shoes and black sunglasses.
When his death became known on Tuesday, Mr. Buscetta was mourned by prosecutors and other officials as a hero of the war against organized crime, jarring accolades for a man who once described the "liberating" feeling that comes with pulling the trigger and watching an opponent fall.
On the meaner streets of Palermo, however, the word "buscetta" has become a slang insult in the same the way "sbirro" is a pejorative term for a cop.
"I am not a pentito," Mr. Buscetta once told Enzo Biagi, one of the best-known journalists in Italy. "I am a man who had to defend himself, and to do so had to tell the truth."

HEADLINE: Stock Trades In London Are Disrupted

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 5

 BODY:
Unsettled by Wall Street's wild swings, European stocks fell today, pulled down by some of the technology shares that had been leading the market higher. But for British investors the real news was that they could not trade for much of the day because of an unexplained technical problem that crippled the London Stock Exchange.
The suspension of trading until late afternoon could hardly have come at a worse time. Today was the last day of the British fiscal year for individuals, when investors usually scramble to reduce tax exposure using a strategy known in the business as "bed and breakfast" -- selling stocks today with an arrangement to buy them back tomorrow. 
 "You had all these private-client brokers coming in today to arrange these deals, finding the stock exchange closed and going ballistic," one broker said.
Moreover, the breakdown coincided with reports that the London exchange was in early merger talks with the Deutsche Borse in Frankfurt, and its negotiating position was clearly undermined by such a technical debacle. Brokers showed no hesitation in venting.
"I think it's diabolical," said David Donnelly, chief investment officer at Gordon House Asset Management. "If you think that in today's technological world, the London Stock Exchange can't open, it's incredible, farcical that there's no backup facility to keep it running."
When trading did open at 3.45 p.m. -- the close was extended to 8 p.m. -- the London market followed the rest of Europe down.
Europe's retreat affected just about every index, with new-economy stocks taking the brunt of the selling, which analysts attributed to fears among investors that the risks of owning technology and Internet stocks had risen because of the huge swings on Tuesday on Wall Street.
"The trans-Atlantic correlation between the two markets is very high," said Paul Horne, a European equity market economist with Salomon Smith Barney in London. But, he said, the fall in European technology stocks was part of a process that had been going on for about a month, driven by expectations of higher interest rates in the United States, Britain and the 11-nation euro-zone.
"The markets are taking profits out of these overvalued and under-earning shares," he said. "There's a lot of hope, but not much earning."
He forecast that volatility would continue on Thursday, as investors bought their way back into old-sector stocks with the potential to benefit from newer technologies.
The Dow Jones Stoxx 50 Price Index of European companies fell 2.8 percent, its sharpest drop since Jan. 4. The Euro.NM index of computer-related shares fell 4.7 percent, extending declines that have stripped 35 percent of its value since its record set on March 10.
And in Helsinki, dominated by new- economy stocks, the General Index slumped 7.7 percent, dragged down by a sharp fall in Nokia, the mobile phone company, which partly recovered before the close.
In Paris, the CAC-40 index closed off 3 percent, and Xetra DAX in Frankfurt fell 2.6 percent. Among individual stocks, the sharpest losses were among technology and computer-related companies with high valuations based on assumptions of booming future profits.
Sonera, Finland's biggest telephone company, fell 8.6 percent; Canal Plus, the Continent's largest pay-TV company, fell 11.4 percent; and Cap Gemini, Europe's biggest computer-services group, fell 9.6 percent. The gloom disrupted plans by some companies for initial share sales. Newconomy, for instance, which aims to provide support for Internet-related businesses, postponed plans for a $96 million flotation. Analysts forecast that the number of such offerings would be sharply reduced.
Despite the misery elsewhere, there was one beneficiary of the day's upheavals in London. Tradepoint Financial Networks, which operates an electronic rival to the London exchange, recorded seven times the trades as usual. "This is a great day for us," a spokesman said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Reagan vs. the Great Government Whale: Or the triumph of legend over history.

BYLINE: By J. Bradford DeLong; This column appears here every Thursday. J. Bradford DeLong is a professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley and co-editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. Four economic analysts -- Professor DeLong, Jeff Madrick, Virginia Postrel and Alan B. Krueger -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
TWO decades ago Ronald Reagan campaigned for president promising to shrink the size of the federal government. And in America's political mythology Mr. Reagan's victory started the rollback of the social insurance state. Mr. Reagan pushed his huge supply-side tax cut through Congress and so starved and shrank the leviathan that was the government.
This is the mythology. But it is not the economic history. In the current budget year -- in fiscal 2000 -- the share of the nation's economic output, or gross domestic product, collected by the federal government as taxes will amount to more than 20 percent, up from an average of 18.7 percent the last five pre-Reagan-administration years, 1976 through 1980. How did this come to pass? What happened to the supply-side line in the sand drawn by Mr. Reagan? 
 The story of how the 1981 tax-cut shift in America's political economy was eroded to nothing has three parts: the 1980's deficits, the early 1990's forecasts and the late 1990's boom.
President Reagan's 1981 tax cut came without significant spending cuts. Nineteen eighty-one was the year of tax cuts. But 1982 and the years following were the years of deficits. Even before the ink of Mr. Reagan's signature was dry, his senior policy makers began loudly and angrily blaming each other for the deficit.
David Stockman, the budget director, and his aides blamed the rest of the administration's unwillingness to think about serious budget cuts. Martin Anderson, who was the White House domestic policy adviser early in Mr. Reagan's first term, disagreed, blaming a Congress that "time and time again" rebuffed presidential plans to cut spending. But Democratic House leaders and Republican Senate leaders accurately pointed out that nine-tenths of the deficit would have remained had Congress accepted every one of Mr. Reagan's spending proposals.
Perhaps the most interesting attribution of blame came late, in the mid-1990's, from Irving Kristol, the conservative intellectual, whose magazine, The Public Interest, had helped start the supply-side boom. Mr. Kristol contended the mistake was in carrying out the campaign promises of 1980, for supply-side doctrine was a political platform, not a public policy, and had a "rather cavalier attitude toward the budget deficit and other monetary or fiscal problems."
The point, he added, was to create a "Republican majority -- so political effectiveness was the priority, not the accounting deficiencies of government."
No matter whose finger-pointing you agree with -- Mr. Stockman's, Mr. Anderson's, the Senate Republican leader Bob Dole's or Irving Kristol's -- the fact of the deficits of the 1980's created slow but inexorable pressure to raise taxes to close the deficit. Indeed, the process of taking back some of the revenue given away by the government in 1981 began as early as 1982 with a tax bill pushed through Congress largely by Mr. Dole.
The pressure to raise taxes was amplified by another consequence of the deficit: slower economic growth. The deficit meant reduced money for investment, which meant lower income growth, which meant lower revenue growth. As a result, the long-term forecasts of the administration's Office of Management and Budget and the Congressional Budget Office kept turning out to be substantially more optimistic than what actually happened. So by the early 1990's, both the O.M.B. and the C.B.O., anxious not to overestimate federal revenue yet again, began -- perhaps unconsciously -- to low-ball their forecasts. In the early 1990's, as the economy weakened and government revenue slowed as well, they produced increasingly pessimistic and horrifying deficit forecasts.
All this further increased the pressure for tax increases. Both George Bush, a Republican, and Bill Clinton, a Democrat, proposed tax increases explicitly aimed at reversing the widening deficits. And by 1994-95, federal revenues as a share of G.D.P. were as high as they had been in Jimmy Carter's term.
Then came the late 1990's boom. Lowered interest rates driven in part by the shrinking of annual budget deficits, coupled with the flourishing of the information technology sector -- partly made possible by extra money no longer going to cover the government deficit that fueled high-investment expansion -- fostered a boom in asset prices.
And as the paper wealth of rich Americans grew beyond their previous dreams, the well-off began to cash in some of their gains. Such increases in the stock of wealth from higher asset prices are not part of G.D.P., which measures the flow of goods and services newly produced, and has no place for changes in the value of assets that already exist. But the Internal Revenue Service collects extra taxes when the affluent sell assets and realize capital gains. Thus the magnitude of the late 1990's boom in production and the value of wealth has pushed federal revenue relative to G.D.P. to their current high level.
In retrospect the people who worked hard in the late 1970's to elect a president to cut federal spending and roll back the social insurance state saw their work go for naught. They had succeeded, or thought they did, with the election of Mr. Reagan. They were elated, and their social democratic adversaries disheartened. But today the level of federal taxes shows no sign of their work.
Perhaps there is a moral here. Perhaps if you are in politics to change actual policy -- rather than to provide jobs for your friends -- it is important to make sure that those you vote and work for do not take political effectiveness and media splash as their sole compass.

HEADLINE: Solomon Barkin, 92, Economist In Labor Movement and Teacher

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Solomon Barkin, a retired labor economist and professor emeritus at the University of Massachusetts who wrote prodigiously about working people, died on March 29 at his home in Leverett, Mass. He was 92.
Professor Barkin spent 25 years in the labor movement, from 1937 to 1963, as director of research for the Textile Workers Union, now part of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. For the next five years, he was a manpower specialist and head of the social-affairs division of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. 
 He taught economics at Amherst from 1968 to 1978, when he was given emeritus status. Then he was a visiting professor of economics at Erasmus University in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, and a senior Fulbright professor at Victoria University in Wellington, New Zealand.
A native New Yorker, Professor Barkin graduated from City College in 1928 and received an M.A. degree at Columbia University in 1929. After stints as a City College instructor and assistant director of the State Commission on Old Age Security in Albany, he served on the labor advisory board of the National Recovery Administration and as a specialist in industrial economics in the Department of Commerce.
His published work started in 1930 with a study of old-age security and extended into the 1980's when he sat on the editorial boards of the Journal of Economic Issues and the French-language edition of Relations Industrielles, where he continued until 1991. He also helped edit periodicals like Technical Change and Manpower Planning, Arbitration Journal and International Labor.
His experiences were reflected in the book "The Decline of the Labor Movement and What Can Be Done About It" (1961), in which he argued that unions were getting bogged down in administering contracts to the detriment of their role as instruments of change.
His other books included "Worker Militancy and its Consequences, 1965-75" (1975). An updated edition, subtitled "The Changing Climate of Western and Industrial Relations," appeared in 1983.
Mr. Barkin is survived by his wife of 59 years, Elaine Rappaport Barkin; two sons, David, of Mexico, and Dr. Roger Barkin of Denver; a daughter, Amy Barkin of Bethesda, Md., and three grandsons.

HEADLINE: Iran Says It Seized Ship Smuggling Iraqi Oil

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 5

 BODY:
Two weeks after the United States warned that increased oil smuggling from Iraq could not be stopped without Iran's help, the Iranian government said today that it had seized a tanker illegally exporting Iraqi oil as it passed through Iranian waters.
The Iranian national news agency said that revolutionary guards boarded an Iraqi ship flying under a Honduran flag on Saturday. The ship was reported to be carrying 2,500 tons of smuggled oil. The Iranian agency said the ship and its captain and crew were in Iranian custody. 
 "If the reports are true, we are pleased to see that Iran is taking measures against this illegal traffic," a spokesman for the State Department, James P. Rubin, said.
"In the past, Iran has taken measures to halt smuggling along its coast, and we hope this is an indication they intend to do so vigorously again," he said.
Mr. Rubin said the United States had not confirmed the arrest, which follows more than 18 months during which Iran allowed what American officials say is significant growth in the illegal coastal trade.
On March 23, Vice Adm. Charles Moore, the American coordinator of an international fleet that patrols the Persian Gulf off Iraq and intercepts illegal shipments, told the Security Council sanctions committee on Iraq that oil smuggling had increased significantly since the fall, with much of the trade beginning in Iranian coastal waters.
Admiral Moore told the committee that a diplomatic or political overture to Iraq was needed and that the smuggled Iraqi oil -- most of it gas oil, similar to diesel fuel -- went to a variety of countries including Iran, as well as to Pakistan and India. Recently, two Thais and a Singaporean were charged in California with trying to buy Iraqi oil, apparently for shipment to Southeast Asia.
Pentagon officials told the sanctions panel that with high oil prices, Iraq could earn more than $1 billion in illegal sales this year.
Under Security Council sanctions imposed in 1990 after Iraq invaded Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein's government is not only prohibited from selling oil without United Nations supervision, but it is also barred from refining oil, as it has to do to produce gas oil.
Since December, Iraq has been allowed to sell as much crude oil as it wants, with profits going to a United Nations escrow account to pay for food, medicines and equipment for a range of public services. A third of the money goes to compensate victims of the Kuwait invasion.
In another sanctions dispute, American officials considered today how to respond to an illegal flight into Baghdad by an Italian plane that was taking anti-sanctions campaigners to Iraq. All flights to Iraq have to seek approval from the sanctions committee.
The pilot of the small Italian passenger plane left Jordan yesterday saying that he was going to Syria and then turned and flew at a very low altitude into Iraq.
On board were, in addition to the pilot, an Italian businessman, identified by the Jordanians as Nicola Grauso; a member of the European Parliament, Vittori Sgarbi; and a French priest, the Rev. Jean-Marie Benjamin. When the plane returned to Jordan today, it was intercepted, forced to land and impounded.
The businessmen were allowed to leave Amman by commercial flights, but the pilot was detained. The priest, who had campaigned against sanctions, remained in Baghdad, the Jordanians said.
In Baghdad, the group said the flight had been deliberately planned to break the air embargo. Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz called the flight a "noble and courageous initiative."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Asian Technology Stocks Fall, Echoing Nasdaq Dive

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 5

 BODY:
In Asia, as in the United States, the bloom is off the rose for technology shares. But here, it has withered more rapidly.
Many stock markets from Tokyo to Singapore declined today as investors followed the gyrating Nasdaq in the United States by dumping shares in technology, Internet and telecommunications companies. The rout was severe in Hong Kong, where the benchmark Hang Seng index plunged 3.4 percent and popular companies like China Telecom and Pacific Century CyberWorks led the retreat. 
 The sell-off has particularly troubling implications for Pacific Century, which is using its stock as currency to finance a takeover of Hong Kong's dominant telephone company, Cable and Wireless HKT. Pacific Century's shares fell 11 percent, to 14.95 Hong Kong dollars, or $1.92. The shares have declined 32 percent since the agreement was announced late in February.
"We're certainly in the danger zone for this deal," said David Webb, editor of Webb-site.com, an Internet service for investors. "The institutional investors who own Cable and Wireless stock are sensible people. There is a point at which they will reject the transaction."
The Pacific Century deal is something of a bellwether because it symbolizes the rise of Internet companies in Asia. The company, controlled by a 32-year-old entrepreneur, Richard Li, has few assets aside from a clutch of investments in Internet start-ups. Yet it has become one of the most highly valued stocks in Hong Kong, rivaling the property empire of Mr. Li's father, Li Ka-shing.
To win Cable and Wireless HKT, the younger Mr. Li vanquished Singapore Telecommunications, a much larger company controlled by the Singapore government. He was able to do so because the board of Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the London-based parent of Cable and Wireless HKT, concluded that selling to an Internet company was more attractive than to another phone company.
But while Cable and Wireless owns 54 percent of HKT, Mr. Li still needs the approval of other shareholders, including China Telecom and the Hong Kong government. He is offering two options for their shares: all-stock or stock and cash. The value of the all-stock offer has dropped to $25.8 billion from $38.1 billion, while the stock and cash offer has dropped to $28 billion from $35.9 billion.
Mr. Webb said the erosion in Pacific Century CyberWorks' shares all but guaranteed that investors would opt for the stock-and-cash offer. That would leave HKT's majority owner, Cable and Wireless, with less cash and a larger stake in Pacific Century. Cable and Wireless has pledged to sell a chunk of that stake soon after the deal is completed, which will put further pressure on Pacific Century shares.
Some experts said they were baffled by the open-ended nature of the deal. "Cable and Wireless didn't negotiate a collar on the stock, they didn't negotiate a walk-away price, and the breakup fee is minimal," said Henry Lee, managing director of Hendale Ventures, an asset management firm in Hong Kong.
But other analysts pointed out that Pacific Century will not make a formal offer to shareholders until May 18. Given the wild swings in technology shares, its stock price could well rebound by then. Despite the steady erosion in the company's shares, there have been no public indications of concern, either from Cable and Wireless or from other HKT shareholders.
A spokesman for Pacific Century declined to comment today, noting only that the terms of the deal would not be modified.
Pacific Century was far from the only technology stock punished in Hong Kong today. Three of the hottest local Internet start-ups -- Tom.com, Hongkong.com and Sunevision -- plunged 16.6 percent, 16.8 percent, and 12.2 percent respectively. After soaring, these companies are now trading below the prices at which they went public a few weeks ago.
Nor was the bad news limited to Hong Kong. In Tokyo, two of the most prominent new-economy stocks continued to languish. Softbank, which owns a portfolio of Internet investments, fell by the Nikkei index's daily trading limit of 5,000 yen, or $47.77, to close at 76,500 yen, or $730.94.
Trading in the shares of Hikari Tsushin, which sells cellular phones and has a joint venture with Pacific Century CyberWorks, was halted for a fourth consecutive session, as orders to sell stock swamped orders to buy. The company recently warned of much-larger-than-expected losses in the six-month period that ended in February.
Despite all the anxiety, many analysts said this was a much-needed correction for Asian markets that had become dangerously overheated.
"The tech bubble is finally bursting," said Marc Faber, the head of his own investment firm here. "In order to burst a bubble, people have to lose money. Now, people are losing money."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Call to Put Social Issues on Corporate Agendas

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 5

 BODY:
A multinational corporation prepares for a major investment in a troubled part of the world. The pickings, from oil or mining or cheap labor, stand to be enormous. But the local government is corrupt. Its security forces are brutal. What does the company do?
Increasingly, according to a report released here tonight by Amnesty International, the answer is fraught with a new kind of corporate risk, not just for the company's operations but its global reputation, retention of quality employees and ultimately its shareholders. 
 In the modern wired world, the company's activities will not simply fall under the microscopic scrutiny of advocacy groups, the report says, those same groups will spread their assertions and criticism around the world within seconds on the Internet.
Far more than in the past, the report argues, a multinational company's stance on human rights will be considered part of its performance. And, it says, companies must be prepared to confront the governments that play host to them about issues ranging from political repression to child labor.
"There is no hiding place," said Sir Geoffrey Chandler of Amnesty International, the London-based human rights monitoring group that wrote the report along with the Prince of Wales Business Leaders Forum, an advocacy organization supported by Prince Charles of Britain to promote socially responsible business practices.
"To go without a policy on human rights is to go naked into a dangerous world," Sir Geoffrey said in an interview.
The report, titled "Human Rights -- Is It Any of Your Business?," signals the beginning of a new campaign by advocacy groups to hold corporate behavior to standards that many multinational corporations had once sought to dismiss.
It cites, for instance, the experience of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group in the Niger Delta of Nigeria in the mid-1990's, when the company's activities were caught between a repressive military regime and the protests of Nigeria's Ogoni people, who demanded that Shell compensate them for extracting oil from their land. The conflict led to the execution of nine Ogoni activists in 1995 -- and, immediately afterward, demands for a boycott of Shell products. As a result, the report says, Shell revised its business principles to commit itself to upholding human rights.
The report's insistence that other corporations should follow the lead of companies like Shell, BP Amoco P.L.C., Reebok International and Levi Strauss & Company reflects how advocacy groups have increasingly challenged businesses over their practices.
In Britain, consumer advocacy groups have succeeded in virtually driving genetically modified foods off supermarket shelves. Corporations are expected to routinely report on their environmental record. Pressure from United States and British groups in the 1990's forced new scrutiny of the way child labor was used in the Asian sporting goods industry, from footwear to soccer balls.
But the newest campaign takes aim not so much at consumers as at the boardrooms of big international companies, urging the most senior managers to consider the hazards of ignoring issues like labor rights, local land rights, the use of security forces to protect foreign installations and the dilemmas of operating under corrupt regimes or in war zones. All those factors, it argues, have become more relevant as multinational corporations play an increasingly dominant role in economic development.
"Companies have a direct self-interest in using their legitimate influence to protect and promote the human rights of their employees and of the communities within which they are investing and/or operating," the report says. "The increasing scrutiny of corporate behavior by the media, consumer groups, community organizations, local and international nongovernmental organizations, and the immediacy of global communication leave companies with little, if any, hiding place."
The report urges that companies incorporate explicit commitments to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in their central strategies and operating procedures and accept outside scrutiny of their performance. "There can be no neutrality," Sir Geoffrey said in the interview. "If you are silent, you are going to be seen as complicit."
It was not clear tonight how the report would be received in business circles. However, a survey by the Ashridge business school in Britain released tonight in conjunction with the report suggested that human rights issues were finding their way onto corporate agendas.
The survey of Fortune 500 companies said 36 percent of respondents "have decided not to proceed with a proposed investment project because of concerns over human rights issues" while 19 percent "have disinvested from a particular country because of concerns" about the same issues. It also found that less than half -- 44 percent -- of companies with a code of ethics or business principles "make explicit reference to human rights."

HEADLINE: Settlement Reported in Bond-Pricing Case

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
More than a dozen Wall Street securities firms, led by the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup, have agreed to pay more than $120 million to end long-running federal investigations into whether state and local governments nationwide were overcharged for Treasury securities they bought, according to people close to the parties in the agreement.
With the settlement, expected to be announced today, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service are wrapping up their investigations into a practice known as yield burning. 
 In several lawsuits filed against investment banks in the 1990's, regulators and municipal officials contended that the banks charged artificially high prices for Treasury securities, which lowered, or "burned down," the yield, or rate of interest, those securities paid. Yield moves in the opposite direction from the price.
The settlement will result in the dismissal of some of the suits, including one filed in United States District Court in Manhattan by Michael R. Lissack, who had been an investment banker at the former Smith Barney. It will also extinguish fears that some investors could face tax liabilities for buying bonds that had been promoted as tax exempt.
The I.R.S. had been studying whether to take away the tax-exempt status of some bonds issued by municipalities. But lawyers involved in the negotiations said they had been told that the I.R.S. would not do that.
A spokesman for PaineWebber Group, the big brokerage firm, said: "We are pleased with this industrywide settlement. It covers municipal reinvestment transactions done throughout the industry from 1990 through 1994 and resolves any uncertainty regarding tax liability for the affected municipal bond issuers and bondholders."
As part of the settlement, PaineWebber is paying about $26 million to the United States Treasury and to clients that issued municipal bonds, people close to the parties said. That amount ranks PaineWebber second only to Salomon Smith Barney, which is paying about $40 million, these people said.
Most of the parties to the settlement, including Salomon Smith Barney, the I.R.S. and the United States attorney's office, would not comment on the agreement before it was announced.
The amount each firm is paying is based on the number and pricing of underwritings they managed that regulators contend involved illegal markups. Some of the biggest firms on Wall Street are paying as little as $2 million, while some smaller competitors are paying much more. Dain Rauscher, a smaller brokerage firm based in Minneapolis, is paying about $10 million, while the Prudential Securities unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America is paying about $6 million, these people said.
As the one who blew the whistle on yield burning, Mr. Lissack, who no longer works on Wall Street, stands to reap a reward of $20 million or more. John Phillips, a lawyer for Mr. Lissack, said his client intended to keep only about $4 million and give the rest to charity and to his alma mater, Williams College.
"Any global resolution involving all the firms will put to rest the issue of yield burning," said Mr. Phillips, a partner in Phillips & Cohen in Washington. "The big benefit is this lawsuit has totally cleaned up this industry."
Mr. Lissack became a pariah in the municipal bond business after he went public with his allegations that investment banks were overcharging for the Treasuries that municipal governments used to refinance their debt. After Smith Barney fired him, he filed suit against a group of investment banks under the federal False Claims Act. That law provides for whistle-blowers to receive 15 percent to 25 percent of amounts recovered from defendants.
Micah S. Green, chief operating officer of the Bond Market Association, an industry trade group, welcomed word of an impending settlement. "In a sense this is everyone standing up and saying, 'Let's put this issue behind us and hold investors harmless and preserve the safety and soundness of the municipal bond market, which is so important to state and local governments.' "

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 548 words

HEADLINE: Conference on the New Economy Gives Clinton a Chance to Glow

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
There was plenty of talk about hard-core economic issues like productivity, technology and stock market valuations today at the White House as President Clinton served as the host to a daylong conference on the new economy and what it means for the nation's future.
On that level, it broke no new ground. But it was the kind of day Mr. Clinton loves and excels at, rich in policy debate and statistics. 
 "Even though the participation of women in the labor force is the highest it has ever been, the unemployment rate among women is the lowest in 40 years," the president asserted this morning, from memory, during a freewheeling panel discussion entitled, "Is the New Economy Rewriting Rules on Productivity and the Business Cycle?"
But just beneath the surface, there was politics at work.
Given that the nation is enjoying the longest economic expansion in its history, with unemployment just above 4 percent and inflation nearly dormant, the administration was happy to have the economy take center stage for the day.
On no other issue does the president have as clear a claim to a legacy, notwithstanding Republican claims that the nation is enjoying not the Clinton boom but a continuation of the Reagan boom.
For the most part, the conference steered clear of overtly partisan messages.
There were even a few Republicans present, including John B. Taylor, an economist from Stanford University who is an adviser to the presidential campaign of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. And much of the informal conversation was about the stock market, with one of the day's biggest draws being Abby Joseph Cohen, the market prognosticator from Goldman Sachs, who reassured the audience that she was still enthusiastic about the outlook for stocks in the United States.
But there were plenty of opportunities for the administration to make points on particular issues. In several instances, Mr. Clinton promoted his free-trade policies, and in particular his top goal at the moment: convincing Congress to approve a trade deal with China.
"It will lead to an opening of the society and a rise in freedom and personal choice," the president said of the trade pact, which Republican leaders intend to bring up in the House near the end of May. "We're talking about the new economy. Two years ago there were two million Internet users in China. Last year there were nine million. I think this year there will be somewhere between 20 million and 25 million."
Administration officials also took advantage of the opportunity to jab at Mr. Bush and Republicans in Congress over fiscal policy, suggesting that the big tax cuts that Republicans are proposing would undermine one of the foundations of the current prosperity, the large and growing federal budget surplus.
What administration officials refer to as Republican tax "schemes" were high on the list of what many participants said were the risks to keeping the expansion going.
When Henry J. Aaron, a fellow at the Brookings Institution, a liberal- leaning research group, asked at a session attended by about 30 people how many of them would support a big tax cut, only two -- Mr. Taylor and John Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group -- raised their hands.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Judge Sets Deadline in May For Microsoft Penalty Plan
The next phase of the Microsoft antitrust case should be wrapped up by late May under a schedule set by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is presiding over the case.
The timetable calls for the Justice Department to propose remedies by April 28 and for Microsoft to make its proposal on May 10. State Attorneys General, meanwhile, appeared to be giving up any attempt to force the breakup of Microsoft. Page A1.
 
'Yield Burning' Case Is Settled
More than a dozen Wall Street investment banks, led by Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney unit, have agreed to pay more than $120 million to end federal investigations into whether they overcharged state and local governments nationwide for Treasuries. C8. 

Metropolitan Life Issues Shares
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company issued nearly 500 million shares to more than 9 million policyholders, making the company's shares the most widely held in America. Shares the company sold in its initial public stock offering closed at $15.375, up from their initial price of $14.25. Robert H. Benmosche, the company's chief executive, said the company was in the position to raise more capital and make acquisitions if it wanted. C7.
 
Arms Charges Filed in Satellite Case
The State Department charged Lockheed Martin with 30 violations of arms export laws in connection with its help in evaluating problems in Chinese-made satellite technology in 1994. The claims expose the aerospace company to a possible penalty of $15 million. A24.
 
Hospitals In Gene-Sequencing Pact
Twelve of New York State's major medical centers and research institutions are expected to announce an agreement to join forces to buy highly discounted gene-sequencing technology and, in some cases, share its use. B7.
 
Technology Stock Sell-Off Hits Asia
Stock markets in Asia were battered as investors sold technology, Internet and telecommunications shares. The Hang Seng index of stocks traded in Hong Kong was the biggest loser, falling 3.4 percent. C12.
 
European stocks fell, pulled down by technology shares that had been leading the market higher. But British investors could not trade for much of the day because of an unexplained technical problem that crippled the London Stock Exchange. C12.
 
Yahoo Posts Profit of $78 Million
Yahoo said it earned $78 million in the first quarter, up from $1.8 million a year earlier, helped by growth in its overseas operations. The company reported a sharp increase in the number users visiting the Yahoo Web site. Yahoo's shares fell $1.8125, to $165.5625. The company released its results after the close of the market, and in after-hours trading, its stock fell as low as $159.75 a share. C6.
 
Fact Over Supply-Side Fiction
Ronald Reagan campaigned for president promising to shrink the federal government, and once he reached the White House he pushed a huge tax cut through Congress. But his mission ultimately failed. In fiscal 2000, the share of the gross domestic product collected by the government as taxes will amount to more than 20 percent, up from an average of 18.7 percent during the last five pre-Reagan-administration years. Economic Scene. C2.
 
Human Rights and Corporate Risk
Amnesty International has issued a report that describes the risk that multinational corporations face when they operate without regard for human rights. C4.
 
Quiz Show Generates Knockoffs
The media are capitalizing on the popularity of the television game show, "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" with an increasing number of spoofs, knockoffs and ripoffs in advertising. Advertising. C10.

HEADLINE: Groups Question $1.6 Million State Grant To Company Tied to Whitman's Husband

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 5

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's husband, John Whitman, was a major shareholder and director of an Internet company that was approved for a $1.6 million grant from the state last November, according to records from the New Jersey Department of Commerce and Economic Development.
Mr. Whitman, a venture capitalist, was on the board of directors of the e-mail company Mail.com last fall when the company applied for and won a state tax incentive grant to move its offices from Manhattan to Jersey City, creating hundreds of jobs in New Jersey, according to company officials. Through Mr. Whitman's family investments and those of his firm, Sycamore Ventures, he owned about 10 percent of the company at the time of the grant application, state officials said today. 
 Although state officials said that neither Governor Whitman nor her husband were involved in the application or approval of the grant, government watchdog groups said Mr. Whitman's role in a company that received state money raised questions of a conflict of interest.
"While there's no evidence of any legal wrongdoing, this certainly gives the impression of a possible impropriety to members of the public," said Pamela Garfield of Common Cause of New Jersey. "We need to be looking at ways to strengthen the laws governing spousal business interests so that members of the public don't have to worry about whether people are given special treatment."
Governor Whitman's spokesman, Pete McDonough, insisted that Mail.com received no preferential treatment and that Mr. Whitman had not been aware that the company was seeking a state grant until after the application had been submitted.
"I would applaud John Whitman for bringing 500 high-paying, high-tech jobs to New Jersey," Mr. McDonough said. "The company took advantage of the benefits New Jersey has to offer any high-tech company and it would be to our detriment if they didn't, because those jobs would still be in New York."
Mr. Whitman joined the board of Mail.com in July 1998 and left several days after the company won the grant. By partaking in a series of stock issues and I.P.O.'s, Mr. Whitman, his investment firm and the charitable trusts he controls have bought more than two million shares in the company. Its stock closed at 12.93 today, making Mr. Whitman's shares worth at least $26 million.
Mail.com officials said their decision to seek a grant from New Jersey's Business Employment Incentive Program was made without the board's knowledge and was suggested by an outside consulting firm that was hired to compare tax incentive packages of various communities. Holly Lehr, a spokeswoman for the company, said Mr. Whitman was not involved in preparing the grant application before it was submitted. Mr. Whitman was not listed on the grant application because only those who own 15 percent or more of the company are required to be listed.
"As far as we know, he wasn't even aware of it," Ms. Lehr said.
Mr. Whitman did not return calls seeking comment. But Mr. McDonough said that once Mr. Whitman learned that the company had applied for the tax incentive, he called Gualberto Medina, the State Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, to ask whether he should disclose his role in the company.
Mr. Medina's spokeswoman, Lisa Kruse, said he told Mr. Whitman there was no need to report his role in the company because he owned less than 15 percent.
Some Democratic elected officials said that Mr. Whitman should have reported his ownership stake in Mail.com to the state's Executive Commission on Ethical Standards before the company applied for a grant.
"If he's an investor in a company, they have a right to apply, but he should have cleared it ahead of time and he never should have had a conversation with Medina," said State Senator Richard Codey, the minority leader.
But Caren S. Franzini, executive director of New Jersey Economic Development Authority, said Mail.com's application was treated no differently than any other. The program, which gives employers as much as 80 percent of the income tax paid by its workers, awarded 62 grants worth a total of $96.8 million last year. Those tax incentives are expected to create 14,300 jobs and spur $1.1 billion in investments by companies in New Jersey, according to state officials.
Ms. Franzini said her staff discovered Mr. Whitman's involvement in Mail.com during routine research of the company's background. But Ms. Franzini said she did not to mention Mr. Whitman's ownership stake to the development agency's board members, who ultimately voted on the application. She did not do so, she said, because the company met the standards for a grant, and she thought it should be judged solely on its merits.
"We're here to treat every company equally," Ms. Franzini said. "To tell you the truth, I think that you'd be raising an ethical issue if we brought up the fact that it was the governor's husband. That would be treating him differently."
The public scrutiny of Mr. Whitman's involvement with Mail.com has rekindled another issue for the governor, the state's troubled new auto emissions inspection system. One director who sat on the Mail.com board with Mr. Whitman is also on the board of the Parsons Corporation, the contractor that unveiled a $400 million auto emissions system last December that has been plagued by computer breakdowns, equipment failures and long lines of angry motorists.
There is no evidence that either Mr. Whitman or the other board member, Jack Kuehler, played any role in the awarding of the auto emissions contract. But the mere connection between Mr. Whitman and Parsons, however tangential, has led leaders of the state workers union to call for a federal investigation of the Parsons contract. Attempts to reach Mr. Kuehler late this afternoon were unsuccessful.
"The deeper you dig, the worse it gets," said Hetty Rosenstein, executive vice president of Communications Workers of America Local 1037, which lost 300 jobs when the auto emissions inspection system was privatized. "We have hundreds of people being laid off, terrible service to the public and a lot of well-connected Republicans making a lot of money."
Mr. McDonough said that neither Mr. Whitman nor his business associates were involved in the state's handling of the auto inspection contract.
"What you're starting to get into here is the six degrees of John Whitman," Mr. McDonough said. "Jack Kuehler is the former vice chairman of I.B.M.; he's probably on a hundred different corporate boards. John Whitman has neither a formal nor an informal role in the operation of state government and had nothing to do with the Parson's contract. So this is just completely irrelevant."

HEADLINE: Greenspan Treads Softly After Market's Gyrations

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
A day after Wall Street endured one of its most unnerving rides, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered soothing words to investors today, saying as explicitly as he ever has that the central bank's interest rate increases are not intended to drive down stock prices.
But as he has now for months, Mr. Greenspan continued to identify the wealth being generated by rising stock prices as the primary cause of imbalances in the economy that could potentially lead to inflation. 
 Mr. Greenspan seemed intent on drawing a distinction between raising or lowering interest rates based on movements in the stock market -- a strategy he said would be ineffective and perhaps inappropriate for the Fed to attempt -- and acknowledging that Wall Street's effects on the rest of the economy are so powerful that they have to be taken into account in monetary policy.
The distinction was subtle if not meaningless to some analysts and investors. In their view, Mr. Greenspan wants to have it both ways, putting pressure on the markets without taking heat for it, and suggested that the Fed chairman did not mind sowing a bit of uncertainty to keep the markets in check even as he reassures them.
"Each time he denies that he's targeting asset prices, he highlights the fact that equity prices are central to monetary policy at the moment," said Rory Robertson, an economist at Macquarie Bank in New York. "Removing equity market strength is going to be part and parcel of removing economic imbalances, whether or not you say that you're targeting equity prices."
Speaking at a White House conference on technology and the economy, Mr. Greenspan was much clearer that he was sticking for now to his strategy of raising rates in small steps until he is sure that the economy is on an even keel. He said the central bank would not go "far wrong if we maintain a consistent, vigilant, noninflationary monetary policy."
The Fed chairman peppered his speech with admiring phrases about the ways in which information technology has reshaped the economy in recent years, calling current conditions "profoundly different" and "without precedent." And he said that the pickup over the last few years in the growth rate of productivity -- potentially the most fundamentally beneficial change of this era in economic history -- showed no signs of slowing.
But Mr. Greenspan warned that the positive developments could be put at risk if the Fed allowed inflation to infect the economy. The risk of that happening, he said, stemmed from the most basic of misalignments in the economy, between demand, which is rising sharply, and supply, which cannot keep pace.
In Mr. Greenspan's view, growth in demand is exceeding the corresponding increase in supply because it stems not from an increase in the nation's capacity to produce but from wealth created by rising prices for stocks, homes and other assets, the gyrations of the last few weeks on Wall Street notwithstanding.
"The rise in stock prices, as well as in the capital gains on homes, has created a marked increase in purchasing power without providing an equivalent and immediate expansion in the supply of goods and services," he said.
Economists, analysts and investors have taken Mr. Greenspan to mean that the most direct way to bring supply and demand into balance is to choke off the wealth effect. But today, Mr. Greenspan moved closer to the more traditional central bank view that the remedy is as simple and as complex as slowing the entire economy, halting the gradual drop in unemployment and arresting the growth in the trade deficit.
"The persuasive evidence that the wealth effect is contributing to the risk of imbalances in our economy, however, does not imply that the most straightforward way to restore balance in financial and product markets is for monetary policy to target asset price levels," Mr. Greenspan said.
"Leaving aside the deeper question of whether asset-price targeting is an appropriate government function," he continued, "there is little if any evidence that monetary policy aimed at achieving that goal would be successful."
He went on to stress that the focus of monetary policy should be the broader economy and any potential imbalances within it.
"Should changes in asset prices foster economic imbalances, as they appear to have done in recent years, it is the latter we need to address, not asset prices," he said.
Mr. Greenspan has long given off somewhat conflicting signals about the market and its influence on policy -- in part because he genuinely seems to be struggling with how the financial markets interact with the real economy, and how central banks should react to sharp moves.
His famous remark more than three years ago about "irrational exuberance" was not a statement of fact but rather a question about how policy makers should recognize when asset price swings are getting out of hand.
Yet he is well aware of the power that the Fed has to influence the markets, and over his nearly 13-year tenure at the Fed has spoken at various times during closed-door meetings of his fear that markets have entered speculative territory.
In early 1994, as the Fed embarked on a series of interest rate increases, Mr. Greenspan was at first worried about giving too big a jolt to the markets but then happy to see stock and bond prices tumble, according to recently released transcripts of Federal Open Market Committee meetings from that year.
"I think we partially broke the back of an emerging speculation in equities," Mr. Greenspan said in a telephone conference call with members of the policy committee on Feb. 28, 1994. "We also have created a degree of uncertainty. If we were looking at the emergence of speculative forces, which clearly were evident in very early stages, then I think we had a desirable effect."
In his only direct comment today on valuations in the market, Mr. Greenspan noted that securities analysts had projected that earnings growth for technology companies would be double that for the other companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
"To the extent that there is an element of prescience in these expectations, it would reinforce the notion that technology synergies are still expanding and that expectations of productivity growth are still rising," Mr. Greenspan said. "There are many who argue, of course, that it is not prescience but wishful thinking. History will judge."

Antibiotic Is Recommended In African AIDS Crisis
The 23 million Africans with the virus that causes AIDS should get regular doses of an affordable antibiotic, best known as Bactrim, to ward off fatal secondary infections, the World Health Organization and the United Nations AIDS program said. A1 

New Prime Minister in Japan

Parliament rejected a constitutional amendment that would have let President Suleyman Demirel seek a second term, a decision that defied senior but aged members of the political establishment. HEADLINE: Elian the Boy, Elian the Symbol

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Elian Waits Inside as Tension Grows Outside" (news article, April 5): There are two Cuban dictatorships. The one in Havana dictates conduct in Cuba. The one in Miami largely dictates United States policy toward Cuba. The dictatorships are in a tug of war. A little boy is the rope. He has lost his mother. The Miami dictatorship is keeping him from his father. 
 By working to reunite him with his father, the Clinton administration is finally defying the edicts from Miami. Perhaps it will now be free to end the embargo that imposes pointless hardship on the Cuban people.

MALCOLM BELL
Weston, Vt., April 5, 2000

HEADLINE: Gates Keeps Washington Dates;
Scheduled Sessions Rarely Touch on Microsoft Troubles

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
William H. Gates had business before all three branches of government today.
In the morning, Mr. Gates -- the founder of the Microsoft Corporation and still considered the world's richest man despite the battering his company's stock has taken lately -- met with lawmakers on both sides of the Capitol, where he expressed confidence his company would overturn a federal judge's stinging ruling this week that Microsoft had violated antitrust laws. 
 In the afternoon, at a White House conference on the new economy, he sat side by side with President Clinton, whose administration had taken him to court. He stuck to the president's agenda -- how to spread technology to the poor -- and studiously avoided any mention of the court case.
 "If you're invited to a forum on global warming, you don't talk about saving the Social Security trust fund," explained Ginny Terzano, a Microsoft spokeswoman, who used to work at the White House. "It would have been inappropriate."
 Mr. Gates also had some business between the White House and the Capitol, at Washington's federal courthouse, but it wasn't on his itinerary. Microsoft's lawyers appeared before Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who ruled against Microsoft on Monday. Judge Jackson set a May 24 hearing on sanctions against the software giant.
 Mr. Gates's visit to Washington showed the many sides of the man.
In court documents filed by the Justice Department, he is portrayed as a ruthless monopolist who built his own wealth at the expense of the marketplace. Mr. Clinton, however, invited him to the White House to highlight his philanthropic efforts through the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
Lawmakers, meanwhile, were aware of his growing political influence. Microsoft topped the list of computer industry contributors to political campaigns last year, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, with $1.2 million going almost equally to Democrats and Republicans.
 Microsoft has long preferred to focus on Washington State, where the company is based, rather than on Washington D.C. But the company has clearly come to realize the need to operate on both coasts.
Today's version of "Mr. Gates Goes to Washington" began about 9:15 a.m. In four back-to-back meetings with House and Senate Democrats and Republicans, Mr. Gates was treated neither as a victim nor a villain, but as a national treasure whose fate in the courts has yet to play out.
"He was treated like an icon of the new economy," said Representative Norman Dicks, a Washington Democrat who set up Mr. Gates's meeting with about 50 House Democrats. "People are willing to wait and see how the lawsuit plays out. The sentiment was that members would like this to settle."
Mr. Gates has plenty of detractors, of course, especially in the Silicon Valley districts that are home to Microsoft's chief competitors. But the naysayers were nowhere to be found today.
"We were very upset and disappointed by the court decision," said Representative Jennifer Dunn, a Washington Republican who arranged Mr. Gates's meeting with about 60 House Republicans. "He was encouraged by our members to hang in there and never, never give up. He said he believes he'll win on appeal."
In a wide-ranging discussion with about a dozen Senate Democrats, Mr. Gates covered subjects from education to health care to the global economy, and the roles industry and Congress play.
 Next stop was an hour with House Republicans, where Mr. Gates, after brief introductory remarks that did not touch on the court decision, forecast a technological future in which even technology-shy lawmakers would carry their daily schedules in a tablet device, and the Internet would be a staple of work and personal lives.
An hour later, before House Democrats who are trying to burnish their image with the high-technology community, Mr. Gates fielded questions about the so-called digital divide between those enjoying the wealth and advantages that flow from access to computers and the Internet versus those who may be left behind in the race to improve their lives. He also put in a plug for high-technology industries' need for more H-1B visas for software specialists and other technical workers, a measure that is now pending in both the House and Senate.
When one Democrat groused that the booming economy had bypassed his district, leaving some highly qualified engineers unemployed, Mr. Gates insisted the legislator send him their resumes.
Instead of tapping into Mr. Gates's software expertise, White House officials invited him to the conference because of his philanthropic efforts. He participated in a panel discussion on how best to bring health, education and technology to poor people the world over.
"The work he's doing around the world, we have admiration for," said a senior White House official. "As far as the company and its practices, we had a problem with that."
Mr. Gates was able to make a similar distinction. His aides say he considers the Justice Department to be the entity pushing the suit against his company, not the White House. He also keeps in mind, they said, that the federal government is one of Microsoft's largest clients.
But there was clearly a bit of angst on both sides before Mr. Gates arrived at the White House.
After the court ruling this week, John Podesta, the White House chief of staff, checked with Joel I. Klein, the assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, to determine whether Mr. Gates's participation in the White House was appropriate. No objection was made.
Aides to Mr. Gates also called the White House after the ruling to determine whether Mr. Gates's invitation, which was issued a month ago, was still valid. It was.
"It didn't appear to be awkward in any way," Trevor Neilson, a spokesman for the Gates Foundation, said of his boss's White House visit.
And despite Mr. Gates's dire warnings about what effect government meddling would have on his company, he sounded positive about the future, sanctions or no sanctions.
"We're at the beginning of what the computer can do to change our lives," he said at the White House. "The best is yet to come."

William H. Gates used to publicly spurn the need to deal with Washington, D.C. But he has been spending more time there lately.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1399 words

HEADLINE: Poaching Adds New Hurdle To Police Recruiting Efforts

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS 

 BODY:
For two years, New York City has been struggling to attract potential recruits to take the Police Department's admissions test, battling a downward trend that saw the number of applicants plummet from 31,000 in 1996 to fewer than half that number last year.
And yesterday, despite last year's $10 million recruiting campaign aimed at city residents, police officials learned that the number had dropped sharply again: only 6,000 people have expressed interest in the latest exam, forcing the city to extend the application deadline for a second time, to April 20. 
 Police officials, union leaders and critics of the department have described a list of factors that hinder local recruiting: the relatively low pay for rookies, the sizzling private-sector economy, the strained relations with minority residents and the shootings of unarmed men that have prompted public outcry.
Now add this: poaching. Even as the city struggles to lure residents -- particularly blacks and Hispanics -- to its own department, police recruiters from Los Angeles have come to New York's turf, offering promises of warmer climes, higher starting salaries and openings at the academy as soon as this summer. And they are having surprising success.
"We're probably fielding 300 or 400 phone calls a day just from people in New York City asking for information about the test," said Officer Jose A. Ferreira of the Los Angeles police, who is recruiting this week at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan. "With our salaries, and with living in L.A. being what it is -- the beaches, the weather -- we're finding a lot of people who are attracted to this work."
No one claims that out-of-town recruiting has caused the steep drop in police applications in New York. But the visit by the Los Angeles recruiters, their first in nearly 20 years, is remarkable for its scale -- and its timing. Not only have they arrived as fewer people are applying to be officers in New York, but they are also competing directly for minority applicants. The Los Angeles department has run advertisements on minority radio stations, inviting all New Yorkers -- not just John Jay students -- to take the test. It is part of a national recruitment effort by the department, which seeks to add 1,000 officers, Officer Ferreira said.
In New York, 34 percent of the department's 40,000 officers are black, Hispanic or Asian. The Los Angeles Police Department, with 9,600 sworn officers, has a minority representation of 50 percent.
"I think that the possibility that Los Angeles police recruiting would be successful in New York underscores the serious problem that N.Y.P.D. has in recruiting minorities," said Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. "You can get African-Americans, Latinos and Asians interested in applying for your police department, if you send out the message that you want them to apply."
Police Commissioner Howard Safir said criticism of the department's recruiting was "made of whole cloth." He said that the department had a list of 41,000 people who passed the test during the 1990's and that he expected only 3,000 to 6,000 openings at the academy in the next two years.
The list, however, includes applicants going back to the mid-1990's, and no one can say how many people on it are still available to be hired.
The number probably includes people who have taken other jobs or have decided not to pursue the next level of testing, including a physical and a background check. And by extending the deadline yesterday, the department made it clear that it still seeks fresh talent.
Nonetheless, the issue of declining applications, Mr. Safir said, had little to do with the department's ability to fill its ranks. He said the drop in applications was a natural extension of the booming economy and what he described as negative news coverage. "Right now, based on the media attention and the way the department has been portrayed in the media," he said, "it is not surprising to me that the people are not applying in the numbers they applied in the past."
Mr. Safir also said Los Angeles was forced on the road to recruit because it could not find enough applicants in its own region. New York recruiters have not had to travel, he said, except for trips to military bases to recruit veterans.
Still, Jerome H. Skolnick, a professor at New York University School of Law who teaches a seminar in police practices, said the recent decline was reason for serious concern. "I think this is really a crisis now -- the small number of potential recruits," Professor Skolnick said. "There is the danger that you may have so few applicants that you cannot get the quality you desire."
Like police officials, Professor Skolnick said the prosperous economy had caused the decline. But he also said the cases of Abner Louima, who was tortured in a Brooklyn police station, and Amadou Diallo, who was killed by the police on the doorstep of his apartment house, have raised awareness of racial tension between the department and city residents, discouraging some applicants from even considering the test.
"Among blacks, it is likely that there is a stigma to saying, 'I am going to be a New York cop,' " Professor Skolnick said.
Patrick J. Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, agreed that the reputation of the department had suffered in recent years. But he said New York City's drop in applications, and Los Angeles's prediction of success in New York, could be attributed to a simple factor: pay. Police salaries in Los Angeles start at $41,000 each year; in New York, salaries start at $34,000.
Mr. Lynch said the gap was particularly irritating because New York's recruits are required to have completed 60 college credits or two years of military service for admission to the academy. In Los Angeles, cadets are admitted to the academy with only high school diplomas.
"I think it's fairly obvious that the New York Police Department is not paying a livable wage," Mr. Lynch said. "Our rookie officers are taking home $700 every two weeks. That's not enough to put food on the table, much less pay the rent.
"We have young officers living in the basements of their parents' homes, while I think Los Angeles is an example of a department that is paying its officers a livable wage, which allows people to follow their passions."
The Los Angeles police hope to take advantage of this gap today. At 8 a.m., at John Jay College, Officer Ferreira will reach into one of 19 sealed boxes, remove bundles of standardized tests and distribute them to rows of potential recruits.
And by Saturday evening, when the last would-be rookie has taken the test, Officer Ferreira and his six colleagues expect to have screened as many as 4,000 applicants, an accomplishment in three days that would rival New York's recruiting effort so far this year.
On the campus yesterday, students who met with the Los Angeles recruiting team had money on their minds. Ato Gordon, 22, a senior from Canarsie, Brooklyn, met with the officers near the cafeteria. He and his peers asked questions about police-community relations and the Los Angeles crime rate, but they also asked about the cost of renting an apartment. Mr. Gordon studied the salary figures on the Los Angeles department's literature.
"I could be in Beverly Hills right now driving around," he said.
Professor Skolnick also described another phenomenon. The New York department is not alone in receiving harsh criticism, he noted, even as crime has declined.
Los Angeles has been roiled by its share of police scandals during the last decade, from the beating of Rodney G. King to the decision last month to disband an antigang unit that had been at the heart of a corruption and brutality scandal.
But none of the students who were interviewed yesterday seemed to know any substantive details about recent controversies in Los Angeles. Many were in their preteen years when Mr. King was beaten by officers in 1991 and riots erupted in 1992. Professor Skolnick said that perhaps when a department recruits away from home, it enjoys a less-biased view among applicants.
"I think some of the reason for the Los Angeles police coming to New York is that they don't have the local stigma in New York," he said. "Knowing this, maybe New York ought to go to Los Angeles to recruit."
