SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1158 words

HEADLINE: The Suits Loosen Up, In an Uneasy Way;
As Dress Codes Are Rewritten, the World Of Button-Downs Puzzles Over Wardrobes

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Walking into the Four Seasons restaurant for lunch on a recent Tuesday, Jim Finn, a senior vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank, suddenly learned what it means to be in the vanguard of a trend: He was the only man there without a tie.
"I had to go boldly and confidently into the room," Mr. Finn said. "I wondered if everyone was whispering, 'Is that a guy with a dot-com and a hundred-million-dollar portfolio?' " 
 No, Mr. Finn is a point man in the newest assault on the business suit that is sweeping through the city's investment banks, consulting firms and law firms, toppling a century of dress codes and pushing some traditional tailors into uncharted waters.
Originally a concession to summer's scorching heat, Casual Friday has given way to Casual Every Day. Conventions are crumbling as old-economy companies find themselves competing for scarce labor against new-media enterprises run by people who take their fashion cues from Silicon Valley, not Saville Row.
From J. P. Morgan to Morgan Stanley to Chase Manhattan Bank and the law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, members of the professional and business elite are being encouraged to trade in their pinstripes for Polo wear and their wingtips for Weejuns. Some employers are sponsoring fashion shows, seminars and even shopping excursions.
Perhaps with good reason. Business casual, as the new standard is called, does not come easy to everyone.
Employers have made it clear that jeans, sweatshirts and T-shirts that are permitted on Saturdays and Sundays will not pass muster Monday through Friday. At the law firm Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, the chairman, John F. Pritchard, said the dress policy could be summed up in a simple rule: "If you have to ask if the clothing is appropriate, chances are, it's not."
It seems that while many professionals have closets stocked with pleated chinos, Shetland sweaters and blazers that conform to the new standards, others do not. "Some guys only have two kinds of clothes -- suits and slob clothes," said Ann Shipley, a partner at the law firm Battle Fowler. "I've seen guys come in here on casual Fridays, and they look awful. They look like they've just cleaned out the garage."
Not surprisingly, retailers that were once perceived as a source solely of leisure wear are only too eager to guide customers through the sartorial transition, which, by most accounts, has placed more of a burden on men than women. Ever since they abandoned the power suits of the 1980's, women have been accorded more leeway in how they dress.
"People have a lot of questions," said Trudy F. Sullivan, the president of J. Crew, which offered discounts to employees of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter when that investment firm went casual last month. "They want to make sure that what they're going to buy is going to be appropriate. We're happy to help."
Seizing on the trend, Brooks Brothers is setting up mannequins in office conference rooms to illustrate different casual looks. On Tuesday, the Polo Ralph Lauren on Madison Avenue staged a fashion show, with lawyers as models, for Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, which is thought to be the first large Wall Street law firm to go all casual all the time. The fashion show demonstrated "ways to distinguish yourself in casual wear," said Scott Omelianuk, the executive editor of Esquire magazine, a sponsor of the event.
Bloomingdale's is inviting its salespeople to seminars with major designers so they can instruct customers on dressing casually and looking good at the same time. "A lot of men don't know how to do that," said Kal Ruttenstein, the store's fashion director.
About a dozen New York companies are organizing trips to Woodbury Common Premium Outlets in Central Valley, N.Y., where corporate shoppers receive discount coupons. Joining the excursion arranged by his employer, Prudential Securities, on a recent Saturday Andrew Kloch, a 23-year-old investment banker, wore black cotton pants from Banana Republic. He described the pants as his "going-out clothes," a category distinct from business casual.
"I don't mind wearing suits at all," said Mr. Kloch, who owns seven of them. "It was easy just to get up and throw a suit on. Now it's a bit more of a pain because I have no business casual clothes."
As with most fashion trends, however, there is no unanimity about the wisdom of business casual.
Many professionals say that dispensing with suits has made them more comfortable and hence more productive. In a March 13 memo announcing the new dress policy, William B. Harrison Jr., the chairman of Chase, the city's largest private employer, said, "A more casual work environment mirrors the more flexible, informal organization that we need to become."
But others say they have no intention of changing lifelong habits. "I'm not going to dress casual," said Richard Beattie, the chairman of the law firm Simpson Thatcher & Bartlett. "And I don't expect I'll see Bill Harrison dressed in chinos at a meeting, either." Like other law firms, Simpson Thatcher has been slower to adopt the trend; it will allow casual dress this summer for the first time.
Mr. Beattie shops at Paul Stuart, the fashionable Madison Avenue store that is not making concessions to the current trend. "These companies are shooting themselves in the foot by letting down their standards," said Clifford Grodd, the store's president and chief executive. "There's no way we're going to do it -- not while I'm calling the shots. Everyone recognizes that we stand for something."
Nearby merchants that also cater to the carriage trade are similarly resistant. "The people in the big firms that we take care of," said John O'D. Kennedy, the executive vice president of J. Press, "they're not dressing down."
Dressing down requires the type of planning that men are not often called upon to make. Under the rules at most companies and firms, old-economy clothes are still mandatory for meetings with old-economy clients. When Mitchell Sonkin, a partner at Cadwalader, was summoned at short notice to a meeting in Philadelphia, he was relieved that he had a suit in his office to change into. "I felt like Clark Kent," he said.
Returning to his office the next day, he had to remember to replace the suit, along with a fresh shirt, tie and shoes to go with it. But he is an enthusiastic proponent of the relaxed dress code. "It has a very positive impact on morale," he said.
Whatever its virtues, business casual has complicated the lives of men who once thought they were immune to fashion gaffes.
"I find the suit easier," concedes Chase's Mr. Finn, who is in his late 30's and buys many of his suits in Paris.
Take heart, Mr. Finn. The tie may be gone forever, but there are indications that yet another change may be in the wind -- a kind of dressing up with softer lines.
"The suit," Mr. Omelianuk of Esquire explained, "is actually starting to make a comeback."

HEADLINE: Agreement Reached to Build a Downtown Sports Arena for Newark

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 5

 BODY:
Paving the way for one of the largest development projects here in decades, the YankeeNets and a major landowner have struck a deal for a new downtown sports arena that officials hope will spark the rejuvenation of one of the state's poorest cities.
The agreement, reached on Tuesday, removes the most serious obstacle to the project, settling a dispute over whether the arena -- a new home for the New Jersey Nets and the Devils -- will be built in the heart of downtown Newark, near the intersection of Broad and Market Streets, or 600 feet to the southeast, next to the city's public transportation hub, Pennsylvania Station. 
 In the end, the YankeeNets, which owns the two teams, succeeded in moving the arena closer to the station, easing its concerns that sports fans arriving by train would be loath to walk through the center of a city that has long been associated with urban blight. Under the new plan, those attending basketball or hockey games will be able to proceed directly from Pennsylvania Station to the arena through an elevated passageway, eliminating the need to walk on the street.
Many urban planners have criticized that plan, saying it would keep visitors bottled up near the station rather than getting them into the historic center of Newark.
As part of Tuesday's deal, Jerome Gottesman, whose company, Edison Parking, owns a critical chunk of the 40-acre redevelopment district, agreed to let the YankeeNets build its $295 million arena on part of his property across Market Street from the station. In exchange, Mr. Gottesman will be given the right to build garages and three office buildings in the arena district, a desolate landscape of parking lots and vacant buildings that officials are hoping will one day buzz with sports bars, shops, nightclubs and restaurants.
The new plan, however, eliminates a soccer stadium for the New York-New Jersey MetroStars that had been proposed in earlier plans and replaces it with a mixed-use development that includes television studios, high-tech office space and space for educational institutions.
Mayor Sharpe James, who supported the YankeeNets plan, hailed the settlement today and predicted that the 18,500-seat arena would be finished within four years.
"This undertaking will create thousands of new jobs for city residents, new opportunities for local families and tax ratables for Newark," he said. "It's a win-win situation for all parties."
The completion of the arena would be an astonishing feat for a city that not long ago was being written off. After decades of calling itself "America's Renaissance City" with few solid signs of rebirth, Newark is finally enjoying the fruits of the nation's economic boom. A performing arts center opened here three years ago to nearly unanimous praise, aging office buildings are being renovated for dot-com upstarts, and city officials have plans for a downtown arts and entertainment district.
Although the redevelopment plan, including the condemnation of about 100 homes and 50 businesses, still requires approval by the City Council and the Planning Board, Newark officials agreed that Tuesday's deal had defused a threat by the YankeeNets to build an arena somewhere else.
City officials are holding public hearings on the proposal this week, although the first session, on Tuesday night, drew scant opposition.
A group of residents initially sued the city to stop the condemnation process, but continuing negotiations between the residents and the YankeeNets have won over even the most stubborn opponents.
Hal Laessig, the leader of a group that has been fighting the project, said the developers seemed committed to rebuilding his neighborhood a few blocks to the south. "It's not what we wanted to see happen, but at this point it looks like a done deal," Mr. Laessig said. "We just hope they replace the houses, galleries and artist studios that will be destroyed."
The settlement ends 18 months of uncertainty over whether the project would ever get off the ground. It moved closer to reality last month, when the YankeeNets announced its purchase of the Devils from John J. McMullen, who had been planning to build his own stadium in Hoboken. The promise of two teams in Newark heightened the project's prospects, especially since Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had made it clear that the state would not help finance more than one sports arena.
Pete McDonough, a spokesman for the governor, said today that the state might contribute $75 million to $100 million toward a stadium project, which would be paid for through a combination of private and public financing. Mayor James has said the city would contribute to the cost of the arena as well.
Harvey Schiller, the YankeeNets chairman, said he could not provide details of the project until Newark officials had approved the redevelopment plan.
In the meantime, the MetroStars are continuing their own pursuit of an outdoor soccer stadium in Newark. The stadium, which would cost from $40 million to $60 million, was originally part of a plan for the arena district, but that plan fell apart last week, when the YankeeNets failed to reach a deal to buy half of the MetroStars from the team's owners.
Nick Sakiewicz, the team's general manager, said he was hoping to build a new stadium near the city's Ironbound section, with its large population of Portuguese and Brazilians. "We really want to be there," he said. "That's where our fans are." Like the Nets and the Devils, the MetroStars now play at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford.
Augusto Amador, who represents the Ironbound area in the City Council, said that local residents strongly supported a stadium and that he was looking for potential sites. "If we build a stadium here, they will come," he said.
Although most everyone seemed pleased that the proposed arena was moving forward, some urban planners said the decision to link it to Penn Station was a missed opportunity. James W. Hughes, dean of Rutgers University's Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, said the plan would prevent some spectators from ever treading on Newark's sidewalks.
"There are advantages to having the arena directly accessible from the station," he said. "But the downside of that is you lose the spinoff effect. Foot traffic that might otherwise help outside businesses ends up staying indoors."

HEADLINE: DIAMOND WARS: A special report.;
Africa's Gems: Warfare's Best Friend

 BODY:
The rough stone emerges from the African soil at fortresslike mines in the war zones of Angola or straight from the muck of a dammed-up river in Congo. After journeying across continents and oceans, after being graded, cut, polished and set in gold along the way, a diamond lands in a display window in Manhattan, transformed into a pricey symbol of eternal love and beckoning to brides-to-be.
The journey can take months or even years. To enforce the myth that diamonds are rare and valuable, most of the world's rough stones are hoarded in London and then carefully fed back into the world market. 
 De Beers, the South African conglomerate that controls two-thirds of the world's rough diamonds, decides how many will be sold, when, to whom and at what price.
Where they are mined responsibly, as in Botswana, South Africa or Namibia, diamonds can contribute to development and stability. But where governments are corrupt, rebels are pitiless and borders are porous, as in Angola, Congo or Sierra Leone, the glittering stones have become agents of slave labor, murder, dismemberment, mass homelessness and wholesale economic collapse.
While market manipulation guarantees the price in world markets, the portability and anonymity of diamonds -- millions of dollars' worth can be smuggled in a sock, and identifying where they came out of the ground is often impossible -- have made them the currency of choice for predators with guns in modern Africa.
"You can't wage war without money, and diamonds are money," said Willy Kingombe Idi, who buys diamonds from diggers in Congo. "People are fighting for money. Everything that happens, it's about money."
De Beers estimates that only 3 percent of global rough diamonds now come from conflict areas in Africa, according to Andrew Lamont, a company spokesman who repeatedly said it was difficult to define a conflict area.
But Christine Gordon, a London-based journalist and independent diamond expert who has been critical of De Beers, said that as recently as the mid-1990's, diamonds from African war zones accounted for 10 to 15 percent of world supply.
In any case, violent goings-on in diamond-rich Africa have done nothing, thus far, to change the consuming habits of Americans, who buy more than half the world's diamond jewelry. Sales jumped about 11 percent last year. Diamond sales are also booming around the world, with De Beers showing record sales last year of more than $5 billion.
 
Digging in the Mud
At the bottom rung of the international diamond trade, the need to scrape up enough money to eat sends Africans like Mati Balemo clawing through the mud of a Congolese stream bed. Mr. Balemo is a digger.
On a recent morning, he and six other diggers set off from Kisangani, in north-central Congo, traveling first by bicycle taxi and then on foot. Along the way, a soldier armed with a stubby machine gun demanded to come along. But he hired another bicycle taxi, which took a spill on a hill, pleasing the diggers.
They arrived after three hours at a small stream where the thick canopy of bamboo and vines made the early afternoon as dark as twilight. The diggers had been working this site for a month and had found only a few diamonds. They used shovels to dam off small sections of the stream. Then they heaped mounds of mud onto the bank. They picked out big rocks from the mud and sifted through what was left with metal screens nailed to wooden frames.
Diggers like Mr. Balemo are driven by the dream of one stone that will change their lives. For weeks or months they work bent over in shallow rivers or in pits. In three years as a digger, the biggest diamond Mr. Balemo ever found was a stone of 2.16 carats worth $800. That diamond, if it were of flawless color and clarity, could retail for as much as $10,000 in New York, experts say. Mr. Balemo split his $800 with five fellow diggers.
Miki Galedem, 30, another digger who started when he was 16, once found a monstrous stone of nine carats. He was paid $4,800. But he was young then, in 1993, and the money disappeared, he said, on "beer and women."
Standing in a pool of water stilled by mounds of mud, the diggers professed not to think much about their business -- where the diamonds go, who wears them and at what price. "Diamonds are beautiful," Mr. Balemo said. "Everyone wants to be beautiful. That is normal."
He was knee-deep in the stream, and had been sifting mud -- a brown stew with pebbles and quartz -- for an hour. Suddenly, he found a diamond. He popped it in his mouth to clean it and then showed off a shiny white stone half the size of a raisin. His friends clapped, and one digger guessed that traders back in Kisangani would pay $20 at most for the stone.
"I'm very glad," Mr. Balemo said, not smiling much, for this was the first diamond in nearly a week. "It's not much money for all that work."
The soldier with the stubby machine gun, who had been watching closely from the river bank, then came over and took the diamond. He folded it into a scrap of paper backed with gold foil and stuffed the packet into his chest pocket.
By the rules of Congo, the guy with the gun got the diamond. Even when the stones are taken from the ground using the most sophisticated equipment, the game is roughly the same.
 
Financing the Arms
In northeast Angola, the Catoca diamond mine -- one of a half dozen such sites in that Texas-sized country -- is an island of modernity in a sea of civil war. Huge earthmovers gouge out the diamond-bearing earth and feed it into a sorting plant, where water, electric vibrators and X-rays separate out about $8 million worth of diamonds a month, an amount expected to quadruple as the mine expands.
The diamonds are stored in a high-security sorting room before they are flown to Europe. As technicians grade the uncut stones, Israeli-trained security guards watch from every angle to make sure that no one slips a rock into his pocket. The mine has satellite TV and 24-hour Internet access, but the only way in or out is by air. To protect employees from attack, they are locked inside the mine's gates every night by guards with automatic weapons.
Until four years ago, the men with guns were rebel soldiers working for Unita, the Angolan rebel group led by Jonas Savimbi. Delfi Rui, a 39-year-old digger, recalled seeing rebels whip an elderly man who refused to dig. He said they had threatened to shoot those who would not give them at least half the diamonds they found.
The Angolan military took Catoca from Unita in 1996, and within two years modern mining began atop one of the planet's largest veins of diamonds. The mine now employs 1,100 Angolans and has the potential to anchor an economic revival in a part of the country where there are no other industries, no money for war reconstruction and no government services. Jobs at the mine are expected to last for at least four decades.
But the persistence of fighting in the area means that men with guns still find ways to milk the diamond business. A private security force controlled by the chief of staff of the Angolan Army, Gen. Joao de Matos, protects Catoca. About 300 armed guards, most of them former Angolan soldiers, have staked out a fortified perimeter around the mine. They charge $500,000 a month to protect the mine from Unita.
Since they were chased away from the mine, Unita soldiers have stayed in the area and terrorized the local citizenry with hit-and-run guerrilla raids. They have forced about 56,000 nearby civilians from their homes. Most are destitute. Land mines have maimed many. Without international food aid, they would starve.
Unita's behavior led the United Nations to impose a diamond embargo on the group in 1998, making it the only African rebel force subjected to such action.
For years, the United States and the white government of South Africa supported Unita, an acronym in Portuguese for the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, as a counter to the Moscow-backed government in Luanda. But with the end of the cold war and of apartheid, Unita lost its military patrons. International isolation deepened when Mr. Savimbi, its leader, lost an election in Angola 1992.
Rather than accept a vote foreign observers judged free and fair, Mr. Savimbi returned to the bush and resumed war against the Angolan government. His fighters seized control of the Cuango River valley, Angola's richest diamond territory, and began a major mining operation that more than compensated for the lost cold-war aid, and made them the richest rebels in Africa.
Diamond money paid for Unita offensives that in the 1990's elevated Angola's civil war to a new plateau of savagery. Highland cities like Cuito and Huambo were all but flattened by artillery shells. More than half a million Angolans were killed. Land mines maimed about 90,000. Fighting displaced 4 million Angolans, and about 1 million continue to depend on foreign food aid. The United Nations Children's Fund now ranks Angola as the worst place on earth to be a child.
At Andulo, Unita's headquarters in the central highlands of Angola, Mr. Savimbi personally haggled with arms merchants and diamond traders who flew in from Europe. The rebel boss bargained using small bags of diamonds, each of which contained several million dollars' worth of gems, according to Robert R. Fowler, the Canadian ambassador to the United Nations and chairman of a committee that investigated violations of the embargo against Unita.
"If the price was $22 million, Savimbi would reach down for four of those bags and two of those," Mr. Fowler said. "The arms dealers had their diamond experts, and Savimbi had his, and they would inspect the diamonds to see if they really were worth $22 million. And then they haggled some more and somebody would throw in an extra bag of diamonds, and off the arms dealers flew."
Mr. Savimbi became a major buyer on the international arms scene. Giant Russian-made Il-76 cargo planes made as many as 22 deliveries a night at Andulo, said Mr. Fowler. The primary source for most of the arms was Bulgaria, the report said, although Bulgarian officials deny it.
The United Nations waited nearly six years before imposing an embargo on Unita diamonds, even though there was never any doubt what Mr. Savimbi was doing with his little bags. With an estimated $3 billion in legal diamond sales, he built Unita into a highly mobile war machine with 35,000 well-armed troops. By the early summer of last year, Unita seemed on the verge of toppling the government in Angola.
The rebels were turned back only because the government went on a $500-million weapons-buying spree of its own, financed by Western oil companies that paid the government more than $900 million for rights to new offshore oil finds.
Although Unita's diamond sales are down sharply from the mid-1990's, the United Nations report said gems continued to play a "uniquely important role" for the rebels.
There is no United Nations embargo on diamonds from Congo or Sierra Leone.
Hunger for looted diamonds is a major reason why six other countries have sent soldiers into Congo. Angola, Namibia and Zimbabwe have sent troops to protect the government of Laurent Kabila, while Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda have sent soldiers to assist rebels trying to overthrow him.
Altogether, they have succeeded in shattering much of the economy of eastern Congo, transforming Kisangani, the major city of eastern Congo, into a gaudy and ghostly ruin.
The streets of Kisangani are nearly empty of cars. The textile plant is closed, and the once-thriving port on the Congo River is quiet. Apart from spotty electricity from a hydroelectric dam, there are hardly any public services left. Public salaries go unpaid. Prices have soared.
The only businesses that seem alive are those buying diamonds from diggers coming in from the dense forest that encircles Kisangani. To catch their eye, storefronts have been dressed in garish paint that shouts the names of diamond buyers like Mr. Cash, Jihad the King of Diamonds and Jehovah Ire, run by one Papa Samuel, "in connection with Jesus Christ." One store is painted with an image of Rambo, his machine gun replaced with a shovel.
Inside the diamond shops it is possible to see hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of stones. Shop owners say the diamonds are often flown out of Congo to Rwanda or Uganda, as commanders from those countries reward themselves for their revolutionary efforts.
"What do you think is the reason for this war?" asked a diamond buyer named Papa Ben, who plies his trade in Kisangani. "It's only about the riches of this country."
Only about a third of Congo's annual diamond production is being sold through the country's official market, according to diamond experts in Antwerp. They say the rest is being smuggled away for sale in bordering countries.
By far the biggest diamond prize in the Congo is more than 1,000 miles to the southwest of Kisangani, near the city of Mbuji Mayi. Diamond experts say President Kabila has allocated a substantial percentage of that huge diamond complex to Zimbabwe, which has sent 11,000 troops to prop up Mr. Kabila's wobbly government.
So Zimbabwe has recently become a major diamond exporter, although it has a negligible local industry.
With their eyes on the prize at Mbuji Mayi, large numbers of Congolese rebels and supporting troops from Rwanda began massing about a year ago to the north and east of the city. If they take the diamond mines there, many military experts believe, Zimbabwe would lose its will to fight and Mr. Kabila's government would probably fall.
 
Allying With Smugglers
In Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, the surgeons were frantic. Scores of men, women and children, their hands partly chopped off by machetes, had flooded the main hospital. Amputating as quickly as they could, doctors tossed severed hands into a communal bucket.
The Revolutionary United Front, a rebel outfit that barters diamonds for weapons, was trying early last year to conquer Freetown. Chopping off limbs was their trademark strategy, as it greatly simplified conquest in the diamond fields of eastern Sierra Leone. When word got out that rebels were moving in, tens of thousands of terrified people would take off. The rebels chased half the country's population of 4.5 million out of their homes in the 1990's. Half a million people fled the country.
One day during last year's carnage in Freetown, a diamond trader approached a reporter at the Cape Sierra Hotel. He stuck out his tongue and from beneath it plucked out a stone, which he offered to sell. When the sale did not happen, the trader popped the diamond back in his mouth and moved on.
In fact, most of Sierra Leone's diamonds were -- and still are -- smuggled into neighboring Liberia for sale, according to several human rights groups and diamond industry experts.
The leader of the Sierra Leone rebels, Foday Sankoh, has established a lucrative partnership with his longtime Liberian friend, Charles Taylor, the rebel-boss-turned-president. Both had training in Libya, both their rebellions began in the late 1980's, and their armies have helped each other fight.
Mr. Sankoh's access to the world's diamond bourses and to arms was secured when Mr. Taylor was elected president of Liberia in 1997. The Liberian government denies this trade, as does Mr. Sankoh.
But a number of diplomats, international relief officials and mining experts say there is persuasive evidence. Liberia was a marginal exporter of diamonds until the mid-1990's. Since then it has it exported some 31 million carats -- more than 200 years' worth of its own national capacity, according to trading records in Antwerp.
After Mr. Sankoh failed to take Freetown last year, he signed a peace deal granting his rebels amnesty for war crimes. The deal, which was brokered by the United Nations, also gave him a government job -- chairman of the Strategic Minerals Commission, which controls diamond mining.
 
Making Diamonds Work
Diamonds need not lead to horror. Botswana, the world's largest diamond producer, is one of the most stable and prosperous countries in Africa. The diamond industry there employs nearly a fourth of the country's 1.5 million people and accounts for two-thirds of government income.
De Beers and the government control the industry in a 50-50 partnership, but there is far more to the country's success than corporate paternalism. For starters, the borders of Botswana, unlike the borders of so many countries in Africa, make sense. Inside the borders, there is ethnic and linguistic unity. There is also a long history of democratic decision-making.
Traditional chiefs rarely take action without first consulting ordinary villagers, who are invited to speak freely. It also helped that Botswana gained independence peacefully. The country was so poor that the British decided it was not worth fighting for, so it was never inundated with guns or soldiers.
When De Beers discovered diamonds in Botswana in 1969, the government had been independent for three years, and the men running it were traditional chiefs who owned cattle. They came from a desert culture where people have to scrimp and save to survive the long, dry season.
During three decades, Botswana's leaders have carefully guided what became the world's fastest-growing economy. They invested in roads, schools and clinics. In stark contrast to the rulers of Angola and Congo, they created an African nation devoted to improving the lives of its people. In 1965, only about half of primary school-aged children attended school. Today, 90 percent of that group is enrolled. Life expectancy, which was less than 50 at independence, is now near 70.
Phones work in Botswana, potholes get repaired, garbage gets picked up, and a lively press pokes fun at the government without fear. At $3,600 per year, the gross national product per capita is seven times higher than the average for sub-Saharan Africa. The standard of living is higher than in South Africa, Turkey or Thailand.
"Diamonds are not devils," said Terry Lynn Karl, professor of political science at Stanford and author of "The Paradox of Plenty," (University of California Press, 1997), a book about the poisonous mix of natural resources, big money and thieving elites in developing countries. "What matters is that there be a tradition of good government and compromise in place prior to the exploitation of these resources."
 
Exploiting a Continent
The miseries of modern Africa are, in many ways, a legacy of its history.
In the case of both Angola and Congo, colonialism obliterated whatever political culture may have predated the arrival of Europeans. It invented huge, largely fictive nations -- Angola is the size of Texas, Congo of the United States east of the Mississippi -- roping together people who regarded one other as foreigners. To make their nation-building pay, colonialists used force to haul off everything from ivory to rubber to human beings.
In Congo, the Belgian colonial state was famously greedy and cruel. Its agents set impossible quotas for production of rubber and ivory, killing or chopping off the hands of villagers who failed to meet them. The novelist Joseph Conrad called it "the vilest scramble for loot that ever disfigured the history of human conscience."
In Angola, the Portuguese were less brutal, but no less toxic. At independence in 1975, several hundred thousand Portuguese residents, virtually the entire educated population, abandoned the country. Some took even their doorknobs with them. They left behind a place where almost no Angolans had any training in statecraft, business or agriculture.
Then for the better part of the last 50 years, the cold war and the white-minority governments of southern Africa injected cash and arms into regional wars.
The Central Intelligence Agency, for instance, supported Unita in the early 1970's and again in the late 1980's. The Marxist government of Angola received military assistance from the Soviet Union and up to 50,000 troops from Cuba. When the C.I.A. was not helping Unita, the rebels got military backup from white-ruled South Africa.
Sierra Leone, a small country in West Africa, had a more benign colonial history under British rule. But since the 1940's, predators who smuggle diamonds have warped every aspect of the nation's economic and political life.
The meddling of colonialists, superpowers and white governments all but stopped at the beginning of the 1990's, leaving diamonds, oil and other natural resources as the primary forage for rebels and governments alike.
In those countries where there was nothing to trade for weapons -- as in Mozambique, where post-apartheid South Africa stopped financing rebellion and post-Communist Eastern Europe stopped financing the government -- war simply fizzled out.
But Angola, Congo and Sierra Leone had plenty of diamonds left over to excite greed, fuel war and to buy favors. The United Nations report on the embargo against Unita described how Mr. Savimbi gave a "passport sized" packet of diamonds to the president of Togo, Gnassingbe Eyadema, as payment for allowing his children to live in Togo and go to school there. Togo has denied it.
Mr. Savimbi "sealed" his friendship with the president of Burkina Faso, Blaise Compaore, by giving him a number of envelopes full of diamonds, as well as contributing to his political campaign and helping his government pay debts, according to the report. In return, it said, Burkina Faso sent Mr. Savimbi three flights of diesel fuel. The government of Burkina Faso denies that.
"Oh, the diamonds, diamonds, diamonds," said a character in Graham Greene's "The Heart of the Matter," a 1948 novel set in Sierra Leone. "You cannot understand how many bribes are necessary."
 
Manipulating Scarcity
De Beers created its cartel 110 years ago when the company's founder, Cecil Rhodes, realized that the sheer abundance of diamonds in southern Africa would make them virtually worthless. By carefully manipulating scarcity, De Beers prospered as perhaps the most powerful cartel in the annals of modern commerce.
In the process, however, De Beers has run afoul of antitrust laws in the United States. The company's senior executives dare not enter this country because of an outstanding antitrust indictment that charges De Beers with fixing the prices of industrial diamonds.
The company's grip on the diamond market has slipped a bit from near-total dominance at mid-century, but it has continued to keep the price of gem-quality diamonds high by being both aggressive and flexible. Through the years, it has sponged up periodic floods of diamonds from Russia, Australia and, until recently, across parts of war-ravaged Africa where it does not own all the mines.
Together with the artificial perception of rarity, what makes diamonds profitable to more than 2.5 million miners, traders, cutters and wholesalers around the world -- and what energizes the $50-billion-a-year retail diamond jewelry industry -- is romance.
That, for the most part, is also an invention of De Beers. In 1938, De Beers hired a New York advertising company to convince millions of couples that the larger the diamond on an engagement ring, the greater their love. In the 1960's, a similar campaign in Japan created a diamond engagement ring "tradition."
Diamonds spilling out of Angola's war zone have had a destabilizing effect on the cartel, first by increasing the supply of gem-quality stones and then by tarring the reputation of De Beers as a company that trafficked in blood-stained goods.
To maintain world prices, De Beers bought up a sizable amount of what Unita was selling -- although the company insists that it bought the diamonds on the open market without any direct dealings with the rebels, and that it stopped all buying when the embargo was imposed in 1998.
Global Witness, a London-based human rights group, embarrassed De Beers in October of 1998 with a report that showed -- citing the company's own annual reports -- how the cartel had pumped large amounts of money into the coffers of the rebels as the war escalated.
A year later, De Beers took decisive action. The company declared last October that it would not buy any diamonds that originate in Angola, except from one government-controlled mine.
Some diamond experts said De Beers' announcement, while laudable, came late -- after Unita, having exhausted the easy pickings in Angola's alluvial mines and having lost considerable territory to Angolan government forces, could no longer roil the world market with high-quality stones.
De Beers moved again last month to sanitize the image of the diamonds it sells. As of March 26, the company says it can guarantee that none of its diamonds originate with African rebels, but come instead from its own mines in South African, Botswana or Namibia, or are bought from mines in Russia or Australia.
Human rights organizations have welcomed De Beers' moves and praise the company for taking steps they say the entire diamond industry should follow. Rebel-mined diamonds, though, can still find their way out of Africa. About a third of diamonds imported into the United States are purchased from traders who are not employed by De Beers and are not bound by its new rules.
 
Tracing the Stones
Near Antwerp's train station, police barricades seal off three narrow streets. In warren-like rooms above the streets, men hunch over precision turntables, grinding rough diamonds to coax forth shapes and colors that lure wholesaler jewelers to Belgium from around the globe.
Eight out of 10 of the world's rough diamonds -- about 125 million carats a year -- pass through Antwerp's Diamond Center. But exactly which of those stones come from war zones in Africa is something Antwerp's experts say they find hard to tell.
Michael Vaughan, managing director of the Diamantkring, one of the four exchanges in Antwerp, said that his business depended on trust, and that if diamonds have been smuggled by African rebels and re-packaged elsewhere, "we don't know about it."
Many diamond traders in Antwerp do not particularly want to know where the stones come from. A recent United Nations report complained of "extremely lax regulations" at the world's largest diamond bourse in Antwerp. A Canadian human rights group, Partnership Africa Canada, calls Antwerp "a diamond smuggler's dream."
Belgium has objected, saying the report ignores major moves in January to set up tougher customs inspections and a new certification system with Angola.
But it is not just Belgium. According to the United Nations report, Antwerp is flooded with diamonds exported from countries passing off smuggled diamonds as their own, complete with false, but official, certificates of origin. The experts say those countries include Liberia, Uganda, Rwanda and Zimbabwe.
One way to keep rebel-mined diamonds off the world market would be to impose a diamond embargo on African countries known to be exporting smuggled stones. Thus far, though, there is little enthusiasm in the United Nations for such a move. "It is tough enough in Angola, believe me," Mr. Fowler said.
Human rights groups and some members of Congress are also calling for a mandatory diamond-labeling system. One proposal calls for a worldwide ban on sales unless diamonds have verifiable documents proving country of origin. A bill introduced in Congress last year would require similar documentation for diamonds sold in the United States.
Representative Tony P. Hall, an Ohio Democrat, and Representative Frank R. Wolf, a Virginia Republican, introduced the bill after seeing the horrors of war in Sierra Leone. "The world looked the other way in Angola for most of the 1990's, while revenues from diamond sales were used to butcher innocent civilians," he said. "We should not stand by as the same thing happens in Sierra Leone and Congo. We should do whatever it takes to cut off the flow of money."
The diamond industry in the United States objects to the proposals.
"There is no way to tell where a diamond comes from," said Eli Haas, president of the Diamond Dealers Club of New York. "Diamonds don't have identifying marks and probably never will. You just can't look at a diamond and say, yes, it comes from Sierra Leone."
That may be changing. De Beers says that it is "actively pursuing" a diamond fingerprinting technology being developed by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police at a forensic laboratory in Ottawa.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1068 words

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY;
A Ford Vice President Has a European Touch

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich.

 BODY:
FORD'S old advertising slogan may need some updating, to wit: Have you driven a Parry-Jones lately?
You have if you've been at the wheel of the Ford Focus or the Lincoln LS in North America or the Ford Puma or Ka in Europe.
 These cars bear the stamp of a single engineer -- Richard Parry-Jones, the Ford Motor Company's group vice president in charge of product development and quality -- as few modern models do. Nowadays, vehicle-development decisions are generally made in committee and executed by teams. 
 Mr. Parry-Jones's involvement goes far deeper, and he may come to be identified with particular models in the way that Lee A. Iacocca is known as the father of the Mustang; as Harley Earl, the legendary General Motors designer, is associated with the flamboyant, big-finned 1959 Cadillac; and as John Z. DeLorean gained fame for creating the Pontiac GTO.
Mr. Parry-Jones is Ford's guru of driving dynamics -- generally considered the way a car feels on the road, plus the feedback it sends back to the driver. While not as eye-catching as tailfins, his signature touch is immediately evident upon taking the driver's seat. Mr. Parry-Jones, a 49-year-old Welshman, has made it his mission to develop a distinctive trademark for the driving experience of each Ford, from the tiny Ka city car to elegant Jaguars -- and now, even to rugged yet luxurious off-road vehicles from Land Rover, which Ford has agreed to buy.
"The refined driving experience is not the thing in the showroom that's going to get people to buy the car," Mr. Parry-Jones said as he steered a 2000-model Focus around the company's test track in Dearborn. "But it's the thing that the customer will discover on the test drive or after the purchase that confirms the purchase decision. It's what bonds the driver to the car after they buy it."
Mr. Parry-Jones oversees Ford's three global vehicle-development centers: the large and luxury car group, which includes Aston Martin, Jaguar, Lincoln and Volvo automobiles; the truck group; and the small and medium group. Mr. Parry-Jones headed the small and medium group, based in England, before he was promoted to his current position in January 1998. That group helped develop the tiny Ka and the Puma, a small, sporty car with racecar-quick steering, for Europe, and the Ford Focus for international markets, including the United States.
 When Mr. Parry-Jones arrived for his new job at Ford's world headquarters here, he immediately jumped into the product development program for the S-Type, a new, smaller Jaguar, and the LS, a midsize sedan that was intended to be Lincoln's first true competitor against Germany's BMW and Mercedes-Benz.
Mr. Parry-Jones, dissatisfied with the driving dynamics of the two cars, sent engineers back to work for fine-tuning that ultimately delayed the introduction of the LS slightly.
"The lessons we learned in Europe with small cars helped me bring those vehicles into sharper focus," Mr. Parry-Jones said.
The LS went on sale last spring and received rave reviews, with particular note of its European driving characteristics -- a marked contrast to the soft and floaty Lincolns of recent years. It received a number of automotive awards, including Motor Trend's 2000 Car of the Year. It has sold briskly, as has the Jaguar S-Type, with which it shares its underbody, its engines and many other mechanical components.
Even more surprising to many automotive enthusiasts, however, has been the performance of the much smaller and far less expensive Ford Focus, which starts at $12,280. In a market segment where manufacturers have historically treated their small cars as appliances, providing bare-bones transportation from Point A to Point B, the Focus stands alone in offering responsive handling and steering that rivals that of many larger, pricier cars.
Automotive journalists have voted the Focus car of the year for both Europe and North America. And, most recently, it won a similar recognition in Canada, making it the first car ever to win that triple crown. Buyers seem to agree: Sales of the Focus are soaring.
"A car's got to feel alive, responsive, quick to react to your desires and inputs," said Mr. Parry-Jones. "These qualities do not just appeal to enthusiasts. They make driving more fun for everyone."
Mr. Parry-Jones contends that a refined driving experience also improves the vehicle's ride comfort, stability and safety. But that doesn't mean every Ford will feel the same.
Instead, the driving dynamics of each car or truck must fit with the character of the brand. A Jaguar is tuned to deliver a velvety ride, silky-smooth power and steady steering, whereas the tiny race-car like Puma "changes direction at the blink of an eye."
Creating that driving experience is a blend of art and science, he explained as he wheeled the Focus around the test track, first at about 25 miles per hour, a speed at which he says he can read everything about the car, then gradually accelerating.
Mr. Parry-Jones spends a large chunk of his time behind the wheel; he logs about 30,000 miles a year evaluating vehicles in the United States, Europe and Japan. A former rally driver, he attended his first race at age 10 and honed his driving skills thrashing a Mini 850 on the roads of his homeland, before joining Ford as an apprentice at age 18. The legendary race car driver Jackie Stewart, who is a consultant for Ford, has been Mr. Parry-Jones's most important mentor.
"My rallying days really gave me an intuitive sense as to how a vehicle performs," said Mr. Parry-Jones. "Rallying teaches you how a car responds when you turn the wheel and how it responds when you push the accelerator."
Before he slides behind the wheel, however, Mr. Parry-Jones pores over piles of statistical information that shows how each car and truck under development is meeting its targets for driving performance, targets that are as stringent for a Jaguar as they are for a Focus, but specific to the brand the vehicle represents.
Then he hops into the car and takes a spin around the test track to see if the scientific data match what he feels. His goal is to build a library of knowledge that can be passed on from one generation of engineers and vehicles to the next.
"Imagine if you could deliver a vehicle that is reliable and refined but also is fun to drive and has a soul," he said. "What's wrong with that?"

PUB-DATE: April 7, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 35; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 2964 words

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION;
Buttressing an Old City With New Artistic Girders

BYLINE: By PAULA DEITZ 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
Like the fantasy pleasure dome of Xanadu, the term movie palace conjures up a magical image: a romantic time when the film world was bursting with technological advances, complemented by live entertainment. In downtown Pittsburgh alone, there were once eight such extravaganzas within a few blocks' radius, and in their heyday, the 1920's and 30's, people flocked to the cinema and to vaudeville acts in an atmosphere that dripped with gilded plaster and crystal chandeliers.
Fast forward 30 years. Pittsburgh was in a financial slump. But the Pittsburgh Symphony, thriving nonetheless, required a new home beyond the Syria Mosque. Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill was hired to design a new home, but, to the city's eventual good fortune, the effort stalled. Then in 1967 Henry John Heinz II, who had recently retired as chairman of the H. J. Heinz Company, made a momentous visit to the once-lavish Loews Penn Theater, accompanied by the president of the symphony. With a grant from the Howard Heinz Endowment, the symphony bought the property and the rest is legend: Heinz Hall for the Performing Arts opened in 1971, with its plush three-story-high domed lobby and an arcade of Corinthian columns with gilded capitals. 
 This became the turning point and the gold standard for an imaginative urban renaissance based on Heinz's theory that the arts lead the way to economic development. Rather than destroying an old neighborhood to build a congested performing arts center, Pittsburgh opted to create a performing arts district: many of its cultural institutions are housed in the restored regal surroundings of its surviving movie palaces, scattered through a 14-square-block area that had been a red-light district. It is now called the Pittsburgh Cultural District and is overseen by the 16-year-old Pittsburgh Cultural Trust.
On a recent rain-slicked Saturday night at curtain time, the streets were bustling with theatergoers coming from parking lots dispersed sensibly through the area or from neighborhood restaurants. The thrill is enhanced by the great marquee of the Benedum Center for the Performing Arts, the former Stanley Theater, where the chaser lights are miraculously intact.
On a side facade of the center, flashing lights still announce "Stanley's Photoplays." Inside, the immense barrel-vaulted lobby and performance hall have been restored to their original palette of Etruscan colors, with decorative plasterwork burnished with aluminum-foil gilt. Relighted with chandeliers, the entire space glows with a festive air that inspires the audience to dress up for the occasion, on this evening a performance of Massenet's opera "Werther" by the Pittsburgh Opera under the artistic direction of Tito Capobianco.
The cultural district here, which includes new public squares and parkland on the Allegheny River, reflects a general mood in Pittsburgh. As the largest inland port in America (the Delta Queen calls about twice a year), it is a true early gateway to the West. At the majestic confluence of the Allegheny, Monongahela and Ohio Rivers, the city encompasses 40 miles of riverfront and more than 2,000 bridges, representing almost every style of engineering.
While this city boasts old, established cultural institutions like the Carnegie Museums of Art and Natural History and obligatory skyscrapers like the 1984 neo-Gothic spires in reflective glass for PPG Place by Philip Johnson and John Burgee, there is a new vivacity that accompanies the emerging biomedical and computer science industries spurred by the research units of its major universities.
 
New Life for Old Buildings
One could say that Pittsburgh's fighting spirit in the face of its loss of the steel industry comes from its namesake, William Pitt, who as prime minister of Britain in the 1750's gave the colonists the wherewithal to do proper battle against the French. After his forces captured Fort Duquesne in 1758, one of Gen. John Forbes's last acts was to name their conquest after Pitt, whose spirit had made them, he said, "masters of the place." This story is inscribed on a plaque outside H. H. Richardson's celebrated Allegheny County Courthouse and Jail, two massive turreted piles of rusticated stone linked across a city street by a Bridge of Sighs providing secure passage for prisoners.
Though Pittsburgh's steel industry died, none of its other important elements did; the city survived, unlike others caught up in a similar economic downturn. To prove it, three department stores still do a thriving business downtown. But there is a lot of vacant real estate, and the trick has been to renovate and incorporate the empty structures there into the texture of urban life in a "practical, affordable, useful and beautiful" way, said Teresa Heinz, who has carried on the family's philanthropic interests since the death of her husband Senator John Heinz III.
The cultural trust's consortium, for example, includes two other theaters in addition to Heinz Hall and the Benedum, with at least 1,200 events a year taking place in the district. The opera shares the Benedum with the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, the Civic Light Opera, visiting dance companies and touring Broadway shows. Now in its 61st season, the opera company has been staging four operas a year. Next year, a fifth, "Therese Raquin," by the American composer Tobias Picker and commissioned in a joint production with the Dallas and Montreal Operas, will be staged at the nearby 1,329-seat Byham Theater, a renovated vaudeville hall the size of smaller European opera houses.
For a site down the street from the Benedum, on the footprint of a vaudeville house demolished after sustaining damage in a 1936 flood, the cultural trust commissioned Michael Graves to design the only new theater in the district. The O'Reilly Theater, now the home of the Pittsburgh Public Theater, has all the charm of Mr. Graves's own drawings of squat classical stone pavilions in rustic landscapes.
 
A Bright Night Life
There is also a whiff of Alvar Aalto in the side view of red brick and blue tile walls. The theater's porous semicircular glass facade is an inviting presence on the streetscape, making it an easy stop for buying tickets. At night the second-level foyer, capped by a barrel-vaulted roof, offers lively views of theater crowds. Behind the foyer's long bar hangs one of Mr. Graves's murals of pavilions in the Italian countryside. Playing at the O'Reilly on a recent weekend was Conor McPherson's peripatetic play "The Weir," with some Irish cast members who lent authenticity to the mystery. The O'Reilly's thrust stage, though close to the audience, is always an island of space unto itself, thus maintaining the theatrical illusion.
The show does not stop in Pittsburgh when the performances end, as a walk in the neighborhood proves. At the central intersection of Penn Avenue and Seventh Street, two squares face each other with public sculptures that exert an especially powerful force after dark. In a fresh interpretation of the civic fountain, the artist Louise Bourgeois fashioned for the Agnes R. Katz Plaza a 25-foot-high spiral mountain of bronze with water rushing down its troughs, which are illuminated fiber-optically with a bluish light.
Seen against the lights of Pittsburgh's skyline, this glowing mound has become a strong nocturnal image, particularly in its park setting of clipped linden trees designed by Dan Kiley. By collaborating, the sculptor and landscape architect have produced a winning urban plaza.
Across the street, the Russian artist Aleksandr Brodsky constructed a different sort of mound, a vast pyramid of Beaux-Arts terra-cotta ornaments from buildings that had been demolished in the district. Long buried in a ditch, the pieces were retrieved and inventoried before the artist carefully piled the cornices, columns and rosettes into a kind of memorial to vanished architecture. "Palazzo Nudo" he calls it.
Set behind a chain-link fence and a cage of metal scaffolding with hanging industrial lights, this elegant scrap pile glistens with new life on a rainy night. While many buildings were destroyed, the streets are now lined with others that were once marred by false fronts but now reveal their original facades intact.
Night lighting is a major ingredient in animating the cultural district and is the basis of another ingenious collaboration, this one between the artist-designer Robert Wilson and the architect Richard Gluckman. In addition to the main avenues and cross streets, the district is filled with back alleys and blank walls next to empty lots where buildings once stood. Lightwalls for beauty and safety were the answer rather than ugly, income-producing billboards.
"Light will be an object and light will be space" and "light will be static and light will be dynamic" are how the team describes a phenomenon that it expects will enliven the neighborhood and in time, no doubt, cities everywhere. While reviving the movie palaces builds on the past, the lightwalls will be one of the trust's contributions to the future.
The first one has been installed on a wall next to a parking lot near the Benedum: an eerie wash of pale light with a horizontal band of the faintest mauve moving slowly down the side of the building. It transforms a drab wall into a theater set.
True to form, people are beginning to move into this loft district (along with one dry cleaner and a florist), and its seven art galleries are a draw during the day, as are the exhibitions at the trust's own Wood Street Galleries. And the adjoining neighborhood, called the Strip and home to Pittsburgh's wholesale food markets, is a lively mecca of shops and restaurants, particularly on Saturday mornings.
Embracing the Rivers
As part of its city planning, the cultural trust has also taken the lead in opening up the adjacent riverfront area: Pittsburgh, like many major river cities, had turned its back on its greatest resource. A 1911 Olmsted Brothers' concept for a narrow collar of parks along the Allegheny and Monongahela that joined where the two met the Ohio at Point State Park had lain dormant until it served as inspiration to another team commissioned by the trust, this time to design Allegheny Riverfront Park at the edge of the cultural district.
A match was made between the landscape artist Michael Van Valkenburgh and the artist Ann Hamilton, who represented the United States last year at the Venice Biennale. A 4,000-foot-long, 35-foot-wide esplanade runs under the three Sister Bridges; it is approached from the street by long ramps with an undulating bronze handrail that connotes thin tree trunks with the smoothness of an arm. High vine screens for Virginia creeper create a vertical wall from the street above, where a second phase of the park will eventually be planted with plane trees.
To border the promenade below Mr. Van Valkenburgh has planted a crush of native flood plain trees and rugged plants, expecting that they will not all survive the periodic flooding and winter ice floes, and interspersed among them boulders collected from the area that give the plantings a Japanese quality and also serve as convenient seating.
When the cement was poured for the walkway along the water, Ms. Hamilton devised a method to lay dry reeds into the wet cement so that the promenade has a bulrush pattern that looks like a fossil from the original shoreline. The rough surface favors walkers over in-line skaters and skateboarders.
Across the Allegheny on Pittsburgh's North Side, art is also acatalyst for redevelopment, as is already well known from the museum dedicated to Pittsburgh's native son Andy Warhol. The story of the sculptor Barbara Luderowski and the founding of the Mattress Factory in 1977 as a museum of installation art on Sampsonia Way is another example of the city's cultural draw.
When Ms. Luderowski stopped in Pittsburgh in the early 1970's, on the way to show her work in New York, she was driven around the narrow streets of town houses on the North Side and fell in love with the neighborhood. She never got to New York. Instead she returned to Michigan, sold her house there and moved to Pittsburgh, where she eventually purchased the old mattress factory that is an ideal architectural framework for conveying the imaginary worlds of installation art. Later she bought a house and a storefront on adjoining streets to expand the museum.
A Community of Artists
The title of the current exhibition, "Installations by Asian Artists in Residence," also explains the museum's method, devised by Ms. Luderowski as the artistic director and by the curator, Michael Olijnyk. The artists live at the Mattress Factory as a community while they build their art.
In constructing his phantom house of cast paraffin wax that fills an entire gallery, the Japanese artist Goro Hirata based his design on a traditional Japanese house with shoji screens. Because the material is translucent, natural light from the windows glows through the walls and shifts during the day. Sora Kim, from Seoul, South Korea, filled another gallery with a product called D-Gravitzer, along with its marketing campaign that proves how being relieved of gravity allows the user to clean ceilings and difficult corners.
Two of James Turrell's disquieting room installations dealing with the perception of light are among the permanent exhibits, as is Jene Highstein's "Bed-Sitting Rooms for Artist in Residence," in which two beds slide back and forth between slots in the wall, depending on the number of occupants in a room.
Even the garden, designed by Winifred Lutz, is installation art. In a brilliant stroke, she created an archaeological site by excavating the basement of a burned-out factory next door, uncovering several levels reached by steps with twisted iron handrails. Planted with grasses and wildflowers, it could be a site from ancient Rome.
 
Cultural Footings
 Pittsburgh is about 365 miles southwest of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
 
Theaters

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Drop in Price As Equities Draw Money

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices declined yesterday as some investors took advantage of rebounding stocks to shift back out of the fixed-income market. 
 The price of the 30-year bond declined 3/32, to 106 19/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 5.79 percent from 5.78 percent on Wednesday. The two-year note, which has experienced a plunge in yield recently as investors moved away from volatile stocks, fell 5/32 in price, to 100 7/32. Its yield rose to 6.38 percent from 6.30 percent, still giving the highest return among various Treasuries.
William McDonough, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, said in a speech to the New York State Banker's Association that inflation was all but dormant in the face of strong economic growth but that the very prosperity that growth generates could expose the economy to risks. Traders said his comments had little effect ahead of the important employment report due today.
The nonfarm payroll data for March is expected to confirm that the the labor market is very tight, possibly reignitinge investor fears that the Fed could become more aggressive in raising short-term rates to keep inflation under control.
Economists polled by Reuters are forecasting that payrolls grew 376,000 and that hourly earnings increased 0.3 percent. The tightness in the labor market is likely to be underscored by a decline in the unemployment rate to 4 percent, from 4.1 percent in February.
Rick MacDonald, an economist with Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, thinks the focus will be on wages and unemployment because the payroll number will probably have two distortions for March: a lift from hiring for government census workers and an extra week because of the leap year. So the data for five weeks is condensed into a month normally reporting four weeks.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Advances in Biotechnology And Retail Sales Spur Rally

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, buoyed in part by news that March store sales at some major retailers were on the high end of expectations.
The rally was also fueled by a jump in biotechnology stocks after the Celera Genomics Group said it completed sequencing the genes of one person. 
 Additionally, investor confidence was upbeat after Alcoa, the aluminum producer, posted earnings that beat Wall Street's estimates.
"For the first time in a week we have solid bids in the market in the growth sectors," said Barry Hyman of Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 80.35 points, or 0.73 percent, to 11,114.27, while the Nasdaq composite index jumped 98.34 points, or 2.36 percent, to 4,267.56. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.97 points, to 1,501.34.
Wal-Mart Stores said sales in stores opened at least a year rose 3.6 percent in March, surpassing analysts' expectations. Its shares gained 2 3/4, to 61 1/8, while those of Home Depot added 3 3/16, to 66 1/4.
Alcoa, whose first-quarter earnings of 95 cents a share beat consensus estimates by 4 cents, gained 1 3/4, to 70 15/16.
The Nasdaq biotechnology index, which includes over 200 United States and European companies, rose 4.89 percent after Celera's announcement of its advance, which could eventually transform medicine and biology. Celera rose 27, to 140.
The next step for Celera is to assemble the sequenced fragments into their proper order to create a genetic map, the basic blueprint of life. With this map, scientists can learn more about genes involved in disease, how medicines work and the workings of basic human biology.
The gain for the biotech index comes on top of a 6.31 percent rise on Wednesday after President Clinton reassured the industry that gene discoveries could be patented.
Other advancing biotechnology stocks included Millennium Pharmaceuticals, which was up 30 17/64, to 173 5/8, and Incyte Pharmaceuticals, up 13 7/8, to 108 1/2.
During the day, the market's gains were pared as investors turned their focus to the United States employment data due out today, which could give hints of the extent of future interest rate increases.
"We're just running out of gas, and with the uncertainty ahead of tomorrow's numbers, I think people are just evening out their blotters and taking home some profits," said Bryan Piskorowski, market analyst at Prudential Securities.
The government will release March jobs data today at 8:30 a.m. Economists in a Reuters survey estimated payrolls rose by 376,000 in March after a softer-than-expected 43,000 in February.
But investors were generally encouraged by the market's early glimpse of first-quarter earnings, analysts said.
"As we get further into earnings, we'll see the fundamentals remain powerful and that will calm unsettled investor nerves," said Thomas Galvin of Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reduces Forecast For Gasoline Prices

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 6

 BODY:
The Energy Department said today that gasoline would cost a good deal less this summer than what had been forecast just a month ago, though the typical household was still expected to spend $170 more to fuel up the family car than last summer.
Prices should peak this month at $1.52 a gallon for regular unleaded gasoline, roughly what it averaged in March, before falling to $1.39 by September. The average for the summer should be $1.46, according to the Energy Information Administration, the statistical agency for the department. 
 That may offer little relief to drivers, who can still expect to pay about 25 percent more this summer than last year. But the outlook is far better than last month's, when forecasters predicted average prices of $1.56 for the summer, with peak months reaching $1.80.
The new forecast, though, carries an important caveat; the agency said that to meet the projection, the nation's refineries would have to operate at close to capacity.
Any major disruptions, which might include hurricanes, explosions and extended maintenance shutdowns, could cause prices to spike above the new predictions. The agency noted that refinery problems early last year in California contributed to a spring jump in gasoline prices there at a time when oil prices were far lower than they are now.
The agency also predicted that the price of imported crude oil delivered to domestic refiners, which averaged $26.75 a barrel in February and March, would drop to $23.50 by the end of this year, and to $21.50 by the end of 2001.
The lowered forecast may take some steam out of efforts in Congress to suspend 4.3 cents of the 18.4 cents-a-gallon federal gasoline tax. That proposal, by Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, has not come to a vote. But in a nonbinding resolution today, senators signaled in a 66-to-34 vote that they lean against lowering the tax.
The government's sharply revised forecast was attributable to the decision last week by OPEC member nations to raise their oil output, said Dave Costello, an economist at the agency, and to the market's surprisingly strong reaction to the increase.
The cartel's production increase "wasn't that much different from what we had kind of been assuming," Mr. Costello said. But crude prices fell by perhaps $1 a barrel more than what had been anticipated.
The new forecast "doesn't mean that all concerns are out the window or anything like that," he said. "It means the situation has brightened up a little bit."
Gasoline supplies have been helped, Mr. Costello added, because with falling oil prices, refiners have enjoyed a wider spread between what they pay for oil and the price they can sell gasoline, in contrast to thin margins earlier this year.
Also, he said, wholesale gasoline prices have dropped lately, in part because of recent upward revisions in estimates of the nation's gasoline inventories.
The revised estimates suggest that stocks of gasoline, while still quite low, have not fallen to the severe levels previously anticipated.
Kevin J. Lindemer, a senior director at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass., said that the government's assumption that domestic refineries can run at 96.8 percent of capacity this summer is attainable, barring major disruptions.
He also attributed part of the recent decline in prices, and the hope for further declines, to psychological factors. "We've taken the heat out of the market," Mr. Lindemer said.
Although the new forecast still predicts the highest summer gasoline prices ever, the agency noted that the situation is not as severe when inflation-adjusted numbers are used. The average 1981 summer price of $1.35 per gallon, for example, translates to $2.52 today.
That is not much solace, though, to motorists paying extra to fuel their car. Lauren Merritt, a senior at Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts in Dallas, said she spends at least $30 a week on gasoline commuting from Kaufman County, Tex.
If they materialize, Ms. Merritt said, lower prices will help a bit. But prices will remain high, crimping her efforts to save for college. "I can't spend as much as I want to on other things because I have to budget for gas," she said.

HEADLINE: Most Nations Fail to Supply Safe Blood, W.H.O. Finds

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 6

 BODY:
More than two-thirds of the world's nations are failing to supply safe blood to their populations, according to the World Health Organization. Their failure adds significantly to the spread of the virus that causes AIDS, as well as potentially deadly forms of hepatitis and other diseases.
The countries where people are most at risk are the poorest and often are those where diseases are spreading fastest, the group found in a survey. These countries contain 80 percent of the world's population, or about 4.8 billion people. 
 On Friday, the World Health Organization, in cooperation with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, begins a campaign to improve the safety of blood around the world.
Poor countries face obvious cost problems in making the blood supply safe. But that is not the only cause of the failure, experts say.
Poor social policies with a low priority on public health programs contribute to the problem, as does inadequate testing. Hospital equipment may be contaminated and sometimes reused, and blood may be stored improperly.
Most important may be the ubiquitous third world practice of buying blood. "Paid donors, it has been demonstrated many, many times, are at much higher risk of being infected," said Dr. David Brandling-Bennett, deputy director of the Pan American Health Organization in Washington. "That, of course, means that even if you do good testing, you have a higher risk of missing somebody."
Dr. Brandling-Bennett said in an interview that travelers who visit developing countries on business usually do not need to fear blood contamination if they avoid risky behavior and, in emergencies, go only to hospitals approved by American embassies or consulates. In the United States, immigrant populations need to have explained to them the importance of full disclosure when people give blood, he said. Blood is no longer bought in the United States.
The Western Hemisphere, said Dr. Jose Ramiro Cruz, the Pan American Health Organization's adviser on laboratory and blood safety, is the world's safest in the handling of blood. "Data collected in the last five years from every single country in Latin America and the Caribbean shows that the position has improved dramatically," he said in an interview. Other regions are not so lucky, the World Heath Organization says. It estimates that tens of thousands of people pick up the virus that causes AIDS and millions are infected annually with hepatitis B and C, which can lead to liver failure or liver cancer. South Asia, particularly India, and Africa are special concerns.
Dr. Kevin Cahill, an expert on tropical diseases in New York, and the president of the independent Center for International Health and Cooperation, said that economics and attitudes both play a part.
"When you deal with many countries where the total health expenditure per capita is in the range of $15 a year, as in some African countries, the thought that you can spend that amount typing and cross-matching blood -- it's a fantasy," he said.
"Not just blood-banking is a low priority; health is a low priority in most developing countries," Dr. Cahill said. "Health and humanitarian issues should be central in foreign policies, not peripheral issues."
Women of childbearing age are among the most vulnerable people in the developing world, experts say. Corinne Whitaker, senior program officer for Africa at the International Women's Health Coalition in New York, said this was especially true in societies where women bear children young and often. They are frequently anemic and their small size makes them prone to injuries in childbirth.
"Getting access to any blood is a challenge in much of Africa," Ms. Whitaker said in an interview. "That's further complicated by the issue of screening for safe blood."
Problems with the blood supply have not been limited to developing nations. Over the last decade court cases have demonstrated to what extent early warnings about the virus that causes AIDS were ignored in the United States, France, Germany, Switzerland and other countries, with the result that thousands of hemophiliacs and others in need of blood may have been infected.
