HEADLINE: Ford to Sell Gasoline-Electric Vehicle in 2003

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Apr. 6

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would begin selling a small sport utility vehicle in 2003 using both gasoline and electric propulsion for better gas mileage. General Motors and DaimlerChrysler are working on similar sport utilities.
The Ford Escape, which is a little smaller than a Ford Explorer and a little larger than a Honda CR-V, will go on sale this autumn with only gasoline engines available. The optional hybrid engine will be offered on Escapes built three years later at a slightly higher price, Ford said. 
 Because the Escape has a carlike underbody, instead of the heavy, pickup-truck-like underbody of Ford's other sport utilities, it gets 23 miles to the gallon in the city and 28 miles to the gallon on the highway with a four-cylinder gasoline engine. Ford said that equipping the vehicle with the hybrid engine would increase its fuel efficiency to almost 40 miles a gallon in the city and on the highway.
In the hybrid models, the gasoline engine and the vehicle's own braking will charge the electric motor, which will not require separate charging. In the Escape and other hybrid automobiles, the gasoline engine shuts off when the vehicle stops; once the driver touches the accelerator, an electric motor powered by batteries gets the vehicle moving again while the gasoline engine turns back on.
Honda has just started selling the Honda Insight, a tiny coupe with a gasoline-electric engine that gets up to 70 miles per gallon on the highway. This summer Toyota will start selling its Prius, a hybrid that is similar to a Toyota Corolla but which gets about 50 miles per gallon.
Ford officials said that they had been working on hybrid technology for years and that their timetable had not been affected by the Japanese offerings or the recent rise in gasoline prices.
DaimlerChrysler introduced a prototype of a hybrid Dodge Durango last autumn that would, the company said, get an average of 18.6 miles per gallon in city and highway driving, compared with 15.5 miles per gallon for the current model with a gasoline-only engine. G.M. has been collaborating with Toyota to develop a car-based sport utility vehicle the size of a Subaru Forester that would also carry a hybrid engine. G.M. and DaimlerChrysler have not yet announced plans for mass production.
Top executives from G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler joined Vice President Al Gore at a news conference in Washington last week on improving fuel economy. William Powers, Ford's vice president for research, said in an interview that the company did not mention its plans in Washington because "we had agreed months ago with our partners we wouldn't upstage each other." A Gore aide said that was true.
Mr. Gore has long sought tighter fuel-economy regulations. The industry supports President Clinton's recent proposal for a $3,000 tax credit for electric and hybrid propulsion automobiles, which would roughly offset for consumers the extra cost of the hybrid engine.
The hybrid Ford Escape will be built on the same assembly line in Claycomo, Mo., that will build the regular Ford Escape, Ford said. The hybrid will use many components from Visteon Automotive Systems, a giant auto parts subsidiary that Ford's board is expected to spin off at its board meeting next Thursday, probably by ordering that Visteon shares be distributed to Ford shareholders.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Goliath of the Hog World;
Fast Rise of Smithfield Foods Makes Regulators Wary

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: TAR HEEL, N.C.

 BODY:
In the coastal plains here, where tobacco once ruled, sit hundreds of corporate hog farms, punctuated by giant lagoons filled with manure. And just off Route 87, not far from the Cape Fear River, is the world's largest meatpacking plant, a structure so colossal that its waste-water treatment plant could serve a midsize city.
The farms and the plant, which can kill seven million hogs a year, belong to Smithfield Foods, the world's largest hog producer and pork processor -- and the company at the center of a fierce debate over the rise of big agriculture. 
 By aggressively acquiring its larger rivals over the last two years and using precision genetics, huge hog farms and giant meatpacking plants to control every stage of production, Smithfield has ballooned into a $5 billion company that accounts for more than a fifth of the nation's pork.
But in doing so, it has come under intense scrutiny from regulators who say that agricultural giants may wield too much control over the food supply.
After Smithfield announced in September that it would acquire Murphy Family Farms, the giant hog producer, the Agriculture Department called the company "absurdly big," and asked the Justice Department's antitrust division to review the deal. More recently, the attorney general in Iowa, a big pork producing state, challenged the merger in state court, arguing that Smithfield is trying to skirt a state law that forbids a meatpacking company to operate hog farms.
There are also growing concerns that the company's hog waste could pose dangers to local water supplies, and that giant hog operations could cripple small farmers.
"All of a sudden we have this 800-pound gorilla in the pork industry," said Betsy Freese, the livestock editor at Successful Farming magazine in Des Moines. "The troubling part for a lot of farmers is if the packer owns production, where are you going to sell your pigs?"
For their part, Smithfield executives say the company has been unfairly maligned and has been a pioneer in developing a more systematic approach and healthier meat.
"What we did in the pork industry is what Perdue and Tyson did in the poultry business," said Joseph W. Luter III, chairman and chief executive of Smithfield, which is based in Smithfield, Va. "Vertical integration gives you high quality, consistent products with consistent genetics. And the only way to do that is to control the process from the farm to the packing plant."
Smithfield is also adapting to a trend that began in the Southeast -- creating factory-size hog farms by using contract farmers, who put up the capital to build special barns and provide the labor to raise pigs to company specifications.
No longer is the market scattered among thousands of small Midwestern farmers, who raise hogs and sell them to meatpackers. Four companies now account for nearly 20 percent of the nation's hog supply, and four big meatpackers slaughter about 60 percent of the nation's pork.
Agriculture, some experts say, is merely mimicking the larger economy. "This is what has evolved out of the marketplace," said John Lawrence, an agricultural economist at Iowa State University in Ames.
In Smithfield's "birth to bacon" approach, everything is calculated: genetics, artificial insemination, barns with automated feeding systems and computers that monitor temperature and ventilation. A special feed, executives say, creates pork as lean as chicken in a brand the company is taking national: Smithfield's Lean Generation Pork.
Smithfield's giant meatpacking factory, a 973,000-square-foot plant here in Tar Heel, about 20 miles southeast of Fayetteville, relies on a "disassembly line," which has its roots in the 19th century, although the system is aided by new technologies, like laser-equipped cutting machines.
In many ways, the Tar Heel plant -- which can process up to 32,000 hogs a day -- is an efficient killing machine. Squealing hogs funnel into an area where they are electrocuted, stabbed in the jugular, then tied, lifted and carried on a winding journey through the plant. They are dunked in scalding water, their hair is removed, they are run through a fiery furnace (to burn off residual hair), then disemboweled and sliced by an army of young, often immigrant, laborers.
On the other side of the plant, which is chilled, teams of workers cut hog meat into smaller pieces. Wearing frocks, rubber boots and earplugs, they stand shoulder to shoulder, dipping knives in hot water and then making quick cuts in meat passing rapidly on a conveyor belt.
Together, Smithfield's five plants can handle up to 19 million hogs a year, turning out more than five billion pounds of pork.
Mr. Luter, a tart-tongued 60-year-old Virginian who runs the company from his Park Avenue apartment in New York City and his home in Aspen, Colo., took over a small meatpacking company his father founded in 1936 and made it into one of the world's largest food companies.
Believing that the big profits were in raising and processing hogs, Smithfield joined forces with three North Carolina producers to form Circle Four Farms. The four companies, which pioneered the use of giant confinement barns that can hold up to 2,600 pigs, agreed to use similar genetics and feed and send all hogs to Smithfield packing plants.
The alliance has moved into Western states but has had less impact in the Midwest because of laws opposing corporate farming. As a result, hog production has boomed in the South and West but is in sharp decline in the Midwest. Chicago is no longer "hog butcher to the world." And Iowa, despite its plentiful grain, is about to lose to North Carolina its title as the biggest hog state.
"Most of our farmers are doing pigs because they were looking for an alternative to tobacco," said Walter Cherry, executive director of the North Carolina Pork Council, in Raleigh. "Twenty-five years ago, we just didn't have pigs. Now, we're doing $2 billion in pigs."
In recent years, Smithfield has acquired most of its Circle Four partners, including the nation's two largest hog producers, Carroll's Foods and Murphy Family Farms. It also bought Schneider, Canada's largest processor, and North Side Foods, maker of McDonald's breakfast sausages. And Smithfield said in March that it would acquire a big Iowa processing plant from Farmland Industries, a huge cooperative.
Ranked as the nation's No. 7 pork producer in 1997, Smithfield is now No. 1; it is also the biggest hog raiser. It sells a large array of branded products like Gwaltney's.
Though Smithfield's share price has fallen recently, Mr. Luter says the company, which made a profit of $94 million on its $3.7 billion in sales last year, will produce stronger and less volatile growth. Smithfield's stock closed unchanged on Thursday, at $22.75, up from its 52-week low of $14.875 in February, but well below its 52-week high of $34.0625 last summer.
Several analysts agree that the outlook for Smithfield is bright. "I'm a big believer," said David C. Nelson at Credit Suisse First Boston, who insists the shares are undervalued, despite a large amount of debt. "They generated the best return of any food company in the last decade."
The company's drive, however, could be upset by a thicket of legal and political challenges. Regulators are considering new measures to cover corporate hog farms. Battles have broken out in Colorado, Missouri and Iowa. In North Carolina, there is a moratorium on building new corporate hog farms.
Putrid smells and contaminated waste water have led to federal fines and a public relations fiasco.
In 1996, The News and Observer of Raleigh won a Pulitzer Prize for a series detailing hog waste problems tied to Murphy Family Farms.
That same year, the Environmental Protection Agency fined Smithfield $12.6 million after its processing plants in Virginia violated the Clean Water Act by discharging pollutants into the Pagan River. The pollutants eventually reached the Chesapeake Bay.
In an interview at his Park Avenue apartment, Mr. Luter acknowledged some lapses, but blamed politicians and environmentalists for distorting the company's environmental record and ignoring the benefits of big agriculture. He said the company was spending millions of dollars on food safety and the environment.
The E.P.A. unjustly fined the company, Mr. Luter said, and ignored its efforts to comply with state laws. "I'm still outraged," he said of the fines. "Much of it came from agricultural runoff. Did it have any major impact on the river? No."
Mr. Luter also scoffs at the idea of dangerous industry concentration. The poultry and beef industries are much more concentrated, he said, pointing to a different culprit in recent low hog prices.
"It's not concentration; it's too many hogs," he said. "It was just too profitable for too long."
With low prices pinching farmers in the Midwest, Congress has responded by trying to put limits on big mergers and restraints on companies like Smithfield.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said he was outraged when Mr. Luter issued a press release saying Smithfield would keep consolidating. "There's always been some consolidation," Mr. Grassley said in an interview. "But the aggressive pursuit of megacorporate agriculture that Smithfield is making will ruin the family farm."
The Agriculture Department is also concerned that consolidation could give meatpackers too much power over prices. "Farmers don't like the fact that they're selling to so few buyers," said Keith Collins, the agency's chief economist.
In Iowa, Attorney General Thomas J. Miller filed suit against Smithfield in January, trying to block its merger with Murphy. Because Smithfield has a meatpacking plant in Sioux City, Mr. Miller said the acquisition of Murphy, which raises hogs in Iowa, violated the state's corporate farming laws, which forbid a company to control farm production and processing.
The state also accused Smithfield of engaging in a sham transaction after it agreed to sell Murphy's hog farms to Randall D. Stoecker, a Murphy employee, for $79 million. Mr. Stoecker borrowed the $79 million from Murphy to create Stoecker Farms, which the state says Smithfield effectively controls.
Last month, a state judge appointed a special investigator to study the case. Mr. Luter said he expected a settlement soon.
With domestic opposition growing, Smithfield has acquired big companies in Canada, France and Poland. "The current hostility from interest groups in this country has made other parts of the world look good to us," Mr. Luter said.
At home, many small farmers are fighting back against the perceived Goliath by joining cooperatives. Many are offering fatter, better-tasting meat that appeals to fine restaurants and other niche markets. They are raising hogs that are free of antibiotics and selling organic pork, at a premium. And legislators are standing behind them. But Mr. Luter insists American agriculture is forever changed, and global markets, not legislators, are charting the course.
"The bottom line is the small farmers have been disappearing for 100 years," Mr. Luter said. "If you want to protect the small farmer, you are going to do it on the back of the American consumer."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 2029 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: Next Year Never Comes;
Grumbling Escalates Among Baseball's Have-Nots

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 6

 BODY:
For baseball fans, hope is supposed to spring eternal each year as the groundskeepers groom the outfield grass and comb the basepaths for the home opener. But here in Kansas City, as in Pittsburgh, Montreal, Minneapolis and many other smaller cities with major league teams, that once-perennial optimism has withered over the last decade in the face of a growing gap between rich and poor franchises.
As Kansas City prepares for its first home game on Friday, most fans here no longer even dream that the once-mighty Royals will make it to the World Series. Expectations have sunk so low that even die-hard optimists say they would be happy if the Royals win as many games as they lose this season. Last year, the team won 64 games and lost 97. 
 "There is no way we can be competitive," said Joe O'Keefe, 34, a lifelong Royals fan, who was watching the season opener on television at Tanners Sports Bar in a Kansas City suburb earlier this week. "They are more of a circus act than a baseball team. You go out there for the carnival atmosphere. You don't go out there to watch competitive baseball."
The cynicism of fans like O'Keefe does not bode well for baseball. There is a growing consensus among team owners, fans and experts on the game that the disparity between high-revenue teams and those in small markets threatens the sport's future popularity. Last year, all eight teams that made the playoffs ranked among the top 10 payrolls in the game. Some owners are asking how baseball can sustain the interest of fans if only a handful of lucrative teams can afford enough stars to have a realistic chance to make the playoffs.
"For teams like Kansas City, we need to change the economic landscape of the game," said Bud Selig, the commissioner of baseball, who once owned another small-market team, the Milwaukee Brewers. "The evidence is very clear that we do have a disparity problem. We are going to crack it, because it's essential to the growth of the game."
In January, the owners voted unanimously to give Selig broader powers to redistribute the leagues' wealth to less affluent teams; he has appointed a panel to explore ways to do that, but so far has not offered concrete proposals.
Baseball officials say the limited revenue-sharing schemes, including a luxury tax on high-payroll teams, put in place in 1995 have so far failed to provide enough extra money to make low-revenue teams more competitive.
There have always been haves and have-nots in baseball. Teams in big cities have always had a natural advantage, because they have a greater population from which to draw people to games and because their local television and radio broadcasting rights are more valuable. In recent years, medium-sized cities like Cleveland and Baltimore have built new ballparks with luxury amenities that have given their teams an economic advantage.
But the gap between rich and poor franchises has grown significantly since the strike of 1994 as players' salaries have skyrocketed, and it has become harder for small-market teams to hold on to their stars, baseball experts said.
"The problem is no one really knows what level of inequality is acceptable," said Andrew Zimbalist, a Smith College economics professor who writes about sports. "You do want the Yankees and the Dodgers to win a little more. But you have to have a threshold of happiness all around. You don't want to have year after year domination by high-revenue teams."
The root of the problem is that baseball teams do not share local broadcast revenues, which vary widely from city to city. In 1998, for instance, the Yankees, with a market of more than 6.8 million households with televisions, received more than $53 million for local broadcast rights. There are about 802,000 households with televisions in the Kansas City metropolitan area, and the Royals received only $7 million in broadcast revenues in 1999.
In the National Football League, by contrast, teams share equally from the league's national broadcast contracts.
 
Financial Gap Just Gets Wider
 Baseball players' salaries have risen dramatically. In 1990, the average team payroll was $17 million and the highest payroll was about three times larger than the smallest. Last year, the average payroll had increased to $48 million, and the highest payroll was six times the size of the smallest. The Yankees spent $88 million on players' salaries last year, or more than five times the $16 million the Royals spent.
"Two players on the Yankees are the whole Royals payroll," said Mark J. Davis, a season-ticket holder. "What does that tell you?"
Standing in line outside Kauffman Stadium today to buy advance tickets, several fans said they still come to the ballpark for the sunshine or to teach their children about the game, but the idea of going to the playoffs seems remote.
"I come here just to show my son what baseball is like, for something to do, to learn the game and to see the other team's stars," said Jason Stahl, a 29-year-old salesman.
Some in Kansas City say the team's problems flow from bad trades and poor management. The Royals have not had an owner since Ewing Kauffman died in 1993, and some critics say the charitable trust Kauffman set up to oversee the team and search for a new owner has been rudderless.
But most Royals fans blame the changing economics of baseball. "We come out of spring training, we know that we are not going to be there in the end," said Charles Graham, a 30-year-old fan. "We don't have the money and the players to be there in the end."
That frustration boiled up in a protest last May, when more than 5,200 fans, organized by Kevin Kietzman, a sports talk-show host, walked out of a Royals-Yankees game in a noisy protest. They wore T-shirts saying "Share the Wealth" and Yankees caps with dollar bills pasted to them.
"It's becoming plain to everyone in Kansas City that the economics have changed," said David Judy, a season-ticket holder. "Now someone would have to be able to lose $50 million a year to be a competitive team."
Teams like Kansas City, which will spend about $25 million on players this year, can afford top athletes only early in their careers, before their salaries go out of reach. Players are eligible to go to an arbitrator in salary disputes after three years in the majors, and they can become free agents after six. Since arbitrators peg salaries to those of the highest-paid players, big-market teams set the price for top players. After three years, the salaries of talented young players often jump dramatically, and after six they are usually snapped up by the richer teams.
"The biggest challenge in Kansas City, quite candidly, is to keep the players we have now, because their salaries just mushroom, they explode," said Herk Robinson, the Royals' general manager.
The best chance a low-revenue team has of winning a pennant is to somehow cobble together a group of immensely talented rookies and make it to the playoffs before they become too expensive. John Schuerholz, a former Royals general manager who now holds the same position with the Atlanta Braves, said even that trick is nearly impossible under the current salary system.
"They might get one year where they can compete and even get the division or a wild-card spot, but to sustain that is impossible," he said.
Once in a while lightning does strike for small-market teams; in recent years, the San Diego Padres and the Florida Marlins reached the World Series. But in each case, the teams' owners sold off many of their high-priced players the following year because they were unwilling to sustain the huge losses necessary to remain competitive.
All this has had a demoralizing effect on fans. Although the Royals have a core of good young hitters in Johnny Damon, Jermaine Dye and Carlos Beltran, it is unclear how long the team can retain them. Last year, only four Royals made more than $1 million. This year, eight players will cross that threshold. With total revenues of about $50 million, the Royals would have to consider letting some of the young stars go if there was another jump in salaries, team officials said.
"Pretty much everyone in Kansas City is saying that as soon as these young kids get a little experience, they will be gone, they won't be here," said Steve Brentano, a fan and the owner of a string of sports bars. "This is like a training camp."
Gabe Duff, a 23-year-old sheet-metal worker, said the revolving door of players wears on fan loyalty. "We have a lot of good talent come through here," Duff said. "I got tired of players coming in and going off to the big-time teams and you would hear about them in the playoffs."
 
Prospective Owner Generates Some Hope
Still, Royals fans are more excited this year than they have been in a while. Friday's home opener is sold out, and many people are hopeful that David Glass, a former Wal-Mart chief executive who is on the verge of acquiring the Royals, will be able to lead a charge among low-revenue teams to somehow level the playing field. Glass's $96 million bid for the Royals has been accepted by the team's board and is expected to be ratified by the owners later this month.
Glass is no stranger to the team, having served as the chairman of the board that has managed the Royals since Kauffman's death. Glass has been a strong proponent of sharing revenue among major league teams, and Royals fans believe he has a powerful ally in Selig.
For his part, Glass said he is confident Selig will do something to redistribute the wealth. "Baseball in general has recognized that the competitive balance has been eroded over the last few years, and I think there is a consensus among the owners that it needs to be restored," he said.
Without more revenue-sharing, Glass said, teams like the Royals risk becoming permanent losers, little more than sparring partners for big-market juggernauts. "If nothing changes, we will have a caste system," he said.
The Royals' second-class status is a bitter pill for older fans who remember the team's glory days in the late 1970's and early to mid-1980's. Those Royals, led by George Brett, the Hall of Fame third baseman, were annual contenders and often fought the Yankees down to the last out. The Royals won the American League pennant in 1980 and the World Series in 1985.
But Kauffman, a billionaire drug manufacturer who looked on the team as a civic duty, was willing to absorb a financial loss to win a pennant. "We will never have an owner like Mr. Kauffman," said Lee Bussinger, a longtime fan and member of Royal Lancers, a booster group. "His pockets were deep enough to bring the players in."
Even if Kauffman were alive, it is doubtful he would be able to contribute the large sums necessary to make the Royals competitive. "In the days when Kauffman was alive, he could chip in $2 or $3 million and put our payroll on a par with the best," said Robinson, the general manager. "When you have clubs with payrolls at $80 million or $90 million, it doesn't make a bit of difference."
 
Another League Offers a Model
Many Royals fans point to the N.F.L. and ask why baseball cannot adopt a similar revenue-sharing strategy. In the N.F.L., the network television contracts are huge, worth more than $2.2 billion a year, with each team getting an equal amount: $59 million a year. Since the league also has a salary cap, even small markets like Green Bay, Nashville and Jacksonville can field successful franchises.
The Kansas City Chiefs have been playoff contenders for decades. They led the N.F.L. in attendance last year at Arrowhead Stadium, a few hundred yards from Kauffman Stadium, where the beleaguered Royals struggled to attract 1.5 million fans last year. In the 1980's, the Royals regularly attracted at least 2.2 million fans a year.
"The disparity in the league is outrageous and the owners have to come along and realize they have to go to something like the N.F.L. has," Jim Bayliff, a 25-year-old watchmaker, said as he watched the Blue Jays trounce the Royals on television earlier this week. "I believe the small-market teams are going to be butchered up and gone."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil Planning Early Payments to International Lenders

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 6

 BODY:
In perhaps the strongest sign yet that the Brazilian economy is recovering from last year's currency crisis, the country's central bank will repay early a large part of a $41.5 billion emergency loan package provided by the International Monetary Fund and other lenders.
The move, announced late Wednesday, would redeem $10.3 billion of loans due in October to the I.M.F., the Japanese central bank and the Bank of International Settlements. Of the $32 billion offered by these institutions, Brazil had drawn $20 billion. 
 After April, Brazil will owe $1.8 billion to the I.M.F. and about $9.5 billion to the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. These loans, which are considered nonemergency funds, have lower interest rates and longer maturities.
"This measure shows that there is no crisis lurking around the corner for which these funds could have been allocated," said Octavio de Barros, the chief economist here for Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria. "Brazil's risk exposure has simply, and drastically, been reduced."
Confounding most analysts' expectations, the economy of Brazil, Latin America's largest, displayed surprising resilience after currency devaluation in January 1999. Helped by strong farm production and a record $30 billion in foreign direct investment, the economy eked out nearly a percentage point of growth in 1999.
Yet it is only recently that data has begun to suggest that Brazil is on its strongest economic footing in years. Industrial production and automobile output are soaring while unemployment is falling. And inflation has been kept in check by an austere interest-rate policy.
These indicators, combined with the success of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's government in raising taxes and cutting spending, have again made Brazil an attractive destination for foreign capital.
Brazil is following the example of Mexico, Latin America's second-largest economy, in repaying funds provided by the United States Treasury to ease the peso crisis of 1994-95.
"The improved scenario has allowed the financial team to pay off its obligations early, which is just prudent financial management," said Paul Bydalek, president of Atlantic Rating, a Brazilian bank-rating company. "What remains to be seen is whether this effort pays off as it did for Mexico."

HEADLINE: Big Board Suggests Ending Links Among Exchanges

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The torturous process of reorganizing United States securities markets took another turn yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange called for ending the aging system that provides rudimentary links between the Big Board, regional exchanges and the Nasdaq stock market.
The exchange also declared its opposition to creating a national "limit-order book" that would closely link markets nationwide. 
 The Big Board proposes scrapping the two-decade-old "Intermarket Trading System," which it says has become unworkably complex and is obsolete thanks to proprietary systems that brokers use to find the best prices across markets.
The exchange's stance was foreshadowed in February when the Big Board chairman, Richard Grasso, told a Senate Banking Committee hearing that he was wary of linking to a broader system.
But by so firmly coming out against a central limit-order book, the exchange appears to be at odds with Goldman, Sachs and other big securities firms, which have called for the Big Board to work more closely with new electronic networks that match buyers and sellers directly. A limit-order book is a single system that would fill orders at the best price, no matter which market is offering that price.
The existing system is meant to find the lowest price at any exchange that trades New York Stock Exchange listings, but Mr. Grasso and other Wall Street executives agree that it frequently fails to work.
Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has said that unless the government requires close links between the new networks and existing exchanges, trading is likely to fragment across different markets, and investors will never know whether they are getting the best prices.
In response to the exchange's announcement yesterday, Goldman said only that "we are supportive of the New York Stock Exchange's reinvention initiative."
"However, we remain strong advocates of a level playing field that allows every exchange and qualified trading venue to compete for best execution through a system of linkages."
Other large securities companies did not return calls for comment.
In a speech yesterday to the Economic Club of Washington, Mr. Levitt also appeared to take a view that differed from that of the Big Board.
"Upstart electronic markets are leveraging technology to challenge traditional exchanges, using computers rather than humans to match buyers and sellers," he said. "A fast-expanding web of connections between customers, brokers, and markets seems destined to weave our many and diverse markets into a true National Market System."
In that environment, Mr. Levitt said, "it would be a profound mistake -- not to mention a dereliction of our statutory duty -- to permit the isolation of any significant market from the rest of our National Market System."

HEADLINE: Low Response To Long Form Causes Worry About Census

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
In the wake of concerns raised by some Republican leaders over the intrusiveness of some census questions, Census Bureau officials have become alarmed that a smaller percentage of households are mailing back their census long forms than did so in 1990.
Census Bureau officials said this week that 48 percent of households had filled out and returned the long form, compared with 58 percent of those who had mailed back the short form. At a comparable time in 1990, the response rate for the long form was 6 percentage points behind that of the short form. 
 Ten years ago, census takers interviewing people in households that did not mail back the long form were able to close the gap to 4.5 percentage points. But officials are fearful that unless there is a significant upturn in the number of households sending in the long form, the gap will not be significantly reduced.
"I don't think it can be," said William Barron, deputy director of the Census Bureau. "I don't think it's going to be."
Information from the long form is considered critical, used as the base for items like the consumer expenditure survey, a key component of the consumer price index; the monthly unemployment figures issued by the Labor Department; and the National Crime Victimization Survey by the Justice Department.
The long form is a 53-question version that is mailed to one in six households nationwide. It asks people to provide personal data on things like income, the amount of time it takes to commute to work, the amount paid for utilities and what kind of plumbing facilities are in their homes.
The short form has eight questions and only seeks information about things like name, age, sex, race and ethnicity.
In some ways this year's long form is less intrusive than in years past. In 1990, the long form had 58 questions; in 1980 it had 65. And this year's form pales in comparison with the long form of 1940, which had 83 questions.
In recent weeks the Census Bureau has received numerous complaints from the public that many of the questions on the long form were too nosy. Census Bureau officials said the level of complaints from the public is not significantly different from what it was in 1980 and 1990.
Several Republican leaders, responding to the complaints, suggested last week that people fill out the form and simply skip questions they find objectionable. Campaigning in Milwaukee last week, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said people should mail back their form and "if they're worried about the government intruding into their personal lives, they ought to think about it."
A survey conducted for the Census Bureau found that in the first two weeks after the forms were mailed out, 10 percent of those polled said they believed the census was too intrusive, Kenneth Prewitt, the director of the Census Bureau, said. In the third week, as news accounts appeared detailing concerns of some Republicans over the questions, the number of people who said the census was too intrusive jumped to 17 percent.
Democrats in the House have criticized the actions of these Republican, noting that the Census Bureau had sent copies of potential questions to Congress in 1997 and 1998 and asked for comments. They received none.
"In 1997 and 1998 not one of these sanctimonious census reformers said one thing when they received books on their desks that said 'this is what we're going to ask,' " said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney of Manhattan, who is the ranking Democrat on the House Subcommittee on the Census.
In recent days Republican leaders have been scrambling to not be seen as trying to undermine the census. Today House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, of Illinois; Representative J. C. Watts Jr. of Oklahoma, head of the House Republican Conference; and Representative Dan Miller of Florida, chairman of the House Subcommittee on the Census, held a joint news conference to urge people to complete their forms, though they still left open the possibility for people to skip some questions.
"I think every American ought to fill it out to the best of their ability," Mr. Hastert said. "If they have reservations about their phone number or some things that they think are private, I think that's a condition that they ought to be able to make their own decision on."
Even as the Republican leaders sought to be seen as friends of the census, some business groups that rely heavily on census data said that the 2000 Census may already be irreparably damaged.
"The cow's out of the barn," said David Crowe, staff vice president of the National Association of Home Builders. "We've had some very negative statements from some influential politicians. I don't know how you counteract that."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Swings in Markets Push Some Margin Buyers Out on a Limb

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
A year ago, Aaron Talsky was doing so well in the stock market that he gave up his Beverly Hills law practice to spend his days buying and selling stocks of the new economy from his home near Laguna Beach, Calif.
When the frenzy for Internet and biotechnology stocks continued into this year, Mr. Talsky, 35, worked out a strategy for even fatter profits. He bought shares on margin, borrowing against the stock he already owned to purchase even more in what seemed to him a one-way street to bull market riches. 
 But the technology selloff that culminated Tuesday brought the first blush of fear to the young investor. Faced with the prospect of having to put up more money in his brokerage accounts to meet margin calls -- a brokerage firm requirement when the value of stocks falls too far -- Mr. Talsky sold shares into the market downturn.
"I saw my money just dripping away," Mr. Talsky said in a telephone interview Wednesday, noting that it was the first time he had suffered huge losses. "I saw balances moving in the wrong direction, and the speed with which it was happening was staggering."
Tuesday's selloff, in which the Nasdaq composite plummeted nearly 14 percent in just hours, has served as an unwelcome reminder of the perils of such borrowing, particularly when brokerage firms tell investors to come up with additional cash. Mr. Talsky, at least, is now vowing to ease up on credit.
But many in the market point to the rise in such borrowing and worry that Americans have gone to troubling lengths to reap bigger and bigger rewards in a bull market that seems to have an infinite number of legs.
"If you look at history, leverage is often a toppler of robust markets; it magnifies the upside and the downside," said Steven Galbraith, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "That's why the investment community is very concerned about this."
And as the stock market has climbed in recent years, so has margin debt, to a record $265 billion in February, from about $152 billion at the end of 1998, according to the New York Stock Exchange. Margin debt now accounts for more than 1.5 percent of the Big Board's total market value, also a record.
In years past, borrowing was a high-risk practice left to professional money managers. Much of the borrowing now, though, is being done by a new breed of investors who are addicted to the market and who have learned to manage their own money and trade online through the likes of E*Trade and Charles Schwab & Company, according to industry professionals.
"We have seen a significant increase in customers using margin, and we think it's indicative of the entire market," said Heather Fondo, a spokeswoman at E*Trade, one of the largest online brokerage firms.
Schwab said that margin calls on Tuesday ran to three times their usual level. Datek Online, another online firm, said Tuesday was one of the five heaviest days there for margin calls. The well-established Wall Street firms, meanwhile, said they did not see a significant increase.
Many brokerage firms have tightened their lending policies. Though the Federal Reserve sets margin requirements -- initially an investor can borrow no more than 50 percent of a stock's purchase price -- the firms may set more stringent rules, even creating lists of technology stocks for higher requirements. The New York Stock Exchange, which also sets rules for its members, has asked securities firms for more information about their lending.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has pushed for an increase in the initial amount required of investors for margin buying. Though he has expressed reluctance to raise the requirement, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, has said he will consider it.
Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor of finance at the Wharton School, says that though margin calls were a factor in Tuesday's rout, they were probably not the primary cause because institutions were heavy sellers. But he said the explosion of online investing and the decline in commissions had exacerbated market swings.
"The biggest factor is the collapse of trading costs," he said. "That's why people are in and out, in and out."
Investors find buying on margin so irresistible because the stock market has been a clear path to riches in the last decade. And in the last year or two, a craving for technology stocks has created multibillion-dollar companies almost overnight, giving rise to the dot-com mania.
Statistics are lacking, but anecdotal evidence suggests that a growing number of people are devoting more time to playing the stock market. Everyone seems to have a story about a friend, neighbor, cousin or former colleague who is trading stocks from his or her bedroom, retired at 48, glued to the Web, researching stocks and talking about price-to-earnings ratios.
"It's become incredibly prevalent," said Charles Pradilla, the chief investment strategist at SG Cowen in New York. "I live in Brooklyn Heights, and my butcher is playing the stock market. He stopped cutting veal chops and started day trading."
In a market of such high expectations and hefty returns, it is only natural that people would begin borrowing to buy into the frenzy. Though this week's action was unnerving, it is too early to conclude that such borrowing will fade.
Arnold Silverman, a 74-year-old retired stereo salesman in Boca Raton, Fla., said his portfolio value jumped early this year and then crashed early this week, nearly forcing him into a margin call on the $300,000 he has borrowed to buy stock. But the market picked up, averting the dreaded request for additional money in his account.
"I got very nervous," Mr. Silverman said. "I got to the edge."
Since he began actively trading a year ago, he said, "If I'm not on the golf course, I'm playing the market."
Some of his activity is with what he calls his fun money. "I'm not that worried," he said, "because I've got a lot of income coming from commercial real estate."
Having noticed that every selloff in the last few years has been followed by a fast bounce back, investors may see little reason to step aside. Michael Stummer, a day trader in suburban Chicago, said he was watching intently when the market turned down -- "for the bottom."
After the Nasdaq composite had dropped 574 points and had begun to recover Tuesday afternoon, Mr. Stummer says he jumped into the market. "I bought a stock at $71 and sold it at $87 an hour later," he said. "I was screaming and yelling."
Mr. Stummer says he made $50,000 in just hours, his best day ever, though he says his partners did not fare as well, largely because they had money tied up in losing stocks and could not muster cash to jump in on the rally.
Day traders often borrow to buy stocks, but most of them close out their positions daily. The real leaders in the long-term borrowing game appear to be active online investors, people like Aaron Talsky.
After 10 years as a lawyer, Mr. Talsky, who also taught corporate finance at the University of California at Irvine, was drawn to the boom on Wall Street. He had heard stories about people trading their own accounts full time, and was reading daily about Silicon Valley entrepreneurs. He decided he simply had to be a part of it.
"There will probably never be a time when things are this good," he said. "Not only is there a historic opportunity that wasn't available five years ago, but I can sit on the beach, I can sit in my bedroom and have the same access as the investment banks."
Though he has no boss, all is not easy. "I probably work three times as hard now," he said. "There's always more information than you can handle. I get up at 6 a.m. and read market briefing, commentaries, look at upgrades, downgrades, and then turn on CNBC."
Since becoming serious about trading, he has bought biotechnology stocks like Maxygen and Protein Design Labs along with Internet stocks like Ariba. He watched them climb and climb and climb until about two weeks ago, when his portfolio faltered. He recalls sitting in an Indian restaurant in Mission Viejo after the market closed one day and sensing an impending disaster. Still, he did not sell. But in the next few days, the market buckled.
Mr. Talsky says he is still doing extremely well after huge run-ups last year, but the psychological impact of seeing giant gains disappear in an instant is jarring. One stock fell to $70 from $300 a share, he said. "But how can you complain when the stock was at $20 three months ago?"
Now, he says he will temper his borrowing, but not give up on the market. This week's sell-off is just a reminder of what he has known all along: the more risk you take, the crueler the market can become.
"In this market," he said, "if you're going to run with the bulls, you're going to get trampled every once in a while."

HEADLINE: Social Combustion in China

 BODY:
Reports are only now reaching the United States of serious unrest in the northeast Chinese mining city of Yangjiazhangzi almost six weeks ago. An account in The Washington Post this week described three days of violent rioting over job cuts and corruption that overwhelmed local police forces and continued until regular army troops arrived. This is just the kind of social upheaval that terrifies the leadership in Beijing, who well know that protests by disenchanted citizens could someday escalate again into a serious threat to Communist rule. Hundreds of economic protests, some of them violent, have erupted across China in recent years, rarely, if ever, reported in the Chinese news media.
The Yangjiazhangzi events were unusually unruly, but worker and peasant protests have become increasingly frequent. Market reforms like the privatization of large state companies produce unemployment and social dislocation. When this takes place in an atmosphere of pervasive government corruption, popular anger is understandable. Unless Beijing enforces higher ethical standards on local officials, unrest could soon become even more widespread. State companies are scheduled to lay off more than 10 million workers before the end of this year. 
 Anger over alleged corruption seems to have played a major role in Yangjiazhangzi. Miners, a formidable protest group in many societies, were already aggrieved over economic issues. A large state-owned molybdenum mine there stopped issuing paychecks early last year. Last November, most of the mine was shut down, but some of its facilities and equipment were apparently transferred to new private owners alleged to be friends of local officials.
What detonated the violence was the belated announcement of an extremely modest severance package for the laid-off workers. The contrast between what looked like an undeserved windfall for the well connected and the shabby treatment of longtime employees became even more of an affront when mine authorities refused to show up at a peaceful protest meeting.
For several years now, Communist leaders in Beijing have seemed haunted by fears of explosive social unrest. Their answer has generally been repression, along with strident nationalist campaigns designed to distract the country's attention from economic grievances. Instead, Beijing should crack down on the corruption that has grown worse with the progress of economic reform. Show trials of a few spectacularly corrupt individuals have not been enough to discourage others on the take.
Market reforms have benefited China and brightened economic prospects for many of its workers and peasants. But the current phase of selling off state factories and mines is creating hardships for many longtime employees. When they see local party officials drawing illicit profits from their sacrifices, they are sure to protest. Beijing should heed the message from Yangjiazhangzi.

HEADLINE: Whitman Defends Grant To Company Tied to Spouse

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 6

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman defended today the state's decision to award a $1.6 million grant to an Internet firm in which her husband was a director and major shareholder, and insisted that the company, Mail.com, had not received any preferential treatment from New Jersey officials.
But the governor acknowledged that interaction between a government agency and an elected official's spouse could create a troubling appearance, and suggested that it might be time to update state ethics guidelines, many of which were written decades ago, when two-career families were rare. 
 Governor Whitman said that existing regulations did not fully address the issues that can confront a political figure whose husband has business dealings with government agencies.
"It certainly raises an issue that I think we're going to have to come to grips with," she said. "I have a husband who has a business, who's very successful at that business, and more and more now across the country, whether the elected officeholder is male or female, they have spouses that have independent incomes and businesses. And to the extent that the public is at all troubled by that, they need to take a look at it."
The State Economic Development Authority's grant to Mail.com was approved last November under a program that allows employers who create jobs in New Jersey to keep up to 80 percent of the state income taxes paid by workers.
Mail.com, one of the world's biggest e-mail providers, was looking to expand to Jersey City last year, bringing hundreds of new jobs to the state. Company officials said a consulting firm told them they might be eligible for a grant under New Jersey's Business Employment Incentive Program and recommended that they apply.
Although Governor Whitman's husband, John, was a member of Mail.com's board of directors and had bought at least 2 million shares of the company's stock, he was not informed of the grant application, said a company spokeswoman, Holly Lehr. When the grant application was filed on Oct. 15, 1999, Mr. Whitman's ownership stake was not disclosed because the state asks only for the names of shareholders who own 15 percent or more of a company, said the governor's spokesman, Peter McDonough.
Mr. Whitman later became aware of the application and told Gualberto Medina, New Jersey's commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, of his involvement with Mail.com, Mr. McDonough said. But Mr. Medina told Mr. Whitman there was no need for him to file any disclosure forms, said Mr. Medina's spokeswoman, Lisa Kruse.
Members of the Economic Development Authority, which evaluates the applications, had learned of Mr. Whitman's involvement in the firm independently, said the agency's executive director, Caren S. Franzini. But Ms. Franzini said she did not disclose Mr. Whitman's role in the company to the board members who ultimately approved the application because he did not own a controlling interest in the company and Mail.com clearly met the qualifications for a grant. Governor Whitman was never involved in the state's decision-making about the grant.
Mr. Whitman resigned from the board on Nov. 18, nine days after the grant was approved. He has not returned calls requesting comment.
Some Democrats, state union officials and government watchdog groups say it was improper for Mr. Whitman to contact Mr. Medina during the grant application process. Richard Codey, the State Senate minority leader, said Mr. Whitman should have asked the state's Executive Commission on Ethical Standards to rule on the matter.
But Governor Whitman brushed aside his criticism as political gamesmanship. She stopped short of proposing any concrete steps to revise the ethics rules or calling for a commission to study the guidelines. But she said it might be unwise to forbid the spouses of elected officials from partaking in tax breaks and other business incentives.
"There certainly should be some constraints as far as doing direct business with state contracts, that kind of thing," she said. "But as long as things are aboveboard, as long as there is no special treatment, I don't know that we should try to stop the spouses of officials from participating in the economy."

HEADLINE: Venezuelan Calls Tune In OPEC's Price Tactics

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 6

 BODY:
For helping to engineer the spectacular rise in oil prices over the last year, fellow members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have rewarded him with the group's presidency.
Now Ali Rodriguez Araque, Venezuela's minister of energy, faces the daunting task of stabilizing prices at a level that both producers and consumers will find acceptable. 
 Mr. Rodriguez's sudden emergence as OPEC's public face is just one sign of the higher profile in international energy affairs that Venezuela is vigorously seeking. Since President Hugo Chavez took office 14 months ago, this nation of 23 million people, the largest exporter of oil outside the Middle East and the leading supplier to the United States in recent years, has gone from lamb to lion on oil matters.
"Under this government, Venezuela has been tremendously assertive, showing that we have our own identity and our own way of doing things," said Alan J. Viergutz, a former president of the Venezuelan Oil Chamber, the main industry group here. "That stands in complete contrast to the previous government, which if not anti-OPEC did not believe in OPEC solidarity."
The creation of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries 40 years ago was in large part the work of Venezuela's oil minister at the time, Juan Pablo Perez Alfonso. But throughout most of the last decade Venezuela's image within the cartel was that of a quota buster whose lack of discipline contributed to low prices for producers and earned the resentment of OPEC's other, mainly Middle Eastern, members.
"In 1997 and 1998, Venezuela's relationship with other members of OPEC was one of invective, of insults," Hector Ciavaldini, president of the state oil company P.D.V.S.A., which also owns the American-based Citgo oil company, recalled in an interview with the Venezuelan newsmagazine Primicia. "It had ruptured."
A month after being sworn in, Mr. Chavez, a populist former army colonel who led an unsuccessful coup attempt here in 1992, castigated Venezuela's previous policy as one of "indundating the market with no respect for production quotas, without giving any importance to the price of a barrel." He promised "a profound transformation," and was as good as his word, immediately cutting production by 625,000 barrels to 2.7 million barrels a day.
That set off grumbling here that Mr. Chavez was favoring his OPEC partners over domestic producers, since the cutbacks led to a recession that is still afflicting the local industry and is likely to inhibit its ability to increase production now. But the price of Venezuelan oil has nearly quadrupled, to $28 a barrel at its peak last month, giving Mr. Chavez an economic and political bonanza he has been quick to exploit both here and abroad.
At Mr. Chavez's behest, Mr. Rodriguez played a key role in getting non-OPEC producers like Mexico to adhere to the production cuts that originally sent the price of oil skyrocketing. Then, at their meeting in Vienna last week, OPEC oil ministers adopted a Venezuelan proposal intended to reduce future turmoil in the market by allowing the price of oil to fluctuate only in a "band" between $22 and $28 a barrel.
In the past, the OPEC presidency has often been seen as a post of much prestige but little practical power. Mr. Rodriguez returned from Vienna, however, saying that his fellow oil ministers had granted him the authority to enforce the price band by decreeing production increases or decreases as he saw fit, without convening a meeting of the whole group.
"If prices fall below $22, we will cut production by 500,000 barrels a day" to push prices back up, Mr. Rodriguez, who did not respond to requests for an interview, explained in a television appearance here this week. "When prices are above $28 a barrel, we will increase production."
The mechanism Mr. Rodriguez proposed has yet to be tested, and in the same television appearance he said that he thought "it will be necessary to have an additional increase in oil production this year" because "prices went down, but less than expected" after the Vienna meeting. There are also many skeptics who believe that the international oil market is simply too unruly for a price band ever to function effectively.
"It is going to be very difficult, if not impossible, to micromanage the market," said Eduardo Lopez, a Latin American oil specialist at Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington-based consulting concern. "OPEC is not a central bank, and though it has found a new strength, you still have all these countries with a different agenda, and on top of that you have cheating."
At first glance, Mr. Rodriguez may seem an odd choice to be overseeing the calibration of supply and demand for a commodity that is essential to modern global capitalism. He was active in a Cuban-inspired guerrilla group in the 1960's and is still a member of a party that is on the far left fringe of Mr. Chavez's coalition.
Eventually, though, he abandoned armed revolutionary struggle and, equipped with a law degree earned in 1961, entered conventional politics. It was after being elected to the lower house of the Venezuelan Congress in 1983 that his interest in oil policy blossomed. He gradually rose to chairman of that body's energy committee and became a member of the National Energy Council.
"Ali is entirely the contrary of the image or stereotype you would have of a guerrilla fighter," said Dr. Viergutz, who is president of an oil investment company and helped develop the oil band concept. "He is a very flexible, prudent and open-minded person, and though he may have been a Communist, he has come to see there are other economic systems besides the state-oriented model."
Legislation has been introduced in the United States Congress to punish oil producers for driving up gasoline prices, a move interpreted here as specifically aimed at Venezuela. OPEC's decision in Vienna to increase output by 1.7 million barrels a day appears to have headed off an immediate showdown, but even so there are other areas in which conflict between the United States and Venezuela may be looming.
As part of the higher profile in world energy policy it has been seeking, the Chavez government has sought and been granted an OPEC heads of state meeting, scheduled to be held here in September. Mr. Chavez has a tour of the Mideast scheduled for June, and he is expected to personally invite two of Washington's most bitter enemies, the Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, to attend the conference.
In addition, the state oil company, acting on Mr. Chavez's orders, has expressed interest in investing in the Cuban oil industry. If it does, oil analysts here have pointed out, it will almost certainly run afoul of United States legislation that calls for sanctions against foreign companies that make use of American assets nationalized in Cuba without compensation.
"Venezuela has always been a major oil producer and exporter," a foreign oil analyst here said. "What has changed is that this government is now prepared to use that weight to become a major player on the international scene."

HEADLINE: School Board Considers Deal To Swap Ads for Computers

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
A task force of New York school officials and executives of several big computer companies is proposing to distribute laptop computers to city schoolchildren and to create a school Web site that would give the companies advertising space in exchange for services and equipment.
The plan, to be considered at next Wednesday's board meeting, comes two months after the board approved a proposal to allow corporate donors to have their names attached to school classrooms, libraries or athletic fields in recognition of donations to pay for the facilities. 
 Board members say the plans, which they acknowledged were unusual for a publicly financed school system, are a way of attracting dollars for programs that could not be paid for with taxes.
Irving S. Hamer, a board member who oversees the task force that has explored the idea for nine months, said he thought the laptop distribution and Internet proposal would be approved by the full board. "This is a major shift in the ways we think about teaching and learning and how we fund these activities," he said.
But critics argued that the two initiatives put the Board of Education well down the road toward being a revenue-generating, advertising-driven entity.
"We have a great deal of concern about the negative potential of using children to promote commercial concerns and using class time for things that could be considered as advertisements," said Vicki Rafel, the vice president for legislation at the National PTA.
The board hopes to expand the use of the Internet in the classroom by creating a central site, known as a portal, through which students could receive homework assignments from teachers, who could swap lesson plans and communicate with parents and school administrators.
William C. Thompson Jr., president of the Board of Education, said he, too, thought that the full board would approve the Web site plan. "It is creative and shows a way that we can move the school system into the 21st century," he said.
Building a Web site that offers advertising to corporate partners is the only way to get their assistance in building and maintaining the system, Mr. Thompson said. Representatives of I.B.M., Cisco Systems and Toshiba America are members of the task force.
Beginning in fall 2001, laptop computers would be distributed each year to all 85,000 fourth graders at greatly reduced cost to parents. Students would be able to click on commercial logos on the school Web site to buy products. Part of each sale would go to the board.
The plan is thought to be the first of its kind by a public school system in the United States. But by embracing commercial enterprise in a way that is anathema to many publicly financed institutions, the Board of Education's plan is a reminder of previous efforts to provide advertising-supported information to schools for use in the classroom. Some of those programs, like the Channel One television network, attracted fierce opposition from educational leaders and parents, who said that such commercial-laden programs wasted classroom time and tax dollars.
Some education groups say that in a world where further tax increases are unlikely, partnerships between school systems and private enterprises are the only way to raise money for new technology programs. "In a new economy, looking for new opportunities to raise capital is just a survival mechanism," said Cheryl S. Williams, the director of educational technology programs for the National School Boards Association.
Moreover, supporters say, the primary beneficiaries of such a program would be children from poorer families, who are less likely to have computers and who have little exposure to new technology.
"If somebody came to me out of the blue and said there should be an advertising-based portal for New York City schools, I would have said that is not the way to go," said Robbie McClintock, co-director of the Institute for Learning Technology at Teachers College at Columbia University and a member of the Board of Education's task force that explored the proposal.
"But as a way of contending with the issue of limited resources and getting well-developed educational programs, it is something you can make a much better case for," Mr. McClintock said. "It is being voiced as a means of bridging the digital divide."
Dr. Hamer said the computers would very likely be leased to students at a discount, perhaps with the cost scaled in some way to a family's income. The plan is to offer updated technology to older students until, after nine years, all students in grades 4 through 12 would be using their own computer in school. The computers would be replaced or updated every few years.
Many of the plan's details remain to be worked out. Some of the proposals will require an open, public bidding process, for example, while others can be enacted under powers already granted to the board and the chancellor's office.
Aware of the potential opposition to financing the computers through the sale of advertising, the task force has been careful to avoid the use of that word, instead using more neutral words of the Internet industry, like co-branding and sponsorship.
In addition, Dr. Hamer emphasized that commercial aspects of the system would be strictly separated from material for classroom use.
He compared the program to the corporate sponsorship of public television programs, where a company's name and logo are featured but no specific products are mentioned.
"It will offer us the opportunity to say to General Electric, 'Please don't advertise your products here, but do some co-branding with us, tell your education story and provide some content,' " Dr. Hamer said.
Dr. Hamer said the Web site would also try to sell fixed spots to companies like Barnes & Noble, and if a user clicked on the company's logo and bought a book, the board would receive a portion of revenue.
That way of generating revenue, known as an affiliate program, is common in the Internet world and is used by growing numbers of schools, Little Leagues and other community organizations trying to raise money.
The difference between those programs and the Board of Education's proposal is that the board thinks companies will pay it to secure a dedicated spot on its portal, because the 1.3 million pupils, teachers and administrators in the school system are a large, captive audience.
The attraction of that captive audience was also behind the board's earlier proposal, passed in February, to name parts of schools after corporate or individual donors.
David Klasfeld, deputy chancellor for operations, said the proposal came about after the board was approached by a private civic group called Take the Field, which is seeking to raise money to rebuild city-owned athletic fields.
The establishment and naming of whole schools is reserved for the Board of Education and is not affected by the naming policy. But sports fields, libraries, cafeterias or classrooms can be named by the chancellor's office in recognition of donors, Mr. Klasfeld said.
"We do have a significant need for the rehabilitation of a lot of these facilities," Mr. Klasfeld said.
Mr. Thompson, the Board of Education president, said he also thought that the naming resolution was a way for the board to be creative in raising money.
"Is it more of a commercialization?" he asked. "A little bit. But we're also being realistic and attempting to do things that generate additional revenues that go directly to students and give them opportunities that more affluent school districts have access to."

HEADLINE: Tribe Wins Federal Approval for Casino in the Borscht Belt

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The federal Interior Department approved plans yesterday for a $500 million casino to be operated by the St. Regis Mohawk Indian tribe in the Catskills, where local officials, hotel owners and many residents have long hoped that gambling might bring an economic revival to the depressed resort area once known as the borscht belt.
Under the proposal, 30 acres of land next to the Monticello Raceway in Sullivan County would be put in trust for the Mohawks for a casino complex. 
 The plan must be approved by Gov. George E. Pataki, but after 30 years of efforts to reverse the fortunes of a rural county where many hotels are shuttered and one-third of the families earn less than $26,000 a year, proponents said the federal letter of approval was a huge step forward.
The 1.8-million-square-foot casino complex, which would be 90 miles from New York City, is expected to draw more than nine million visitors a year, fueling jobs and businesses in Sullivan County. Analysts predict that it will hobble the growth of the casino market in Atlantic City.
"The governor has said he's supportive of Indian casinos in traditional resort areas like the Catskills," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki. "But we want to give ourselves a chance to look over the letter."
Over the last six months, Governor Pataki has come under sharp attack from anti-gambling forces in New York, as well as from Donald J. Trump and other casino operators in Atlantic City. Union activists have also been critical, because the Indian casino would not be bound by labor or civil rights laws.
"The fun starts now," said Rusty Pomeroy, chairman of the Sullivan County Legislature. "We're going to make a final push on this deal. All the anti-casino activists and Donald Trumps will come out of the woodwork. Albany will be a battleground. If it's approved, it will spur development the likes of which have never been seen in Sullivan County before."
It is unconstitutional to operate a casino in New York State, except on the sovereign land of Indians; the Turning Stone casino, for example, is operated by the Oneida Nation 30 miles east of Syracuse.
More than four years ago, a group of investors and local business people in Monticello offered to donate 30 acres to the Mohawks for a casino project.
The Mohawks, in turn, asked the Interior Department to take the land in trust for the tribe under a seldom-used provision of federal law. The trust would establish a tax-free sovereign Indian territory where one did not previously exist. The Mohawks already have a small money-losing casino at their tribal home on the Canadian border near Hogansburg, N.Y.
Yesterday, Kevin Gover, the assistant secretary for Indian affairs, sent a letter to Governor Pataki saying that he had determined that a casino "would be in the best interest of the tribe and its members, and would not be detrimental to the surrounding community."
"We have always believed that the merits of the project would lead to its approval," said Robert A. Berman, a financier and local resident who leads the group that plans to build the casino. "After close examination of the application and years of review, it's not surprising that the federal government came to a positive determination. We hope that Governor Pataki will agree."
Under the terms of the agreement with the Mohawks, Mr. Berman's group would build and operate the casino under a seven-year management contract giving the tribe 65 percent of the revenue. That percentage may change as the contract is reviewed by the National Indian Gaming Commission. The tribe, in turn, would contribute about $5 million a year to the county.
Mr. Berman's partners include Ralph and Joseph Bernstein, developers based in New York, and Alpha Hospitality, a casino operator.
Governor Pataki has long said that Indian casinos could be a boon for faded upstate resorts like the Catskills and Niagara Falls. But only a few days after a judge threw out two lawsuits challenging the governor's right to approve gambling projects on Indian land, Mr. Pataki filed a bill that would require the State Legislature to approve Indian gambling initiatives. The move caused confusion: opponents of gambling hailed the decision, while proponents of the Monticello casino pointed out that the Mohawks already had a compact with the state allowing gambling.
"For the first time in years there's a buzz in Sullivan County," said United States Senator Charles E. Schumer, who had lobbied the Interior Department on behalf of the casino project. "I'm going to try to persuade the governor that the state should stand aside and let it happen. This is the kind of shot in the arm this area needs."
The prospect of a casino in Monticello last year touched off a land rush, in which politically connected developers spent more than $40 million snapping up woodland, dilapidated hotels and golf courses. But little construction followed.
David Flaum, a developer from Rochester who has contributed tens of thousands of dollars to the Republican Party, bought the 336-acre Shawanga Lodge property last year. And Louis R. Cappelli, a Westchester developer and another heavy Republican contributor, bought the Concord and Grossingers hotels, two of the most fabled resorts in the Catskills, where thousands of Jewish vacationers were entertained by Danny Kaye, Milton Berle and Eddie Fisher.
Last month, Mr. Cappelli announced that he would build a $500 million resort on the Concord property that he hoped would become a year-round attraction.
Most analysts say that a casino in Monticello would become an immediate attraction, because of its rural setting and proximity to New York City, Westchester and Rockland Counties and northern New Jersey.
"There is a reasonably strong latent demand that would nicely feed Monticello," said Steve Rittvo, president of Urban Systems/Innovation Group, a gambling and leisure consulting firm. "Monticello will be able to scoop up a good portion of the bus market."
For that reason, casino operators in Atlantic City like Mr. Trump have lobbied against the Mohawk venture and provided money for gambling opponents in New York.
Casino revenues in Atlantic City have grown only modestly in recent years, in part because of competition from race tracks in Delaware and large Indian casinos in Connecticut. A Monticello casino would almost certainly restrict any growth in the Atlantic City market, but analysts said it was unlikely to actually cause a drop in revenues.
"There's no question it takes away potential customers and everybody would prefer it not be there," said Jason Ader, an analyst with Bear Stearns. "But I don't see Atlantic City revenues going down because of a Monticello casino."
