HEADLINE: Long March Ends in South Carolina, But Little Time Is Left to Lower Flag

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., April 6

 BODY:
By his own estimate, Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. of Charleston had walked nearly 275,000 steps when he turned the corner onto Main Street this morning and finally saw the Confederate battle flag that he and hundreds of others had been marching since Sunday to remove.
Since setting out from Charleston, 120 miles away, he had endured death threats, roadside obscenities, wet clothes and blisters so painful that they needed medical attention. And for all that, there was only a slim hope that the state Legislature would vote to remove the flag from atop the Statehouse dome before the end of the year's session. 
 But the mayor seemed energized by the sight of the object of his derision, and there was a new force in his steps as he finished the last few blocks of his protest march and stood under the dome to speak to a crowd that had grown to nearly 2,000, about two-thirds of it white.
"Every religious denomination, every business organization, every civil rights organization, college boards of trustees and presidents and athletic directors, and average citizens, rank and file, have said, remove the Confederate battle flag," Mr. Riley told the crowd. "And our Legislature, with only a few more days left in the legislative session, hasn't even begun to debate the bill. They are out of step with the people of South Carolina."
Mr. Riley, a Democrat, chose the long march, with its evocation of civil rights struggle and Gandhian protest, to demonstrate the widespread frustration with the presence of the flag in a position of sovereignty. The mayor, a South Carolina institution who has been popular since taking office in 1975, had hoped to draw attention by marching with civic leaders and well-known football coaches. He attracted nearly 600 marchers on the first day and close to 1,000 on the last leg today.
But the difficulty faced by his cause seemed to be illustrated by the 300 or so counter-demonstrators who waved large Confederate banners on the north steps of the Capitol while Mr. Riley, Gov. Jim Hodges, and others spoke on the south steps. Some of the pro-flag speakers called their opponents "scalawags" and urged them to leave the state. The legislative supporters of the flag have blocked most efforts at a compromise, like moving it to a statue of a Confederate general near the rear of the Capitol, or putting it in a glass case on the Statehouse grounds.
As a result, the deadline for new legislation will pass at the end of this month without even a vote on moving the flag. The Legislature raised the banner in 1962 during the centennial of the Civil War and kept it up as a gesture of defiance to the civil rights movement; now only the Legislature can remove it. But several strongly pro-flag legislators have used every parliamentary procedure at their disposal to block the compromise bills, and now there are only nine working days left in this year's session to get a bill onto the floor.
The Senate did make some progress on the issue today, voting to put a compromise bill at the top of the agenda, meaning it could be debated and voted upon next week, then sent to the House. But legislators said they did not know if there were enough votes to stop a filibuster, should one of the opponents of compromise begin one.
If the issue is not resolved this session, the statewide tourism boycott imposed by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in January could continue for another year, with potentially serious economic consequences. Tourism officials told the governor on Wednesday that the state was losing hundreds of conventions and countless vacation trips because of the N.A.A.C.P. boycott and the growing image of the state as intolerant. Business leaders, who have been in the forefront of the anti-flag effort, have said another year of the boycott could be ruinous. Even the Columbia police chief, Charles Austin, said today that he hoped a compromise would be reached soon, because he was worried about public safety in the city if the marches continued.
Mr. Hodges, a Democrat who favors a compromise, has not said whether he would call a special session if the Legislature does not act. But he accepted the palmetto-tree state flag that Mr. Riley carried with him from Charleston, and said he hoped that the passionate feelings demonstrated by the march would change a few votes inside. "Anytime a legislator looks out the window and sees this kind of crowd, it has the potential to change their mind," he said in an interview.
In his speech today, before he took off his cracked sneakers and prepared for a rest, Mr. Riley, 57, listed what he said were the hateful uses of the Confederate battle flag over the years, like its use as a symbol of the Dixiecrat Party that split from the Democrats in 1948 over civil rights. (A statue of the Dixiecrat leader, Senator Strom Thurmond, stood near the Capitol with its back toward the rally.)
But the matter was more immediate to Gail Jones, a black woman who walked every step of the march alongside the mayor. As the manager of a Circle K convenience store a few blocks from the Statehouse on Main Street, she has to see the Confederate battle flag every day.
"I'm tired of having to lower my eyes every time I go to work," Ms. Jones said. "I just don't want to see it anymore, and that's why I marched."

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about efforts to have the Confederate battle flag removed from the South Carolina Statehouse referred incorrectly to the remaining possibility of a Legislature vote this year. HEADLINE: An African Tragedy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
An April 1 editorial describes the dynamics that have led to tragic reprisals against environmental activists. It is even more tragic that the next such crisis could be financed by the World Bank.
The State Department's 1999 human rights report had a litany of human rights abuses by Chad and Cameroon, including extrajudicial killings, "disappearances" and female genital mutilation. Yet the World Bank is poised to lend $300 million to them and to the Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Chevron Corporation to develop oil fields in Chad and build a pipeline to Cameroon. 
 Political corruption in the two countries makes it unlikely that any pipeline revenue will pay for programs for the poor, which the World Bank touts as its primary mission. More likely are loss of land, environmental degradation and worsening repression.
 
DELPHINE DJIRAIBE
Washington, April 3, 2000
 
The writer is president of the Chadian Association for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China's No. 1 Oil Company Goes Public With Whimper

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 7

 BODY:
Stalked by protestors, spurned by investors, and star-crossed by a fickle market, China's flagship oil company, PetroChina Ltd., plodded through its first day of trading in Asia, closing 5 percent below its offering price on a day when the Hong Kong market rose.
The company's shares fell today on the New York Stock Exchange after closing unchanged in their first trading session on Thursday. PetroChina's American depository shares closed today at $15.1875, down $1.25. 
 PetroChina has been singed by a political firestorm surrounding its initial public offering in the United States. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. led a patchwork alliance of labor unions, Republican lawmakers and Tibetan monks who accused the company of human-rights abuses and of planning sweeping layoffs in China.
But in Hong Kong, where the protests were a sideshow, analysts said PetroChina was handicapped by the market's indifference to companies that deliver their product through steel pipes rather than digital ones.
"Investors are focusing on high-tech dreams," said Andrew Look, a director at Prudential Portfolio Managers (Asia) Ltd. "This is an old-economy animal. For investors looking for action, they are going to look elsewhere."
PetroChina's chilly reception bodes ill for other Chinese state-owned companies that plan to issue shares later this year. Among them are two other old-style companies, Sinopec, the second-largest oil producer, and the China National Overseas Oil Company, the No. 1 offshore oil company. Only China Unicom, the second-largest telecommunications company, may catch the wave of technology investing.
Some fund managers said they expected that the offerings of Sinopec and China National Overseas Oil would be delayed. Moreover, they warned that the protests coordinated by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. could be mounted against other Chinese companies with close ties to the government.
"At this point, it is more of a nuisance than a threat," said T. L. Tsim, an independent analyst. "But if the Nasdaq and the Dow were to drop 1,000 points, the unions will feel they are fighting for the lives of their workers. It could turn ugly all of a sudden."
Trading in its home country did little to help PetroChina. Its performance here was actually worse than on the New York Stock Exchange, where the company's American depository shares closed at $16.4375 on the first day of trading Thursday. That was the price at which they were offered last week.
In Hong Kong, PetroChina's stock closed at 1.21 Hong Kong dollars, or 15 cents, a share, in brisk trading. That is 5 percent less than the offering price of 1.28 Hong Kong dollars, or 16 cents.
Goldman Sachs & Company, PetroChina's principal underwriter, bought shares in both markets to prop up the price. But its intervention did little more than cushion the losses in Hong Kong. Goldman had already scaled back the size of the offering from $7 billion and set the share price at the low end of its predicted range.
It also had to drum up support from investors like BP Amoco, which bought 20 percent of the shares for $578 million, and three Hong Kong property developers, who together invested $350 million. In the United States, a coalition of human-rights groups and groups concerned about Tibetan issues said they would organize a boycott of BP Amoco's gas stations to protest the investment.
Still, executives close to PetroChina are looking on the bright side. Two weeks ago, the company was fending off charges that its parent, China National Petroleum, was plundering the environment in Tibet and aiding an outlaw regime in Sudan. Now the company has raised roughly $3 billion -- in a week when both the New York and Hong Kong markets were seesawing wildly.
In that respect, PetroChina's initial public offering is reminiscent of another Goldman-led offering, for China Telecom. That company, China's largest telecommunications provider, began trading a few days after the Asian currency crisis tore through Hong Kong's market in October 1997. After a nail-biting debut, China Telecom traded solidly and raised $4.2 billion.
PetroChina also fared better than China National Overseas Oil, which was forced to cancel its $2.5 billion offering at the last minute in October because of anemic investor response. Analysts said the underwriter, Salomon Smith Barney, priced the shares too high. Goldman, they said, learned from that example.
"This stock was priced very cheaply," Mr. Look of Prudential Portfolio Managers said. "A lot of its performance will depend on oil prices. But eventually, it will be a benchmark stock and every asset manager will have to have it in his portfolio."

LENGTH: 686 words

HEADLINE: New Premier Predicts a 'Rebirth of Japan'

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 7

 BODY:
In his first policy speech before Parliament, Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori vowed today to continue and expand the economic and other reforms started by his ailing predecessor, Keizo Obuchi, who is in a coma after suffering a stroke on Sunday.
"In the wake of Mr. Obuchi's illness, I was unexpectedly appointed as prime minister," Mr. Mori said. "I believe it is divine intervention that I succeed Obuchi, and I will carry forward his policy aspirations and strive to develop them further." 
 Mr. Mori, who took the reins of government on Wednesday, described a variety of broad policies that he said would bring about a "rebirth of Japan," which is struggling to overcome a stubborn recession, record unemployment and widespread corruption.
He said he was willing to undertake necessary reforms, some of them painful, to revive the economy and create new jobs. "I intend to do my utmost to place the economy firmly on the path to real recovery," he said. "I am ready to share the pain with the Japanese people."
Mr. Mori promised to improve social welfare, carry out regulatory reform and promote information technology as a catalyst for growth.
He also pledged to strengthen ties with the United States and Asia and to work hard to ensure the success of the eight-nation economic summit meeting in Okinawa in July.
But most of Mr. Mori's 15-minute address this afternoon simply duplicated Mr. Obuchi's policy agenda, and the new prime minister offered no specific programs or initiatives to lift the country out of its worst economic slump since World War II.
Under Mr. Obuchi the government began slowly opening its markets to foreign competition, companies began downsizing their payrolls and Parliament approved a huge economic stimulus program.
The economy has shown some signs of improvement, although unemployment reached a record high of 4.9 percent in February and growth has been weak.
Mr. Mori, who reappointed all of Mr. Obuchi's cabinet members, is widely considered a caretaker prime minister until new elections, which must be held by October.
In his speech today, Mr. Mori gave no indication of when he planned to call elections. The opposition wants them held soon, but leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party have said they would prefer to wait until the Okinawa conference is over.
Some political analysts, and legislators from both sides, criticized Mr. Mori's parliamentary debut, saying it lacked substance.
"It was a very hollow speech, empty and irresponsible," said Minoru Morita, an author and political commentator. "In the past, prime ministers always tried to show their own flavor or individuality, even if they inherited their predecessor's cabinet. Mr. Mori didn't try to show any color of his own."
Hiroshi Hase, a governing party lawmaker and former professional wrestler who like Mr. Mori is from Ishikawa Prefecture in central Japan, said the speech left him disappointed. "The prime minister only talked generally about economic structural reforms, but I wanted him to elaborate and go into more detail," Mr. Hase said.
Some government officials and members of Mr. Mori's party acknowledged that the prime minister's speech lacked originality but said it would be gratuitous for Mr. Mori to propose major new policy initiatives so soon after taking office.
Moreover, major changes to the budget for 2000 are virtually impossible now that the spending package has been put in place, the officials and lawmakers said.
Mr. Mori said it was important for his party to maintain its coalition with two others, New Komeito and the new Conservative Party, which was formed after the Liberal Party fled the alliance last week. Mr. Mori, who is known to be a shrewd dealmaker, is credited with keeping the large coalition intact despite the parties' widely varying policies and agendas.
Expressing regret about a recent series of corruption scandals in the police and public security forces, Mr. Mori called on public servants to improve their ethics and discipline. A former education minister, Mr. Mori also promised to undertake educational reforms.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: LORD ARCHER ARRESTED
The millionaire novelist and peer Jeffrey Archer was arrested and released on bail in connection with a sexual scandal that forced him to resign last fall as the Tory candidate in next month's London mayoral election. Lord Archer, 59, stepped down when it emerged that he had persuaded a friend to lie in court in his $800,000 libel case in 1987 against The Daily Star. The paper, which said he had sex with a prostitute, wants its money back. Warren Hoge (NYT) 

AUSTRIA: CITIZENSHIP BOOM
Austrian citizenship was given to about 25,000 foreigners in 1999, up 38.7 percent from 1998, Austria's statistics agency said in a report. Nearly half were of Turkish origin, and some 27 percent were from the former Yugoslavia. Applications for citizenship can be made after four years' residence. The new government has pledged to limit the annual number of immigrants to 8,000. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
ITALY: TRAFFIC BAN
For the third time this year, cars and motorcyles will be banned from city centers tomorrow in a bid to reduce air pollution. A total of 174 cities will apply the ban, 29 more than took part on the last occasion, in March. The ban will apply from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
PERU: U.S. WARNING
The United States Senate unanimously passed a resolution calling on President Clinton to contact President Alberto K. Fujimori to insist that elections scheduled for tomorrow be free of fraud. The resolution said that if international observers judge that the vote is not clean, the United States should review all political, economic and military relations with Lima and "work with other democracies in this hemisphere and elsewhere toward a restoration of democracy in Peru." Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
COLOMBIA: REBELS KILL POLICE CHIEF
A regional police intelligence chief and two other officers died when Marxist rebels shot down their helicopter over a combat zone in Valle del Cauca Province, in southwest Colombia. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia rebels said one policeman was taken prisoner. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
INDIA: KASHMIR OFFER
Home Minister L. K. Advani said the government is ready for talks with the All Parties Freedom Conference, an association of groups opposed to Indian rule of Kashmir, but conference leaders say they will take part only if Pakistan is included, which India has ruled out. The conference and Pakistan maintain that Kashmiris have the right to vote on whether to join India or Pakistan. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
INDIA: KASHMIR KILLINGS
Security forces say they killed five foreign militants who were involved in the massacre of 36 Sikhs in Kashmir, but local residents said two of the exhumed bodies were actually those of missing relatives. The police have been accused of firing into a crowd of Kashmiris protesting the killings, leaving eight demonstrators dead. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
NORTH KOREA, JAPAN: TALKS END
Talks between the two countries on setting up diplomatic relations ended as a dispute lingered over whether Japan should compensate Korea for its colonial domination. After the talks, the first between the two nations on the topic in eight years, North Korea said Japan had agreed to apologize and pay compensation. Japan immediately disputed the claim. The two sides did, however, agree to meet again in Tokyo next month. (AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: ETHIOPIAN MISSION
Interior Minister Natan Sharansky will leave for Ethiopia today to see whether 26,000 Ethiopians descended from Jewish converts to Christianity a century ago should be brought to Israel, his spokesman said. The so-called Falash Mora are claiming their "right to return" to Israel. Most of Ethiopia's 70,000 Jews went to Israel in 1984 and 1991. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ISRAEL: MATZO CRACKDOWN
Authorities are cracking down on price-fixing by what they call "the matzo cartel." They have summoned the four main companies that produce the unleavened breads to a hearing next week. They will try to force them to lower the normally high prices charged during the weeklong holiday of Passover, when matzos are eaten. Deborah Sontag (NYT)
 
PERSIAN GULF: TANKER SEIZED
The United States Navy said it was holding a Russian oil tanker in the Persian Gulf while it does tests on oil found aboard, ostensibly to see whether it came from Iraq in violation of United Nations sanctions. Officials of the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group said the oil was theirs and had come from Iran. The Russian Foreign Ministry accused the Navy of stopping the tanker simply because it was Russian. (AP)
 
IRAN: JUDGE ORDERS INQUIRY
The most powerful figure in the conservative-controlled judiciary ordered an inquiry into allegations that the Intelligence Ministry coerced one of eight Islamic hard-liners arrested on suspicion of involvement in a plot to kill Saeed Hajjarian, a leading strategist in the reform movement who was gravely wounded in a shooting on a Tehran street. The order by Judge Mahmoud Hashemi-Shahroudi appeared to be part of a broader power struggle between hard-liners and reformers. John F. Burns (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
RWANDA: BELGIAN APOLOGY
Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt of Belgium, on a visit to Rwanda, asked forgiveness for the 1994 genocide that killed up to 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu. At a ceremony marking the killings, Mr. Verhofstadt said, "I confirm that the international community as a whole carries a huge and heavy responsibility in the genocide." In 1997, a Belgian Senate study said that Brussels, the former colonial power, had advance knowledge of the genocide plan. (Agence France-Presse)
 
RWANDA: ONLINE HELP
The online relief program Netaid.org has begun a campaign to increase the safety of motherhood in Rwanda. In cooperation with the International Rescue Committee, the Rwanda Ministry of Health, CNN and Time magazine, Netaid makes it possible to donate through the Internet an $8 "birthing kit" for mothers and babies. One in nine mothers and 65 of every 1,000 newborns in Rwanda die of infections caused by unsanitary conditions in childbirth. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

HEADLINE: Ethnic Loyalties at Stake in Bosnian Elections

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, April 7

 BODY:
Bosnian voters choosing municipal officials on Saturday must decide whether to stick with ethnic parties that led them to war eight years ago or heed international appeals and make a change.
In the four previous elections, municipal and national, since the Dayton peace accord was signed in 1995, voters have not significantly weakened the ethnic Serbian, Muslim and Croatian parties that steered the region into war. 
 The United States and its European partners -- which under the Dayton agreement virtually transformed Bosnia into an international protectorate -- are reducing peacekeeping forces and trying to determine whether the expensive effort to rebuild Bosnia is paying off.
"I'm not interested in recommending to my bosses in Washington that they put any money into areas where you have people who are doing all they can to obstruct Dayton implementation," said Thomas Miller, the American ambassador.
"But if we can show some achievement this year, we have the decent chance to convince the American people and leaders to continue the assistance."
Some 3,308 local council and mayoral posts are at stake in the test of strength between ethnic-oriented parties and parties committed to the goal of the Dayton agreement.
International officials hope Bosnia will follow the example of Croatia, where voters rejected the nationalist Croatian Democratic Union of former President Franjo Tudjman in January after nine years, electing a reformist government.
But political analysts like James Lyon of the Independent Crisis Group believe international appeals have little resonance among Muslims, Serbs and Croats radicalized by the war.
"They say to themselves: 'I'm more afraid of the other nationality than of my own crooks,' " Mr. Lyon said. He predicted that except in Muslim-dominated Sarajevo and Tuzla, Bosnians would vote along ethnic lines.
Such voting patterns have long obstructed reconstruction efforts, despite American and European investment of more than $5.1 billion since the Dayton agreement.
Muslim, Croatian and Serbian politicians who remained in power after the war transformed Bosnia into a series of fiefs, monopolizing resources, driving away foreign investors and discouraging refugees from returning to areas controlled by rival ethnic groups. Bosnia's unemployment rate is over 60 percent; corruption is rampant, and more than a million people have been unable to return home.
Nevertheless, the hard-liners' grip on power is strong. Although Mr. Tudjman's party was beaten in Croatia, the Bosnian branch is expected to win most of the races in Croatian areas.
In Bosnian Serb areas, the Serbian Radical Party remains strong, even though international officials have banned it from standing for office. The radicals have called for a boycott, and their newspaper, Greater Serbia, urged supporters to "smash the boxes, destroy the ballots."

HEADLINE: Educators See Merit In Web Site With Ads

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
Eleven years ago, an entrepreneur began Channel One, a television news program that was broadcast to schools and included commercial advertising. The State Board of Regents banned the program as exploitative of classroom time, making New York the only state in the country to shun Channel One.
Yesterday, however, the chancellor of the Board of Regents took a far different position on another proposal that could bring commercials to the classroom. He said that a proposal by the New York City Board of Education to build an Internet site that accepts corporate advertising, in exchange for computer equipment and services, deserves serious consideration as a means of introducing students from low-income families to the new technologies sweeping the country. Such a site could also help address the state's serious teacher shortage by allowing classes to be transmitted over the Internet. 
 The Board of Education's proposal "may require a higher degree of flexibility on our part" than the Regents exhibited regarding Channel One, said Carl T. Hayden, who as chancellor heads the board that sets state education policy.
"In New York City in particular, the teaching shortage is so severe that one of the most crucial ways of dealing with it might be through the use of technology," Mr. Hayden said. "So there may be a compelling need for something like this. But there would have to be ironclad safeguards in place to make sure that children are not exploited."
Mr. Hayden's comments echoed those of teachers and parents of schoolchildren from across New York City, who expressed some misgivings about the commercial aspects of the board's plan but embraced its educational objectives, particularly the idea of offering reduced-price computers to children who otherwise might not be able to afford them.
Reginald T. Brown, a dance teacher at Public School 305 in Brooklyn who also has taught computer classes at the school, said advertisements on the Web site would not bother him.
"The Internet can give students a broader understanding of learning," Mr. Brown said. "It teaches them that learning is not linear, that you can go from way over here to over there in one step. If you have a Web site with commercials on it and the Board of Ed benefits from it and children are benefiting from it, by all means do it. And the technology exists to turn off the advertisements during class time."
But Donald Czajkowski, a former teacher from Staten Island who now works in training programs for the teachers' union, said he thought computers and a Board of Education Web site should be paid for in some way other than by exposing children to advertisements.
"The city's got a lot of money, and New York State has got a lot of money," Mr. Czajkowski said. "These computer companies could afford to take a little bit of a loss and donate the computers. That would be a way for them to invest in their future employees and their future customers."
The proposal, developed over the last nine months by a task force that included Board of Education officials and representatives from technology companies, including I.B.M., Cisco Systems and Toshiba America, will be formally presented to the full Board of Education on Wednesday. The plan anticipates offering laptop computers at a discounted price to all 85,000 fourth-grade students each year.
The cost of the computers, plus e-mail accounts for all 1.3 million students, teachers and administrators, and the design and maintenance of the Web site, known as a portal, would be met through the barter of advertising space on the Web site. In addition, the board would sell advertising space to retailers offering their products for sale to the system's users.
Advertising and commercial interests have encroached ever further into classrooms around the country in the 11 years since Channel One fostered a nationwide debate about commercialism in public schools.
In 1989 and again in 1993, the Board of Regents prohibited the use of commercially sponsored television programs in the state's public schools.
Since then, schools in many other states have adopted the offerings of companies like ZapMe, which gives free computers to schools but requires that the computers accept advertisements of corporate sponsors in the screen margins.
Even in New York, the door has been opened slightly. The State Legislature recently gave schools the ability to sign contracts with soft-drink companies allowing the companies to pay schools for exclusive rights to sell soda in school buildings.
"I didn't like that one either," Mr. Hayden said. "But keeping a perfectly pristine position on this might be impracticable."
Irving S. Hamer, the Board of Education member who oversees the task force that developed the plan, said that any advertisements on its Web site would be separated from the educational content, a factor that Mr. Hayden said would be significant in how the Regents view the proposal.
In addition, he said, parents would be given the ability to opt out if they did not want their children to receive e-mail messages, and there would probably be some sort of filters made available to parents to keep children away from pornography that is available to anyone with Web access.
That gives some reassurance to Maria Torres, whose child is in the first grade at Public School 75 in the Bronx. "I know that in school they are starting to teach kids things about how to make it in the business world, and they should be learning about using computers and the resources there," she said. "But a fourth grader needs to learn how to go to a library or a bookstore and look things up, not how to buy a book online."
Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said the proposal represented a difficult choice for teachers. "I don't like the commercial part of this and exposing kids to it when they are a captive audience," she said. "But do we then deny kids what they absolutely need in order to be competitive in a global economy?"

HEADLINE: Old-Style Protesters Seize on a New Fervor;
Graybeards of the Radical Movement Use Police Brutality Rallies as a Forum

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

 BODY:
These days, when New York's streets beckon and protesters gather, Joel Meyers arrives with a 9-foot-wide crimson banner demanding freedom for a death-row inmate who killed a Philadelphia police officer. Bill Davis, 57, an avowed Communist, appears to circulate the party's newspaper, The People's Weekly World.
And then there's Gary Phaneuf, 44, who at 6 feet 6 inches towers over fellow protesters and attends demonstrations with one thought in mind. "We're out here to make socialist revolution," said Mr. Phaneuf, a disciple of Trotsky who was arrested on assault charges at one recent demonstration. "We don't beat around the bush." 
 Fervent about their causes and determined to make their point whenever and wherever they can, these protesters and others from a divergent cross section of the city's radical organizations have long trudged out to demonstrate on myriad issues, more often than not in the face of lagging passions and dwindling interest. But now, with the city in the midst of a series of loud, large protests against police brutality, they are hitting the streets again, energized and looking for opportunity.
"They have their finger in the wind, and they know what's happening on the activist front," said Jeff Goodwin, a sociology professor at New York University who studies the city's social movements. "They know where the big demo is going to be. They show up with their newspapers, try to sell it and get their point across. And if they're really lucky, they'll find someone who will come to their meetings and, who knows, join up with the group."
The radicals -- many of them white men in their 40's and 50's who cut their teeth in the heyday of protests, the 1960's -- remain a distinct minority among the young black and Hispanic New Yorkers protesting over the acquittal of four officers who fatally shot Amadou Diallo and subsequent shootings in which undercover officers killed unarmed black men, Malcolm Ferguson and Patrick M. Dorismond.
But the protests, which are attracting hundreds of passionate young people outraged about police tactics and looking for solutions, have provided a forum for radicals to draw a link between police brutality and what they see as the failings of American society. And for some, the hope is that the demonstrations will amount to something more.
"We're always looking for one issue that can spark something, that can sustain on ongoing movement," said Scott Scheffer, 45, a bookkeeper and member of the International Action Center, a liberal organization founed by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark. "It could be that this is the thing that does it. It's exhilarating to see so many people out there. That's the fun part for me. People are angry and they're emotional and they want to do something."
At a rally on Wednesday in Union Square Park organized and attended mostly by college and high school students, Mr. Davis worked the crowds, passing out the Communist Party's paper and sidestepping other radicals handing out their literature. "People's Weekly World," he announced, a bundle of papers under his arm. "Pages 4 and 14. Giuliani is out of control. That's about police attack at the Dorismond funeral."
Mr. Davis, a member of the Communist Party for 29 years, has a snow-white beard and red suspenders that put him in sharp contrast to the youthful crowd, who listened as hip-hop artists and fiery poets railed against the police. But many took his newspaper, thanking him and making small talk that left him beaming.
"I know you don't get a lot of discussion when you're handing out the paper," he said. "But some of the people look at the paper and come back and call up and then you have discussions. This is really to attract their attention."
Whether the effort is having lasting effect, though, is another story.
"These folks are part of the landscape; I don't see them as a significant part of the landscape," said Gregory Tewksbury, a professor at the New School for Social Research, who is working on a book about education and social movements. "I think that for a lot of people they tend to sort of not make a lot of sense and, hence, not make a lot of impact."
Richie Perez, a founder and one of the leaders of People's Justice 2000, the grass-roots group that has organized Manhattan protests that attracted hundreds after the Diallo verdict, said that some of the older radicals had seemed out of place at some of the demonstrations. At a Bronx rally, he said, two radicals shouted about the evils of capitalism.
"At that moment, Wall Street and capitalism were far from what people were thinking of," said Mr. Perez, 55, a former member of the Young Lords, a militant Puerto Rican group of the 1960's. "They were outsiders in this community, and they didn't understand this and respect the sentiments of the people."
The visibility of the veteran protesters has also brought hostile words from City Hall.
After demonstrators and the police clashed in Brooklyn at the funeral of Mr. Dorismond, the Haitian-American security guard shot in a tussle with a plainclothes officer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said "demagogues" with "political and divisive purposes" in mind had touched off a melee in which 23 police officers were hurt and 25 arrests were made. The police said a variety of traditional leftist groups, as well as some newer grass-roots organizations, had instigated the violence.
One of those arrested was Mr. Phaneuf, who was captured on a police video hovering over an officer who had been pummeled to the ground, according to a law enforcement official who viewed the tape. Though he denied hitting the officer, Mr. Phaneuf has remained strident. In an interview, he said that taking chances was a part of protesting. "Maybe you'll get arrested and maybe you'll get beat up and maybe you'll get killed, but it goes with the territory."
Many of the older radicals scoff at the mayor's accusations, saying that they disavow violence and that the police are at fault.
"The mayor has been seeing reds all over for several months now," Mr. Davis said.
Mr. Davis said he hoped to link the problem of police brutality to economics, and to suggest that socialism could end inequality and racism in America. "We want to bring that idea to the people that this oppression by the police is related to the economics of the country," he said.
Dr. Goodwin said such views did not mean that the old-time leftists were not sincere about the latest cause, fighting police brutality. "I think it would be wrong to see them as simply as parasites or opportunists who don't care a whit for the particular issues that are being protested," he said. "They are serious people. I don't think it's incompatible to say that they are truly opposed to police brutality and they also have ulterior motives."
Robert Lederman, 49, a street artist who has protested for years against Mayor Giuliani's policies, often arrives with dozens of placards caricaturing the mayor as Hitler, complete with the Fuhrer's mustache. Ron Painter, coordinator of the Workers Committee for Self-Defense, comes armed with a newsletter, "Fighting Words," which calls for mass labor disruptions. And Mr. Meyers, 56, the demonstrator with the crimson banner, is steadfast in his belief that Mumia Abu-Jamal, a former Black Panther, is unjustly on Pennsylvania's death row.
The veteran protesters are an eclectic mix. Hillel Cohen, 50, of the well-organized International Action Center is a researcher at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Another, Bill Doares, 45, of the Workers World Party, is a copy editor for a magazine. Greg Dunkel, 59, who calls himself a "Marxist radical" interested in Haitian issues, is a data processor.
What sets them apart is that free time is spent in meetings with like-minded radicals, perhaps not plotting the overthrow of the country but still looking to shake things up. They devour newspapers and political tracts and keep an ear tuned to stations like WBAI, which has a large black audience and adheres to leftist political causes. "I really do feel that that my mission in life is what I do after work," said Mr. Scheffer, who said he came to New York in 1987 because it was a hotbed of activism.
Mr. Davis, a father and homeowner from Queens, said he had loads of time to spare since retiring as a social worker. He prefers spending it at Communist Party headquarters on 23rd Street or participating in protests, he said.
"It's a lot more fun than spending 50 hours a week selling aluminum siding," he said. "And when my wife says I'm spending too much time doing this, I give her a list of all the bad habits I don't have. I don't gamble. I don't drink to excess. I don't run around with other women."

HEADLINE: A Cartel for Doctors

 BODY:
The House is preparing to vote on a bill that would permit independent physicians to bargain collectively with health plans -- in effect to form a union -- even though they do not work for a common employer or work together in any other way. This is a terrible idea. The bill would invite doctors to form cartels, jack up prices, boycott health plans and exploit consumers in ways that are permitted to no other independent businessmen in the economy. The legislation may induce physicians to pour contributions into the campaign chests of politicians during an election year, but patients would suffer the nasty consequences. That is why the Consumer Federation of America, the Department of Justice, the Federal Trade Commission and many leading antitrust authorities oppose the measure.
The legislation, proposed by Tom Campbell, Republican of California, has already sailed through the Judiciary Committee. It would permit independent doctors to bargain collectively to negotiate fees and working conditions with health plans. The purpose of the bill, says Mr. Campbell, is to put doctors in a better position to negotiate better deals when they go up against huge health insurers. 
 But doctors do not need the artificial help. Individual health plans rarely dominate regional markets. In urban areas, a single health plan typically accounts for less than 10 percent of patients. Doctors can avoid doing business with a plan they do not like.
Salaried physicians are already allowed to form unions, and tens of thousands have already done so. What is new, and dangerous, about the Campbell bill is that it would extend this right to independent doctors. That would give doctors the ability to conspire to fix prices and engage in other types of anti-competitive behavior, such as collectively refusing to provide services to a health plan that tries to drive a hard bargain. That could force the health plan to succumb and guarantee that patients would pay substantially higher prices for medical services.
The obvious consequence will be to raise insurance premiums. Physician unions could also be used to stymie health plans that try to weed out doctors who practice bad medicine.
Current laws already permit physicians to act cooperatively when it benefits patients. Doctors can, for example, coordinate efforts to raise standards of medical care and form networks to improve care. By contrast, the cartels envisioned by Mr. Campbell would victimize consumers.

HEADLINE: Methane Boom in Wyoming Proves to Be Mixed Blessing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: GILLETTE, Wyo.

 BODY:
An energy boom is roaring through the Powder River Basin here in northeast Wyoming. Methane Madness, some locals call it. Others compare it to the Gold Rush. It is a race to some of the richest methane gas deposits in North America, in a place industry executives call "the Saudi Arabia of coal."
In varying degrees, the boom is affecting 25 other methane-producing states as the nation's demand for cleaner, cheaper fuels intensifies. But nowhere is the impact more pronounced than in Wyoming, where low taxes and a shrinking population are causing a bleak fiscal outlook for the state government. 
 Here, the scramble to extract methane is viewed as crucial to the state's ability to prop up its budget and so maintain services. At the same time, however, it is markedly changing the face of 25,000 square miles of rugged prairie where livestock and wildlife far outnumber people.
In so doing, it is touching nerves already frayed by long battles between the owners of land and the owners of minerals below it. They are often different people, and that means mining can frequently proceed even if the owners of the surface land object.
Now the methane rush is driving a wedge between those who applaud the economic benefits of mining and those who say it is not only damaging the land but also squandering the region's most precious resource, clean water.
Methane, the chief component of natural gas, is mined here in a process that entails flushing millions of gallons of water out of coal seams along with the methane itself. That displacement, some scientists fear, will destroy ancient aquifers and surface ecosystems and dry up water sources that ranchers and their livestock depend on.
Ten years ago, there were fewer than 50 methane wells in the Powder River Basin. Now, with cheaper drilling technology and a growing demand for cleaner-burning fuels, Wyoming has issued permits for nearly 11,000 wells, almost half of which are in production. Industry officials predict that the number could reach 50,000 in a decade, a growth rate higher than those forecast for the 25 other methane states, including Colorado, Texas and Alabama, which boast high-production sites.
"It's terrible what they're doing," said Mary Brannaman, pointing to gas pumps and new gravel roads lining the 500-acre ranch near the town of Sheridan where she and her husband, Buck, train horses. "We didn't want any of this. It was absolutely beautiful back here. They can't just come in here and rob the earth. My maternal instinct tells me that it's not good."
Even lawmakers who concede that Wyoming needs every tax dollar the energy companies generate say the development may be too rapid.
"We depend on the minerals, but we haven't addressed the problems of water," said State Senator John Schiffer, a Republican whose district includes the western side of the basin. "We need to do hydrology studies, but I'm afraid we're a year, maybe two years, behind the curve on this."
In Montana, where the basin juts into a small slice of the state's southeast, officials are reaching the same conclusion. The Montana Board of Oil and Gas has agreed to stop issuing any new permits until a state court hears arguments on an environmental group's request to conduct a study of the mining's impact on the area. The ruling does not affect production on 260 permits already granted.
Here in Wyoming, Mr. Schiffer said, state officials are watching water issues closely. But any legislation that would slow production is not expected. As more localities and industries around the country convert from coal-burning plants to natural gas, methane is playing a larger role. Experts say the use of methane is expected to double within a decade or so, and reserves from the Powder River Basin could last 30 years.
For the state -- the most sparsely populated in the country and one of the few with no personal income tax -- the taxes from gas production, as well as the royalties that the state gets for the mining of that small part of the underground gas that it owns, are generating an increasing amount of revenue: more than $231 million in 1998, 13.6 percent of the budget, from $187.7 million four years before.
And many of the state's residents benefit more directly, although they frequently have no choice, lacking the right to refuse development unless they own not only the land above the methane but also the mineral rights themselves.
Robert Sorenson, whose family owns a 5,000-acre ranch outside Gillette that is being mined for methane, said they would receive $35,000 from the company building a pipeline across the ranch, in addition to royalties paid to people who own the mineral rights on their properties.
The Sorensons, whose ranch has been in the family since 1908, are relatively lucky. The majority of property owners in the basin do not own rights to all the minerals below, a common Western circumstance that dates from homesteading days, when the federal government retained mineral rights as a condition of land transfer. Over the years, mineral rights below many properties have been sold separately from the sale of surface land, creating what isknown as "split estates."
In the Powder River Basin, the federal government still owns about 58 percent of the rights, individuals about 36 percent, and the state the remaining 6 percent. And if a property owner who has no mineral rights refuses to sign an agreement with the company that has leased them, the company can post a bond with the federal or state government to begin development.
Sometimes, as in the case of the Sorenson ranch, rights to minerals beneath a given stretch of land are held by a variety of people. Mr. Sorenson said he and his family shared mineral rights to 800 acres with people they did not know. That means that even if the Sorensons had refused the deal their partners signed with Pennaco Energy, the Denver company that is mining the gas, production would have proceeded.
"You really have no choice," Mr. Sorenson said.
Many people in the basin contend that no amount of money is worth the impact that methane mining is having on their lives and land, even with assurances by drilling companies that the land will be restored when gas supplies are exhausted. They resent that their rolling hills are now dotted with gas drills, heavy trucks, bulldozers, new roads, piles of pipes, ditches to accommodate them, and reservoirs freshly dug to hold some of the water pumped out in the mining process.
By far, however, the greatest concerns involve water. At current methane production levels, gas companies are routinely pumping out 500,000 barrels -- 21 million gallons -- of water a day, much of it potable. Some is piped into new reservoirs. Some is sent into nearby creeks and streams. Some is added to existing ponds. Some is siphoned off to seek its own level, creating bogs and swamp. Some finds its own release point: when methane drilling started miles away from Forest Dunning's home, water began shooting up a venting pipe that was installed on his property years ago to monitor gas movement from coal mining.
Wherever the water goes, said Walter R. Merschat, a geologist from Casper who has studied the hydrological impact of methane drilling, scientists do not yet know the long-term consequences of its displacement from underground havens where it has remained for tens of thousands of years, or how long it takes to build up there again.
"We're just beginning to feel the effects of all this," Mr. Merschat said. "But from what I've seen, it's not the right thing to do for good water."
With greater frequency, state and industry officials are being made aware of citizen concerns through environmental organizations, like the Powder River Basin Resource Council, which are beginning to organize protests. One occurred in late March in Denver, where demonstrators disrupted a symposium on methane production to demand that energy companies mine fewer wells in the basin and stop dumping ground water onto the surface.
Some state mining restrictions already address water issues, and after a protester interrupted a speech by Paul M. Rady, president and chief executive of Pennaco, on production in the Powder River Basin, he assured the audience that energy companies were operating responsibly. "There are laws and regulations in place," Mr. Rady said. "We and other industry players abide by them."
For the state, the balancing act remains a fragile one, the concerns of the basin's residents weighed against the needs of an industry that is contributing mightily to Wyoming's economic growth at a time when legislators are resisting new taxes.
"The development has been faster than we probably prepared for," said Gary Beach, administrator of water quality for the state. "As a result, the last couple of years have been a learning curve for us. We feel we have taken giant steps to reach a balance with the right level of protection. But at the same time, we don't want to impose unreasonable burdens on the industry."

HEADLINE: Bush, in Reversal, to Meet With a Gay Republican Group

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 7

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush said today that he had invited a small group of gay Republicans to talk with him at the governor's mansion in Austin, Tex., next week, a development that stood in contrast to his longstanding refusal to meet formally with the Log Cabin Republicans, a leading gay political organization.
The gay Republicans who are scheduled to visit the Texas governor are not representatives of the organization. In fact, a spokesman for the Log Cabin Republicans complained today that Mr. Bush would be sitting down with a hand-picked group of gay supporters as a way of avoiding the kind of substantive policy discussion that officials with the organization would like to have. 
 But the simple fact of the planned meeting, which came only after Mr. Bush wrapped up the Republican presidential nomination, hints at the governor's desire to project a more moderate image in the general election than he did in the primaries. Mr. Bush's remarks on the topic today suggested the same interest.
"This is a different time," he said at a campaign stop here this morning, explaining why he was now willing to meet with gays but had previously avoided such an encounter.
"The campaign is over," Mr. Bush added, referring to the primaries. "It's important for me to unify our party. And I welcome the gay Americans who support me, some of whom are members of the Log Cabin Republican club."
The comments by Mr. Bush, who allied himself strongly with social conservatives in the primaries, are part of a pattern of statements, symbols and gestures by which he seems to be trying to inch back toward the center of the political spectrum.
In the last month or so, Mr. Bush has indicated an incrementally greater receptiveness to gun-control legislation and has publicly chastised the National Rifle Association for harsh comments it made about President Clinton. The governor also announced several new education proposals that underscored a federal role in the nation's public schools and more federal spending. And he repeatedly staged or appeared at events that prominently featured minorities.
Early next week, in Cleveland, Mr. Bush plans to make a series of proposals that aides say are intended to help lower-middle-income Americans climb a few rungs higher on the economic ladder.
One of Mr. Bush's aides said the multi-faceted plan that the candidate intends to announce on Tuesday would include ways to help these Americans buy health insurance, an issue that has been conspicuously absent in the governor's series of policy proposals since he began his presidential campaign bid last June.
Mr. Bush's comments today about gay Republicans came at a news conference after a speech he delivered to the National Hispanic Women's Conference in downtown Los Angeles. During his speech, Mr. Bush repeatedly cast himself as a sensitive Republican eager to reach out to all kinds of voters.
He repeatedly dropped Spanish sentences and phrases into the speech. "I want the American dream -- el sueno Americano -- to be available for every willing heart," Mr. Bush told more than 300 Hispanic women. "This great country belongs to you as much as anybody else."
In his news conference, Mr. Bush expressed concern about news reports that a Texas official he appointed to oversee law-enforcement training in the state had made racially insensitive comments in a 1998 legal deposition. The Associated Press reported on Thursday that the official, Charles W. Williams, had said in the deposition that terms like "porch monkey" were not racial slurs.
Mr. Bush said he had not heard about the deposition until late Thursday and wanted to learn more about it before saying what he thought should happen to Mr. Williams. But he added: "From what I know about the story, they are very troubling comments. I don't accept racism in any shape or form. And, at the very minimum, he ought to apologize."
Mr. Bush did not go into much detail about his planned meeting with gay Republicans, which was largely set up by Charles Francis, a gay public relations consultant in Washington who is the brother of James B. Francis Jr., chairman of the Texas Department of Public Safety. Jim Francis has been a fund-raiser for Mr. Bush for many years.
Charles Francis said in a telephone interview that he would be among a dozen gay Republicans visiting the governor's mansion, and that the group included Mayor Jim Stewart of Plattsburgh, N.Y., and former Representative Steve Gunderson of Wisconsin.
The group also includes some officials with state chapters of the Log Cabin Republicans, Mr. Francis said.
He said Mr. Bush had long wanted to meet with gay supporters and seemed more eager now that the primaries were over.
"George and I were talking awhile back," Mr. Francis said in the interview, "and he said, 'Why don't I hear more from gay conservatives?' I said, 'I really look forward to making that happen.' "
Mr. Bush has repeatedly declined to meet with the Log Cabin Republicans, who have expressed eagerness to press him on issues like gay marriage and his willingness to appoint gay people to posts in his administration. The governor has indicated an adamant opposition to gay marriage and has given hazy and sometimes contradictory answers when asked about appointing gay people.
Kevin Ivers, a spokesman for the Log Cabin Republicans in Washington, said that next week's meeting was an easy way out for Mr. Bush. "He gets to say he's met with gay Republicans," Mr. Ivers said, "but he also picks and chooses people who he knows are eager supporters."

HEADLINE: Job Growth Sets 4-Year Peak Despite HigherInterest Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Despite five interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve in less than a year and the promise of more to come, the economy continued to barrel along in March, generating more new jobs than it has in any month for more than four years, the government reported today.
The economy added 416,000 nonfarm jobs during the month, the Labor Department said, more than most economists had anticipated and the biggest surge since February 1996, when the number of jobs increased by 454,000. 
 The unemployment rate fell just slightly, but after rounding was reported unchanged at 4.1 percent.
Workers continued to benefit from the tight labor market as employers paid more to attract and keep workers, with average hourly earnings increasing by 5 cents, or 0.4 percent for the month. The rise in wages, while not enough to set off major warning signals about inflation, suggested that some inflationary pressures might be starting to build.
The report somewhat overstated the economy's strength. A good chunk of the new jobs in March -- about 117,000 -- were temporary positions created by the Census Bureau as it set out to count the population. Other technical factors also swelled the count somewhat.
But the numbers did nothing to alter the assumption among investors and economists that the Fed would raise rates again at its next meeting, on May 16, in an effort to slow the economy to a pace that would reduce the risks of inflation.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has repeatedly expressed concern that the declining pool of available workers will eventually set off a spiral of rising wages and prices, endangering an expansion that last month entered its 10th year.
Since there is little evidence of inflation so far, and given that wage increases have not accelerated sharply, most analysts are projecting that the Fed will hold its rate increase in May to a quarter of a percentage point. The central bank's benchmark federal funds target rate currently stands at 6 percent, up 1.25 percentage points since June.
Higher interest rates take at least six months and perhaps as much as a year to have an effect on the economy, and there is little evidence that tighter monetary policy has slowed growth to within the Fed's non-inflationary speed limit of 3.5 percent to 4 percent. The economy grew at a 7.3 percent annual pace in the fourth quarter of 1999, and analysts are predicting that growth in the first quarter may have been as much as 5 percent.
"Taking into account all the special factors that went into the March employment situation, plus the fact that the unemployment rate remained steady at 4.1 percent, this latest glimpse at the economy suggests that the Fed will continue its policy of incrementalism," said Kenneth Mayland of ClearView Economics, a consulting firm.
In a speech today, Mr. Greenspan emphasized his growing conviction that an acceleration in the growth rate of productivity -- which among other things is a powerful force in helping keep inflation contained even as wages rise -- is not a temporary fluke.
Continuing huge investments in technology by American businesses "support a distinct possibility that total productivity growth rates will remain high or even increase further," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech that was broadcast via a videoconference from Washington to a group of technology executives in St. Louis.
Mr. Greenspan also repeated his assertion that the Fed has had little choice but to raise rates at a time when the longer term rates set in the credit markets have been rising. To keep its own short term rates down while long term rates are rising, Mr. Greenspan said, would require the Fed to inject money into the economy, a step that would almost certainly fuel inflation.
Mr. Greenspan did not mention today's employment report.
To some economists, the most striking element of the report was its suggestion that the intense demand for workers is drawing more people into the labor force, allowing the labor force to expand at a pace above the growth in the working age population. To the degree that the labor pool is expanding, it would diminish concerns that a lack of workers will inevitably lead to an inflationary surge in employment costs.
Despite the robust pace of job creation, the number of potential workers has actually increased over the last two months, using a measurement often studied by Fed officials in tracking the labor market. The number of people who are unemployed, plus the number of people who are not actively seeking a job but would like one, increased by 124,000 in March after rising by 237,000 in February, according to a calculation by James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
Noting that the unemployment rate has fallen by 1.5 percentage points over the last four years, economists at Salomon Smith Barney said in a report today that the rate would have fallen much more sharply had it not been for the tremendous influx of new people into the work force.
"By our calculations, if the participation rate had not risen during the past four years, the sharp rise in employment would have cut the unemployment rate to less than 3 percent," the report said. "This suggests that, without the pickup in labor force growth, either employment growth would have slowed or inflation pressures would have intensified."

HEADLINE: SENATE SETS STAGE FOR A MAJOR FIGHT WITH BUDGET PLAN

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
The Senate approved today a $1.8 trillion budget plan for next year that seeks to restrain the growth of government and throws into sharp relief the bruising political battles between Congress and President Clinton in this election season.
The Senate voted, 51 to 45, largely along party lines, to endorse a Republican-written budget blueprint that is nonbinding but is politically significant because it provides a framework for specific spending and tax bills for the fiscal year 2001, which begins Oct. 1. 
 The measure calls for increases in spending on the military and education; cuts or freezes in many other domestic programs; a reduction in taxes by at least $150 billion over the next five years; a new $40 billion prescription drug benefit as a part of Medicare, and paying down publicly held debt with the surplus generated by Social Security.
The Senate measure must now be reconciled with a similar bill the House passed on March 24. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois has expressed optimism that Congressional negotiators can finish their work next week, before lawmakers leave for spring recess.
The emerging bipartisan consensus to wall off the Social Security surplus complicates the goals of both presidential aspirants. It hampers the ability of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to carry out his plan to cut taxes by $483 billion over five years, and constrains Vice President Al Gore's ability to increase social spending.
"There will not be big swings in expenditures in our government and there will not be big swings in tax cuts," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, who heads the Budget Committee.
As the House was forced to do last month, Senate Republicans were put in the awkward position of backing a smaller tax cut than their party's presidential nominee. Mr. Domenici suggested there was no disagreement with Mr. Bush over the size of the tax cuts, and if the governor is elected, a Republican Congress would warmly embrace his plan and try to find more money to bridge the gap between their two plans.
Democrats, however, attacked the budget resolution as a missed opportunity to put the nation's fiscal house in order and address the needs of the most vulnerable Americans. Two Republicans, Lincoln D. Chafee of Rhode Island and George V. Voinovich of Ohio, joined 43 Democrats in opposing the budget bill.
"The Republican leaders turned their backs on a great opportunity to prepare for the future," said Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat. "The American people want us to pass a good budget that helps our families, our seniors, our children and our economy."
President Clinton said in a statement, "This new Republican budget combines bad fiscal policy and a flawed economic strategy."
A few major differences in the Senate and House bills could hinder a quick settlement. House Republicans want the Senate to agree on a strategy to send Mr. Clinton as many as four tax-cutting bills throughout the summer. But Senate Republicans want to limit the number of bills on the Senate floor for fear that Democrats will use them to force votes on issues that could embarrass Republicans.
Indeed, in a week of spirited debate, senators cast symbolic but politically important votes on gun control, the minimum wage, the federal gas tax and military spending.
The way for today's vote was cleared when senators agreed on Thursday to increase the Pentagon's allocation by $4 billion next year, to $311 billion. The agreement resolved an impasse between two Republican military hawks, Ted Stevens of Alaska and John W. Warner of Virginia, and a fiscal conservative party member, Phil Gramm of Texas, who has sought to restrict spending.
Democrats scored political points on several amendments. The Senate approved, by a vote of 53 to 47, a nonbinding resolution calling on Congress to adopt wide-ranging gun control measures by April 20, the anniversary of the fatal shootings at Columbine High School in Colorado.
Senators also approved a measure urging the minimum wage be increased by $1 to $6.15 an hour over two years. In another Democratic victory, lawmakers voted 51 to 49 to break $2.7 billion out of the Republicans' $150 billion tax cut to use for Pell Grants for low-income college students.
In a defeat for the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, senators went on record against reducing the federal gasoline by 4.3 cents a gallon.
In a test vote, senators agreed, 66 to 34, that the budget should not assume that the 18.4-cents-a-gallon federal gasoline tax would be reduced by that amount. Mr. Lott has championed a proposal to suspend that part of the tax, approved in 1993 on a tie-breaking vote by Mr. Gore.
Despite the setback, Mr. Lott's spokesman, John Czwartacki, said the senator would press ahead with a vote on the measure next week.
Earlier, senators voted, 51 to 49, against dropping a provision from the budget resolution that assumes the government will reap $1.2 billion by 2005 for allowing oil drilling in Alaska's environmentally sensitive Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
On Thursday, lawmakers spent much of the day skirmishing over rival proposals whose main purpose was to embarrass the two parties' presidential nominees.

HEADLINE: Despite Approval, Fate of Catskills Casino Is Murky

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki sits in the eye of a gambling hurricane now that the federal government has given its approval to a long-proposed Indian casino in Monticello.
For decades, the issue of casino gambling has periodically generated fierce debates across the state. But the looming possibility that the St. Regis Mohawks will be allowed to build a $500 million casino next to the Monticello Raceway in Sullivan County has galvanized a broad array of forces, from real estate developers to competing casino operators and antigambling groups. The issue has also split Democrats and Republicans from New York City to Albany. 
 They are now all training their gaze on the governor like a pack of wolves circling a campfire. Mr. Pataki, who has long been supportive of a Monticello casino, has maintained that he has the executive power to approve the casino. But in a move that confounded both sides, he submitted a bill in March that would require the consent of the State Legislature, where, proponents fear, the proposal would very likely die. Mr. Pataki's bill also mandated a local referendum once the proposal was passed by the Legislature.
"This'll be a raging battle in Albany," said Richard Fields, an investment banker active in Indian gambling projects. "The political dynamics will give even the most seasoned lobbyists a migraine."
On Thursday, the Interior Department approved plans for the casino, which would be operated by the Mohawks on a 30-acre parcel put in trust for the tribe, whose ancestral home is on the Canadian border. Only 90 miles from New York City, the complex is expected to employ 3,000 people and draw 9 million visitors.
The proposal now has to be approved by Governor Pataki. But no one is sure what he will do next. "We're going to need some time to go through all this," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the governor.
The role of the Legislature, however, is up in the air. Lobbyists and politicians in Albany are unsure whether the governor will push for his legislation, or approve the Monticello casino after the Legislature leaves Albany for the summer. Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker and a Democrat who generally supports casinos in depressed areas, said he was unsure whether the governor could act unilaterally and would not comment further.
The Republican majority leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, who has been opposed to gambling, is against the governor's bill for constitutional reasons. He contends that the State Constitution forbids slot machines, though it is not clear whether that applies to gambling on Indian land.
But Donald J. Trump and other casino operators in Atlantic City have already dispatched lobbyists to Albany to fight the project, while politically connected real estate developers who recently bought land in the Catskills for hotels, conference centers and resorts are counting on the casino.
"I'm one of the biggest property owners in New York, and I think it's going to drain a lot of money out of the city," Mr. Trump said yesterday.
Mr. Trump conceded that he was also concerned about how a casino in Monticello would affect his casinos in Atlantic City. "I don't know what the impact would be," he said, "but I can't imagine it would be positive."
Senator Charles H. Schumer supports the Mohawk casino, saying it would be a "shot in the arm" for the Catskills resort area, while a fellow Democrat, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, has called for a moratorium on casino gambling until the cost and benefits can be assessed.
Niagara Falls, Buffalo and Lake George want the same kind of economic boost that Monticello expects, and other Native American tribes in the state want a chance at casino revenues. The Pataki administration, in turn, has used the possibility of new casinos as a bargaining chip in negotiations with the Mohawks, Oneidas and other tribes who claim ownership of thousands of acres in central New York.
"This decision will reshape the global relationships between the administration and other Indian nations," Mr. Fields said. "It will also be watched carefully by the other resort communities pressing for gambling as an economic catalyst."
Gambling opponents who criticized the governor in newspaper advertisements for what they described as his pro-gambling stance are warily waiting for what happens next.
Governor Pataki has long said that Indian casinos could provide a real boost for resort areas like the Catskills, Niagara Falls and Lake George. He has also maintained that he has the power to approve an Indian casino, without going to the Legislature. But only days after a judge threw out two lawsuits challenging his position, the governor submitted the bill requiring legislative approval and local referendums. Mr. Pataki said at the time that the bill would speed up the approval process by avoiding lengthy legal challenges.
But whether the bill applies to the Monticello project and the Mohawks, who already have a gambling compact with the state, is murky enough that both sides in the debate are claiming victory. The governor's office has refused to issue a definitive statement.
"We saw his legislation as a victory and applauded him for looking at this in the right way," said Tom Hunter, president of the New York Institute for Law and Society, a conservative antigambling group. Mr. Hunter's group has ceased publishing a series of newspaper advertisements attacking the governor and urging Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to reject Mr. Pataki as a potential vice-presidential running mate.
But Gus McDonald, the executive director of the St. Regis Mohawks in Hogansburg, said he was confident the governor would approve the casino without going to the Legislature. He pointed to the last line in the governor's bill, which states that it will apply only to gambling compacts entered into after the legislation takes effect.
"His people have indicated to me that he would have no problem signing the letter," Mr. McDonald said yesterday. "How fast he does it, I don't know."
In Monticello, Mayor Gary P. Sommers, a Republican, was buoyed by the Interior Department's decision this week and undeterred by the maneuvering in Albany.
"The governor needed to protect himself if he's being considered as a national candidate," he said. "I think it was meant to quell the opposition. But I think this will be signed off at the state level very shortly."

ACTIVISION, A VIDEO GAMES PRODUCER, CUTTING JOBS

BYLINE: Bridge News

 BODY:
Activision Inc., a producer and distributor of computer and video games, announced reorganization plans yesterday that will result in a charge of $66 million and an unspecified number of job cuts. The company, based in Santa Monica, Calif., said it was consolidating its Expert Software subsidiary into its Head Games unit, eliminating nearly all jobs at Expert and discontinuing several of its product lines. The revamping is aimed at accelerating development of games for next-generation consoles and the Internet. The company, whose games included Toy Story 2 and Nightmare Creatures, said the reorganization would result in pretax savings of $11 million.
