PUB-DATE: April 9, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 35; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1427 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO;
A Radio Host Empowered to Follow His Whims

BYLINE: By VALERIE GLADSTONE; Valerie Gladstone's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the choreographer Bob Fosse.

 BODY:
MOST radio shows are as predictable as sunrise. Dean Olsher has decided to surprise listeners by following his own fancy. Mr. Olsher, a former cultural correspondent for National Public Radio, will be the host of "The Next Big Thing," a one-hour weekend program that will go on the air this summer on WNYC. Over dinner in Manhattan, months before its debut, he said excitedly, "It will be about anything." Not about the next big thing? "No," he said, laughing, "the title is ironic."
To give listeners an idea of what he is up to, Mr. Olsher, who at 36 looks like a young college professor, has been presenting a series of specials to commemorate WNYC's 75th anniversary. The first, "This Is What I Live For," broadcast earlier in the year, will be rebroadcast today at 4 p.m. 
 As the show begins, Charles Mingus's mellow "II B.S" fades in the background. "Pop psychologists have started to tell us that it's a bad idea to equate who we are with what we do for a living," Mr. Olsher says. " 'Don't define yourself by your job,' they say." The Mingus returns before he continues. "It's such a downer when somebody says, 'That's why they call it work; otherwise they'd call it play.' Wouldn't it be great if that idea would be replaced with what Buddhists call 'right livelihood' -- the idea that what you do for a living should be a natural extension of your personality?"
The talk then turns to dream jobs, with Mr. Olsher confessing his own secret wish to play cello with the Guarneri Quartet. But is David Soyer, the cellist with the Guarneri Quartet, content? No, it turns out. When Mr. Soyer comes on the air, he fantasizes about being a tugboat captain, although not in choppy seas. What about the tugboat captain Buddy Cantrelle? The job is lonely, he reports. Running a Cajun restaurant might be cozier. And so it goes, until Mr. Olsher discovers, in his idiosyncratic survey, that nothing beats being paid for animal care.
How quirky can jobs get? Mr. Olsher visits the actress Sally Parrish backstage at the acclaimed play "Wit"; though pivotal to the drama, she has few moments onstage. The 85-year-old Dolly Gallo explains why she does not want to be paid for selling gifts at a South Street Seaport shop, interspersing gossip about her customers with salty memories of her childhood. Other unusual New Yorkers appear before the program closes with a dramatic reading by the actor Barnard Hughes of Herman Melville's melancholy short story, "Bartleby the Scrivener," whose protagonist stubbornly refuses to work. Artfully, Mr. Olsher comes full circle.
"I wake up in the middle of the night thinking about ideas for upcoming programs," Mr. Olsher said. One brainstorm led to a segment in February called "Every Day Is a New Thing to See" in which he accompanied the architectural historian Tony Hiss on a tour of Grand Central Terminal, chancing upon little-known glories. On the same program, the writer Paul Auster read from his stories about the physical space of New York. A March special on consumption, "How Can Anybody Explain the Success of a Product Like Jell-O," sparkled with segments by David Rakoff and Janeane Garofalo doing improv comedy in the style of Nichols and May.
It seems Mr. Olsher was destined to create a radio program. How many kids spend their youth, as he did in rural Hunterdon County, N.J., ignoring television and hooked on "The Bob and Ray Show" on WOR and Jonathan Schwartz on WNEW? "I always got attached to the people on the radio," he said. After college at Simon's Rock in Great Barrington, Mass., and graduate studies in musicology at the University of North Carolina, he signed on as the afternoon announcer at WUNC in Chapel Hill in 1985 and freelanced cultural reports for NPR before being hired as a correspondent in 1996.
Dean Cappello, director of programming at WNYC, was crucial in getting "The Next Big Thing" on the air. "Dean had been a standout on NPR," Mr. Cappello said. "I wanted to set him free." They had both been thinking about a New York-focused show with a magazine format that would do things differently. Fortunately, Laura Walker, president of WNYC, was already planning to expand the station's cultural programming. "I'd like to see the arts talked about with the same passion as sports and politics," she said. Later this year, the station will broadcast another cultural program, "Studio 360," with the journalist Kurt Andersen as host.
But even with WNYC's enthusiastic support, Mr. Olsher has a tough road ahead. While special series and shows devoted to music are mainstays of public radio, daily and weekly cultural programs have not had much luck. The few noteworthy exceptions include Garrison Keillor's "A Prairie Home Companion," from Minnesota Public Radio; Terry Gross's "Fresh Air," from WHYY in Philadelphia; Leonard Lopate's "New York & Company," from WNYC; and a relative newcomer, Ira Glass's "This American Life," from WBEZ in Chicago.
One reason for their scarcity is that ever since NPR became a major news source during the Persian Gulf war in 1990, news has increasingly dominated air time on public radio. "We spend five times more money on news than culture," said Kevin Klose, NPR's president, vowing a change. In fact, the network just hired Bill Davis, former general manager of WUNC in Chapel Hill, specifically to oversee that change.
Others in the field think it will take a minor revolution for public radio to regain its creativity. Partly out of frustration, Jay Kernis, who had produced popular news-oriented programs for NPR, left the network in 1987 to become a producer of "60 Minutes" on CBS-TV. For Mr. Kernis, the question is whether NPR and Public Radio International (PRI) are supplying the 600 public radio stations with the programming they should have. Radio, he said, echoing the CBS producer Don Hewitt, has a journalism part and a show business part, an Edward R. Murrow side and an Ed Sullivan side. "Right now," he said, "the Murrow side is more appreciated. We need storytellers. People are hungry for shows like 'A Prairie Home Companion,' 'Fresh Air' and 'This American Life.' "
These programs were not overnight hits. "A Prairie Home Companion" went on the air in 1974 and was only picked up by NPR in 1979. Ms. Gross, considered by her peers to be one of the best interviewers in the business, became the host of "Fresh Air" in 1975 and slowly built enough of a following to be distributed nationally by NPR in 1989. Mr. Glass's "This American Life," with its first-person stories, fiction and poetry, has been on the air since 1995 and is now one of the fastest growing programs in public radio, nationally distributed by PRI.
"I knew how to market myself," Mr. Glass said. "I hired a part-time publicist, sent out funny postcards, and offered every station entertaining spots for their pledge drives." Just as important, Mr. Glass connected with his listeners.
But charismatic hosts and lively subjects do not necessarily keep shows on the air. In 1989, NPR launched "Heat," with John Hockenberry as the host. An innovative mix of public affairs segments and performances, it lasted barely a year. "The recession came along, and the network wasn't finding the underwriting dollars they had committed to," said Steve Rathe, president of Murray Street Enterprise, which created the program with WGBH in Boston. "It wasn't NPR's own baby. I understand." Sometimes, he said, even the brightest executives cannot identify the next good thing. "The greatest successes have been built by passionate -- maybe a little crazy -- individuals scattered around the country."
Another adventurous program, "Anthem," produced by NPR in 1998, did not last quite two years. One of its hosts, Rick Karr, now an NPR cultural correspondent, thinks its concept was too complex to sell to stations. "It was more than offbeat music," he said. "We couldn't sum it up in 10 words. It was also expensive. The best way to launch one of these programs is fast and cheap."
But someone also has to be willing to stay with them while they build an audience, as Melinda Ward, a senior vice president at PRI, has done with "Sound and Spirit." That show, introduced at WGBH in Boston in 1996, draws on a wide variety of spiritual music and ideas. "It took quite a while for people to know what to expect from it," Ms. Ward said.
Mr. Olsher fully appreciates the risks of his venture; still, he is intrepid.
"I feel," he said, "as if I've found the keys to the sandbox." That must be something like discovering your "right livelihood."
